Essentially, You Don't Mess With the Zohan isn't all that different in tone and sensibility from Sandler's previous films, but he's really trying in this one, and the effort pays off.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The movie has lean, to-the-point simplicity, which is refreshing in an era when so many films take needlessly bloated, talky routes into their story (for more on this, see Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull).
As unappetizing as the subject may seem, Errol Morris' Standard Operating Procedure exerts a hypnotic pull anyway.
A subtle, measured work, which means there will be many who find it dull and pointless.

Careful not to repeat the past, The Incredible Hulk does a lot of things Lee's The Hulk didn't: It's lighter and faster-paced, it's funnier and it embraces (instead of ignoring) the 1970s TV series that furthered the character's popularity.
WALL-E is Pixar's E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial or its Pinocchio: an archetypal fable about loneliness simple enough -- yet deep enough -- to instantly captivate anyone who sees it.
Even if the game isn't entirely successful, it's fun to play along.
The battle sequences are tremendous, and the performances are captivating, making for the sort of rousing, giant-scale entertainment that a figure as towering as Genghis Khan deserves.
A thoroughly satisfying and engaging children's picture that never forgets those kids probably didn't get to the theater by themselves.
It's the path del Toro takes to get there that gives the film its propulsive kick: You literally never know what's coming next, and what does is always better and cooler than you could have imagined.
It's proof that popcorn entertainments don't have to talk down to their audiences in order to satisfy them. The bar for comic-book film adaptations has been permanently raised.
This is a stunning coffee-table book, but it's not really a movie.
Even at the start of his career, Van Sant has always been an artist who has savored the bittersweet pleasure of sadness and pain.
The thoroughly unconvincing drama Resurrecting the Champ might be based on a true story, but that doesn't mean you're going to believe a single frame of it.
A sleek, handsomely made bauble buoyed by a cast much stronger than the flimsy material deserves.
Shortbus' surprisingly sweet, compassionate tone never flags, helping the movie overcome its own flaws.

Aside from satisfying some kind of ghoulish curiosity about how such an incident could possibly happen, there's precious little in Death of a President to justify the extremity of its central conceit.
An exercise in blood-soaked nostalgia, a look back at an era (the late 1970s and early 1980s) when Miami was a bad and dangerous place to live.
Allows us to understand just how heavy the crown really sits.
Flat-out hilarious -- arguably the funniest American comedy since Airplane!
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A Good Year is never less than visually ravishing, its warm, inviting vistas of the French countryside and its unhurried, pleasant vibe putting the viewer in the same frame of mind as Max.
The experience of watching Babel is undeniably riveting: Even if the film doesn't really lead anywhere, you still can't take your eyes off it.

Casino Royale isn't perfect, but it's surprisingly entertaining, even exciting for long stretches, and Craig manages to find new dimensions to a character that had long ago become a tired caricature. Everything old is new again, indeed.
Fast Food Nation would have benefited from a longer running time -- the movie often feels like it's missing big chunks of plot -- but Linklater's cautionary message gets through.
Little Children slowly loses its grip, becoming just another story about infidelity, albeit an exceptionally polished, well-acted one.
The fact that you might emerge from the theater eager to give their albums a listen is a testament to how effective this lively and stirring movie about freedom of speech really is.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Despite Aronofsky's obviously earnest and heartfelt efforts, this would-be trippy fantasy about love and death is kookier and sillier than anything else.
The usually enjoyable time-travel paradoxes about how changing the past would affect the present coming off as more annoying intrusions than anything else.
For Your Consideration always seems a bit too tame for its own good: It never busts out the way you hope it would.
One of the amazing things about Volver is that Almodóvar once again manages to make a preposterous, overloaded plot seem sublime and organic.

The movie is essentially a vehicle for Smith, but the actor more than rises to the challenge. Rarely has attaining the American Dream seemed so impossible or daunting or so intensely, profoundly satisfying.

Rocky Balboa is far from essential, and there are moments in it bad enough to make you wince. But I dare you not to feel at least a tiny little rush when that opening bell rings, and Rocky starts swinging one final time.
There isn't a moment in this self-conscious, uninvolving movie when you aren't aware you are watching an experiment, which might make a good lesson for film school students on what not to do.

A funny thing happened to The History Boys on the way to the screen. The players are the same, the dialogue is pretty much identical, but the vibrancy of the play -- its exhilarating immediacy -- has been muted.

This glitzy, infectious and unusually heartfelt musical doesn't always hang together as a satisfying narrative -- too many characters compete for too little screen time -- but its pleasures are numerous enough to override its flaws.

Despite the bleakness of its vision, Children of Men is also thrilling, both for its groundbreaking style (there are action sequences here unlike any filmed before) and its complex, vividly realized ideas.

Perfume: The Story of a Murderer never tries to make Jean-Baptiste sympathetic but he's not rendered monstrous, either: He just is a victim of a passion larger and more powerful than any one man can handle.
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: As successful as the unlikely casting of Timberlake turns out to be, some of Cassavetes' other choices are disastrous.
Befitting a story about magicians, The Prestige is certainly tricky and deceitful. But it's also too elegant and classy to resort to cheap third-act revelations as a way of juicing its story.
If Flags of Our Fathers lacks human dimension, though, it certainly succeeds as an exploration of the nature of heroism.

The second half of Man of the Year bears practically no relation to the irreverent comedy the movie's trailer sells you -- much like a politician who doesn't keep any of the promises that lured you to vote for him.

Through its very specific story, the movie illustrates how absolute power can corrupt those who wield it, resulting in a man who, once ensconced as a nation's leader, uses all his available resources to ensure his own survival.

As plentiful as its ideas are, A Scanner Darkly often feels hollow, and more than a little monotonous, because Linklater has not quite succeeded in overcoming the aggressively uncinematic nature of Dick's novel.

despite the childlike nature of the story, Lady in the Water will prove too confusing for most kids, which is a shame, since they're also the ones most like to greet that giant-eagle business with something other than a derisive laugh.
This is more of a thinking man's action flick -- a small, intense film made on a giant canvas that finds Mann experimenting with and pushing at the boundaries of mainstream filmmaking.
The result is decidedly minor Woody, and unlike Match Point, far from essential.

The film's clear and informative exploration of the collusion between the private sector and government agencies, along with the auto giants' wielding of their financial power to sway legislature, can't help but raise the viewer's ire.

'What does diablo mean?' 'It's like Spanish for fighting chicken.' If you cracked so much as a shell of a smile reading that, then run, don't walk, to see Talladega Nights, where you will get an entire year's worth of equally irresistible nonsense.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The movie is also spooky and atmospheric, has at least three great jolts and an equal number of memorable gross-outs, including what has to be the goriest and most protracted eye-gouging of the year.
Strong performances by the three leads ... help to make up for the story's sliver of a plot.
World Trade Center feels like the respectful and tender beginning of a dialogue between filmmakers and audiences about a subject most would rather not revisit via their entertainment.
Snakes on a Plane is neither as good nor as bad as you'd hoped it would be: It's just a mediocre exploitation picture with an inspired premise.
The hijinks in Accepted are as wild as a sixth-grade prom.
It's pitch-perfect, impeccably conceived and replete with subtext and meaning. It is, in other words, a masterpiece.
A portrait of adolescents who learn to form makeshift families when their natural ones let them down, and who are too confident and resourceful to wallow in self-pity.
Invincible is one gigantic pile of cornball clichés, but there's no denying the movie works you over anyway.
Dogged by an inert, stale aura that overcomes everything and everyone in the movie.

Brian De Palma spent three years struggling to get The Black Dahlia made, which helps explain why the movie has the feel of something that was left in the oven too long: It's both overcooked and undernourishing.
It's the kind of picture that is so eager to celebrate its self-importance and social significance, it suffocates under its own seriousness.
Flyboys is so schematic and contrived, you can anticipate exactly what scene is going to come next, and who will be the next to die in combat.
As charming and inventive as Gondry's fanciful visions are, they aren't enough to substitute for the lack of an involving story.
Running on for a butt-numbing two-and-a-half hours, The Guardian overstays whatever forgiving nature one is willing to extend.
If watching people having their faces cut off, getting their legs amputated and having their throats tenderly slit is your idea of a horrific good time, you'll certainly get your money's worth here.
movie_title: The Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Beginning (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A great, resonant, psychologically complex popcorn movie made by a cast and crew of filmmakers at the top of their game. Welcome back, Marty.
The star-heavy cast, which includes such big Spanish names as Carmen Maura, Marisa Paredes and Veronica Forque, are a treat to watch even when their dialogue isn't all it could be.

Infamous isn't able to convey the great sense of guilt and responsibility Capote wrestled with -- he needed a man who trusted him to die in order to finish his book -- becoming instead a more superficial and pedestrian tale of doomed love.
Idlewild doesn't exactly hang together, but its parts are something to behold.
By placing us on the opposite side of the battlefield, the movie forces us to approach it from a fresh perspective. The technique also lends Letters an uncommon timelessness.
This wan, by-the-numbers romantic comedy, which marks the directorial debut of screenwriter Susannah Grant, is so superficial and formulaic that even Garner's mega-watt grin can't completely save it.

In Hannibal Rising, the bad Dr. Lecter finally enters the pantheon of movie monsters for real: Like Freddy Krueger and Jason Voorhees, he, too, now has a sequel that's been made strictly for the sake of a buck.
In all their variations, with many of them graced by the presence of big-name actors, these 18 movies coalesce into an incandescent portrait of a city rife with possibilities for romance.

Director Tim Story does the same sort of efficient, impersonal job he did on the first movie, keeping things at such a basic, almost childish level that it seems the movie is aimed squarely, if not exclusively, at the 12-and-under set.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: I can't imagine anyone seeing Once and not instantly falling in love with it.
... the equivalent of a gripping page turner.
The overriding tone of A Mighty Heart is neither indignant nor sentimental: The film is consistently cool.
With a minimal amount of blood and virtually no gore, 1408 still manages to give you a major case of the creep-outs.
Ratatouille is the most straightforward and formulaic picture to date from Pixar Animation Studios, but it is also among the most enchanting and touching.
Moore may play loose with the facts, but you don't have to believe every frame in the movie to come away thinking that the message in Sicko is not only worthwhile, it is also inarguable.
Far from the crass, just-for-the-money sequel it appeared to be on paper. It's a genuine blast.
When a movie keeps you this entertained without insulting your intelligence, it's hard to complain.
The most surprising thing about Michael Bay's much-anticipated, blockbuster-bound Transformers is how funny the movie is. I don't mean funny in an unintentional, Pearl Harbor kind of way.
What ultimately makes the film so satisfying is the seriousness and affection with which Apatow treats his characters, no matter how drug-addled or misguided they may be.

It's the familiar faces that help make Phoenix the best Potter movie yet. Director Yates, who is expected to return for the next installment, continues the shift away from set design and toward performance.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A lot more clever than it initially appears.
Hairspray delivers an even bigger sugar rush than the hit Broadway musical, which had already expanded on the exuberance of the 1988 John Waters comedy that spawned it.
There's a near-tactile pleasure to the special effects in Sunshine that is uncommon in this era of CGI imagery.
It's easy to understand why Herzog was driven to tell this story twice.
In a way, the film is more of a Simpsons celebration than anything else -- the mother of all anniversary episodes.
Jason Bourne may or may not return, but it's hard to imagine another Bourne movie ever topping this one.
There's a lot of music in El Cantante, with Marc Anthony more than doing justice to Lavoe's insanely catchy, groundbreaking songs. It's whenever the music stops that the movie runs into trouble.
As coarse as the movie gets, there is always an undertone of sweetness to accompany the toilet humor.
By flaunting its own stupidity, The Ten practically dares you not to laugh at it, like a stand-up comic who sells an unfunny joke through the ferocity of his delivery.
The elegant presence of Kidman and Craig helps ease the inanities of the script.

Ghosts of Cite Soleil is too brief and limited in scope to provide a complete picture of Haiti's turbulent history, but its images of how so many of its citizens live and die on a daily basis -- is both heartbreaking and unforgettable.
A darkly comic, squirm-inducing portrait of everyday familial dysfunction amplified by an unusual element.
It manages to turn an internal, solitary activity into fodder for an engaging, even exciting movie.
The kind of movie that rockets so far beyond the line of credibility and so deeply into the realm of utter stupidity, you start to wonder if the filmmakers aren't putting you on.
The longest and talkiest installment in the blockbuster Pirates trilogy, At World's End doesn't even have the decency to provide a good action sequence until more than two hours in.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Although there's no denying the threadbare nature of the script, watching Murphy riff can be a formidable entertainment on its own.
A movie that is so tightly wrapped in highbrow airs and lofty significance, it forgets how to breathe. Only Vera Farmiga brings any trace of personality or spontaneity to the picture.

Fincher and screenwriter James Vanderbilt, who spent more than a year researching the script, have made one of the most detailed, factually scrupulous crime dramas to ever come out of a Hollywood studio.
300 is at its best when it settles for purely visceral thrills.
A deft piece of storytelling that tightens the noose slowly, growing more absorbing and suspenseful as it goes along.
This lighter-than-air bauble proves a pleasurable diversion indeed -- as long as that heart beating inside your chest has at least a mild propensity for the romantic. Bring a date.

After the Wedding ends up feeling far weightier than it first appears, with its plot contrivances and unlikely coincidences generating such a messy range of emotions, they end up feeling a lot like real life.
A suspenseful French drama with a Hitchcockian flair for manipulation that manages to be simultaneously elegant and shamelessly entertaining.
movie_title: The Page Turner (La Tourneuse de pages) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The Terminal is so beautifully directed, so pleasurable to watch and so thoughtfully put together, it's a disappointment when you realize, halfway through, that the movie is going to fall way short of a masterpiece.
There isn't a moment in the movie you feel you've seen done quite this way before.
What could have seemed insufferably self-pitying becomes strangely moving instead -- a sign of a filmmaker placing his absolute trust in their material and coming up all the stronger for it.
There's nothing about Bug you'd call pleasant, but this dark, intense picture is the best and most vibrant movie Friedkin has directed in decades.
This has to be the crassest, most excessive, vulgar and gratuitous wartime spy story ever told, which is exactly why you should see it.

Beautifully performed by actors who make as much use of silent glances and body language as they do dialogue, and directed in an instinctual, subtle manner that trusts the audience to derive meaning from scenes where nothing much seems to be happening.
Colorful but pedestrian biopic of the legendary Cuban singer Benny Moré.
A lavish, ambitious picture, with an international cast and the polish of an A-list Hollywood production, that often plays like a telenovela in period dress, only without the camp value.
A heartfelt but overly schematic movie that, in its attempt to explore the true cost of living one's life in denial, ends up superficial and banal.
Rarely plays out the way you expect. Director Bong is careful to deliver the promised scares, but he is also willing to overlook plot formulas to explore his own interests.
Eventually the film's limitations catch up with it, and you start feeling like you've seen all this before, maybe just not told exactly the same way.
Lean, mean and without a single frame of self-conscious, aren't-we-cool humor in its 81 minutes, Vacancy is exactly the movie the bloated Grindhouse should have been.

This is a wonderfully imagined, heartfelt piece of pop entertainment that soars not only for its spectacular eye candy, but also during the moments when its protagonists simply stand still and talk to each other.
You can see what they are striving for, but Georgia Rule is so artificial, it feels like more of a flow chart than a slice of life.

28 Weeks Later doesn't just recycle the premise, apocalyptic mood and insane violence of the original: It adds thematic layers to its zombie milieu, deepening the scares while justifying the sequel's existence.
As this intimate, beautifully observed film unfolds, you realize that the story's themes are relevant no matter what age you happen to be.
The Custodian makes excellent use of cinematography, color and camera movement to convey the gradual restlessness brewing within Ruben.
Vaughn is stuck playing the straight man to a collection of stooges, and he looks utterly bored doing it.
Illustrates the pain and anguish of the 1994 Cuban rafter exodus.
A sporadically amusing, occasionally funny, but ultimately bland and pointless time killer.
Cynics may roll their eyes at Hardball's earnestness, but the movie proves even the most conventional stories can move and engage you, provided they're told well.
Glitter, the kind of movie only 11-year-old girls who dot their i's with hearts would find bearable, is filled with unintentionally humorous moments that tower over any comedy released this year.
Although the movie never so much as flirts with melodrama, there is still a bittersweet undercurrent throughout Adventures of Felix.
Watching it feels like leafing through an old photo album you've been forced to thumb through one time too many.
Valli's cameras capture one breathtaking image after another.
Roughly half the jokes in Zoolander fall flat, but they're all delivered with such energy and enthusiasm, even the dud gags are never annoying.
Until it collapses into a pile of contrivances, Don't Say a Word makes for a serviceable, workmanlike thriller.
A well-oiled, slick and efficient fun-house ride, one that moves too quickly -- and is too much fun, really -- to nitpick.
Being bad brings out the best in Washington, and his performance elevates Training Day past its familiar street-cops scenario into something richer and far more engrossing.
If you don't care for [Kattan] -- or if you have no idea who he is -- the prudent move would be to steer clear.
A big-hearted, generous movie that never patronizes the audience.
A good-natured cross between Bonnie and Clyde and Jules and Jim, Bandits isn't much more than a pleasant dawdle.
A dull, sluggish bum-out.
The Last Castle often feels choppy, as if chunks of connecting narrative had been lopped off in the editing room.
A mature, insightful and extremely well-acted study.
[Lynch's] never before married his subconscious impulses to an accessible storytelling style in such a satisfying, beguiling way.
Gloppy and touchy-feely.
Often makes for a compelling comedy-drama about family ties. It's only when the cancer takes center stage that the movie feels like a wash.

If the premise of Domestic Disturbance interests you at all, you're better off renting 1987's The Stepfather ... That film was everything Domestic Disturbance is not: taut, suspenseful, unpredictable, and not the slightest bit condescending.
Movies like Monsters, Inc. literally make you feel like a kid again, marveling at the joyously inventive sights before you, and that's a feat that should not be taken lightly.
An instant cult classic, one that's tailor-made for multiple viewings and bound to be popular among college students.

Heist is Mamet's biggest and most accessible thriller to date, and if you've never seen any of his films, the movie will work its devilish magic. But for the initiated, Heist carries a whiff of disappointment.
A cracked piece of storytelling -- a funny and constantly surprising exercise in comic tension.
As vacuous as the backstage glitz and debauchery it pretends to criticize.
For all its genre trappings, this is an intelligent, probing study of an ordinary woman under extraordinary duress.
What O lacks in believability, it more than makes up for with a stunning relevancy.

For the first 30 minutes of Jeepers Creepers, writer-director Victor Salva seems to be spinning the Gein legend into an eerie, grandly effective creepfest. Then the movie veers off onto a drastically different and less satisfying track.
[Read's] unpredictability lends Chopper considerable suspense.
It's all smoke and fireballs, spectacle without any real punch.
It's a bauble, but an ingenious one, and it's also the work of a diehard romantic.
The liveliest and most engaging time killer to come out of Hollywood in a long while.
The movie is pretty funny, except it's not a comedy.

Aimed even more squarely at the 10 and under set that made the 1998 original a surprise box office smash, this amiable, if uninspired, family outing chucks out much of the gross-out crudity of the first film in favor of cleaner, cuter animal antics.
The kind of movie only the people starring in it could love.
The King Is Alive intrigues mainly for its spare style and brittle, sweat-soaked performances.
Its characters, the two and four-legged varieties, are too lazily drawn for the film to register as more than a pleasant time-killer.
Its single-mindedness still makes for a refreshing change from the preposterous bloat of most contemporary action movies.
The most puzzling, trippiest piece of pop fantasy of Spielberg's career.
It's pleasant, and not nearly as hollow as, say, The Phantom Menace, but it's never truly captivating.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (2001)

movie_review_blurb: As dull as the movie is, at least it's not Pearl Harbor.

A visually extravagant but curiously flat, muted adventure -- one so lackadaisically plotted and structured that it's easy to lose track of what is happening on the screen, even though there's never much to keep track of to begin with.
Leaves you wishing they hadn't tried so hard to do something different.
Hedwig makes for an unforgettable heroine, the perfect center to this wonderfully odd, vivid and dynamic movie.
It has a cheap, slapdash look that indicates no one behind the camera was interested in anything other than another fat payday.
Coming near the end of a summer season filled with overproduced, underwritten movies, The Others feels like a small miracle.
Kitano's most enjoyable, flat-out fun movie, provided you can stomach the violence.
The dumbest, most risible retelling ever made of the exploits of legendary bank robber Jesse James.
The movie is so cheerfully, furiously relentless, its contagious silliness wears you down.
Subtle, deeply humane.
The equivalent of a comedian emptying his junk drawer of every stray joke and gag he never found a place for, the movie is sloppy and scattershot, and proud of it.
movie_title: Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back (2001)

movie_review_blurb: It's more than a little sad to realize this is what Carpenter's career has come to.
For the farce it so desperately wants to be, the film often feels slack and too reliant on so-so punch lines for laughs.
Angel Eyes is so dull and marshmallowy, not even Lopez's naturally piquant charm can liven it up. It's a mopefest.
A blast of pure movie bliss, a hilarious, imaginative and exhilarating love letter to the romantic in all of us.
An engrossing, tough-minded drama about the slippery morality of espionage and the harrowing decisions agents must make to serve the greater good.
The cinematic equivalent of being poked in the ribs with a fork for two hours, this relentlessly irritating comedy redefines the term 'over the top' -- and we don't mean that as a compliment.
At heart, the film is not that far removed from a well-written soap opera, but its modern-day Delhi setting and its cultural subtexts make up for the pat familiarity of its situations.
Jaglom has never been required viewing, but he has never been this trivial, either.
It's the cinematic equivalent of a good page-turner, and even if it's nonsense, its claws dig surprisingly deep.
The story begged for a darker, more biting resolution, but that might have been deemed too bleak for a movie that is almost entirely bile.
Remains more of a riff than an actual movie.
It's a fairly pedestrian adventure.

Schroeder is sometimes able to disguise his contempt for the material and elevate it into something serviceable (like Single White Female). In Murder by Numbers, though, even Schroeder can't keep his own boredom from showing.
The actors do a good job of overcoming the stagebound feel of The Cat's Meow, which, for all its charms, sometimes feels as self-obsessed as the characters it slyly mocks.
[Raimi's] passion for his source material is evident in every frame of this big, light, endearingly square movie.
While Hollywood Ending has its share of belly laughs (including a knockout of a closing line), the movie winds up feeling like a great missed opportunity.
It's the sort of thing Roger Corman would have cranked out in the 1960s to fill out the bottom half of a drive-in double bill, except Corman would have never taken himself this seriously.
As bizarre as it is, Vincent's gradual estrangement from society is also easy to identify with, which makes Time Out especially compelling.

Attack of the Clones is a triumph of technology over humanity, and if it falls short of a completely fulfilling experience, it also achieves the kind of primal emotion movies were invented for: wonder.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: The summer movie season has barely begun, and already we have its first big surprise.
Fans of the off-beat, your movie has arrived.
A beautifully rendered but unimaginatively plotted cartoon about settlers, Native Americans and the horses caught in between.
Proves the 32-year-old Nolan is the real deal, a gifted storyteller who knows how to use style, mood and composition to illustrate his characters' inner lives along with their actions.
The movie isn't just hilarious: It's witty and inventive, too, and in hindsight, it isn't even all that dumb.
It's a testament to how effective The Sum of All Fears really is that it sends you home feeling more scared than you were before.
An informative, nostalgic trip back to a fascinating era, told by those who knew it best.
Schumacher bungles the action sequences as badly as he bungled Batman and Robin, and he pushes the violence to the limits of the PG-13 rating.
The script is riddled with so many cliches, you count on the battle scenes to wake you from your stupor.
Tense, terrific, sweaty-palmed fun.
A pleasurably jacked-up piece of action moviemaking.
[N]o matter how much good will the actors generate, Showtime eventually folds under its own thinness.

If all of Ice Age had been about the tenacious rodent's misadventures, the movie might have been a minor classic. But Scrat is a minor supporting character, and Ice Age is just passable entertainment.
There is considerable pleasure to be had watching a Hollywood formula crowd-pleaser, no matter how irreverent, that's been made with intelligence, wit and style.

At its core, an involving, sweetly touching love story, buoyed by Crowe's natural, poetic dialogue and his knack for writing characters (especially women) who feel like real people instead of plot devices.
Genuinely transporting.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)

movie_review_blurb: A treacly, synthetic and wildly overlong drama that aspires to Frank Capra-style uplift, but winds up suffocating you with its aura of bogus, store-bought nostalgia.
After a leisurely first half, The Devil's Backbone becomes utterly spellbinding, its tension mounting in steady increments.
movie_title: The Devil's Backbone (El Espinazo del diablo) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: A relentlessly dull chase flick with an inexplicably high-toned cast.
Feels artificial, a concoction designed to be outrageous and cool, instead of earning coolness on its own merits.
Leaves you with plenty to think about regarding the demands society places on working women, and the scorn they face when they choose career over family.
Scott boils down the war film genre to its purest, most devastating essence.
A biopic that is as messy as the life it details.
Even in its quiet moments, the movie is possessed by a moody, tenebrous aura that reflects the characters' state of mind.
It's a bit of a mess, the work of bratty geniuses with talent to spare, but unsure of what -- if anything -- they're trying to say.
Weber's eclectic, grandly engaging documentary, is as personal as movies get, a generous and candid first-person exploration of the wide-ranging influences that inform the photographer's work.
Although this may be no one's idea of a pretty story, Corben manages to make it utterly absorbing.
movie_title: Raw Deal: A Question of Consent (2001)

movie_review_blurb: The work of someone who has read too much of his own press, and in his rush to make a film to address critics, forgot to come up with a movie worth seeing.
A profoundly hopeful and optimistic film about people's ability to bounce back from just about anything.
The film would have been a stunner under any circumstances, but with the situation in Afghanistan and the Middle East worsening on a daily basis, No Man's Land feels even more relevant.
Unlike A Soldier's Story, which tackled the same theme within the confines of an engrossing, unpredictable story, too much of Hart's War feels like finger-wagging.
Dragonfly has no atmosphere, no tension -- nothing but Costner, flailing away. It's a buggy drag.
Wallace has fashioned a gung-ho piece of conventional entertainment that would have been a natural fit for John Wayne but today feels a bit too naive for its own good.
If the dramatics of the movie fail to engage as fully as they should, Kandahar remains fascinating as a piece of lyrical journalism.
movie_title: Kandahar: Le soleil derrière la lune (2001)

movie_review_blurb: The Time Machine isn't so much an adaptation of H.G. Wells' seminal novel as it is an appropriation. The film borrows liberally from the book, but doesn't treat it with much respect or affection or even understanding.

Moretti is interested in simple behavior, captured at a polite but insightful distance, and this quiet, subtly moving drama says more about the qualities that make us human with a whisper than most other movies can say with a shout.
movie_title: La Stanza del Figlio (The Son's Room) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Scotland, PA is Macbeth done with bell-bottoms, fast food and absolutely no pretension. It's that last bit that makes this amiable, shaggy Shakespeare satire so engaging -- and so disposable, too.
What Crush lacks in substance and originality, it makes up for with sheer likability.
A gleefully fractured fairy tale that never becomes cynical or crass.
Strip away its 14th Century trappings and A Knight's Tale is just a Middle Ages Rocky that spares no cliche in its unduly long, 2 1/4 hours.
Twelve-year-olds weaned on Nintendo may not mind, but anyone who remembers the tactile thrill of an alarmingly real boulder rolling down on Indiana Jones in Raiders of the Lost Ark will be left cold.
A piece of pure storytelling.
Richard Gere has never been better cast.
Teaching Mrs. Tingle is a spectacularly mediocre movie!

Despite the constant raunchiness, South Park: Bigger, Longer & Uncut has a genuinely sweet undertone, complete with some very funny musical numbers so well integrated into the story that even the folks at Disney could learn something from them.
As absorbing as much of it is, Unbreakable winds up as a mild disappointment.
As pre-packaged as airplane food!
Soft-edged and sweet.
An insanely over-hyped dud.
Thrillingly clever and fresh!
Avoids the kind of cheap manipulation inherent in its underdog scenario, leavening its uplift with sober (but never maudlin) drama.
It's the details that make Mystery Men such a goofy good time!
With Erin Brockovich, [Soderbergh] pulls off his most impressive feat yet: giving crowd-pleasing baubles a good name.
Dismayingly predictable and rote.
The film has no center to hold it together: It feels much, much smaller than its parts.
A perfect bore.
In the end, Mission: Impossible 2 is really The Tom Cruise Show, and it's not an entirely successful endeavor.
The only thing the movie lacks is a pulse.
Charming and exciting.
Frequency is often reminiscent of Spielberg at his most mawkish -- and at his most affecting.
As exquisitely crafted as they are, The Cell's horrors are all two-dimensional. Watching them is like flipping through the pictures in a macabre coffee-table book.
Terminally frosty and remote!
As it stands now, Pay It Forward winds up making a very good case for never going out of your way to help anybody.
For all its post-modern quirks, The Way of the Gun can't help but feel pointlessly derivative.
Has some very funny moments, but they're all drowned out by an overbearingly sentimental script.
Redford is so fascinated with the mythical qualities of the novel's premise ... he doesn't realize how anemic the tale really is.
The Big Kahuna is best taken as an acting showcase for DeVito (whose low-key, deeply affecting performance is unlike anything he's done before) and Spacey.
The story is not the thing in Time Code. It's the way in which it is told that makes this one so intriguing.
Ashes of Time Redux is primarily a sensory experience that deserves to be seen on as big a screen as possible.
Quote not available.
Preposterous? Yes. Ridiculous? That, too.
Yes, it is perfectly, utterly predictable ... but its details aren't, and they are worth savoring.
A $100 million production of a 10-cent script.
The 6th Day takes place in a future where quarterbacks earn $300 million a season, cars drive themselves, smoking is illegal and people still can't write a decent screenplay.
For all its technical wonders, Dinosaur is strictly kids' stuff.
If only Hytner had chucked the cliched script and turned Center Stage into a full-blown song-and-dance musical, the movie might have been something special.
The movie's attempts at zaniness are flat, almost embarrassing.
You may resent some of the tactics von Trier uses, but there's no denying the devastating power of his film.
A shockingly, unbelievably bad movie.
The Ninth Gate is far from essential viewing.
What The Contender lacks in sophistication and subtlety, it more than makes up for with sheer verve and chutzpah.
The movie has the feel of a joyous blow-out party, and it's hard not to get swept up by its upbeat energy.
A brisk, mean and unexpectedly funny crime caper.
A wryly observed mother-daughter drama that earns its laughs -- and tears -- the old-fashioned way.
A cracked romantic comedy, with an emphasis on cracked.
Lost Souls doesn't even give us a good exorcism.
A mess.
The movie feels schematic and derivative.
The kind of self-reflective exercise The Last Action Hero could only dream of being.
This is really a showcase for Streep, who makes the well-trodden formula sing anew.
A movie that revels in the primal thrill of swords tearing into flesh and blood spraying in huge, arterial gouts.
The movie is competently made, but it deals with characters and situations so well-worn, there is no conceivable way to breathe any fresh life into them.
Certainly provocative, but the movie smacks mostly of sour grapes.
Unrelentingly dull.
As light and fluffy as it is, Return to Me still proves surprisingly inviting, thanks to some canny direction by actress Bonnie Hunt in her filmmaking debut.
The Replacements does have its moments. There just aren't enough of them.
Fantastic, cheeky fun.
Remarkable -- easily the most searing movie-going experience of the year.
A modest entertainment.
Too much of this belabored romance is devoted to the surprisingly unfunny complications that ensue when Mary discovers the true identity of her new crush.
Worth seeing for Dafoe's performance alone, a singular mixture of camp and pathos that echoes the tragic, romantic allure of vampires in literature and film.
It's best to just enjoy Hannibal for what it is: A decadent, elegant waltz about evil's seductive bloom.
A shapeless, chaotic, overly frantic comedy that manages to make almost no sense.
Soulful, deeply moving.
A rollicking romantic comedy with an alarmingly high body count.
Not conventionally satisfying, but it is thoroughly seductive.
Cusack makes High Fidelity seem less self-indulgent than it is: It's impossible to imagine the movie without him.
[A] beautifully made bummer.
Relentlessly stupid and grating.
If I were 8, I would want to see it 800 times.
Overambition is a rarity in spy thrillers nowadays. If The Tailor of Panama doesn't quite gel, the attempt is still worth savoring.
Leconte lets The Widow of St. Pierre resonate in ways that transcend its black-and-white scenario.
movie_title: The Widow of Saint-Pierre (The Widow of St. Pierre) (La veuve de Saint-Pierre) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: While too animated to ever be boring, winds up feeling embarrassingly banal.
Has the feel of an instant classic, a melodrama with an exacting precision and a visceral, propulsive energy.
Both subtle and formidably odd, and already you can feel an enthusiastic cult following forming.
There's no subversiveness, no wit, no bite. It's a lazy piece of work.
All these years later, the sight of a man walking on the surface of the moon has lost none of its power.
It might have all seemed hip and edgy 10 years ago, but today, it just feels tired.
Gas -- the hot air variety -- is exactly what Driven is made of.
There is a lot to like in this stab at the rat-tat-tat lunacy of 1940s-era screwball comedies.
The last hour is pure torture -- because it forces a group of likable actors to mug their way through a procession of scattershot situations that lack any kind of comic pop or ingenuity.
As the intended start of a franchise, The Bourne Identity is a bit of a bust.
A flattening pile of artifice and conceit disguised as a road comedy.
This is pure formula -- and practically identical to the story arc of Good Will Hunting -- but Van Sant keeps things just off-kilter enough to make it compelling anyway.
At some point near the start of the 21st Century, Hollywood must have secretly decided science fiction is really just a synonym for drivel.
Aggressively bland coming-of-age story!
Censored or not, Eyes Wide Shut remains an absorbing, haunting and ultimately profoundly moral work by a filmmaker working at the peak of his craft.

It has a mythical pull to which anyone who's ever felt trapped inside an office cubicle, yearning for escape, will relate. The surprise is that the movie makes that cubicle seem like a mighty nice place to be.
A rich, marvelous movie -- the kind that enchants on so many different levels, it leaves you feeling giddy.
The real star of the film is Alan Ball's exceptional script, which continually reveals new, surprising layers in characters that initially seem like cartoonish types.
Deep Blue Sea is an enjoyable little B-movie, mean and gory and single-minded in its pursuit of cheap thrills.
The protagonists of Light It Up seem strangely tender and vulnerable, and the movie does a remarkable job of making their plight moving.
If you're going to direct a piece of crass, nonsensical junk, at least have the decency to release it straight to video, where it belongs.
Isn't She Great is so bland and sentimental, it makes trash seem boring.
Apt Pupil is a welcome attempt to reclaim the horror film genre from teen-driven slasher flick formulas!
Monumentally silly.
The most intelligent, thought-provoking exploration of race since Spike Lee's Do the Right Thing.
Unusual for a movie directed by an actor, a lot of the supporting performances in Crazy in Alabama are downright bad.
What's most effective about Life is the skillful way in which it blends poignancy into its broad tale.
It is a straightforward celebration of heroism under duress, and it is impossible to resist.
A refreshing change from the current trend of gross and grosser humor.
Once its central premise is established, though, Here on Earth begins to fall apart, done in by a flat, boneheaded script that paints itself into a dramatic corner.
Mel Gibson is at his loosest and most playful for much of What Women Want.
Tom Hanks is in nearly every frame of Cast Away -- for more than an hour of the film, he's literally the only human being on the screen -- and yet you never grow tired of watching him.
A marvelous, saucy romp.
Feels at once too slow and yet oddly truncated.
Watching Chocolat is like binging on a bottomless box of truffles: Tastes good and sweet at first, but after a while, you start feeling a little green.
The movie's scope is breathtaking, delivering the most expansive portrait of the illegal narcotics trade ever put on film.
The movie has the feverish intensity of a bad dream, leavened with a subversive sense of humor that is both sophisticated and cracked.
Once its premise is established, Saved! doesn't have anywhere to go, repetition creeps in, and jokes that might have otherwise been funny start eliciting groans instead.

Nothing fantastic or supernatural ever happens, but you can still feel cosmic forces at work behind the scenes, conspiring to repeatedly test the movie's characters, doling out reward and punishment in equal doses.
The movie is a joy to watch.
The Rundown doesn't break any new ground, but it doesn't leave you wishing you had stayed home, either.
A premise in search of a story.

Achieves its ecstatic, giddy high because it is peopled by immensely likable, endearing characters, all led by the tireless Black, who could make even the staunchest country music fan believe that rock 'n' roll can, in fact, change the world.

Out of Time isn't entirely memorable, and it contains enough plot holes to drive a train through, but the movie is almost all pleasure, stand-up Hollywood entertainment without a trace of pretense, served straight up.
Even when sketched in broad terms, Rogowski's downward spiral makes for compelling viewing, and to her credit, director Stickler never romanticizes her subject.
movie_title: Stoked: The Rise and Fall of Gator (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Kill Bill: Vol. 1 is self-indulgent, overwrought, shallow and ridiculous. It is also brilliant, a blast of cinematic lunacy and as much of a guilty pleasure as the schlocky movies Tarantino adores.

Deals with themes Eastwood has often explored before, but never so delicately or with as much sad wisdom: The way in which our past haunts our present, the lasting repercussions of violence and the cruel inexorability of fate.
Just as humorless as the original, but it's also slicker, glossier and resoundingly artificial.
Runaway Jury is an adequate, unremarkable piece of work, but as they say in the book world, you won't be able to put it down.
Wonderland never gives us a single reason to care about any of these people.
A disastrously clumsy, heavy-handed movie.
What's miraculous about My Life Without Me is that the movie avoids bathos almost entirely, its considerable potential for cloying sentimentality undercut by a streak of wry, gentle humor.
It's a dry, intellectual exercise better suited to tea and crumpets than soda and popcorn.
For all its clammy atmosphere and sinful airs, In the Cut is a cold, airless, frustratingly detached experience.
Despite the script's uneven nature and occasional lapses of logic, Coyote succeeds at involving you in its heroes' dilemma.
Deftly captures the pressures that accompany holiday gatherings.
Conclusively proves that the Wachowskis had little substantial to add to the premise of the 1999 original.
Worth seeing, for one simple reason: Will Ferrell.

The characters' endless conversations, which range from health care to Mao to heroin, are never less than engaging, and Arcand's obvious affection for all his characters, deserving or not, proves contagious.
Utterly transfixing, a pure and heartfelt ode to artistic expression and the creative process.
I am Cesar is cute and charming, although it never quite overcomes the feeling that it wouldn't exist if there had been no Amelie.
It's a ride few movies, if any, have ever been able to offer.
movie_title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)

movie_review_blurb: It's a devastating portrait of smart, civilized people driven to behave in uncivilized ways, until it's too late.
It may have taken two decades for Hollywood to finally fall in love with Lane, but Under the Tuscan Sun proves it was better late than never.
Murray has never been better than he is here, but then he's never had a part that fit him so well, either.
A one-note take on a complex subject.
Although there are moments in the film when his visual style threatens to overwhelm the story, Scott keeps the stylistic flourishes to a minimum.
If Rise of the Machines never feels as essential as the first two movies, it doesn't feel like a rip-off, either.
The summer's oddest, most unexpected blockbuster has arrived.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The League of Extraordinary Gentlemen feels overly busy, unwieldy and hollow.
The latest collaboration between director Michael Bay and producer Jerry Bruckheimer, two filmmakers who bring out the worst in each other, is just as bloated and fatuous as their previous efforts.
Swimming Pool offers something few other movies this summer can match: A dreamy, intoxicating sensuality.
Lara proclaims: 'Some things are not meant to be found.' I nodded quietly in my seat in agreement and then thought, 'Some movies are not meant to be seen, either.'
movie_title: Lara Croft Tomb Raider - The Cradle of Life (2003)

movie_review_blurb: No matter how shaky the acting gets or how threadbare the plot becomes, Spy Kids 3-D always gives you something wonderful to look at.
It's the sort of bizarre, ill-conceived picture you can't believe exists, but are secretly glad it does.
Buoyed by strong performances from Perez and Miami-resident Milian, Washington Heights overcomes the familiarity of its premise through its passion and conviction.
A movie so thin it borders on nonexistence.
[An] uneven but undeniably sweet movie.

Reminds you how our culture's emphasis on success and stardom in any field -- and the betrayal of ethics to attain them -- has a cumulative, corrosive effect on society, no matter how small the stage may be.
An insufferably artsy, pretentious work, the sort of picture that gives art films a bad name.
S.W.A.T. is a compendium of missed opportunities, uninspired action and clichés so tired, you wish the screenwriters had called 911.
Much like the lives it depicts, Mondays in the Sun is repetitious, uneventful and, in the end, dull.
movie_title: Mondays in the Sun (Los Lunes al sol) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Anyone weaned on these movies -- which is to say, pretty much anyone who grew up during the 1980s and 1990s -- will get a kick out of seeing how those two universes, with all their respective tropes and rules, have been melded.
There's a fine little western lurking inside Open Range: Too bad it gets drowned out by director Kevin Costner's pretentiousness.
It is Frears' sure directorial hand, along with some deft performances, that keeps Dirty Pretty Things from ever edging into the risible.
Scott and Davis keep you interested in the Hursts' dilemma as a couple wondering when the flame in their romance blew out, and whether or not there's any hope of rekindling it.
If The Magdalene Sisters occasionally flirts with cartoonishness, the movie is tempered by Mullan's considerable filmmaking skills.
Reminds you that sometimes, simply getting out of bed each morning can be the most heroic of acts.
The story's third-act detour into tragedy is predictable and unwelcome, providing a resolution that is too pat and familiar to be moving.
A ferociously entertaining and mean little horror movie that achieves the kind of outrageous vibe best enjoyed in a crowded, noisy theater.
Even when Mexico isn't exactly making sense, it's still a blast to watch for its sheer chutzpah.
movie_title: Once upon a Time in Mexico (2003)

movie_review_blurb: It's the performances that hold Buffalo Soldiers together.
The year's most compelling cinematic conversation piece.
The movie is slight but extremely effective, and its characters so engaging that even the sad finale, which is not entirely unexpected or original, manages to pack surprising power.
For those who don't mind a little bile in their eggnog, it's the perfect antidote to all that prefab Christmas cheer.
The worst thing about Starsky & Hutch is how devoid of actual jokes the movie is. It's all premise, no substance.
One of the most gripping and harrowing looks at mountain climbing ever filmed.
This smart, absorbing movie, which has been sharply edited by Felipe Lacerda, never feels like it's spreading itself too thin.
A thoughtful, audacious meditation on love and relationships that finds a group of wildly disparate talents clicking together in perfect unison.
movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Faster, leaner and more compact than the original.
The first nine minutes of Taking Lives are, in fact, compelling and good ... Sadly, the rest of Taking Lives is not worth paying for.
Irritating when it should be amusing, dumb when it should be zany, flat when it should be snappy.
An enjoyable slice-of-life drama that offers a couple of hours spent in the company of people whose lives are recognizable from your own.

Yes, it's all astoundingly dumb. But it's also surprisingly effective, largely due to Johnson, a charismatic, likable screen presence who displays none of the arrogance and vanity of a Vin Diesel or Steven Seagal.
Despite its shallow feel, Hellboy still succeeds as a piece of relentless pop entertainment.
A crushing bore.
Vol. 2 isn't exactly disappointing, and like all of Tarantino's movies, I suspect it will improve with repeated viewings. But for now, Vol. 2 leaves you pondering what could have been.
Thomas Jane is just wooden and buff enough to pull off the role.
Man on Fire awakens a genuine sense of bloodlust in the viewer.
What it lacks in freshness ... Mean Girls makes up for with its shrewd insights into the female adolescent psyche and all its accompanying neuroses.
An unsatisfying, overly restrained bore.
Energetic, nostalgic, occasionally troubling.
A failure on every conceivable level -- from its trite, pedestrian dialogue to its static, torturous pacing.
The rare kind of movie where the badness just adds to the fun.
Despite all its oversized spectacle, the movie feels small and unimportant, just the latest in a growing trend of large-scale, ancient-war epics.

Scherfig shows a flair for comic melancholy ... as well as eccentric characters like Wilbur, who initially comes across as off-putting and self-obsessed, but later becomes, if not exactly warm, at least sympathetic.
A passable, although unremarkable, exercise in crime-drama formula.
As good a movie as anyone will ever make out of J.K. Rowling's revered novels about the boy wizard.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The original film's mix of romanticized innocence and sexual adventure has been replaced by after-school- special plot twists and puppy-love handholding.
The Passion doesn't suffer from the airless, pious airs that drag down most biblical dramas: It has a muscular, pounding energy and lyrical, almost gothic beauty.
A well-intentioned but horribly trite drama about acceptance and fulfillment that plays like an after-school special with naughty words and sex thrown in.
The entire film is a charged sensory experience -- a cinematic turn-on.
Gives Gigli serious competition for worst film of the year honors.
Suffers from the same problem that has plagued every movie Ron Howard has ever directed: It's crisp, efficient, well-made and strangely, vaguely dull.
A textbook example of how star power alone can sometimes shore up a rickety vehicle.
Like all of the Farrellys' previous movies, Stuck on You suffers from an episodic script and an overly long running time plagued by too many dull, laugh-free patches.
A movie that exceeds even the most formidable expectations without straying from its singular path.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: There are so many beautiful, tender moments in In America ... that it's easy to forgive Sheridan's manipulative ploys.
There just isn't enough in the movie, despite its marvelous design, to warrant another visit to this material.
[Law and Kidman] share a fatal lack of chemistry together, and it's a flaw this grandly ambitious movie cannot overcome.
[An]uncommonly ambitious, superbly acted, frustratingly flawed drama.
A small movie with a gigantic performance by Charlize Theron.
Kramer has gotten strong performances from his cast (Baldwin is particularly good as the strangely likable, but still horrible, casino owner).
Elephant makes the Columbine shootings seem both abstract yet more painful and vivid.
A mad masterpiece.
Every time Japanese Story threatens to become hackneyed, the movie regains its footing thanks to Collette's lead performance.

A triumph of sheer cinematic craft that mirrors its characters' contemplative natures while extolling the virtues of lives simply led.
Taps into the terrifying rush and excitement that accompanies a child's loss of innocence: the dislocating realization that the world is not the safe, neatly ordered place it once seemed to be.
movie_title: I'm Not Scared (Io non ho paura) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A portrait of people in a permanent state of waiting who -- with only one poignant exception -- refuse to let go of their dreams.
A soft, simplistic look at a tough, complicated subject.
It does ... make a powerful argument against capital punishment, no matter which side of the debate you happen to take.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Maddening, challenging and audacious, Dogville is an unlikely masterpiece.
An uncommonly perceptive and balanced drama about a topic often treated in movies (especially thrillers) as a mere plot device.
movie_title: Te doy mis ojos (Take My Eyes) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Never becomes cloying.
An insanely timely cautionary tale about American omniscience and the fallible belief that rationality will always win out.
movie_title: The Fog of War: Eleven Lessons from the Life of Robert S. McNamara (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A high-wire act of storytelling, tone and old-fashioned chutzpah.
The movie is a giant goof, and a good one, as long as you're in the mood to play along.
This smart, genuinely creepy movie also feels real, which is why its horrors hit so hard.
Despite all the constant discussion of raging hormones, hot babes and whipped-cream bikini contests, the movie is Disney-clean and curiously asexual.
A cautionary tale with one exclamation mark too many, The Rules of Attraction simply tries too hard.
Deeply unsettling, occasionally exasperating movie.
Too much of this well-acted but dangerously slow thriller feels like a preamble to a bigger, more complicated story, one that never materializes.
Formula 51 is so trite that even Yu's high-energy action stylings can't break through the stupor.
In scene after scene, Spirited Away unleashes so much wonder and visual imagination that you end up watching the movie in a state of rapturous, awestruck bliss.
Seeing Seinfeld at home as he watches his own appearance on Letterman with a clinical eye reminds you that the key to stand-up is to always make it look easy, even though the reality is anything but.
There is a light, carefree bounce to much of Charlie that makes the film a rollicking good time even after its plot has become a drag.
Punch-Drunk Love knows how to reap epic delight from the most precious of details.
By turns hilarious, infuriating, moving, manipulative, self-serving and, most importantly, absolutely required viewing.
The cumulative effect of the relentless horror on parade numbs the movie's power as a work of drama.

As much as I laughed throughout the movie, I cannot mount a cogent defense of the film as entertainment, or even performance art, although the movie does leave you marveling at these guys' superhuman capacity to withstand pain.

Watching this cold, detached movie, you never get the sense that Schrader cares one whit about Crane or is even curious about understanding the compulsions that wrecked his marriage and career and eventually cost him his life.
What Bloody Sunday lacks in clarity, it makes up for with a great, fiery passion.
You don't need to take Femme Fatale seriously in order to derive great pleasure from what De Palma is up to here.
For all its grit, 8 Mile ends up radiating a joyful, hopeful vibe. It's an old-school charmer.
If Frida doesn't tell us anything that we don't already know, it does dramatize Kahlo's life with a fiery, soulful beauty.
If Heaven doesn't quite achieve the transcendent power that Kieslowski might have attained, it comes close.
The movie often feels as if it were just marking time, counting on your memory of the first two films to make you laugh at characters who seemed much funnier, and less belabored, seven years ago.
Deftly navigates the line between high art and mainstream entertainment.
If Treasure Planet falls short of Lion King's classic status, it still proves there is plenty of room in animation for movies that aren't geared exclusively to 8-year-olds.
This cold, occasionally dull movie practically defies you to embrace it.
A witless, unoriginal mishmash of gangsta-drama clichés.

The Two Towers is crammed with so much adventure and incident, so much derring-do and visual wonder, it makes the talky Fellowship feel like the homework assignment you couldn't get out of doing, with the new movie as your reward.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: The fact that Swept Away got made at all implies there simply is no dissuading Madonna from her movie-star aspirations. Her tenacity is admirable, but it's also block-headed.
It's the performances that elevate White Oleander into something more substantial, none more so than Pfeiffer's portrayal of ferocious motherly love.

None of these characters resembles anyone you've ever met in real life, unless you happen to know annoyingly self-involved people who speak in glib sentences that could have only come from the pen of a screenwriter.
By staying true to Harris' novel, Red Dragon makes for compelling viewing.
A soggy coming-of-age drama, one loaded with a single fresh conceit and plenty of tired, wheezing ones.
movie_title: The Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys (2002)

movie_review_blurb: A peculiar misfire that even Tunney can't save.
Runs a quick 80 minutes and yet it still feels padded.
For all its great potential, Reign of Fire turns out to be just another bughunt movie -- a disappointingly talky, haphazard one.
A movie that sends you out of the theater feeling like you've actually spent time living in another community.
Its subject matter may be grim, but the film itself is exhilarating.
Often, the film feels more like a state of mind, combining the factual hardness of a documentary with the startling beauty of a surreal, fantastic dream.
A low-budget affair, Tadpole was shot on digital video, and the images often look smeary and blurry, to the point of distraction. Then again, in a better movie, you might not have noticed.
What's surprising about Full Frontal is that despite its overt self-awareness, parts of the movie still manage to break past the artifice and thoroughly engage you.
Brooding, gripping movie that held a recent preview audience in such rapt attention, you couldn't hear a single candy wrapper crinkle.
Leaves you wishing Rodriguez had saved some of his ideas for another movie. There's a difference between fast-paced and chaotic, and Spy Kids 2 often blurs the line between the two.
movie_title: Spy Kids 2: The Island of Lost Dreams (2002)

movie_review_blurb: At its best, the movie gives you a taste of the epic Scorsese intended, an epic that, sadly, will forever remain in the filmmaker's imagination.
If it's not entirely memorable, the movie is certainly easy to watch.
Simone doesn't have anything to say about the vapidity of celebrity culture, other than the obvious.
Undisputed isn't exactly memorable, and as far as its prison setting goes, it has nothing on HBO's infinitely more brutal Oz. But as late-summer time killers go, you could do worse.
Even at his most obnoxious, Evans remains a fascinating figure.
movie_title: The Kid Stays in the Picture (2002)

movie_review_blurb: For all its merits, One Hour Photo winds up as just another exercise in genre, although an assured and effective one.

City by the Sea suffers from dialogue that often sounds like convenient exposition as well as from a climax that feels too pat and prosaic. But the film is peppered with small, explosive scenes that have a refreshing complexity.
What The Four Feathers lacks is genuine sweep or feeling or even a character worth caring about.
Surprises you with a reservoir of emotion and sentiment that happily counters the film's trendy ironic veneer.
See it now, before the inevitable Hollywood remake flattens out all its odd, intriguing wrinkles.
The characters in Secretary never feel the least bit human.
Who writes this stuff, anyway? Does this not sound like utter gibberish?
It's a half-a-hankie tearjerker, a meek, polite weepie.
Aniston's performance conclusively proves something she had only hinted at before: She's the Friend most likely to become a bona fide movie star.
With Adaptation, Kaufman has found an entirely new way of telling a story, belying the old credo that there's nothing left that's new for the movies to show us.
The acting helps push the movie past its familiarity into something that rings earnest and true.
As subversive as any of Almodóvar's early films, but in an infinitely more thoughtful and mature manner.
A gleefully repulsive movie.
You could argue that The Real Cancun isn't worth shelling out seven bucks for when you can get the same thing on TV, and you would be right. But it sure beats Fear Factor: The Movie.
Identity doesn't outfox the audience; it just makes us feel like suckers.
Rarely has being bad seemed this dull.
The movie's contrivances begin to rankle.
A comic-book movie with a sense of playfulness, a welcome streak of humor and just the right touch of gravity.
There's nothing in the utterly enchanting Raising Victor Vargas you haven't seen before; you'd just be hard-pressed to name another movie that did it as well.
A fascinating record of how the movie fell apart, piece by piece, with everything short of a natural disaster conspiring against the filmmaker.
As a piece of razzle-dazzle, shut-your-mouth -and-slap -you-silly eye candy, Reloaded more than delivers. But where's the head candy? Where's the complexity? Where are the goods?
In The Shape of Things, love doesn't just hurt: It bites, and bites deep.
It thrives on the hush before the explosion instead of its aftermath, and it's that eerie sense of expectation that gives the film its thick aura of suspense.
A sparkling exercise in movie cool.
Lacks the insane, anything-goes energy this premise deserved.
Parental anxiety may not be the kind of stuff children's films are usually made of, but this perfectly enchanting movie knows how to cater to its kiddie audience without condescending to them.
One of the many pleasures in Spellbound is watching the reactions of these young brainiacs.

Too much of 2 Fast 2 Furious plays like a colorful but inert timekiller that you might tolerate while dozing off in front of the TV, but only because you are too sleepy to reach for the remote control.
Under Leconte's artful direction, a believable bond develops between the men, each envious of the direction the other's life has taken.
movie_title: The Man on the Train (L'homme du train) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: It may sound like a mere disease-of- the-week TV movie, but A Song For Martin is made infinitely more wrenching by the performances of real-life spouses Seldahl and Wollter.
Lands with a thud right from its painfully unfunny prologue and maintains its plodding, exasperating course straight through to its car-chase-and-shootout finale.
As he did in When the Cat's Away, Klapisch demonstrates an understanding for the way young people caught between the demands of adulthood and their lingering adolescence behave.
Winged Migration is, without question, the best documentary about birds I have ever seen.
Beautiful, touching and shamelessly manipulative weeper.
For all its stylistic energy, The Hulk remains curiously flat and uninvolving whenever the monster is offscreen.
There's a profane but strangely tender rawness to this sometimes brutal movie, anchored by Compston's remarkably assured debut performance.
A bland waste of time.
By turns endearing and hilarious, Lilo & Stitch is proof the folks at Disney should break their own rules more often.
A funny, smart, fearless movie.
A wise, delicate and immensely touching romance.
The movie feels like the work of a filmmaker who has earned himself a break. Because it's Spielberg, the audience gets to share in the party.
With its instantly catchy score, imaginative choreography and rat-tat-tat pacing, Chicago is as weighty as a bag of cotton candy, and just as addictive.
A cuttingly funny, moving portrayal of a man searching for meaning in his unremarkable, unmemorable life.
The movie hums with a vibrant energy, which is powered by the terrific ensemble cast and the glowing cinematography by Rodrigo Prieto.
A stylistic throwback to such classic 1970s cop dramas as The French Connection and Serpico, with a 21st century helping of the old ultra-violence.
Brody tracks Szpilman's descent from smug celebrity to feral, starving man with uncommon subtlety.
Demonstrates a vivid imagination and an impressive style that result in some terrific setpieces.
This somber, draggy movie, which is nothing like the breezy, lunatic comedy its TV ads promise, takes Barris' claims at face value and plays them for stone-faced drama.
An uncommonly perceptive and finely shaded character drama.
For all its ambition, Daredevil can't overcome the fact that at its colorful center lies a perfect blank in a bad suit.
The Hunted is so openly, defiantly derivative of 1982's First Blood, you figure there has to be a copyright lawsuit brewing right this very minute.
This grating, witless, exasperatingly dumb movie, about three women who discover they're all dating the same man, is happy to trade on tired cliches.
It is a work specifically designed to disturb and disgust, and it accomplishes both goals so completely some people will find it impossible to watch at all.
Trades primarily on gags about towering hairdos and the sight of Paltrow squeezed into a procession of Hooters-tight uniforms.
If Dreamcatcher ultimately feels like an unwieldy pastiche, at least it's never boring.
It is as emotionally raw and wrenching as life itself.
'Things are not what they seem, because we're kind of making this up as we go along, without any semblance of logic or reason, in order to make you feel stupid.'
It's telling just how uninvolving Till Human Voices Wake Us is that by film's end, you'll just be relieved it's over.
Claustrophobic and profoundly creepy, Spider isn't a pleasant viewing experience, and that's the point.
There's a purity of purpose in Gerry -- a clean, unwavering focus -- that makes the movie feel strangely exhilarating, even when nothing is happening on the screen.
Loud and frantic and filled with all sorts of business, but it's also empty and inert, a creative exercise that would have played better as a 30-minute short.
Did executives at New Line Cinema purposely keep A Man Apart on the shelf for more than a year because they were hoping to capitalize on Diesel's popularity after last summer's XXX?
That rare breed of crowd pleaser, one in which it doesn't matter that you immediately know how it's all going to end, because getting there is so much fun.
The remarkable 3-D photography, which adds amazing depth and detail to the projected image, makes even the pointless passages absorbing.
Witty little B-movie.
Rachel Getting Married is a portrait of a family reeling with pain and resentment -- and rising to the challenge of dealing with it head-on.
The lowest of lowbrow film genres -- the teen sex comedy -- is elevated to lyrical new heights.
By taking the time to make that connection with the audience, The Promotion ensures we'll forgive these guys anything -- and laugh along with them -- in their quest to advance their lots.
The film has some vague things to say about class and racial differences, but they are drowned out by the sounds of blasting shotguns and huge knives being plunged into chests.

Hawke and Delpy, who co-wrote the screenplay with Linklater, have the sort of rapport that makes you believe they've loved each other for years. This makes it all the more painful when they start to drift apart.
Most of the celebrities playing things straight (Michael Cera is a notable exception, portrayed as a cokehead sex addict who likes blowing cocaine into people's faces without warning).
Man of Steel starts feeling like just another generic superhero movie - the exact opposite to the radical and unique stamp Nolan placed on the Dark Knight trilogy
A warm and affectionate comedy about that last great summer when you're 13 or 14 and you don't realize just how much your life is about to change and things will never be the same.

The latest collaboration between director Zal Batmanglij and screenwriter Brit Marling suffers from the same problem as their previous picture, Sound of My Voice: It's taut, compelling, unpredictable and completely wipes out in the final few minutes.
Why did Coppola make this movie?
World War Z opens with an undeniable bang. But if this is the way the world ends, we're going out with a whimper.

Director Gore Verbinski has adopted the more-is-better approach he used in the Pirates of the Caribbean series, crowding the movie with so many extraneous characters and subplots that the film becomes an endurance test.
There are long sequences in this movie that merit that most overused of terms: "Awesome."
Mocking the improbable characters and bizarre juxtapositions is too literal and superficial a reading of this dreamy, entrancing movie.
An uncommonly intense and frightening experience.
V/H/S/ 2 is raw and rough-edged and rude. It is also, for the hardcore horror fan, a total blast.
Although there are some light moments and traces of dark humor, Broken's overall aura is one of dread.
The coming-of-age tale The Way, Way Back is sweet, heartfelt and utterly trite and predictable from beginning to end.

Whatever role prejudice have played a part in the shooting - Oscar and his friends were black, and the officers were white - Fruitvale Station refuses to turn the incident into a statement on race and divisiveness.
A creepy experiment that stays with you.
Just as comic-book movie fatigue was starting to set in, along comes The Wolverine to revive a moribund summer of superheroes.
Blackfish is intended to rattle and provoke in the hopes of bringing about change.
An unremarkable, standard-issue shoot-em-up that rests entirely on the charisma of its two stars.
Furiously exciting sci-fi, carefully considered and loaded with allegories and social commentary.
A timid gloss on a hardcore subject.
Just when it seemed like Allen was going to settle for cranking out a comic bauble every year for the rest of his career, he comes up with a vital and vibrant knockout of a movie.
Too bad, too, that the CGI creatures in the film look as fake as the monkeys in Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull.
Apropos of its title, The English Teacher feels like a movie written as a homework assignment.
The summer movie season has barely begun and already it has its first 10-ton turkey.

This odious, mean-spirited movie appropriates the title and the characters from the previous pictures and sends them on a would-be adventure involving gangsters, gold bars and that pinnacle of hilarity, decapitated giraffes.
And justice for all? Hardly.
After Lucia builds to an almost unbearable level of tension, and although you may think you know how the story turns out, Franco has a different idea
An oppressive, bloated bore, the latest argument that CGI kills the imaginations of talented filmmakers.
Despite its astronomical body count, John Dies at the End never takes itself too seriously, and neither should you.
Having fun has rarely felt this dangerous.
Pulls off the seemingly impossible feat of making this horrific crime seem dull.
The Evil Dead was an absolute blast. Evil Dead is just a well-made gross-out, and it's kind of a bummer.
You don't have to buy any of the nutty theories in Room 237 to appreciate what director Rodney Ascher has accomplished.

Blancanieves, which won 10 Goyas (Spain's equivalent of the Oscars) and was a smash hit in its native Spain, has traces of a kinky undertone and an uncommon willingness to embrace the darkness inherent in this fairy tale.
The Place Beyond the Pines is hackneyed and dull: Not a single moment rings true.
The plot of Trance is purposely convoluted - you're supposed to get more and more confused as the story unfolds, not always sure if what you're watching is a dream.
In The Act of Killing, director Joshua Oppenheimer pulls off the impossible: He confronts great, incomprehensible evil and puts a human face on it.
The filmmakers don't even have the courage to see the story to its proper end, opting for a ridiculous finale that feels vaguely insulting.
You come away from Mud fondly remembering those two boys, especially Ellis, who has taken his first steps toward adulthood and discovers it suits him just fine.
The Big Wedding is a would-be screwball comedy that forgets to throw in the screws.
Just like he does with those crummy Sherlock Holmes movies, Downey elevates this rather flimsy material with his sheer presence.
The movie plays like an undercooked pie that hasn't had enough time to cool and settle.
Savor In the House for its meta-exploration of adolescence, class resentment and suppressed desire, but don't expect much more.
A departure for Studio Ghibli - an emotionally nuanced, nostalgic look at the past that is grounded in everyday reality but retains the humor and delight that are part of the studio's trademark.
The movie delivers the goods on both narrative and razzle-dazzle action levels.
Simon Killer is a sensory, experiential film - more of a state of mind than a straightforward story.
The film works better as a thrilling but superficial celebration of two incredible athletes instead of a personal portrait of two world-famous women who continue to make sports history.
That churning in your stomach may be unpleasant, but it's necessary for the film to deliver its knockout punch.
Like many South Korean films, revenge is a major theme here, although the way Kim handles it is particularly subtle and surprising: It sneaks up on you.
This is easily Bay's best movie, the work of a filmmaker with a cracked sense of humor that he is able to share with the audience.
It's a slight but uplifting charmer that serves as a feel-good bookend to the sadder first film.
What seemed edgy and brash in the original film is now routine and old-hat.
Can a comedy be too funny for its own good?
The movie takes a calm and intellectual approach to an inflammatory subject, elevating what could have easily come off as propaganda into a reasoned and thoughtful work of journalism.
Kimberly Peirce's new adaptation of the classic Stephen King novel is a grave but listless thriller.
This timely documentary passes the test as a work of balanced journalism about a man of fascinating contradictions.
Who knew My Dinner with Andre could be reworked into such an engaging romantic comedy?
The film stands alone as a tender portrait of adolescence at its most vulnerable and how we manage to survive it, even when surrounded by predators and wolves.
Here is a movie that, much like its eponymous character, never quite figures out what it wants to be.
12 Years a Slave is at times difficult to watch but always impossible to turn away from.
