Even if you know the original by heart, the new Earth has a couple of surprises in store, although the message remains the same: Watch it, Man.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: From an early footchase in which the careening camera gives us a tour of the maze-like slums, to the ridiculously uplifting Bollywood dance number that plays over the end credits, Slumdog Millionaire makes for kinetic, exhilarating entertainment.
Breakfast with Scot isn't much on originality, but it is sweet enough to overcome the most cynical skeptic.
Despite the great care and research that went into the movie, Frost/Nixon pales in comparison to Oliver Stone's Nixon when it comes to humanizing the infamous leader.
Muccino, who balanced humor and pathos so well in Happyness, goes too heavy on the melodrama this time, at the expense of practically any other emotional shadings.
Yes Man is fine as far as Carrey comedies go, but it's even better as a love story that just happens to make you laugh.
The more you ruminate on Synecdoche, New York, the more resonance you find in it.
Pixar's most mature and refined chunk of animation to date.
The Brothers Bloom feels different from any crime caper you've ever seen, even though its machinations still revolve around con artists who play tricks on each other -- and the audience.

The Hangover remains unrepentantly irresponsible and hilarious throughout, culminating with what could be the funniest montage ever to grace a picture's end credits. The summer's first sleeper hit has arrived.
Just about the only trick the movie doesn't resort to is The Screaming Cat That Jumps Out of Nowhere, although there is a pesky crow fond of cawing suddenly in Dolby Digital 5.1 sound.
Cute? If you say so. Funny? If I had a nickel for every time I laughed, I'd have a dime.
This is the funniest movie of the summer.
Inglourious Basterds transcends the war genre to become its own kind of unique picture: A bloody blast of pure movie bliss.
A shrill and gaudy comedy about the quest for celebrity.
This is a slight and unessential picture, but its quirky, compassionate tone seems destined to attract a cult following, and members of high-school drama clubs everywhere will be riveted.
Dancy's eye-opening performance reveals he's a bona-fide acting talent, capable of carrying a movie without ever playing to your affections.
Charles Bukowski would have loved this foul-mouthed, fiery, reckless woman. Against all odds and common sense, you will, too.
Watching the film feels a lot like leafing through an album of someone else's vacation photos: Pleasant, but gets old fast.
Mike Judge's Extract has some huge belly laughs, a terrific ensemble cast and more than a few instances of inspired comic brilliance. So why doesn't the movie ever really take off?
Lorna's Silence doesn't work, but it's a beautiful misfire.
In an ideal world, every Hollywood studio suit would be forced to sit through District 9 as part of a curriculum titled "How to Make a Summer Movie That Delivers."

My One and Only isn't exactly memorable, but this little, personable movie is a fine showcase for Zellweger's talents and a paean to the sort of mid-1950s America best remembered in Norman Rockwell paintings.
It does make you want to pull out some old records and listen with a new appreciation for certain sounds you once might have taken for granted.
Replete with clips and anecdotes, The Beaches of Agnes is a treat to anyone who already cherishes Varda's films and a perfect primer for those who haven't yet discovered her work.
movie_title: Les Plages d'Agnès (The Beaches of Agnes) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: In director R.J. Cutler's snappy documentary about the making of the September 2007 issue of Vogue editor Anna Wintour exhibits an icy, unflappable veneer.
The psychedelic-era Beatles would have loved this film.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A whimsical and light-hearted spin on a serious story of corporate whistleblowing.

Not since Brian De Palma's Carrie has a horror movie so effectively exploited the genre as a metaphor for adolescent angst, female sexuality and the strange, sometimes corrosive bonds between girls who claim to be best friends.
Forget about living forever: This new Fame will be lucky to hang around for a month.
Fleischer never lets Zombieland tip over into drama for too long, because the overriding mission here is to laugh in the face of the apocalypse.
For all his lack of objectivity and occasional fact-twisting, Moore takes on dauntingly complex subjects and turns them into hugely entertaining, provocative pictures.
Whip It is completely predictable from the first frame. It also is ridiculously, utterly entertaining.

That song (Jefferson Airplane's Somebody to Love), which becomes a sort of mantra to the movie, is the key to understanding what the Coens are after: When the truth is found to be lies, and all the joy within you dies, you better find somebody to love.
Acker's strange little critters turn out to be oddly endearing, even if you get the feeling this battle has been fought before.
Owen, who doesn't get many roles like this but should be signed for more, brings a compelling and sturdy realism to Joe, making him likable but not insufferable.
Most of The Goods just sits there, a lumpen load of dullness.
movie_title: The Goods: Live Hard, Sell Hard (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's just stupid and inept, which are not uncommon traits at the tail end of the summer movie season.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Land of the Lost becomes an endurance test -- one that's too borderline bawdy for families and too dull and rote for anyone over 15. Who, exactly, is the intended audience for this drivel?
Romance is hopeful and upbeat enough to make even the staunchest cynics swoon.
Listening to Tyson tell his side of the story, you come to understand him with new depth and complexity.
Hiring Tony Scott to direct The Taking of Pelham 1 2 3 is like hiring Michael Bay to direct My Dinner With Andre: A colossal mismatch of director and material.
‐ Miami Herald

Illuminating and occasionally revolting.
Proper Eyes disappoints in terms of its story, which turns out to be too slight.
At least the special effects in Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen are remarkable: You never tire of the endless variations of robots Bay and his computer-generated effects crew come up with.
Most of Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs is pedestrian kiddie fare. At least the 3D helps counter the film's prevailing dullness.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Michael Mann's extraordinary Public Enemies is an unusual sort of gangster picture, a near-impressionistic recreation of the last year in the life of one of American history's most notorious bank robbers.
If you've never experienced a Miyazaki movie, here's your chance to try one. Come on in. The water's fine.
As pleasurable as revisiting the glossy, witty, misadventure-filled realm Hughes created for his adolescent characters is, you've also been here before. Often.
Most contemporary sci-fi movies come on with all CGI-guns blazing, trying to blow the roof off the theater. Moon settles for trying to blow your mind instead.
The Harry Potter films will be regarded as one of the most remarkable series in film history, and Half-Blood Prince is the franchise's Empire Strikes Back.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Afghan Star reveals that the Afghan people strongly crave to make up for years lost to Taliban repression and catch up with the 21st century.
Like every war before it, the U.S. invasion of Iraq has generated its share of movies. But The Hurt Locker is the first of them that can properly be called a masterpiece.
Say no to Hollywood hackery and cynical, demographic-courting filmmaking. Say no to movies made by people who condescend and treat you like bleating sheep. Say no to The Ugly Truth.

With astute and subtle precision, [director] Shelton burrows deeply inside the psyches of her characters who do not want to admit that they've changed considerably since they last saw each other a decade before.
After a promising start, this ambitious but ultimately clunky and unwieldy movie dissolves into a pile of ideas in dire need of dramatization.
This is Apatow's emotionally darkest, least-genial film, and an exceptionally good and subtle Sandler embraces the duality of his character, a man beloved by the world who secretly hates everyone.

Action-packed tale provides laughs while selling products.
movie_title: Lego: Liga da Justiça Vs. Liga Bizarro (2015)

movie_review_blurb: More suspense, peril, and potential scares than usual.
movie_title: Thomas & Friends: Sodor's Legend of the Lost Treasure (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Strong toy marketing, but also lots of positive messages.
A few positive messages but more scares than usual.
Cheesy talking-dog tale is filled with potty humor, bullying
The Peanuts friends cleverly team up to best a bully.
Musical features city fun for the ghouls, lots of new toys
movie_title: Monster High: Boo York, Boo York (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Silly, scary ghoulfest has lots of peril, frights.
movie_title: R.L. Stine's Monsterville: Cabinet of Souls (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Brutal but inspiring docu about 2013-14 Ukrainian uprising.
movie_title: Winter on Fire: Ukraine's Fight for Freedom (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Confusing and commercialized ponies-as-human-teenagers tale.
movie_title: My Little Pony Equestria Girls: Friendship Games (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Routine rom-com with talking dogs and mild potty humor.
Trite underdog kid golfer tale has crass language, alcohol.
Barbie forgoes fashion for exciting secret-agent adventure.
Birth of Christianity artfully animated; biblical violence.
Funny animated sequel has cartoon jeopardy, potty humor.
Fun teen road trip adventure has smoking, swearing.
Sincere, tween-friendly tale of teen girl and horse.
Witty, comic action promotes toys and superheroes.
movie_title: LEGO DC Comics Super Heroes: Justice League - Gotham City Breakout (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Beautiful visuals, rewarding story of transcontinental train
Anti-Democrat docu has strong political agenda; violence.
movie_title: Hillary's America: The Secret History of the Democratic Party (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Gentle docu celebrates miracle of butterfly migration.
Farcical '70s comedy-mystery hybrid has violence, profanity.
Wholesome but uninspired monkey tale.
Intense, extremely violent, and sexual superhero tale.
Action-packed cartoon with animal heroes in frequent danger.
Gritty biopic has sex, violence, drinking, great music.
WWE tie-in features monster car mayhem, wrestling violence.
movie_title: Scooby-Doo! and WWE: Curse of the Speed Demon (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Kids will enjoy this playful, modern-day fairy-tale musical.
movie_title: A Cinderella Story: If the Shoe Fits (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Cheesy superhero spoof with web stars; profanity, violence.
Action-packed teen superhero tale has comic book violence.
movie_title: DC Super Hero Girls: Hero of the Year (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Classic Peanuts film is as charming and relevant as ever.
Exceptional tale of a family in crisis; cursing, alcoholism.
movie_title: When a Man Loves a Woman (1994)

movie_review_blurb: Adventure-filled Peanuts journey has some sad moments.
Superhero battle filled with cartoon mayhem, nonstop action
Sweet, wholesome faith-based romcom has positive messages.
Live-action tale has spooky scares, teens in jeopardy.
movie_title: R.L. Stine's Mostly Ghostly: One Night in Doom House (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Entertaining train tale with mild peril, positive messages.
Smart heroine saves the galaxy in outer-space adventure.
Rebooted ghouls are less scary; some mild peril.
movie_title: Monster High: Welcome to Monster High (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Searing docu decries racial bias; intense violence, cursing.
Goofy Christopher Guest faux docu has sex, bawdy language.
Superb concert film has some cursing, provocative songs.
Heroes time-travel and fight evil in funny, inventive tale.
movie_title: LEGO DC Comics Super Heroes: Justice League: Cosmic Clash (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Joyous '90s musical-drama has lots of profanity.
Profoundly moving docu about dog rescue and recovery.
Moving, faith-based tale of football star's unexpected rise.
Awe-inspiring, insightful docu spotlights American astronaut
movie_title: The Last Man On The Moon (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Engaging, smart docu includes kids in food decision-making
Zany, kid-friendly adventure welcomes old fans and new ones.
Solid messages and mild scares are fun; more toys for sale.
Heartbreaking tale of child sex trafficking finds hope.
Boy's animated odyssey has lots of action, suspense, scares.
Brutal, sadistic cult drama has lots of violence, language.
Squeaky-clean but so-so dance tale pushes Skecher shoes.
movie_title: Twinkle Toes Lights Up New York (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Classic tale from daughter's viewpoint; some violence.
movie_title: The von Trapp Family: A Life of Music (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Old-fashioned, star-studded, father-daughter comedy.
Trite faith-based tale has mature themes, lots of violence.
Powerful WWII concentration camp film is horrific, violent.
Comic '80s military romp has violence, nudity, language.
Earnest WWII tale of Jewish child separated from parents.
Imaginative tale about grief may be dark, confusing for some.
Gender-bending musical farce; sexual content, profanity.
So-so sequel has mild cartoon action, some potty humor.
Thrilling boxing docu covers race, politics; some profanity.
Thoughtful indie brother-sister drama has lots of profanity.
Stunning visuals in short docu about modern space program.
Uneven junior high coming-of-age tale has comic stereotypes.
Still-relevant '70s comic fantasy has some profanity.
Action-packed jungle mystery has suspense, peril.
movie_title: An American Girl: Lea to the Rescue (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Engaging musical comedy has action-packed slapstick.
movie_title: Tom and Jerry: Back to Oz (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Delightful '80s romcom has some profanity, sexual references.
Sandler tale has gory violence, sex, and nonstop profanity.
Winning, sweet-natured '80s romcom has profanity.
FBI man meets cute kids in trite comedy; violence, profanity.
Two franchises merge; fewer scares, more tie-ins.
Wholesome modern-day Western romance with some mystery.
DeNiro is the real pleasure to watch.
The Skulls is an appallingly bad film on many levels.
Behind a triumphant tale of self-discovery is a subtext of anxiety that ultimately enhances what might have been a pretty ordinary film.
The acting is excellent all around.
Despite these shortcomings, the lesson is resolved as it should be -- with acceptance.

It's pretty funny to watch as every family member she runs into asks when she's going to settle down, but there is really little difference between them and the host of older characters in Austen's novel who constantly scheme and plot marriage connections
Like most holiday movies, The Family Man is meant to have a very positive message, but it's a message that is troubling too.
The Last Castle will likely do very well at the box office, not because it is particulary good, but becuase, simply put, timing is everything.
Much of the "comedy" in The Pink Panther 2 is a rehashing of the jokes from the first film.
'Maybe,' I thought, 'This film will be different.' Then again, maybe not.
Agreeably witty and bizarre, but patience is required to sustain interest in its intricately oddball, non-verbalized story for nearly an hour-and-a-half.
Multilateral in its capacity to surprise, affront and delight in equal measure.
An intriguing case study of the corrosive power of art over love and intimacy.
A valuable and timely contribution to the understanding of the tradition and practice of Tibetan medicine.
None of its parts add up to much narrative substance.
Despite occasional nuances, we can see from a long way off where Sunshine Cleaning is headed.
As much fun as 17 Again has with its young-again reverie, the conclusions Mike reaches are not fantastic, but, more accurately, adult.
Knowing's premise is intriguing, even if it ends up being a familiar race-against-time-disaster-movie.
Observe and Report proposes that a man who feels worthless is capable of a violent rage. If this sounds edgy, it's not.
Monsters vs. Aliens is both a spoof and celebration of mid-century creature features, offering positive, if well-worn, "messages for the kids."
This tale of three codgery sea captains looking for a wife is not all that romantic, or especially comic.

Adventureland is as tidy and predictable as it sounds. And it falls into that annoying trap that seems to plague this sort of film, relying on an unrelenting '80s soundtrack to set tones and cue plot points.
Race to Witch Mountain holds no surprises (even granting that it's a remake).
Fired Up! is the worst of its kind: a cheap imitation of much better films, a 90-minute dirty joke with no punch line.
The other mother in Coraline is mother-love gone berserk, all-consuming and self-serving.
Under the Sea 3D offers a rare and gorgeous look at marine life from the heart of the Coral Triangle.
In its stories of immigration, Crossing Over raises questions: how far are we willing to bend the rules to get what we desire? What will we risk to uphold our own values?
New in Town subjects Lucy (Renée Zellweger) to a series of life-changing revelations, most stemming from a reductive big city/small town dichotomy.
Like Toy Story, A Bug's Life, and Monster's Inc., it features amazing animation, great characters, sharp wit, smart humor, and a story both timeless and timely.
I love a great action movie as much as the next person, and XXX is definitely that.
The conflicts here are familiar, but The Rookie presents them admirably and resolves them without sap overload.
He's Just Not That Into You is a standard chick flick, which isn't necessarily a bad thing: it's cute and comic and organized according to fixed, mostly ancient gender roles.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: In Hannah Montana: The Movie, Miley Cyrus gets back to her roots, re-learns the importance of family, and purges herself of the poisons of materialism. For a minute.
Up is full of fun and fantasy, and also earns its PG rating with complex emotional situations.
Paris 36 is ultimately about men and power.
Is Anybody There? provides an insightful and sensitive look at the pain of isolation and the connections between people, no matter their ages.
Thankfully, Roger Michell's film doesn't linger on... banalities for long.
The portrayal of Thomas' decline is visceral from the first moments to the last, evoking that same second-hand queasiness one experiences watching, say, Leaving Las Vegas.
This journey is a string of moments, all leading to Harry Potter.
movie_title: Magic Beyond Words: The JK Rowling Story (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Letters to Juliet does poke fun at itself occasionally, but not enough to keep us from saying, "Grazie!" when it finally ends.
(500) Days of Summer may not be a particularly happy love story, but it's a love story all the same.
Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs alters the pattern established by the previous two films, focusing not on the herd but on action-packed, 3-D adventure.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A charming mix of humor and heartbreak.
I Love You, Beth Cooper is yet another in the long line of shameless knock-offs being shoveled into theaters near you.
In Brüno, most of the stunts feel staged, more like The Hills than Cultural Learnings.
The troubling thing about Margaret's "punishment" is the implication that she deserves it in the first place.
The cluttered storyline of Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen amounts to a convoluted treasure hunt.
Jennifer Aniston is stuck, again.
As O'Horten begins, it's clear that Horten will manage his retired life much the same as he has his working one, with consistent routines and a decided lack of improvisation.
If the adults in My Sister's Keeper are repeatedly compromised in the honesty department, the children seem to embody truth physically.
Earth caters to a younger audience, keeping its biological and environmental lessons at a basic level of understanding.
The Great Wall doesn't have a single dull moment, thanks to the visuals in 3D. But if you seek something deeper, beyond the spectacle of fantasy war movie tropes, this one's quite forgettable.
If you love horror as a genre, skip this one and revisit the 2002 film instead or perhaps, watch Gurmeet Ram Rahim Singh's latest MSG film. That's bound to give you the creeps.

Sad yet uplifting, frightening yet inspirational, Lion breaks your heart into a thousand pieces and puts them back together in the end. It makes you believe in miracles and embrace hardships by celebrating courage and resilience in its own unique way.
Intense and thoughtful, the film salutes those who show extraordinary courage and resilience in the face of terror.
If patience is your asset, this unhurried suspense drama can be watched for Akshaye Khanna's crackling screen presence, acting prowess and sublime charm.
What essentially works for 'Beauty and the Beast' is its relevance.
To cut a long story short, Going in Style is a warm and wonderful film on friendship and life post 60. Watch it with your best friends for life as some relationships are worth melting for indeed.
It takes a while to decipher what this weirdly unique film sets out to project. A preposterous ending doesn't help either but if you like ambiguous storytelling, you might fancy this one.
Aftermath, with its promising premise, could have been an intense drama but what you get instead is a wandering, forgettable story that reeks of nothingness.
The Zookeeper's Wife is an incredible real life story that reminds us what makes us human - our ability to hope and rise beyond the darkness and hatred.
Despite the inconsistency in pace and vision behind this unique take on the legend of Arthur, Ritchie pulls it off in style.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: While Bajpayee drives the film, Rao delivers an equally compelling performance. You look at Siras through his eyes as he shapes your perception of the man.
Despite a decent cast, this unhurried reboot is way too ancient for your liking.
This business drama falls short of being a powerful biopic but if you are a loyal customer of McDonald's, a budding businessman or a Michael Keaton fan, you'll like it.
Despite a few flaws, Ron Howard's film is a competent adaptation and offers mild cerebral entertainment that manages to engage you. Go join the hunt.
This heart-breaking tale on life and death leaves a lump in your throat. It is enormously engrossing but is not for you if you seek light-hearted entertainment and romantic escapism in movies.
Speaking of comedy, the punches and the Black guy jokes are silly. The action scenes are decent and work to certain extent but the film is avoidable on the whole as it lacks 'intelligence.

This heartwarming tale of friendship stays true to Spielberg's standard of excellence and vivid imagination. He manages to recreate the E.T magic, thanks to a similar moving storyline and an endearing background score.
Damon slips into his character seamlessly even at 46, the flimsy plot, however, weighs him down.
The speedster's fans won't be disappointed for sure.
While the theme or the emotional story may not offer anything new, Lowery's therapeutic execution deserves a watch for sure.
Watch it for the actors and the gorgeous sea-coast imagery.
Live by Night is not an out-and-out gangster film. If you don't go in expecting the same, you'll enjoy watching it.
Queen of Katwe is your quintessential triumph-of-the-underdog story - predictable, yet inspiring. It may unfold slowly just like a game of chess but stimulates your heart and mind, nonetheless.
Eventually, even the deliberate bad jokes dry up and the gorgeous beach shots struggle to keep you under its 'future vacation' dream spell.
Like WoIff, if you as intrigued by incongruity and inconsistencies in people's behaviour, you will love this wonderfully made thriller, that unfolds like an enchanting fictional puzzle.
To cut to the chase, this crime thriller mostly works for its engaging plot and edge-of-the-seat action instead of its star power.
This one's effective in portions, but falls short of holding your undivided attention.
You walk into this film, hoping to feel claustrophobic but walk out trying to shake off boredom.

Gosling shines as a prickly Jazz purist, who conceals his emotions while Stone stands out as the sparkly girl, whose eyes speak a million words. Together they are magical and so is this eternal love ballad that will change the way you look at life.

If you like morbid whodunit thrillers that make you feel like you are trapped in a dark room with no glimmer of hope whatsoever; this brutal, twisted and voyeuristic tale is bound to leave you gasping for breath.
It's the execution and poor dialogue that makes this film a damp squib.
The Dark Tower keeps you engaged but fails to go beyond offering you some generic escapism.
Instead of mounting tension, which is crucial for this genre, the film is inundated with umpteen songs and romantic flashbacks that eventually kill the pace and continuity.
It's sweet and sentimental story is bound to leave you teary-eyed.
The film had the potential to be way more effective; nonetheless, it's a sincere effort that deserves to be acknowledged.
An indescribable, mind-numbing experience.
It manages to inspire, arouse compassion and strike a spiritual chord.
It's spectacular, yet can leave you exhausted.

With a talented cast at its disposal and even a decent plot, it's a shame that the film fails to capitalise on either. The script loses steam eventually, making the director resort to bizarre slapstick comedy and a farfetched climax.
Surkhaab is extremely relevant and a poignant tale of survival that deserves to be seen.
American Sniper is hard-hitting, no doubt, and predominantly a performance-oriented film, where Cooper shines. It isn't the Clint Eastwood classic you expect it to be, though.
Emotionally intense, deeply absorbing and visually engaging.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Lines that are genuinely funny get repeated to the point that they cease to amuse you.
Punjabi superstar Gippy... seems overwhelmed by the seniors around. He seems comfortable playing second fiddle to Dharmendra.
Bezubaan Ishq looks like an unintentional spoof of dated romantic films.
As Tony Stark, RDJ infuses that much needed spark and life into the movie with his superb one-liners.
Touted as one of the most expensive films to be made in India, this highly anticipated part one of the two-part period epic, manages to enthrall you with its sheer scale and grandeur.
Gour Hari Dastaan not only salutes its unsung hero, but the resilience and indomitable spirit of people like him.
movie_title: Gour Hari Dastaan: The Freedom File (2015)

movie_review_blurb: While The Martian is not an edge-of-the-seat thriller like Gravity, it is gripping nonetheless and strikes an enjoyable balance between entertainment and science.
The script is extremely weak. Limited one-liners are repeated throughout and Raajpal Yadav's motormouth character adds to your agony.
Nonetheless, it's not about the actors, this one lacks humour, heart and a story. Watch Kangana and Lisa Haydon in Queen instead.
Though not as endearing as the first film or funny as the second, Despicable 3 achieves what it sets out to - entertain the kids.
Spider-Man: Homecoming breathes new life into the MCU (Marvel Cinematic Universe) as well as the friendly neighbourhood superhero that was forever torn between love and responsibility.

Despite the story's massive potential, Raz's sincere but dimly-lit drama, monotonously shot within the four walls of a church or a heritage room, ends up being a tedious watch. Just like its protagonist, it lacks drive and a sense of purpose.
Overall, this one's creepy and unsettling but will largely appeal to a niche audience, owing to its languid pace and world cinema sensibilities.
Also last but not least, our sympathies for Patrick Stewart, who lends his voice to the poop emoji. Yes, you heard that right.
Laced with visual excellence, you applaud his film's larger than life canvas but despite the efforts, [Ajay Devgn's] second directorial venture fails to engage you emotionally.
To cut to the chase, this one's a forgettable sequel, which has its moments but not enough to deserve a big screen viewing, unless you are obsessed with talkative squirrels.
movie_title: The Nut Job 2: Nutty by Nature (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Despite an uneven narrative and historical inaccuracies, Victoria and Abdul is a delightful film that deserves to be watched for Judi Dench.
If you don't mind some shallow, video game-esque entertainment, this one doesn't disappoint.
Nonetheless, if you enjoy formulaic chaos and are fine with cliched celebration of human resilience, this one's quite engaging.
Absolutely engrossing.
What it lacks in technology (given today's 3D animation standards), Chaar Sahibzaade makes up for it with its strong and engaging content.
Right from the opening scene, Titli snatches you from the safe and secure confines of your home and drops you amidst the violent chaos, caused by the crime inflicting dysfunctional family.
Overall, the film is a joy ride as it boasts of an adorable father-son quirky banter and the ninja adventures. You are bound to fall in love with Dave Franco and Justin Theroux for sure. Watch it.
If you are a fan of fast-paced heist thrillers, this one's watchable if not as entertaining as the prequel.
This is a fascinating story told in a fascinating way. Much recommended for those who crave to see Tom Cruise in films beyond the formulaic but entertaining Mission Impossible series.
When compared to Burton's work, this one pales in comparison. If you haven't seen his film, you are bound to find this wondrous, a journey worth taking for sure.
Anaarkali of Aarah is an unexpected winner that stuns you with its authenticity.
The foot-tapping kala chashma song in the end infuses that much required energy and zest into the film.

Kunal is confident, Zoa pleasant and Manasi Scott effective as a shrewd businesswoman. The stunts are decent as well. It's the story that doesn't bhaag enough. It's too stagnant and drab for a thriller.
Engrossing from start to finish, Soumendra Padhi deserves a standing ovation for bringing this rollercoaster journey of a child prodigy and his ambitious mentor to celluloid.

The film intends to send out a noble message and manages to a certain extent but gets too preachy towards the end. The never-ending moral science lecture in the climax is uncalled for and predictable.

If you are familiar with Mumbai's working-class neighbourhoods, where the hearts of the poor are bigger than the pay packages of those residing in the mushrooming high-rises, you'll be able to notice the beauty of Banjo.
A few scenes seem unfunny. Songs are pointless. Also, the story moves at a lethargic pace and it gets to you since you can predict the ending.

We appreciate the filmmaker's noble intention of raising awareness among masses and the rural audience in particular about issues like child labour and child trafficking. However, we wish the execution was as convincing.

The film gives the impression that the story wasn't pre-decided and it was directed on a scene to scene basis with no particular purpose in mind. It thus wanders around aimlessly like its protagonist - rebel without a cause.
Court not only mirrors the reality of court proceedings but also makes us question our own beliefs and notions.
Borg's motto, 'one point at a time,' is also perhaps the most significant life lesson that one can take home from this stunning masterpiece that studies two men, who played to win.
Tijori's film has its moments but it's way too tedious to be called Do Lafzon Ki Kahani.
Ebn-E-Batuta works as a comedy with its intentional and unintentional humour but as sci-fi, it fails to deliver.

In times where materialistic things have taken precedence over people and good old values, ETKS is one of the most socially relevant films to have come out this year. It's not just a film but a philosophy.
Despite its flaws, ATC2 can be watched, if you are a diehard Nana Patekar fan. On second thoughts, watching the original again would be a smarter move.
Despite the flaws, Sunny's idealistic film exudes the sincerity and unbreakable spirit of a common man.

What stands the film apart is its relevance to today's times. It touches upon social issues like class discrimination or aversion towards human abnormalities that continue to plague our society even today.
Poignant and melancholic, Ruchika helps you in finding your voice amidst the chaos of the city.

Of course it has its share of a few creepy moments, but it is undoubtedly the most cliched and inconsequentially descriptive film of the lot. In the end, it simply exhausts you more than scaring the living daylights out of you.
Mukkabaaz is a total knockout.
Though it is Gerard Butler who may pull in the crowd, Pablo Schreiber makes his presence felt the most and ends up making an impression.
Known for making films that work towards bridging the age and gender gap, Balki's Padman is an empowering film that gives you the wings, despite the odds.

When you watch a Kapil Sharma film with a straight face, you know there's something wrong. Not that he doesn't act well or anything. It's just that his character isn't funny enough as one would have expected.
KKLH is so tedious, inconsequential and long that by the end of it, you feel like you've spent days and not hours watching it.
More than its visual brilliance, what captivates you the most is Del Toro's ability to capture the minutiae of his ordinary characters' everyday life.

Despite its misogynistic nature, Ranjan's lighthearted approach to counter gender stereotypes in modern relationships makes his take fascinating...The casting works well as all performances are in sync with the film's cheeky demeanour.

Red Sparrow fails to take flight as the chilling spy thriller you'd expect it to be...Jennifer Lawrence's terrible Russian accent and deadpan act don't help either. Despite the genre and an attractive cast, the film's mind games are way too tiring.
If you like horror as a genre, and prefer a genuine theme over sheer succession of scary sequences, you will like this one.
Barring the earnest performances of the lead actors and the supporting cast, there's absolutely nothing wild or memorable about Dil Juunglee.
Replete with nudity and violence, if eccentric crime dramas with a dash of dark comedy are up your street, The Nice Guys is your film.
Overall, the family comedy manages to pull the right strings and change the present (if not the history) of Indo-Pak relations for the two hours that it lasts. Buckle up and enjoy the ride, Janaab!
Sadly, the film doesn't even fall into 'so bad, it's good' category. It is outright boring and thus not even perversely entertaining.
While the tension is maintained brilliantly throughout, we wish the ending was as gripping or effective.
Cuaron keeps his film as realistic as it can get. No melodrama, no far-fetched stylised action scenes or convenient plot twists. The film stays unpredictable till the end.
Earnest performances lend depth to the characters, making them come alive.
Lucy may fail to woo the mainstream audience as it doesn't boast an extravagant budget or thrilling special effects.
The climax might seem underwhelming for some but the build-up is a sure-shot winner. Deserves a sequel...
Grim, taut and smartly paced, Kill The Messenger is undoubtedly one of the best crime-dramas of the year. Watch it.
Nightcrawler is tense and appalling, yet strangely funny, intriguing and engaging at the same time. Watch it.
In spite of being presented in an unhurried, episodic manner, you will not find this over two-hour long docu-style indie film sluggish, for it showcases the minutiae of everyday life beautifully.
The film has a message at its core but the execution is way too simplistic with the actors acting as if they weren't paid.
With its subtle scares, Jessabelle starts out really well. It's the abrupt, illogical ending that spoils the fun.
The dadzillas put you to sleep with their cliched humour as they make desperate attempts to win over their children.
The film comes across as an underwhelming fan tribute to Twilight and The Hunger Games series.
Heartbreaking, uplifting, liberating...Joy makes you instill faith in your abilities once again. It has that The Pursuit of Happyness (2006) feel to it.
The Boy is strange, odd and even awkward but we hope the sequel is truly scary... the real deal.
Theatre actor, writer, director Sushama Deshpande commands your unflinching attention from beginning to end with her unsaid words and raw emotions.
The birds are cute, but an unambitious storytelling sans twists and turns, makes this bird-watching unexciting if not tedious. The screenplay lacks depth and so does the conflict between characters.

The film could have been much better than it eventually turns out to be. But if you don't mind watching a modest family drama, reminiscent of the 90s, you won't mind being privy to this emotional alliance.
The voice-over cast led by Jay Baruchel and Gerard Butler are terrific and so is the new addition, Cate Blanchett.
As a film about a woman embarking on the path of self-discovery, caught between marketing and the media, the film works. As a tale on political one-upmanship, it doesn't.
Brilliant would be an understatement.

This movie has some heartbreaking moments and is moving, but on the lighter side, it is also somehow reassuring that we are never alone. Amour treats the subject of love in a manner that has seldom before been visited on screen.
The dialogues are profound; especially the ones exchanged between the Capt. and Muse, where the latter expresses his helplessness.
If you find mirrors spooky, stay away. And if you love to check yourself out in the mirror, this low-budget thriller will compel you to think otherwise.

Free Birds is quite forgettable and generic for your liking. If your kid still insists, let him or her watch it. Meanwhile, you can dream of a scrumptious meal, while taking a short nap in the theatre.

Insidious Chapter 2 is tense and intriguing. If you haven't seen the previous film, this might work better for you. Also, for the fainthearted, if you analyze your dreams way too much or face sleep disorders, stay away.
Even if you are not into fairy-tales, you'll love this one for it's unpredictable and thus keeps you engaged throughout.

Spine-chilling cinematography evokes that much required eerie feeling throughout. Dramatic costumes are another highlight. The film makes our hopelessness pit against our own indomitable spirit of survival. Who wins?

Characters are not developed enough. You don't feel for them. Result being, you end up as mere spectators instead of well-wishers. While the film preaches 'passion' for whatever you do, it is exactly what seems to be missing from it.
The only noteworthy thing about the movie is the concept it started out with - which to be fair, is unique. But despite that, it goes wrong in almost every other department.
While the setting, cinematography, background score, outfits, imagery, everything is ideal for a 'magical love story', the adaptation is way too convoluted and unconvincing.
Her is riveting, unconventional but not an insane love story. If you are reading this review on your smart phone, you might already be in a relationship with it!

In spite of using the standard elements of a high school drama (read: Mean Girls-meets-The Princess Diaries), Vampire Academy doesn't suck (pun intended)! It's about friendship, high-school crushes, romance and much more.
For avid fans of espionage thrillers, Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit is modestly watchable. For the rest, wait for something different.
This Robocop manages to resurrect the franchise and establish a strong build-up for sequels to follow.
[A] loud and agonizingly dull sequel that inherits all the problems that plagued its predecessor - and then some.
[Auteuil] deftly achieves what amounts to an actor's paradox: He brings to the forefront a character who exists in the background.

I cannot believe this is the Todd Haynes who topped my ten-best list in 2002 with the magnificent, unforgettable Far From Heaven. Headed for the No. 1 spot on my ten-worst list, I'm Not There is a tumultuous disappointment.
A welcome relief from all the war and violence we've been getting lately, it's a wonderful, heartfelt experience, executed with meticulous principles and penetrating artistry.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Hot off the headlines, this is one timely thriller that delivers its message with a huge punch and no heavy speechifying.
It's positively amazing how boring so much sex can be when it subs for character development and compelling narrative.
Margot at the Wedding provides ample evidence of just how low Noah Baumbach has sunk.
This movie probes your inner conscience without losing sight of its breathless entertainment value.
Grim, hard to take, and nightmare-producing, Trade is not for the faint of heart.
Michael Clayton literally knocks its brains out trying to be clever, but it ends up being the same kind of smart-alecky filmmaking most of Mr. Clooney's movies are famous for.
A botched-heist thriller with labyrinthine plot twists, suspenseful character revelations and out-of-sequence narrative elements befitting a grand opera mounted on a massive scale.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Lambs is utterly lacking in any kind of recognizable cinematic arc, convincing logic, coherent narrative or persuasive political viewpoint.
Writer-director Joseph Greco makes a nice feature-film debut telling a true, disturbing story about a 10-year-old boy struggling to cope with a schizophrenic mother.
It is mercifully less than 90 minutes long, but make that an hour and a half of witty, captivating enchantment.
The movie is not a great piece of filmmaking, but it shines a light on a perverse and sordid part of the world few people have ever seen.
This is a nice little well-meaning idea for a movie, but even with three writers on the payroll, it never really catches fire.

Martian Child was directed by Menno Meyjes, who wrote the screenplay for The Color Purple, and written by the distinguished team Jonathan Tolins and Seth Bass. How could so many good people go so wrong?
The ending is so lame it made me feverish. Then I remembered the perfection that came before it, and concluded that this is, without question, the best movie ever made by the eccentric Coen brothers.
The Mist is one of the best screamfests I've seen in years, and a whale of an entertainment.
With more style than substance, the story is so thin it evaporates like a puff from a hookah.
To everyone's credit, this film faces these issues bravely and humorously, eschewing any hint of emotional manipulation.
Excellent, deeply introspective performances by Frank Langella and the phenomenal Lauren Ambrose inform and enhance Starting Out in the Evening.
Mr. Affleck is laying the foundation, brick by brick, for a promising new career.
A tight, surprising little thriller that strongly captures the bogus appeal of life in the Hamptons.
Time for a new book by Jane Fonda, and this time I expect a full chapter on how she got snookered into doing Georgia Rule.
A knockout roller-coaster ride custom-made for adrenaline junkies, it's easily the savviest and most satisfying spy movie in years, besting both of its preceding Bournes -- Identity and Supremacy.

Brawny but brainless, Pearl Harbor is another bloated, irresponsible example of history according to Disney-a lame juggernaut that falsifies the facts, assaults the senses and leaves you blind, deaf and soulless.

At a time when most films wallow in mankind's basest instincts, Man in the Chair is a rare, once-in-a-blue-moon kind of movie that celebrates the best qualities in people and makes you applaud the human race.

Over-produced, over-publicized, over-designed, over-computerized and just plain over the moon, it's so preposterously overwrought with so many bewildering plots juggling simultaneously for over-emphasis, there's no entry point for criticism.
A valentine to the City of Light, Paris, Je T'Aime threatens no electrical power outages, but it does leave a nice candlelight glow.

It's a ponderous, anemic bore about how to play poker that exploits the trendy gambling fever that is all the rage on the Internet and cable TV, but doesn't have enough energy to keep the most catatonic tournament-poker addict awake.
Cleverly plotted, suspensefully structured, professionally acted and tightly written.
For all the good work that went into it, the movie is as phony as a game of three-card monte.

Please don't tell me it was supposed to be played for laughs all along, because I don't buy it. Too late to save it from doom, the twists and snafus in Mr. Brooks start coming too fast for the audience to absorb, and the movie turns delusional.

The movie, the voice of Piaf, and a performance that turns Marion Cotillard into a great new star shimmer with the kind of beauty, power, intensity and visual opulence you might want to experience again and again.

Pierrepoint turns a morbid subject into a fascinating case study of the last official prison executioner in England. The result is both a balanced, carefully researched film and a thoughtful, reflective treatise on capital punishment.
Send your teenagers to Nancy Drew if you're seeking an effective revenge for all their MTV TiVo's. It's a movie with the charisma of gangrene.
Flat, abstruse, predictable and unable to raise your pulse rate higher than a blip on an EKG.
There isn't much acting here, but there is entirely too much vomiting, and the prose turns laughably purple, too.
Regardless of how long you last in 1408, the logic to which you are entitled never comes.

All too often, the point of the story collapses under the weight of [director Winterbottom's] political priorities. He's a prolific Don Quixote, committed to tilting cinematic windmills, but he goes about the job clumsily.

A potentially commercial audience-pleaser that retains all of the characteristic Herzog complexity and nuance, Rescue Dawn is an electrifying action adventure that clamps your nerves with jaws of steel.
Joshua is a reason for applause.
With Transformers, director Michael Bay has once again claimed the year's top honors for loud, stupid filmmaking.
When Hairspray slows or stumbles, which it often does, the direction and choreography (both by Adam Shankman) pull it back together fast, and it keeps on trucking.
This is England is a vile exercise in nihilism that goes nowhere fast.
An unnecessary but somewhat charming remake of Mostly Martha, the delicious 2001 German film about food, love and family values that enchanted a lot of skeptics, including me.
J-Lo really delivers the goods. I haven't always been a fan, but she makes this movie a must-see.
The snappy, new wave dialogue and a sprightly cast that considers suburban insanity as normal as an addiction to nasal spray and one-calorie breath mints turns Juno into an incendiary comic spree.
Since it began shooting in June 2006, it's been on the shelf ever since, and you'll instantly know why. It's like watching ice melt.
The Walker is not a polished or coherent film. It's more like a work in progress. Casting Woody Harrelson was a tactical error from which the overall concept never recovers.

When you see how hopeless the lives of the American people have become in endless independent films that drive the movie audience away in mobs, you understand why the big, dumb action comics and Will Ferrell alleged comedies make all the money.

Clumsy and inept in demeanor but a whirlwind of comic energy, with an air of self-congratulatory winsomeness, Simon Pegg steals this otherwise minor but enjoyably unpretentious little comedy and pockets it like a Mars bar.
Even if you are only moderately curious about the events that led up to the pointless death of a musical icon, I think you'll find it a film of arm-twisting fascination.
Flawless is anything but.
The best thing that can be said about Sex and Death 101 is that it's not quite as bad as Hudson Hawk. That is not a recommendation.
A heartbreaking and memorable cinematic experience.
A marvelous film, small in expense but big in stature.

So much good work must not go overlooked. I just loved this movie because it's witty, intellectual without being pretentious, and filled with characters who are logically stressed and anxious to connect to a world outside of themselves.
I liked director Vadim Perelman's provocative first film, House of Sand and Fog, but this one is a mess.
You know what garbage is, but until you see Funny Games, a bucket of swill by Austrian wacko Michael Haneke, you have no idea how bad it can smell.
A funny and touching story about the way we create families both by blood and by choice.
Noise is a funny movie about a serious issue, delivered tongue in cheek but with real conviction.
Like television's Six Feet Under and the recent film Juno, it's the perfect antidote to the dopey, butter-cream-frosted teen flicks of John Hughes -- Pretty in Pink with poison sauce.
A lovely, lyrical film with perfect timing that is a welcome relief from BlackBerrys, iPods, gas taxes, punk rock, the failing economy and the boredom of cutthroat election campaigns.
This audacious puzzlement is worth seeing, I guess, for some startling and innovative visual designs. But it doesn't amount to anything more substantial than a technical tour de force.
It's as contrived and convoluted as all the other Indiana Jones movies, but not as much fun.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: War, Inc. was non-directed by Joshua Seftel, who is to film direction what Marvel Comics is to classical literature. It was filmed in Bulgaria -- and they should never have allowed it out of the country.

Bottom line: a provocative, groundbreaking TV series that worked in 30-minute segments has been bloated and padded into nearly two and a half hours of tedium and gratuitous product placement for everything from Vuitton to a new Mercedes-Benz GLK.

Mother-son incest, adultery, full-frontal nudity, murder and suicide may not lure summer ostriches hellbent on burying their brains in entertainments as forgettable as Chinese menus, but what a haunting experience they'll miss.
It certainly won't be everyone's cup of breakfast bitters, but you can't dismiss it nonchalantly.
I can sit through just about anything, but I draw the line at two hours and 15 minutes of fuchsia vomit. To suffer through this kind of hell, movie critics deserve combat pay.
It's one of the most relentlessly honest and bleakly disturbing mirrors to American despair since American Beauty, at half the price.
Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day is a trifle of a movie confection, sweet and gummy as a jelly bean -- and 10 minutes later, just as forgettable.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Stylish without being overly stylized, intelligent without being boring, Married Life is a classy throwback to the good old days when subtlety meant something at the movies and watching Hitchcock was a good reason to stay home.
It is distinguished, hypnotic, brilliantly executed and positively electrifying.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: I Am Legend is a grenade that goes off when least expected. It has more horror than heart, but it is never boring.
Francis Ford Coppola's first film in 10 years deserves serious attention, but this massive dose of Nembutal only manages to render you too comatose to think.
The Bucket List is a messy free-for-all, but it's a genuine pleasure to watch two hired hands literally running the rodeo.
A mild comedy that penetrates its see-through cellophane wrap with a few good laughs and many performances that are even better.
For rock-bottom nasty, with no social relevance, there is The Air I Breathe, a load of amateurish bilge so silly I thought I was watching a screening at Comedy Central.
There is no escape from desperation in this not-so-long-ago Romania, but 4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days is striking, original and memorable.
Untraceable has flaws, but this cat-and-mouse team is so hypnotic that all you do is sit there waiting while they deliver one big shock after another.
For a hot-button issue movie with a lot of potential for character development, it's slower than Christmas and disappointingly sluggish.
The Band's Visit is a lovely first film from young Israeli director Eran Kolirin that offers a Middle Eastern inflection on the bittersweet stylings of Jim Jarmusch and Aki Kaurismäki.
I would like to tell you this gross-out-on-camera is every bit as bad as its title implies, but that would not be entirely true. It is much, much worse.
A gruesome, confused stumblebum of a movie.
Definitely, Maybe is a romantic comedy you don't have to feel embarrassed to embrace.
For a story aimed at the moppet market, The Spiderwick Chronicles is one that holds the interest without unbalancing the I.Q.
A piece of idiotic sci-fi piffle called Jumper looks like $90 billion wasted on 90 minutes of popcorn junk. Even the butter is phony.
You'll scream, all right -- but not from fright.
I salute the inventiveness, imagination and cockeyed teenage humor in a delightful new movie called Charlie Bartlett. It picks up where Juno left off.

The sense of déjà vu I had watching so many runaway vehicles crashing and smashing through the narrow cobblestone Spanish streets only reminded me how much more fun I've had watching the running of the bulls in Pamplona.
A sexy Tudor soap opera about the beautiful, sensual and tragic second wife of Henry VIII.
Open the big cinema floodgates and Bonneville is just a trickle of Poland Spring, but the trio of ladies are always watchable.
For a film that is basically about a hip, New Wave fairy princess, Penelope has both old-fashioned charm and a freshly modern approach to the subject of media manipulation and celebrity culture.
Atonement is everything a true lover of literature and movies could possibly hope for. It is unquestionably, without any reservations, my favorite film of the year.
Jindabyne requires patience, but the payoff is rewarding.
Every frame is informed and fueled by Mr. Estevez's impassioned mourning for a figure who came close to changing the course of American history. Bobby is exciting, involving and riveting.

it is amazing to discover just how much this absorbing, intelligent picture has going for it: a strong sense of time and place, interesting characters, painfully sincere direction and an intriguing scenario that pauses and breathes in all the right places
Even though Loverboy is only 86 minutes long, as it wore on, I wore out.
Strictly for fans on school vacation.
The Devil Wears Prada is the first classy, elegant and really entertaining film of 2006.
This is a mindless comedy about sex that is never remotely funny, with a cast that is never remotely sexy, and which, in one case, is downright revolting.
There is no question about the inspired tragedy and incinerating fury of Mr. Macy's bravura center-ring performance.
Deeply touching and brutally frank.
Hollywood cannot pollute the ozone with anything more idiotic, contrived, amateurish or sub-mental than Lady in the Water.
The film is too slow for my taste, but for perfectly formed characters and authentic human conflict, Heading South is beautifully written, carefully photographed and eventually devastating.

This is a feel-good movie that is not dependent on gags or stupid gimmicks, but on intelligently observed, slightly cockeyed people and their interactions. It is positive and uplifting, and a grand time is had by all.
For an independent film, it is quite a rewarding big-time experience.
Woody Allen is on a roll. Or maybe I should say he's on a crumpet. After the brilliant Hitchcockian thriller style of Match Point, he's now reverted back to his old wry, dry comedy style in Scoop.
A richly textured and very entertaining movie that actually knows the value of telling a good story with skill, precision and excitement.
A creepy head-scratcher more atmospheric than believable.
The split screen sabotages [Canosa's] best intentions; it's a conceit that only manages to make the viewer irritable.

The scalding talents of the moody, introspective young actor Ryan Gosling are sharply focused in Half Nelson, elevating an otherwise slight and depressingly offbeat film high above the realm of the ordinary with blast-furnace force.
It's a lurid fiction, told in a clever documentary style that makes it look uncomfortably real.
Empty and moribund.
Hollywoodland, a fascinating, intelligent and probing new film noir about the unsolved Tinseltown mystery surrounding the death of actor George Reeves.
A sorry and misguided rehash of Robert Penn Warren's famous 1946 novel.
Director Niall Johnson and his co-writer, Richard Russo, have shrewd eyes for quaint British mannerisms and keen ears for the eddies of their curious speech patterns.
Miami Vice is crummy, pointless and brain-dead. No revelation there. But I didn't expect it to be so boring.

If satire is the thing that closes on Saturday night, then political satire is usually doomed to close one night earlier. In the case of a pretentious monstrosity called Land of the Blind, it's a miracle it ever opened at all.
The pieces of the puzzle don't fit together to form a coherent or satisfying narrative, and all you're left with is a big, dumb 'Huh?'
A Prairie Home Companion is about as charming as waking up with a dead animal in your bed.

The point of the film is that anything is possible when you open your heart to new experiences. Simplistic, for sure. Simple-minded, maybe. But the feel-good pleasures in a movie with this much positive thinking are undeniable.
movie_title: Marilyn Hotchkiss Ballroom Dancing & Charm School (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The unspeakable dialogue is so incomprehensible it seems like a whole new language.
Like Bettie herself, the movie is wholesome and sexy at the same time. I liked it immensely.
Nothing ever happens in Friends with Money, but a pleasant time is spent waiting.
Kinky Boots is hilarious and poignant enough to suspend skepticism and erase doubts.
[Cheung] catalogs every up and down on the carousel of a recovering drug addict with a mix of despair, pain, strength, realism and poignancy that is mesmerizing.

Hard Candy is supposed to be another cautionary tale about the dangerous risks of online chat-room dating, but ends up being just another psychological horror flick about pedophilia in which Little Red Riding Hood turns the tables on the wolf.
Everything in it -- every confusion, every line of unspeakable dialogue, every red herring, every camera setup -- has been borrowed from some movie you've seen before.
... United 93 is an exemplary attempt to relive history, inspired and powerful.
... it's too long, politically confusing and painfully self-indulgent, loaded with too many tertiary characters and darting from one subplot to the next like a butterfly with hiccups.
Although Water is easily Ms. Mehta's richest and most complex film, it is still the work of a humanitarian, made with incredible tenderness and real concern for the plight of her female characters.
Disturbing but riveting...
Call it The Exorcist Meets Poltergeist, and head for the shelves at Blockbuster, where it will undoubtedly turn up soon.
Crazy Like a Fox is sure-fire stuff, guaranteed to generate good will and do no perceivable harm.

Dead Man's Shoes is for the true connoisseur: a tight, well-made, evocative piece of filmmaking that recalls the extreme emotions in some of Sam Peckinpah's genre-benders about retribution and vigilante justice.
As idiot movies go, this one is as sub-mental as you might expect.
The movie grows mean-spirited and ugly instead of psychologically stimulating or emotionally sound.
The glum losers of all ages in Twelve and Holding are too miserable and loopy to arouse much interest -- or to hold an audience's attention for a running time of 94 minutes.
What's wrong with The Da Vinci Code can be summed up in one word: everything!
The narrative surrealism can be annoying, but it's never less than riveting, and the acting is superb.
I don't approve of remakes, but The Omen redux is riveting, imaginative and ultimately bone-chillingly satisfying.

The result guarantees a thrill a minute for all ages, and a few tears, too, in an old-fashioned kind of war movie with heart (in the best kind of tradition) that keeps you on the edge of your seat with your mouth wide open.
From start to finish, it is artistic, viable, wry and wrenching.

A thunderous performance by Forest Whitaker as Ugandan dictator Idi Amin informs and ignites The Last King of Scotland so far beyond its limitations as both a biopic and a political thriller that he becomes the movie itself.
Formulaic but so well-made that you choke on the thrills in spite of yourself.
Perfume: The Story of a Murderer is another nauseous example of style over content: a toxic tale of serial homicide set in 18th-century France that creeps you out faster than it makes you think.
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: ... a dull and dreary snooze.
The entire project seems like a diabolical conspiracy to destroy one of the few icons we've got left, but luckily that's where it fails most of all.

A blistering indictment of Germany's substitution of one Kafkaesque regime for another, as well as a human reminder of how some reviled instruments of repression turned out to be more complex than we ever dreamed about.
I doubt if it would have been considered slick or glam-sham enough to hold even Warhol's interest in the days when he stuck the label of high art on everything that popped out of a Polaroid.
The technical revels are arresting, but Seraphim Falls is slow of motive and thin of plot -- a western that dies with its boots on.
Real pleasure comes in small, refreshing doses in Puccini for Beginners.
After the plethora of alleged comedies we've been getting lately, this feel-fine rom-com with Hugh Grant and Drew Barrymore is a perfect warm-hearted, heart-shaped antidote to the winter blahs.
Breach is a tough, bare-knuckle look at the new cyber-terrorism that holds you captive from start to finish.

Contrived, incomprehensible gibberish that exists for the sole purpose of exposing a miscast star in a career stretch for which he is pathetically unprepared. It's the worst kind of flop, a flop for its own sake.
In boots, spurs and bow-legged jeans under his homemade Stanley Kubrick space suit, Billy Bob makes dreamers of us all.
[A] stark, terrifying and magnificently directed and researched crime thriller.
Whatever did the actors see in this pig slop?
Another coming-out flop.
The bigger political issues and the refusal of the Western world to intervene gnaw at the edges of this movie throughout, but it is really the human portraits of the people that keep you engrossed.
In an attempt to be unconventional and surreal, the film has no arc, and everyone talks in shorthand. But Ms. Bullock gives Premonition a truthful center.
In Black Book, every performance, every white-knuckle detail registers like a powerful drug, and when it ends, you know you've been to the movies. It's The Perils of Pauline with swastikas.
The TV Set, about the Hollywood cultural miasma called "pilot season," is the kind of sharp, satirical picture of show business as no business that so badly missed the mark in For Your Consideration.
The movie is original and disappointing at the same time. But I still have faith in Mike White.
The gifted and resourceful Mr. LaBoeuf is a young actor worth keeping an eye on, and director Caruso mounts a neat sense of suspense with tight camera angles and judicious, fast-paced editing.
An exceptionally suspenseful nail-biter.
I found it slight but enchanting, which is not the same thing as slightly enchanting.
Snow Cake suffers from the same faults that plague most Canadian films: It drones itself to death with the pace of a drunken ant, and the ending takes longer than to arrive than Christmas morning.
Clocking in at nearly three hours, The Good Shepherd is a numbing history of the C.I.A. that leaves you Novocained.
Flashy, flamboyant and ferocious, Dreamgirls is just plain socko!
The overwrought director sees Marie as France's most misunderstood monarch, but provides nary one sane member of the court who misunderstands her.
When I think what sentimental tripe The Queen could have been in the hands of amateurs, I bow in gratitude to all concerned.
Infamous is infinitely fascinating, cinematically breathtaking and largely impeccable.
Don't try this at home.
Brilliantly conceived, articulately written, sensitively acted, filled with deeply penetrating emotions and breathtaking action, it is the greatest cinematic canvas of war since Saving Private Ryan.
The movie is more infuriating and contrived than suspenseful and clever.
A Scottish Harold and Maude, with none of the charm.

Babel is a brilliant, profound and devastating film that explores the dangers and consequences of what can happen when words fail, communication ceases and all you've got left are feelings. Babel is a masterpiece.
Once again, the director confronts women on the verge of a nervous breakdown in a film full of humor and affection.
Despite Mr. Noyce's attempt to achieve a sense of balance and restraint, the material covers an overly familiar landscape with no special insight or sense of purpose.
Despite the promise to turn the audience into converts if they've never heard the music before, listening to the Dixie Chicks is, to me, not unlike metal spikes scraped across a sidewalk grating.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The paperback edition of Patricia Bosworth's mesmerizing book is being published again this week. My advice is forget about the movie and grab this literary gem fast. You will really learn something. You will learn nothing from Fur.
movie_title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus (2006)

movie_review_blurb: There have been other movies about heroin addicts, but none more harrowing than Candy.
The History Boys is one of the best, most reverent, comprehensive and seamless transfers from stage to screen ever made.
Chris & Don: A Love Story does what a good documentary should. It informs the mind and broadens the horizon while never losing its entertainment value.

Harsh Times is an hour-by-hour diary of two crazy, unreliable, irresponsible dudes trying to find a way to fit into the same society they hate, facing one hurdle after another until they appear to butcher half of Los Angeles.
[The Fountain] doesn't make one lick of sense, and it doesn't seem to be about much of anything at all.
Blood pours from every orifice in what looks like a terrible waste of Smucker's raspberry sauce.
Blood Diamond is never dull.
A movie so loaded with charm that it makes you glow all over and puts a smile in your heart.
The Painted Veil tells a mesmerizing story while honoring all of the classic traditions of superior filmmaking -- a magnificent accomplishment that will haunt you long after it ends.
Where is Major Clark Gable now that we need him?

The movie and its pint-size star clear all hurdles subtly and valiantly with a surplus of charm, saving Kit Kittredge: American Girl from blandness and turning it into one of the summer's most pleasing surprises.

It's a lengthy, engaging, information-packed tribute to an early activist who dedicated the last years of his life to gay rights before it was fashionable, and paid the ultimate price for his passion.
It's dismaying to think of all the wonderful performances Edward Norton has given in movies nobody ever saw. This one is high-octane slumming that will keep him in Bentleys for years.
It's a romantic piffle stuffed with so much candy that your skin could break out.
How could this many talented people get so utterly, confoundingly messed up? How could a director considered such an icon make so much money and demonstrate so little control?
A vulgar, happy-as-cancer aberration that takes the dysfunctional family idea to a new low. Whimsical, yes. Happy, never.
The Willis-Morgan team is about as on point as four legs with the ankles missing. The sequel will undoubtedly star Adam Sandler and Chris Tucker.

With tired eyes, a hesitant stoop and thinning hair, William Hurt makes only occasional appearances in films these days, but he's forgotten nothing about the kind of niche acting that informed his early work and won him a coveted Best Actor Oscar.
Shot by Barry Ackroyd, the same cinematographer who filmed The Hurt Locker, and using the same camera techniques, this movie looks like outtakes from a much better film.
This is another dreary collaboration by husband-wife team Bradley Rust Gray and So Yong Kim, who have no idea what to do with a simple narrative.

Not a masterpiece, perhaps, but technically polished, with inspired performances and enough suspense that by the time Mr. Hamm found the redemption that freed him from his own demons, I was so wired I needed a Valium.
The usual grumpy cynics will undoubtedly call it sentimental and manipulative. Ignore them.

Johnston sacrifices originality for computer graphics and stop-motion camera tricks, and the script, by Andrew Kevin Walker and David Self, bulges with real howlers: "I didn't know you hunted monsters." "Sometimes monsters hunt you!"
It's just another oblique backfire from Tim Blake Nelson, whose work as a writer-director in general wallows in a bog of mediocrity.
Observing the phases both father and son endure as they try to forgive and prioritize in order to survive makes La Mission a poignant and unusual film, one that you won't soon forget.
The Edgertons are a clever pair, all right, even if The Square seems repetitive and sometimes a bit hackneyed.
It's too dull for grown-ups and too nightmarish for children. It makes Nip/Tuck look like a Mel Brooks musical.
With Handsome Harry, the widely respected independent filmmaker Bette Gordon has hit a bull's eye.
Fresh, scintillating and downright terrific...
This movie is a triumph.
movie_title: The City of Your Final Destination (2010)

movie_review_blurb: I can think of no better way to describe Paper Man than the blogger who wrote that the point of this awful movie is "No matter how immature you are, you can always remain married to Lisa Kudrow."
Staying awake during this ordeal of incompetent, incomprehensible stupidity is not difficult. It's so noisy that you can hear it in the next town. Staying interested is something else entirely.
A tepid spoof that only occasionally evokes a reluctant smile.
A ludicrously pretentious train wreck masquerading as a movie.
Calm and jaded as I am, I was left so paralyzed with terror by this movie that I chewed a whole pencil in half watching it.
We all know how rotten today's movies can be, but even at the bottom of the slag pit, you won't find a load of garbage any smellier than From Paris With Love.
Mel Gibson desperately needs a good movie. His fans need to see him in one. I am sorry to report that Edge of Darkness is not it.
The New Zealand director's trademark recipe of fantasy, realism and computerized visual effects turns The Lovely Bones into a thrilling adventure.
The arrival of a movie with as much intelligence and artistry as The Last Station should also be accompanied by the sound of trumpets.
As a movie, it has all the life of a boxed pink taffeta sample at Bergdorf that never leaves the stockroom.
A soap opera ensues with more clichés than one movie can survive.

It has beautiful cinematography, a star performance that is shocking in its authenticity, a careful eye for nuance and detail and an irresistible blend of action and romance that should spell automatic success.
Every emotion is underscored with sugary music, every narrative plot progression telegraphed with the mechanical structural stiffness of a made-for-TV movie.
A small movie with a big, big actor.
At its center lie three accomplished performances, by Ben Foster, Woody Harrelson and Samantha Morton, that are not to be missed.
In the "whatever were they thinking of" genre, a new entry: Women in Trouble.

Onstage, there was so much glamour I couldn't decide whom to concentrate on. In the movie, they're so obnoxious I just wanted them to shut up and go home. The movie is busy, but in their failed homage to Fellini, they've lost his mystery and humor.

This is a lavish and lovingly detailed period piece that attempts to re-create England's last golden age, but the enchanting Ms. Blunt is the whole movie, and it wouldn't register even a small bleep on the Richter scale without her.
Well directed but sketchily written by actor Scott Cooper, the film relies a great deal on the star to flesh out what is only implied. It's a lot of work, but Mr. Bridges is merely miraculous.

Mr. Ritchie is one of the worst bogus "directors" in film history. I just hoped he might have grown up enough to enlighten the world about the secret lives of two of my favorite mystery characters. Alas, they're both as cardboard as a Madonna lobby
A silly but mostly delectable holiday confection guaranteed to put a smile on your face and keep it there.
This is minor Tennessee Williams, but times are hard. I guess minor Tennessee Williams is better than no Tennessee Williams at all.
movie_title: The Loss of a Teardrop Diamond (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Ms. Arnold's chief talent is the way she makes us understand and even sympathize with both their flaws and attributes. The people in Fish Tank are neither good nor bad, but merely human, with elements of both.
Even after the action leads to a final series of revelations that render everything else preposterous, you will still feel the adrenaline. Boredom is not an option.
It arrives on the 150th anniversary of the book, and the baroque direction by Jon Amiel is determined that we should live every single minute of it.
The film is based on a play, but it is to the director's credit that it never shows the claustrophobic trappings of a proscenium stage.
movie_title: The Girl on the Train (La Fille du RER) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the blood and gore, 7 Days is a cut above the usual splice-and-dice horror festival, but it's not for the squeamish or fainthearted.
If you value your I.Q., avoid a horror called 44 Inch Chest like V.D.
At a time when every penny counts, where do they come up with the money to finance a movie this boring?
The film is flawed, rambling and much too long, but in the end it leaves the audience cheering.
Abetted by a thin story line and episodic screenplay, The Good Heart never goes anywhere important, but director Dagur Kri creates a spellbinding ambience.

One of the many pleasures in this exemplary film is watching the women grow and evolve, revealing more about themselves in each successive scene. Fraught with pitfalls, the narrative comes together seamlessly.
What emerges is time pleasantly spent with a slice of life that examines a romantic détente between two cultures. Like smoke from an Egyptian hookah, the melancholia lingers.
A pulsating revelation on many levels at once.
Mao's Last Dancer is a masterpiece.
Talk about movies that cannot possibly live up to their titles.

The all-night orgy of stupidity that ensues is so contrived that instead of examining friendships and love, it only made me wish they had all drowned, saving us from 95 minutes of wooden, boring and inconsequential embarrassment.

Mr. Landau invests each move with sincerity and directness, and with her flawless skin and ageless smile, Ms. Burstyn still has the candlelit sweetness of spun sugar. Even in a disappointing film, watching her is indeed lovely, still.
Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps is a movie only a hedge fund manager could love.

Nothing this underrated actor has done previously measures up to the emotional diversity, focus and self-control required of him in a one-man exercise in underground suspense that Alfred Hitchcock would envy.

There is no defining story of lasting importance here, so the directors opted for a small narrative, a lot of drawings and snippets of the trial. It's filled with graphics, but doesn't really amount to much of a film or an illumination of the man's life.
The film knocks itself unconscious trying to be whimsical and offbeat, but is so contrived that it is as embarrassing as it is unfunny.
The Social Network combines a multitude of impressions and conflicting first-person accounts in a trajectory that is refreshingly coherent.
Mr. De Niro fails to make anything about his miserable character poignant, and Mr. Norton's overwrought intensity borders on hysteria. The desired moral dilemma never arrives.
I'm a sucker for this kind of stuff, and there is plenty of it in Secretariat. This is one terrific movie about one terrific horse.
Shifting gears to a softer, gauzier mood, Clint Eastwood's Hereafter finds the masterful icon charting new terrain.

Filled with nuance, intricate emotion and a refreshing absence of melodramatics, Conviction is a moving exploration of light and love shining through the darkness of despair. Its impact cannot easily be shaken.
You will go away with your heart full and your eyes wide open.
You just wonder what Jake Scott, the director son of Ridley Scott, and Ken Hixon, the confused and inconsistent screenwriter, were smoking. Whatever it is, I'll have what they're having.
Nothing works.
The movie has been through as many hurdles getting here as dear, sweet Jolene, but sometimes the most engaging movies are the ones worth waiting for.
Excellent, polished, meticulously researched and entirely galvanizing.
Kristin Scott Thomas breathes new life into a woman who was invented by Flaubert and copied by Francoise Sagan.
Zac Efron is going places as an actor of value. But he deserves better movies than Charlie St. Cloud.
Simple, straightforward and stirring without sentimentality, Get Low is a treasure.
Salt is about as believable as a secret training program for military pilots consisting entirely of kangaroos in flight helmets. But it must be said that the star carries her load admirably.

O.K., life without structure or purpose leads to disillusionment and angst, but we knew that already. I'll be darned if I know what deeper lesson we're supposed to learn after suffering through 88 minutes of misery.

There's nothing wrong with a squishy, sentimental romantic confection now and then. But Letters to Juliet is a mere lollipop. It's gone before its 101-minute running time expires, and you're left with the stick.

It's about low-rent failures who survive by finding optimism through humor and friendship. It's uneven, but its optimistic message -- lost causes can find strength through friendship and bonding -- is contagious.
