The story behind Touching Home is more inspiring than the film itself, but don't let that deter you. It's the kind of can-do miracle that reminds us all that anything can happen and everything is possible.
Part of the film's ability to hold attention must be credited to the guileless sincerity of Jesse Eisenberg's performance.

The movie is slow, talky and takes time getting started. Often it seems like an infinite amount of sound and fury, signifying nothing. But the uniformly terrific acting by the attractive cast keeps it meritorious.
The only thing memorable about Sex and the City 2 is the number two part, which describes it totally, if you get my drift.
Micmacs may not be everyone's cup of capricious comedy, but it delivers an audio-visual picnic of surprises that makes craziness contagious.
The movie doesn't work, but the sets and CGI effects are fascinating, and the actors carry on like they're in some kind of meaningful futuristic experience of lasting value.

I doubt if it has much commercial appeal, but even with its flaws, it could be fresh and offbeat enough to please discerning art-house audiences who ask for more with their Irish breakfast tea than a water biscuit.

Exquisitely designed, lushly photographed, beautifully acted, this historic footnote to the secret lives of two of the most brilliant and fascinating people of the 20th century is absolutely mesmerizing. Who knew they were lovers?

You don't get winsomeness, innocence and cuddle-me charm. Nobody will ever tap her to play Doris Day. But you do get one unique dame with a love she doesn't sell cheap, and a hidden heart bigger than her Botox budget.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: None of this makes sense; no character motivation is ever analyzed; and by the time the end credits roll, everyone in the film is dead already. The film is seriously lacking in a sense of redemption, and I couldn't find a moral purpose with a spyglass.
Elegantly directed and exquisitely photographed, the movie is a triumph, and so is [Swinton].

Although the film is labeled a comedy, it hovers on the dark side in so many shadows that it is rarely amusing. Yet it never has the courage to fully explore the havoc a real Oedipus complex can wreak on the lives of real adults.
Even Helen Mirren on a bad day is better than nine out of ten American film queens polluting movie screens on any given Sunday, but really, this is one time she should have stayed in bed.
Touching and funny in their upheaval, the people in The Kids Are All Right open the door to a brand new examination of family values that leaves you charged and cheering.
None of this prattling drivel adds up to one iota of cogent or convincing logic. You never know who anyone is, what their goals are, who they work for or what they're doing.

Valhalla Rising is nothing more than an updated version of the kind of time-honored Hollywood Viking movie Kirk Douglas used to do in his sleep, which means lots of inhuman, bone-crunching violence and no plot.
A serendipitous journey worth taking.
There's no arc here, no real pathos, and the direction is like watching snow melt on the side of a road.
The ugly stuff in this movie is so over the top that sometimes you are forced to stifle a laugh, but the star always comes through.

Everyone works well under the perfunctory direction of Kirk Jones, but even with an easily resolved fade-out replete with turkey and cranberry sauce, Everybody's Fine has the look and taste of leftovers.
Many films have been made about the perils of parenthood, but none with a more attractive and entertaining mom on the verge of a nervous breakdown than Uma Thurman in Motherhood.
Each director had a deadline of two days to complete his segment. The result is every bit as truncated and zigzaggy as you might imagine. The whole thing looks like it was edited with pinking shears.
Written by Amos Poe and directed with moxie by Amy Redford, it's the ultimate movie about optimism.
See it at all costs. It is both wonderful and devastating.
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Good acting and sincere direction by Damian Harris act as beacons to light the haunting corridors of an underworld spook house.
Quantum of Solace, the 22nd entry in the interminable franchise, is one of the most pointless, chaotic and forgettable of them all. It is also one of the dullest.
It's an enjoyable way to pass 90 minutes. But to call it an important movie with big ideas is like saying Miley Cyrus sings like Ella Fitzgerald.
Based on a short story by the great Irish writer Maeve Binchy, the film has structure, resonance and a welcome respect for well-delineated characters, beautifully observed by a distinguished cast.
As for Sissy Spacek, I can't think of a sounder role to reflect the unique qualities that make her so special.

Like Jack Palance in Requiem for a Heavyweight, the man you're watching not only has the role of a lifetime; he seems to be living it, too. The result is the most brutally honest performance of the year.
The crisis of faith faced by everyone in Doubt raises the biggest doubt of all.

No matter how bad you think the worst movie ever made ever was, you have not seen Synecdoche, New York. It sinks to the ultimate bottom of the landfill, and the smell threatens to linger from here to infinity.
A flawless, moment-to-moment autopsy of a marriage on the rocks and an indictment of the American Dream gone sour.
The comedy is harmless as a farm-fresh egg, sunny side up and runny in the middle. Pleasant enough going down, but an hour after breakfast you can't remember what it tasted like.
The cast works hard to make you believe they believe what the screenwriter tells them to believe. But in the end, it all seems contrived and silly.
Taken is the kind of exploitative junk everyone expects from no-talent French hack Luc Besson.
It has all the depth of a television sitcom parody. In the end, it's hard to tell who is more miserable -- the losers on the screen or the victims in the audience.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Unfortunately, Donkey Punch delivers a donkey punch of its own.

Two Lovers has roots in pure soap opera, but its gentle pacing and delicate performances lift it blithely above the dangers of parody as it tells the story of two tortured misfits groping in the dark for human contact.
This movie is a fiction -- and it makes no sense at all.

The Caller is a loopy, talky, 92-minute two-hander with Elliott Gould and Frank Langella (on a downward spiral following his juicy triumph in Frost/Nixon), written and directed by a force to forget called Richard Ledes.

Writer-director Wayne Kramer gets uniformly terrific performances from a fine cast playing pawns in the game of sex, violence and betrayal that diminishes the noble tradition of naturalized citizenship.
The Curious Case of Benjamin Button is a monumental achievement -- not only one of the best films of the year, but one of the greatest films ever made.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Changeling is the real deal, as good as any film [Eastwood] has ever made, and 10 times more electrifying than most. It grabs you by the throat and never lets go.
This is an amazing film for a directorial debut, but Mr. Claudel eschews sentimentality with what practically amounts to quiet heroism.

Too much technical information about circuit boards, Motorola transistors and U.S. patent laws eventually takes up more screen time than Kearns' sympathetic story, leaving the viewer restless and bored.
A mutton-headed waste of time that is every bit as moronic and meaningless as its title.
The direction by somebody called Austin Chick gives the appearance of being phoned in from an Internet bar in another town.
None of them can sing, and nothing they do looks natural. Rarely have I witnessed so many pros appear so clueless.
The Dark Knight is insurmountable fun.
The stuff that happens in a tense, taut new movie called Felon is nothing less than electrifying.
The film version of Evelyn Waugh's Brideshead Revisited transforms one of the quintessential novels of the 20th century into one of the grandest, most enriching films of 2008.

Obscured by ugly, dark photography, a jumbled script, mumbled performances, and clueless direction that make it impossible to see or hear a lot of what's going on even if you cared, the result is a film of monumental incompetence.

A marvelous, beautifully made, feel-good movie that is guaranteed to revive everyone's flagging faith in American pride at home and abroad -- something in these sorry, perilous times we're desperately short of.
Funny, animated, appealing in an aw-shucks sort of way, the star milks maximum impact from a unique body language that is refreshingly knock-kneed and bow-legged at the same time.

It's Brian Cox's powerful but low-key performance and an abiding respect for animals that can't defend themselves that invest this simple, straightforward narrative with an understated passion that is unforgettable.
A depressing but well-made adaptation of a Philip Roth novella by Spanish director Isabel Coixet.
Ed Harris reunites with Viggo Mortensen, his co-star in A History of Violence, and the chemistry is easygoing and understated. But he should have left the direction to someone else.
It looks like outtakes from the nauseating bubble-gum fantasy Marie Antoinette.
A classy tearjerker with butter-cream frosting, raised to the level of (maybe undeserved) artistry by the convincing sincerity and no-nonsense honesty of Diane Lane.

I don't know what to tell you about a dismal bucket of nauseating swill called Choke, except to warn that if you spend hard-earned money to sit through it, you deserve to do exactly what the title implies.

Even when it feels contrived, The Lucky Ones is enhanced by Mr. Peña, Ms. McAdams and especially the terrific, always surprising Mr. Robbins, in performances so likable and well timed they carry you aloft, like a flag.

Acted and written with enormous style but with front and back doors open to experiment and surprise, it's a film that challenges you to keep a jogger's pace to keep up with it, then leaves you breathless.

The extremes are so barbaric few audiences will sit through them, and despite the allegorical intentions, the apocalyptic literary views in the José Saramago novel upon which it is based fail to translate coherently to the screen.
Body of Lies is yet another in a long, tiresome line of loud, violent, nauseating and incoherent riffs on how mercenary and inhuman the spooks in the C.I.A. are, even to each other.
The smart performances, humorous dialogue and brisk pacing of Laurie Lynd's direction are all warm and friendly -- a nice antidote to misguided junk like I Now Pronounce You Chuck and Larry.
Clears up the murky facts and shines a klieg light on the dark, shadowy corridors of the George Bush White House. The story takes on a vital new importance.
Not a great movie, but disarmingly entertaining -- especially when you have to rub your eyes to believe what you're seeing (or cover them to avoid what you're not seeing).
The Cake Eaters is a small but rewarding slice of realism that is a nice antidote to the surfeit of slasher movies that have been polluting the ozone lately.
It's a brilliant work of power, maturity and vision that should not be missed.
Slick, super-contrived, pretty to look at and totally, completely preposterous.
The improbable romance between the two stars is a stretch, but their chemistry is undeniable. Unfortunately, much of the film is too implausible to forgive.
If you object to public offenses of decency, smut that reduces the oxygen in the brain or just plain lousy, amateurish filmmaking, it's easy enough to avoid Funny People like the swine flu.
A touching and engaging film about a likable and attractive young man who suffers from Asperger's syndrome.
The pace is too languid to sustain much viewer concentration, and whatever the characters go through seems only peripherally connected to the shooting in the diner. Close, but no cigar.
This movie is an emerald of enchantment in the current sewer of cinematic trap rock.

Half of the movie seems fresh and hair-raising. The rest is just disappointing and predictable. At least it provides the underrated Steve Zahn, a likable and inventive actor with natural talent, with a starring role. He makes every minute count.

Maybe the novel by Audrey Niffenegger, which a number of people seem to have read and enjoyed, was more convincing, but the unsatisfactory, yo-yo script by Bruce Joel Rubin, makes no real effort to explore the inner emotions of the characters.
A colorfully written, expertly directed and beautifully acted romp about the early life of actor George Hamilton that is guaranteed to make you feel warm all over.
World War II was more serious, complex and horrifying than all this comic embellishment, but if I sound critical, I apologize in advance. I had a helluva time watching Inglourious Basterds.
Could benefit from a little less of the balanced historical context and a little more of the movie madness of Quentin Tarantino.
Viggo Mortensen gives the performance of his career in the faithfully rendered film adaptation of Cormac McCarthy's heartbreaking apocalyptic novel The Road.

Up in the Air often looks like an American Airlines commercial, and I wouldn't call it a feel-good movie per se, but there's a certain satisfaction watching two snappy, beautiful people at the top of their form.
Intended as a farcical antidote to big-screen bores about Afghanistan and Iraq, it's twice as pompous and endlessly tedious.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's a once-in-a-blue-moon experience that tests the boundaries of film, with an electrifying, positively Oscar-worthy performance by salty stand-up comic Mo'Nique, as the most monstrous mother on the planet.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the gimlet eye of Richard Eyre, former director of England's Royal National Theatre, and the top-echelon talents of an impressive cast, a dreary, disabled disaster called The Other Man drops dead at the starting gate.
Since neither character is ever explained or examined with any real insight, the viewer ceases to care early on. The overriding effect is paralyzing tedium.

Mr. Owen plays all the colors and emotions of the parenting dilemma with a probing wit and a sense of humanity that are thrilling to watch. Roguish yet vulnerable, he gives a performance that is both rough-hewn and gently nuanced.
Not one of their best films, but because of its sincerity and the parsing away of sentiment and pretension, it is, in many ways, one of their most likable.
Captivatingly written, directed and acted with sensitivity and nuance, this is one of the best films of the year. It lives up to its title in more ways than one.
Thanks to sensitive direction and a natural, exemplary script, both of which by the talented and never syrupy James Mottern, Trucker holds its emotions firmly in check throughout.
It's a short, 95-minute ride on its way to home video. This is a shame, because the two actors in the title roles are real comers on their way to bigger things.

Written by a weirdo named Trent Haaga for no other purpose than to outrage, Deadgirl is part S&M porno, part supernatural chiller, and worthy only if you're interested in how far movies can go before the police arrive.
For a movie with the potential for so much global-warming electricity, it's disappointingly low on voltage.
Not since The Informers, based catatonically on the idiotic Bret Easton Ellis book, has the screen unleashed a Hollywood abortion as dismal and dead-on-arrival as Shrink.
Thanks to two wonderful, offbeat performances by Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Zooey Deschanel, this movie has charm to spare. It looks you right in the eye and tells the truth.
The title is wrong. They should call it Spinning Into Margarine.
It looks like it was made for one-half of Joan Crawford's old soundstage Pepsi-Cola budget and sounds like it was written by chimpanzees.

The prison escape movie -- a tired genre -- gets some fresh energy in The Escapist, a compelling, carefully written and totally gripping film from the U.K. that is acted with naturalism and conviction by a smashing cast.
Rarely have I seen such a waste of worthy talent.
State of Play is the latest incoherently written, mass-entertainment gibberish by the overrated Tony Gilroy.
A harrowing, compelling and profoundly true story that dares to tackle an important but too rarely exposed issue of the abuse of power in the American criminal justice system.
At the risk of sounding churlish, I have to admit the alleged charm of this comic misadventure eluded me totally.
A rancid load of swill called The Informers, from a depraved 1994 book by Bret Easton Ellis, is, like The Soloist, a look at the underbelly of L.A., but the resemblance ends there.
The Soloist is a moving, inspirational story told in a straightforward style, refreshingly devoid of sentimentality.
This is an empty, boring sedative by Jim Jarmusch, a writer-director with not enough talent to be either.
All told, a sparkling, classy and ultimately satisfying experience.
Annoyingly hammy and trite.

The true test of any successful horror flick is how wretched it makes you feel. At the very least, it should inspire a banquet of dread or offer a canapé of anxiety. After Drag Me to Hell you won't mind walking home alone.
Without a trace of tempo or one shred of narrative pacing, What Goes Up is not really a movie; it's the cheapest kind of amateurishness that looks like it was shot with a cell phone.
If it wasn't so boring, the dialogue would be a laugh a minute. The acting is so abominable that the cast is better off unmentioned.

Not only does it waste the audience's time with 102 minutes of misery and despair, but it also trashes the talents of four fine actors who should have stayed in bed reading better screenplays that deserve attention and enhance careers.
The result piles on relentless thrills and unimaginable horrors, with a shock ending guaranteed to make you scream out loud.
Whatever Works is a dubious idea at best, but when nothing works, it's time to throw out the script and move on to omething that does.

The writing team of Jeremy Leven and director Cassavetes have joined forces with a great cast to bring the best-selling book by Jodi Picoult to life with a purity that can only be called inspirational.
Thrilling, glamorous, richly textured and breathlessly action-packed, it is one of the best movies of the year.

Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince, the sixth and worst installment yet, is two and a half hours of paralyzing tedium, featuring another colossal waste of British talent and a plot a real witch couldn't find with a crystal ball.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: What makes pretentious, low-budget-indie filmmakers think the world is waiting breathlessly to absorb their personal memoirs like groundbreaking new recipes for meatballs?
In the age of low-budget independent grab-a-flicks, this high-powered waste of time proves what superior talents have to do now to collect an occasional big-studio Hollywood paycheck.
On_Line is the kind of thing I dread -- a movie about digital technology directed by an expert in interactive media and video games.
Despite fine performances and occasional moments of fascinating visual beauty, Ask the Dust is long, lazy, plotless, formless, overwrought, hysterical, unconvincing and very, very boring.
Lethal for kids and an unspeakable insult to adults, this unreleasable fiasco is a torture for all.
As the sulking, moody male hustler in the title role, [Franco] has all of Dean's mannerisms and self-indulgence, but none of his sweetness and vulnerability.
See it for Edward Norton, who does his usual job of turning sackcloth into satin.
A vivid, spicy footnote to history, and a movie that grips and holds you in rapt attention from start to finish.
A fine film that proves the past is never too bleak -- or the future too hopeless -- to discover a productive new life, and a home and family to share it.
This is the kind of movie where the big scene is a man shot out of a cannon into a vat of ice cream.

Fragmented and stinking vaguely of literary pretentiousness, The Hours is a stretch -- it's missing the spinal fusion that might have held it together with the kind of cinematic coherence I found sadly lacking.
Simply and truly put, it is devastating.
It's 89 minutes of pure agony without a laugh in sight.
A great film of integrity and unforgettable power that leaves you breathless with gratitude.
Flawed but unmistakably moving, Amen shines a flashlight on the darkest chapter in modern history.
One of the best and most furiously paced films about the controversial LAPD since L. A. Confidential.
This self-indulgent bilge is about -- absolutely nothing!
A technically proficient but emotionally vacuous historical pageant.
What is the point of a gothic Edward Gorey riddle if it's got all of the depression and none of the drollery?
Grading on the curve, I give it high marks for trying something different, but somewhat lower ones for entertainment value.
It has power above and below the waist, and proves that not all the navels in L.A. are in the oranges.
More an exercise in how to lose an audience in 10 minutes.
movie_title: How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Powerful and profound.
It pretends to be a meaningful slice of Americana, but only succeeds in serving masses of tedium while driving its heavy foot down its own throat.
A banal but necessary footnote.
A meticulously directed, deliciously acted, humorously written work of skill, energy and imagination.
Not bad enough to dismiss but too dense and boring to praise, let's just call Martin Scorsese's Gangs of New York the year's longest and most expensive cinematic disappointment.
Adaptation gets an A for audacity and a Z for Zzzzz...
It's been a long time since the screen has produced a more charmingly muddled or more consistently interesting kid than 17-year-old Jason (Igby) Slocumb.
Like all great films about a life you never knew existed, it offers much to absorb and even more to think about after the final frame.
Red Dragon is so good that it might be the final word on Hannibal Lecter.
It's as preposterous and phony as a Confederate C-note, but Reese Witherspoon has so much natural beauty, talent and charm she guarantees more fun than the day the hogs ate Willie.
Manipulative and brush-stroked with so much Disney gloss it looks polyurethaned.
How odd that a tribute to a wildly theatrical presence should turn out so dull and prosaic.
Mr. Moore aims at so many targets and tilts at so many windmills that his arguments lose persuasion.
If there is one thing worse than a Guy Ritchie movie, it's a Guy Ritchie movie with Madonna in it.
From both a great and a terrible story, Mr. Nelson has made a film that is an undeniably worthy and devastating experience.

From the opening razzmatazz and Vegas lounge-band arrangements behind the credits, to the crime-lab murder scene itself, Mr. Schrader captures the air-conditioned look and feel of the Hollywood dream factory.
The greatest movie about an artist since Vincente Minnelli grafted the psychological turmoil of Vincent Van Gogh onto the screen in Lust for Life.
The terrific and bewilderingly underrated Campbell Scott gives a star performance that is nothing short of mesmerizing.
O.K., so I'm the wrong audience for this teenage junk.
It's a forgery that diminishes not only the originality and pleasure of the film it copies, but also the entire school of filmmaking it wants to emulate.
Every element in Far From Heaven harmonizes, in the kind of colossal achievement that revives my faith in movies and keeps me coming back for more.
This is a film of enormous heart, compassion and intelligence that tackles vital issues with wrenching, thought-provoking honesty and cinematic skill.
The most thrilling, lavishly designed and imaginative Bond picture in years.
Highly recommended viewing for its courage, ideas, technical proficiency and great acting.

The story is timeless, but when adapted to the modern age, it makes for a wrenching film -- never preachy or sentimental, and refreshingly non-judgmental about the fundamental and contradictory issues it raises.
In all fairness, I must report that the children of varying ages in my audience never coughed, fidgeted or romped up and down the aisles for bathroom breaks.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Fiasco of infuriating pretentiousness and numbing incoherence.
A television event that truly deserves the label.
Goldie Hawn and Susan Sarandon are an inspired dream team.
Raping and pillaging and blowing things up is mainly what this movie is about, although it claims to show how the most robotic, dehumanized soldiers can be transformed by human suffering.
Stupid, sophomoric and moronically silly, it leaves you with the feeling that you might welcome shock treatment just to get your brain back.
If you don't go away entertained, informed and sated with satisfaction, you need to have your pulse checked to see if you still have one.
A complex story, repellent but full of tension and surprise. It holds attention raptly.
Empty, minuscule and pointless.
Two parts psychological thriller and one part pretentious French art-house head-scratcher that leaves you mumbling, 'Duh.'
A great film that deserves genuflection.
A juicy, character-driven western with a real plot that spins a hypnotic narrative.
A delightful blend of American sensibility and French chaos in a movie that is sunny, surprising and consistently entertaining.
Shapeless and without a shred of originality, the movie mimics and copies pieces of a number of old movies, all superior in every way.
A charming and luxurious romantic interlude.
In the old days, a feverish programmer like 28 Days Later would end up on the bottom half of a double bill.
Everyone in it needs a blood transfusion, and before it's over, so will you.
Good Morning, Night is as tired and inconsequential as week-old pasta.
Elephant is so contrived and minimalistic that it has the dramatic effect of a line drawing.
Dogville is like climbing the Matterhorn with a cement block tied to your back.
A sad movie about the irony of inescapable destiny, it left me captivated and trembling.

If you have better eyesight and a stronger lower lumbar than I do, you might confront the challenge of reading six hours and six minutes of subtitles with more enthusiasm than I did. But it's still six hours and six minutes out of your life.
movie_title: The Best of Youth (La meglio gioventù) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The epitome of what a feel-good movie is supposed to be but rarely is, this one is beautiful to look at and life-affirming to think about, and it doesn't have a pretentious bone in its head.
What saves My Life Without Me from the status of a five-Kleenex weepie is the maturity of vision that permeates the writing and direction and shines through each performance.
None of this adds up to much of a movie; it's more like a filmed hodgepodge of not-fully- thought-out ideas and one-liners and small shards of jaundiced polemic.
A solid whodunit, with disturbing, provocative, take-home insights into human nature.
Young Adam makes no sense and doesn't seem to be about anything except dirty floors, splintered fingernails and eye sores.
It's the kind of predictable programmer that used to fill the bottom half of double bills, but it's worth the effort to catch Ms. Griffiths.
It has no tempo, energy or pulse.
Big, dopey and crammed with special effects that take the breath away.
The characters have no wit or charm, the plot has no conflict or development, nothing happens for any reason other than script requirements.
A first-tier thriller, Phone Booth will make you think twice before you ever enter a public phone facility again, but while it curls your hair, it makes you think.
Embarrassed and clueless, Mr. Nicholson is clearly slumming. As a goopy, doofus pet-clothes designer whose only talent is nostril-wiggling, Mr. Sandler comes closer to playing his real self.
One of those rare and exemplary motion pictures that is likely to make audiences of strangers want to hold hands.

Mr. Jordan has lovingly recreated much of what glittered in the hard French thrillers that once starred Delon and Belmondo, and provided a superbly customized vehicle for the salty charms of ashtray-voiced Nick Nolte.
It's a curious and unsatisfying lark, in which Robert Duvall the actor is rendered speechless by Robert Duvall the writer and sideswiped by Robert Duvall the director.

A film that revels in the insights of Duras' writing and the wisdom of Ms. Moreau's ripe experience as an actress -- a perfectly observed hommage to two extraordinary women of distinction, alone but never lonely.
A funny, articulate, imperfect, sometimes messy, often infuriatingly sentimental, but always caring and spirited movie.

Mr. Scorsese is a great director who often fails, but you have to give him credit for always being on the prowl for new and demanding subjects, even when the results are disastrous, and for remaining true to his own vision, even when it is not shared.
An unsettling and unforgettable masterpiece of skid-row poetry that punctures the heart.
It's another movie about a dysfunctional family, but this one is different because they're original, lovable, forgivable and fascinating.
Conjuring memories of my own student days in the bayou belt, I recall English professors on Southern campuses who were the spitting image of everything Mr. Travolta says and does in this film.
movie_title: A Love Song for Bobby Long (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Vibrant, thrilling, colorful and somewhat campy.
Like a lounge revue on a second-class cruise ship.
A real Gothic page-turner in the William Faulkner tradition.
Sinks to new depths of incoherent pretentiousness.
Riveting, historically valuable and heart-skippingly exhilarating.
A feel-good film of such originality and sweetness in a summer of otherwise derivative sequels and remakes that it practically qualifies for miracle status.
To paraphrase Paul Rudnick's Premiere magazine movie-critic alter ego, Libby Gelman-Waxner: It's flat, cold, fork-resistant and tasteless, if you ask me.
Undeniably galvanizing, immensely watchable and damned good filmmaking.
Everything about it is stultifying, unexceptional and dull.
It is my sad duty to tell you it is wooden, artificial, contrived, infuriating and as phony as an invitation to bring along a tape recorder to dinner with J.D. Salinger.
Lyrical, sweet-natured, touching, sexy and very funny, A Home at the End of the World is also beautifully served by an exemplary cast.
movie_title: A Home at the End of the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Not one enigmatic person in The Door in the Floor asks to be liked, but you like them anyway.
For all its flaws, I, Robot is arresting to look at.
How rare to see a film that says there is still a value system out there, that being thoughtful and caring is not uncool.
This is a family movie on a grand scale, enhanced by lush cinematography and throbbing music, with a minimum of dialogue and an endless assortment of thrills.
Another of those incoherent Robert Ludlum spy thrillers with more logistics than logic.
One of the most galvanizing and unforgettable films of the year.
The kind of movie that almost guarantees the loss of a few I.Q. points.
A tight, well-made, evocative piece of filmmaking for true connoisseurs of gangster movies that is unnerving, yet completely sure of every step it takes.
As violent thrillers go, Collateral goes down quite nicely, stirring up hardly any acid reflux at all.
Another mediocre lunacy from the overrated M. Night Shyamalan.
A breathless and dazzling caper that knocks your socks off.
A shapeless mess.
It's lavish but lulling, and at two hours and 18 minutes, it's something of a bore.
Moore is too precious a commodity to fritter away her time and talent on a no-thrills thriller as bland and superficial as The Forgotten.

I, for one, eagerly await the sequel to Bernie.

A somewhat reserved but sensual and gratifying movie that finds and polishes connections between literature and the screen while further catapulting the wonderful British actress Gemma Arterton several notches up the ladder toward international stardom.

It's tender, clever, wise and highly recommended.

Realistic and refined, but uneven and disappointing.

Sad and often laugh-out-loud funny.

Yawn.

movie_title: In the Name of My Daughter (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The tender magnetism of Blythe Danner turns an intelligent, sensitive story of love among the not so young into a work of art.
movie_title: I'll See You in My Dreams (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's described as a smart, suspenseful psychological thriller, but there's nothing smart about it, and as an alleged thriller, when the mysteries are explained in a twist finale, it could use a psychologist of its own.

Unfortunately, nobody ever won an Oscar for washboard abs. And nobody is going to win five seconds of admiration for 115 minutes of tedium in The Gunman.
Another inconsequential Noah Baumbach parody of so-called "normal" people trying to function in a fractional society changing too rapidly to keep up with, While We're Young is a dreary bummer.
Into each life some rain eventually falls, and in a bomb called Serena, golden couple Bradley Cooper and Jennifer Lawrence, united for the third time onscreen, arrive soaking wet.
Nothing turns out the way you expect it. Everyone has an F.A.O. Schwarz gift box full of surprises before 5 to 7 smoothly sails into its final sunset over the Manhattan skyline, and so will you.

It's a touching film that entertains with warmth and humor while teaching us something about history, law and justice with enormous heart, subtlety and compassion, brilliantly acted and skillfully written. Is there anything Helen Mirren cannot do?
Nothing wrong with a little gore as long as the result is a few goosebumps. This one is no scarier than running out of ink in the middle of a midterm exam.
The movie moves as slowly as the oncoming fog, but Juliette Binoche is always a pleasure to watch ...
The movie tries too hard to promise nail-crunching terror that it never really delivers.

This movie could make you pre-diabetic. That's an observation, not a criticism.
he Road Within backfires by emphasizing the same quirks and imbalances it seeks to soften. Reducing it to the genre of idiot comedy doesn't advance the cause, either.

As a director, Mr. Crowe's camera meanders all over the place; as an actor, he mumbles and growls his way through the carnage like it was nothing more important than a re-make of Gladiator, filmed on old sets from Gene Autry westerns.
This filmed version of Hardy's fourth novel is well worth seeing. It rises head and shoulders above most of what we've been seeing lately.
There are good things in it, but Ms. Hunt is smart, observant and bright enough to make films that resonate with more freshness than this. Maybe next time.
The movie is nothing more than a labored series of skits that play like ideas from rejected TV pilots.

I am tempted to say it's another sorry example of what women have to do to keep an acting career going today, when all the juicy roles go to men. Unfortunately they have only themselves to blame. They are both listed in the credits as executive producers.

I found the whole thing pokey and plodding, but there's no denying the fact that even when sitting through Mr. Holmes seems numbing, Mr. McKellen is a force so powerful he's his own reward.
It revives the pleasant art of storytelling most of today's young filmmakers have all but abandoned, and cures (temporarily, anyway) my allergy to Adam Sandler.

Moving effortlessly between big Hollywood movies and modest New York stage vehicles, [Gyllenhaal has] turned into quite an actor. Few stars make such concentrated efforts to improve their craft while rising through the ranks of stardom.

movie_review_blurb: Some people will find it too emotionally wrenching to watch, but there are moments of raw, understated sensitivity, encapsulating the ache of regret at the heart of Shelter.
Bryan Cranston brings the complex personality of Trumbo to life with substance and humor.

So boring it defies description. By the Sea is not only a dog; it's a dog that's got fleas.

movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's a funny, offbeat idea for a farce up to a point, but the joke wears thin too fast to sustain interest and the Hesses lack the originality and cleverness to juggle their balloons in the air in any fresh way.

As a memorable work of cinema, it misses every important mark by a mile.

Posing as a bogus thriller without one line of believable dialogue or one single thrill, Mojave is 93 minutes of gibberish with guns and phony literary pretentiousness about two thugs in a duel of weapons and words that goes nowhere fast.
Another slash-and-dice programmer with no redeeming factors whatsoever.
"What's the point of any of this?" asks Cassie. I kept hoping, but no such luck. It's a question that is never answered.
I expected nothing special and wound up being thoroughly exhilarated.

A mildly entertaining but well acted, sumptuously photographed and smartly written comedy with dark undertones about culinary addiction that can only be called "delicious."

One of the best movies of the year.

Slow as Christmas, but the two protagonists grow on you, like a Virginia creeper vine climbing a garden wall.

Be forewarned: It is dreadful.
Basically another tough genre workout that is all too familiar, with enough tension and violence to keep an audience alert if not riveted.
The sheer courage of Ms. Aniston grows on you, like a lichen. So does the movie.

A not-so-thrilling heist thriller that drones along mechanically between explosions and car crashes with Ewan McGregor, who is making entirely too many movies these days, none of them worth writing home about.
Maybe in future installments there will even be something that resembles a plot. For now, the entire movie is about as sexy as a root canal.
Expensive, derivative and boring as mattress ticking masquerading as designer fabric ...
A fresh, unexpected and welcome take on vampires-from New Zealand, of all places.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A deeply personal memoir, so well written and carefully observed that it draws the viewer into the ambience of postwar England with a persuasive power that makes you feel you're part of the same experience.

A smorgasbord of pornography masquerading as violence, Everly is so repugnant and pointless there were times when I wanted to call for help.
Mr. Cronenberg's reputation for daring defeats him here.

Unfortunately, there aren't many thrills and the pace is so slow that I fell asleep from tedium waiting for something that resembled a goose bump.

I can see no real reason for a sequel to the delicious 2011 hit The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel. It was perfect the first time around. But the second jog around the track passes the time pleasantly enough.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Anthony Hopkins plays the king of the hops, and he is excellent. So is the rest of the movie, a sober, no-frills account about the highest ransom ever collected up to that time-$10 million and counting.

It is borderline unwatchable.
It ultimately proves questionable and unconvincing, but in this case, failure to launch is noble. It keeps you creeped out and fascinated.

Not a great film in the same vein as Badlands and Pretty Poison, but a very good one that is well worth seeing.

Another lethal boring and relentlessly inert load of self-indulgent twaddle cut from the same maddening bolt of existential cloth as the Texas-based writer-director's other pseudo box-office bombs ...
If your craving for monsters from Mars needs immediate attention, Life passes the time painlessly.
Beautiful and challenging, Bokeh has a pristine look and chilling feel of its own that contributes enormously to the mood and tone of the whole film.
Despite J.K. Simmons' gruff charm and inarguable charisma, the movie is so slight it vanishes without a trace faster than the dislocated Ginnie.
None of it makes one lick of sense and it quickly becomes clear that Mr. Perkins couldn't care less.
It doesn't burn through the conscience and haunt you forever like Schindler's List, but in spite of its laid-back reluctance to shock and horrify, it's never trivial or boring.
What is the target audience for this particular brand of cotton candy? Teenage girls dreaming of first love while sipping cherry pop?
I'd like to tell you how rabid, illogical, far-fetched and stupid Colossal is, but words fail me at last.
I was enchanted and overwhelmed by it and my prediction is that, if you care about filmmaking, you will be, too.
A formulaic and manipulative tearjerker that is really nothing more than a woman's picture from a man's point of view.

A throwback to the good old days when adventure movies had riveting performances, gorgeous camerawork and the ability to tell stories that made sense, The Lost City of Z holds attention and keeps you fascinated.
Mr. Gere saves the day, investing Norman with sad, quirky mannerisms and a variety of desperate character revelations that make him tragic and lovable at the same time.
movie_title: Norman (Norman: The Moderate Rise and Tragic Fall of a New York Fixer) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Do something memorable, and do it fast. Obit implies that the obituary page, like everything else, is fast becoming a dying art.
An Edgar Allen Poe ripoff that reminds all and sundry of too many old Technicolor crypt soirees from Hammer Films in the 1960s, but without the campy elements.
It's a routine story, worth seeing for the galvanizing (pulverizing?) star performance by a smashing Liev Schreiber in the title role.
3 Generations is contrived, but the heartfelt performances keep the threadbare material on track-witty, warm and wise.
The most depressing Mother's Day present since Mommie Dearest, only not half as funny.
Sometimes beauty and charm are enough to turn a middling movie into pure ambrosia. Diane Lane has plenty of both ...
An exhilarating movie propelled by two mesmerizing star performances-Emma Stone and Steve Carell.
A charming, beautifully photographed modern fairy tale about love and gardening, This Beautiful Fantastic is worth seeing in spite of its dumb deterrent of a title.

Judi Dench can do no wrong, and playing Queen Victoria for the second time in the richly satisfying Victoria and Abdul is an acting lesson par excellence that proves how rapturous it is to watch this great artist do everything right.
An unflinching centerpiece performance by the character actor Robert Patrick as the embittered Tison is so toxic you can't take your eyes off him, even when the watching gets tough.
Malkovich has built a career mumbling his way through one disastrous movie after another, but this time he's got company.
This remarkable movie-factual and funny, always surprising and unconventionally written, directed and acted-sets the record straight with an adrenalin rush that overwhelms the senses.
The more I try to find some kind of justifiable meaning and relevance, the more I find The Shape of Water a loopy, lunkheaded load of drivel.
To make room for all the boring songs, historic facts are all but eliminated, leaving only the bare bones of Barnum's life.
Hostiles breathes fresh oxygen into a genre as old as a Confederate cough.
[A] valid, fact-filled and invigorating movie ...
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Anderson's movies are never coherent enough to appeal to the mainstream, but this one is so ravishing and meticulous and exquisite that you have no difficulty ignoring its inherent lack of logic.
It is never boring, and its plea for inclusion, acceptance and tolerance over bullying in the confusing fabric of a changing society is laudable.
There are occasional flashes of sweetness and charm, but the parts don't add up to anything substantial.
I've often written that even on a bad day, Woody Allen is better than everybody else on Sunday. This is true again of Wonder Wheel.
Touches the viewer with the subtle emotional wallop of a feather brushing against the heart.
The film's great triumph is Daniela Vega, a transgender actress and singer, who makes an indelible impression in the leading role.
Despite good intentions, the movie never lives up to the breathless excitement the real-life story promises.
This lumbering trilogy of trash based on the books by E. L. James has so run out of blood and oxygen that it has varicose veins.
Basmati Blues is the kind of easily forgiven early career move that is best released on home video and forgotten.
The Female Brain is without evidence of critical thinking from anyone involved.
Annihilation is a demented science-fiction comic book of a movie that makes less sense than a butterfly mating with a buffalo.
A well-meaning, expertly acted film, it unfortunately drowns in its own sorrow, making its commercial prospects dim.

There isn't much chemistry between the leads, and their sex scenes don't sizzle, but the fault lies with the dopey, confusing script by Justin Haythe that fails to develop their characters with any depth or purpose.
Debut director David Freyne has obviously seen entirely too many George Romero movies for his own good.

With an agonizing rupture of craft and common sense, it showcases a performance of screaming, over-the-top hysteria by Nicolas Cage that must be seen to be fully believed, but that is not a recommendation.

The direction by Luca Guadagnino is reminiscent of Bertolucci's sensitivity at its best, the fabulous cinematography by Sayombhu Mukdeeprom rapturously captures the rich work of art that is Italy in summer, and the actors are to die for.
Rees has a firm hand and a clear vision that gives Mudbound a balanced coherence that keeps you involved.
It is always Gary Oldman's phenomenal performance that keeps the film airborne.
Wyle is so good as he goes through the stages of pain, rage, remorse and resignation that he keeps you caring and alert.
Without realizing it, American Made is a wincing metaphor for Tom Cruise's movie career-which, come to think of it, is exclusively and embarrassingly American made, too.
Nothing big happens, but director John Carroll Lynch zeroes in on the undeniable pathos and hidden feelings in Mr. Stanton's map-lined face.
A trite little comedy so jumbled, disconnected and bad you can't believe it doesn't star James Franco.
Labored and boring, The Mountain Between Us is a soap opera in the snow that fritters away the time and talents of Kate Winslet and Idris Elba for all the wrong reasons.
The impression is a disturbing film of energy and compassion that left me with an inescapable sadness, from which director Baker offers no way out.
You won't walk out of Walking Out.
Given the limitations of his role, I can't praise Andrew Garfield enough.
It's quite a story and a cinematic task writer-director Angela Robinson is not always up to. But I wasn't bored, and in this anemic year that's saying a mouthful.
It's so sincere and admirable that it seems churlish to voice objections, but the fact remains that it isn't very good.
movie_title: Same Kind of Different As Me (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Not a single scene works as anything more than a total waste of good film.
It's A Raisin in the Sun Meets The Donna Reed Show.
You can call Novitiate divinely inspired and mean it.
The sober, nuanced, and deeply affecting Thank You For Your Service covers old ground with a fresh take and finds something new to say about it at the same time.
It hit me unexpectedly-like a snowball between the eyes.
Woody Harrelson in the title role has enough spice to keep the viewer alert and attentive.
The movie is about choices, alternatives, and how one woman regains control and balance through patience, trust and courage.
The best thing about Last Flag Flying is that Ethan Hawke is not in it. Otherwise, it's business as usual, and the business is excruciating to get through.
While Branagh's revised version retains the basic elements, the mistakes he makes are numerous.
I didn't like Three Billboards, but I respect McDonagh for taking his lewd, vulgar screwballs in directions without a compass and leaving viewers wondering where in the world the film will go next.
It's a typical example of the kind of empty, lunk-headed movies that are made these days by directors who think it's interesting to watch two people walking down the street carrying boxes.
I'm a sucker for these survival stories that show the best side of man's humanity, and Gyllenhaal makes this one a stronger achievement than most.
Totally unconvincing, contrived, and phony as one of those reducing creams that promise to eliminate varicose veins but only give you hives.
Another expensive throwaway aimed at milking money out of people who still read comic books. Color it stupid.
Boring, derivative, and infuriatingly illogical, Lavender is a ghost story with no thrills, no surprises, and no sense.
A tsunami of questions blows across the muddled action in a screenplay that provides no answers, and the eventual mess that unravels defies credibility to the closing credits.
The Nice Guys is another sub-mental movie for morons churned out by the kind of sophomoric Hollywood machine that trademarks the works of Judd Apatow & Co.
There are elements of The Hand That Rocks the Cradle here, but Mr. Farr and an excellent cast of four give it fluidity and balance without the familiar "gotcha."
Me Before You is not without punishment, but it's so well made that it survives every drawback.
I was spellbound.
Recycles the plots of a long list of movies as diverse as Body Heat and the Jennifer Lopez flop The Boy Next Door, with just a pinch of The Postman Always Rings Twice.
It aims to be laugh-out-loud hilarious but never rises above a few wan chuckles.
movie_title: Therapy for a Vampire (Der Vampir auf der Couch) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Worth seeing as another entry in the rise of Léa Seydoux, a star of Gallic charisma if ever I've seen one.
movie_title: Diary of a Chambermaid (Journal d'une femme de chambre) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: I'd like to tell you how dumbfoundingly awful The Neon Demon is, but I know when to give up.
The script is contrived and tedious, but Ms. Cruz (who also produced the film) is so persuasive that she makes even the most sentimental moments credible.
I guess Solondz wants to show the pain and detritus of human experience but with satirical pokes at American life in particular. The results are more unnerving than humorous.
The premise is not without purpose, but clichés abound, the film lacks narrative thrust and the camerawork looks like one of those slick British Cadbury commercials for after-dinner mints.
You have to admire the sheer physical scope of this epic, even if there are no animals in it.
The word for Fathers and Daughters is anguish-for everyone on the screen and in the audience, too.
Despite a frustrating fizzle of a finale, it's a movie that enthralls the senses and engages the mind for two hours, proving no movie is too long when you're having fun.
Romantic, bittersweet and funny as hell, Café Society turns Hollywood inside out, rooting through the superficial tinsel to find the real tinsel. You go away gobsmacked, beaming and happy to be both.

A vile, nauseating and incomprehensible pile of saddles-and-spurs gibberish sane audiences will undoubtedly avoid at all costs.

Quitters has more style than substance, but it's a cut above most, mainly because first-time director and co-writer Noah Pritzker has a lot of sensitivity toward a familiar subject that renders it real and touching if not exactly original.
The fun wears out fast and so does the "gotcha" factor.
Situations are not always convincing, and motivations are so weak that whole sections of explanation seem to be missing.
This dog is dead on arrival, and except for one weird comic performance by the star, there's no hope for reviving a pulse.

A trash wallow in sex, nudity, violence, cruelty to animals and the skewering of contemporary society ...
It's as exhilarating as any epic American thriller, and better than most. Racing pulses and a state of awe and terror are guaranteed.
With the corpse of a nightmare called Knight of Cups, I have finally given up on Terrence Malick. This dog of a film is as riveting and fascinating as a walk-in bathtub.

Slow as an inchworm and about as thrilling as buttermilk.
The Confirmation is a nice change of pace from most of the hateful violence we're getting these days-inescapably inconsequential but ultimately endearing.

I had a hard time buying so much concentrated bile, and for me, the film loses an objectivity that might have otherwise scored points for the destructive nature of competition that can wreck a decent man's corrupted psyche.
The mumbling ineptitude of Ethan Hawke that makes it impossible to make out half of what he's saying in any given scene.
This is a movie that is easy on the ears and even easier to like.
I admire Richard Linklater, but anyone who fixates on memories like these suffers from a case of arrested development. It all looks like old reruns of dated TV sitcoms, like Welcome Back, Kotter.
Throats are slashed, guts are spilled, blood spurts. Don't say I didn't warn you.

Standing Tall shows the misery and pain of youngsters in rebellion against the social construct that made them that way, as well as the frustration of the public servants who work overtime to give them hope.

If Miles Davis the horn player is an idol, you can see this movie and still be a fan of his masterpiece recordings. But if you want to know what he was like as Miles Davis the man, you won't learn a thing from Miles Ahead.
Mr. Elliott's story is not helped by James Franco, who plays him with his usual smug catatonia.
About as thrilling as a fried grasshopper canapé.
Sing Street has the potential to achieve unmistakable popularity with not only teens but also audiences of all ages.
Charming, insightful and funny.
It looks expensive and comes off bland.
Its craft is evident, its sincerity is admirable, and it's the kind of movie about which you can say, "There's not a hair out of place," and mean it.
There's nothing predictable about any of the angles, and Mr. Abaire's script reveals a surprise around every corner.
The result is a film so personal you watch transfixed, caught up in a life that is constantly enthralling, with a universal appeal that extends beyond the exclusive Hills of Beverly.
The big problem is twofold: there are too many characters to keep up with, played by too many women who look too much alike.
The Childhood of a Leader is a dark and creepy work, flawed but ambitious and well worth seeing.
It doesn't eventually add up to much, but the acting is deeply sincere, and I was touched in unexpected places.
The effect is a series of vignettes that fail to hold attention even though the movie clocks in at a merciful 83 minutes.
A mesmerizing, engrossing and beautifully made cinematic experience, rare as a pink unicorn, that enchants for more than two hours and makes you wish for at least one hour more.
An exemplary film of such exceptional wisdom, beauty, clarity, sensitivity and emotional depth that I had to rub my eyes to believe it.
If you love classic movies and their potential to sweep you up into a world outside of your own experience, this one will rock your world.
See it and I promise your own heart will skip a beat with happiness and joy.

A carefully compiled dossier on the life of an ordinary woman in extraordinary times whose dignity and grace under pressure humbled the world at the time and influenced future generations without planning to.
As an exercise in voyeurism, this is a movie that sleeps on its feet. Shannon is too good for this nonsense, and Poots has got to do something about that disastrous name.
The movie comes off as a well-intended tribute to the fabulous MGM musicals of the great Vincente Minnelli, made by people who have never seen one.

Fences is a labor of love and attention must be paid. You don't get writing or acting of this caliber every day, and in this particularly dreary year of second-rate everything, this movie is something special.

The navy-blue cinematography of Boston is well lit, the Florida atmosphere looks like a commercial for Dade County orange juice, the actors all look like they are awaiting directions from Affleck by cell phone.

Patriots Day is the third Berg-Wahlberg collaboration and although it doesn't measure up to the chills and excitement of their first film, Lone Survivor, it does raise goose bumps with its accuracy, realism, and attention to detail.
The actors are fine, but the material doesn't give their talents much room to stretch.
The splendid actors ... make up for the weaknesses with performances that radiate strength and integrity.
The movie, lamely directed by first-timer Adam Smith, drifts from campground to fistfight, without much purpose or impact. The accents, thick as cold porridge, just drift.

This is a filmmaker with almost no real talent for coherence, originality or purpose and in spite of his insistence on audience secrecy, his overly contrived plots are easy to figure out before the beginning of the second reel.
One of the must-see entertainments of the year.

The Daughter offers a good but sadly wasted cast, obscured in the eye-rubbing mist of a foggy Down Under countryside and struggling to rise above the sludge of a basic soap opera with literary pretensions.
Warm, heartfelt but decidedly wan.
The terrific cast is well worth watching, but everything else about this wayward movie mistake leaves you feeling just awful.
Has even the target audience for this junk finally had enough?
Asante resorts to a few corny clichés (spinning newspaper headlines to denote time, place and issues of the day), but she has a charming way with the actors and her leads are truly irresistible.
It's a harrowing, sensitively realized study of cruelty, revenge and post-war retribution that ranks high among films about the cost of war and its continuing damage to humanity.
As a film, it's uneven and clumsy, but as a responsible political statement about the chaos we live in now, it's both enlightening and troubling.
Ford never finds the proper way to blend the complex narratives into a coherent and cohesive structure.
In spite of the harrowing details, the film builds compassion for even the most disturbing characters and scenes.
There isn't one genuine thrill in the whole thing. I've had bigger scares from my goldfish bowl.
It's too twisted and implausible to be everybody's cup of tea, but it keeps you glued to the screen from beginning to end.
A tender showcase for a different kind of Jerry Lewis that utilizes the strengths and frailties of a 90-year-old show business survivor as few films have ever done.
Slick and wonderful to look at but too slight to hold its own weight and too inconsequential to generate much suspense.
A beautiful, poignant and illuminating French film that manages to make a familiar history lesson seem freshly observed.

Hanks does an admirable job of showing Sully's humiliating stress while his reputation was being challenged, with the first-rate support of a cast that includes Laura Linney as his wife, and Jamey Sheridan and Anna Gunn as his surly inquisitors.
Whatever were they smoking?
The story is true, and the message it delivers-with care and help, the disenfranchised can become role models and inspire others-is unabashedly sentimental, but in a good way.
Noisy and tense-though familiar and unimaginative ...

Another illuminating performance by Rachel Weisz and a brilliant screenplay by the distinguished British playwright David Hare make Denial one of the most powerful and riveting courtroom dramas ever made.
The Great Gilly Hopkins passes the time in its own way-slowly, painlessly and forgettably.
A conventional Hollywood biopic, punctuated by a fury that sprays raspberry juice all over the camera with enough graphic slash and flash to turn your stomach.
It's a nail-biter that exposes the hazards of immigration from the side of the victims, and the victims are not you and me.

The only reason to see Certain Women is the cast. These are interesting actresses who go out of their way to avoid mainstream movies, but whatever attracted them to this dismal yawn is anybody's guess.
I don't think it can fail to evoke a smile or a sigh from anyone with a heart.
American Pastoral tries to be loyal in its adaptation, but the material is film-resistant and flat as cardboard.
King Cobra is a cut above most homoerotic masturbatory screen fantasies, but not by much.

A total disaster that's been hanging around the editing room gathering dust for more than a year, you can't call it deadly because that would imply it's still alive. This one is already dead on arrival.

A fascinating exploration of how a great mind worked by allowing the quality of his scripts to determine the style of each film-including not only the inner life but the camera, the clothes, the entire visual approach.
It's so well made that Bleed for This won me over despite my aversion to timeworn sports pictures that tell basically the same story.
It is violent, harrowing, heartbreaking and unforgettable. And yes, it was directed by Mel Gibson. He deserves a medal, too.
None of it makes any sense, but logic is the last thing any of the minds attracted to this kind of junk want or expect.
As a dramatic postscript to the factors that led to Japanese surrender, its power and importance are undeniable.
Arrival is a weird flick, slow and tedious, too metaphysical for Rod Serling's The Twilight Zone and most likely to appeal to people who like to play video games and solve puzzles.
Writer-director Stephen Knight gets more suspense out of the restricted nature of Locke's predicament than you would ever think possible.

Like most of today's young directors who neither want to nor know how to tell an actual story in a traditional way with a beginning, middle and end, writer-director Jay Martin jumps around like a spastic colon.
What fresh hell is this?

The great screenwriter Steven Zaillian's elaborate, convoluted script, so muddled that even after it's over you still don't know what it's all about, is a drawback -- but the movie is a master class in sinister style, tense and deeply uncomfortable.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: War Horse is a don't-miss Spielberg classic that reaches true perfection.
There's nothing even Ms. Streep's craft and resourcefulness can do to make this cold, humorless woman of iron likeable, and the whole thing is too dry to sustain so much screen time.

Maybe if it had manipulated me less, it would have moved me more.
Not a great movie, but satisfying enough to hold attention and win your affection -- a rare blue-plate combo on today's overcrowded menu of movie chaos that sticks to your ribs and stays there.
You anticipate every scene before it happens and figure out every secret before it's revealed.
If the objective is to make the audience ill, The Divide succeeds.
Don't expect high art, and you will leave Joyful Noise smiling to the beat.

Scathing and funny and cynical about contemporary society and the hypocritical way we live now, Carnage may not be the dream movie I expected, but it has a dream cast of pure, unimpeachable ensemble perfection.
The whole point of this time-wasting farrago of idiocy is that women can cut, kick, slash, burn, maim and kill just like men -- and make bad movies that are just as stupid.
Prepare to be devastated.
I admit I admire the writing and acting of the two brave stars, who declare war on film in which there is only one enemy to fight -- their child's deadly disease.
The point is to show the misery of a underprivileged woman ahead of her time, but so much dedication for such a small payoff makes you wonder why.

I ask myself, how can any movie that calls itself a horror film also be boring at the same time? You will find the answer in The Innkeepers.
If you crave action, dialogue, explanations, character revelations and clear plot resolutions, Perfect Sense never lives up to its title.
Let's hope Dolly finds her way back to center stage and never goes away again.
It takes quite a time before the pieces of a poisonous puzzle appear, and when they do, they don't always fall into place with clarity.
Private Romeo will undoubtedly be regarded by some as a curio, but it's a sweet, sympathetic and surprising one, highly recommended to the adventurous spirit in an enlightened and changing world.
I can't get it out of my thoughts, and I recommend it highly.

Ms. Theron, a true beauty and one of the screen's most exquisite actors, keeps the film airborne even when it seems dangerously earthbound. She's a one-woman emergency rescue squad.
It's the study of a man whose soul has been peeled away, like coring an apple. But I wouldn't call it sexy -- or entertaining. What does Brandon learn? What do we learn?
Something odd is happening to Mr. Cage's face. His skin is yellow, his cheeks are swollen, and his head is too big for his body.
Surreal but disappointingly drab, it's still not the best Almodovar in years.
Ms. Olsen, a revelation throughout, feeds every scene with poignancy. It's an alarming but gratifying achievement.
If larger truths have been overlooked, the subject is still wrenching enough to make Oranges and Sunshine an inspired work of dignity and purpose.
As a movie, it's so tightly framed you gasp from claustrophobia. As a film of cryptic boredom, I cannot believe the actors were able to say their lines without cue cards.
Unlike most alleged Hollywood rom-coms, Like Crazy is delicate, uplifting and definitely worth investigating.
Rarely has Mr. Gere walked through any movie with so little energy and so much indifference.
[It] was made three years ago, shelved in some musty editing room where unreleasable movies go, and looks it. The dust still shows.
Historians are already calling Anonymous preposterous humbug, but I found it a complex cornucopia of ideas and panache. You go away sated.

For a film about one person that reveals so little about the subject, 94 minutes is longer than it sounds.

What, exactly, is the point? Only the director of a pile of crap that includes Dogma, Dancer in the Dark and Antichrist knows for sure, and even that is severely doubtful.

It's worth seeing for the sharp but uneven human observations in the script and direction by Alexander Payne (Sideways), and sometimes it's fun (but mostly exasperating) watching George Clooney trying to act as he struggles through...
It's good to see so much talent and feeling in one movie, and Another Happy Day has plenty of it.

Something moved me deeply watching Ms. Williams as the tragic Marilyn, illuminating the girlish joy, erotic glamour and self-destructive suffering of a public icon who was privately a bottomless pit of need.
The Artist is so wonderful that the audience applauds everything, including the dog.

As Freud, who believes the basis of all insanity is sexual repression, and Jung, who is monogamous and resistant to such extremist views, the miscast male stars are bland as dust and look like a box of Smith Brothers cough drops.

It's not much fun watching an Australian director whose small goal in life is to ape French provocateur Catherine Breillat. There's not much thrill in watching Ms. Browning, who is so anesthetized she seems to be dreaming whether she's asleep or awake.
A morbid, misguided mess with a fractured narrative, guaranteed to drive audiences away in droves.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: An unnerving warts-and-all portrait of a man staggering around in circles of arrogant self-deception.
A bargain-budget bore by writer-director Liza Johnson about a female soldier back from a tour of active duty in Iraq who cannot adjust to life at home.
This is a naive director with so little insight you wonder what comic books he's been reading.
Take a chance and you will be rewarded with a work of nightmarish force that is unforgettable.
Not even Ms. Witherspoon can save it. It is, however, high time she started thinking about saving herself -- and what's left of her film career.
In the final scene I found myself laughing and crying at the same time.
The movie careers downhill with the speed of an unhinged kangaroo with one foot.
A corny, overwritten movie made by a director with nothing to say.
Most of it seems baffled and unclear. Some nice ideas floating around in here, but A Bag of Hammers is one of the few movies I can remember that appears to be composed mainly of outtakes.
A clever, quick-witted, informed and terrific movie!
Battleship is dopey, preposterous and unintentionally hilarious in all the wrong places, but as directed by Peter Berg, it is also energetic, fast-moving and bracing.
Like all Wes Anderson movies, it is naïve, mannered, pretentious and incomprehensible.
It has warmth, humor and an understated sweetness that is not to be taken for granted.
It's about as entertaining as an iron lung.
The jabber is maddening, but with all due respect, the actors are wonderful, the performances as natural as inhaling. Still, in Emily Blunt's case, there is such a thing as too natural.

Pop songs, beautiful bucolic scenery and the joy of watching Jane Fonda fizz in a fun role that looks like a no-brainer are elements that a skilled director like Australia's polished Bruce Beresford blends with perfection.

After so many hellish apocalypse movies, Seeking a Friend for the End of the World is intelligent, dignified and emotionally satisfying.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It's time to pack up the Vuitton and come home, Woody. Your inspiration is thin, you're running out of euros, and you're having a bad day.
It's a fascinating film that I enjoyed thoroughly.
Don't miss this one. A brave and inspired antidote to time-wasting mainstream movies, it is unlike anything you've seen before or will likely ever see again. In short, it is unforgettable.
Will it make you wince with embarrassment? That's a promise. Will you also laugh? In double-time, like a Rockette.
People Like Us is informed by real feelings uncorked like a lost bottle of Cabernet Sauvignon hidden away in a dark corner of a private wine cellar.
The actors are so good ... that they make you want to see what they could do in a better movie than this tedious acting-class experiment.

Black Butterflies is a dark, moving depiction of the life and death of a brave rebellious, idiosyncratic woman who made significant strides toward changing the world around her and paid a heavy toll for her passion.
