It's a spirited, eloquent film-delightfully offbeat, deliciously different and well worth investigating.
Even though Friends With Kids is not a movie everyone will identify with, it fills 107 minutes with enough visual popcorn to keep you satisfied.
Adrien Brody, one of the weirdest looking actors of the millennium, plays Henry Barthes, a man so emotionally blocked by a lifetime of disillusion that he cannot connect with any other human being.
Seeking Justice is an intense thriller so full of shocks it keeps you wired from start to finish.
This futuristic tale of teenage violence is so not my kind of movie that I approached it grudgingly, so imagine my surprise when I ended up being totally exhilarated and enjoying it immensely.

The Deep Blue Sea is uneven and somewhat tentative in its evocation of a certain kind of fading moss rose among English womanhood, but it's mature, sophisticated filmmaking that is so welcome I recommend it highly.

It is amazing how much hair-raising action and fluid movement this film captures in the confined interior of a car trunk, or how many mood shifts Mr. Dorff conveys in a performance that can only be called multi-dimensional.
Intruders is never scary, and it's so implausible and uninvolving that even when it's being explained, it is still unconvincing. Talky psychology is a poor substitute for supernatural thrills.

Lee Hirsch is certainly one who is making a difference. I endorse him and his brave, powerful movie and urge you to see it for yourself. You might leave Bully with rage, but you will not leave Bully with indifference.
Quote not available.
An entire row of what they call "fanboys" at the screening I attended laughed all the way through the movie, although I failed to see anything remotely amusing.
It all sounds dreadful, like the pilot for another brainless comedy series on network TV, but it grows on you.
Monsieur Lazhar builds hope in the face of tragedy and sheds new light on the question of what is truth and how we find it.
When all is said and done, the dog is the only thing you care about in Darling Companion.
For the most part, Morning Glory is a delicious movie that will make you jump for joy.
These are neither good people nor interesting savages, and they're not worth caring about. Neither is the movie.

Like the nonfossil fuel alternatives Mr. Clooney pushes in his campaign rhetoric, the adrenalin rush of The Ides of March provides a sexy alternative to most mainstream political movies about dirty politics. Others dip. This one soars.
Dirty Girl is a bad movie with no insights that is broadly drawn and genuinely plagued by filthy dialogue. You don't laugh. You just wince, and wonder how the whole thing ever got financed.
My mind kept wandering.
It isn't clever enough to be even momentarily diverting, and it's about as sexy as oatmeal.
You gotta hand it to Charlotte Brontë. One hundred and sixty-four years since she gave hyperkinetic Victorian schoolgirls their first sleepless nights, she's pulling them in all over again.
Smith keeps the fog, mist and rain machines working overtime, but to such little purpose that Black Death often looks like outtakes from Fiddler on the Roof.
Carefully written, sensitively directed and beautifully acted...
Directed with a pulsating fervor by Neil Burger, Limitless is absurd but entertaining action-adventure escapism.

There is so little dialogue of any significance that I can't figure out why the film is credited with three screenwriters, but Ms. Scott knows what to do with the camera to show dark psychological forces at work...
Catherine Hardwicke is Anne Rice with a camera.
Waris Dirie is an inspiration, inside and out, and so is this movie.

Mr. Nolfi, who is also making his debut as a director, is another unfortunate Christopher Nolan wannabe, so the movie is a preposterous muddle that borrows heavily from Inception, without a single original idea.
Delightfully relevant, [Deneuve] gets her best role in years, and she plays it to the hilt.
The result is unbearable junk. What went wrong? Just about everything.
Harmless coming-of-age stuff, but you've seen it all a million times.
Who goes to the movies for 104 minutes of punishment? Where is John Wayne, now that we need him?
Close but no cigar.
See it, enjoy a ripping good yarn and learn something.
A gripping, life-enhancing low-budget little film about the physically and emotionally punishing struggles of a single mother raising an autistic child.
An extraordinarily sad, touching and compassionate documentary...
Applause is deserved, but if ticket sales are as passive as I predict, it means overlooking a very good movie indeed.

There isn't much dialogue, and most of the 98-minute running time is devoted to locking in one terrifyingly gothic encounter after another, but the characters are well defined, and director Mickle makes every dime of his micro-budget count.
I was immensely impressed with Mr. Thurston, an appealing actor with intelligence and self-assurance who is going places, and writer-director John Gray, who has already arrived with a bang.
Xavier Dolan is the new darling of Canadian cinema, and it's easy to see why.
Not only disgusting and unendurable, but filthy and boring, too.

Mr. Anderson has evidently watched a lot of old Twilight Zone reruns. So much of the film's dense, murky palette evokes menace without mayhem, but the wrap-up at the end by Rod Serling is sadly missed.
This one is strictly for Cher fans who like their campy shtick loud, lewd and ludicrous. But the biggest problem among many is that it's not her movie. She's hardly in it.
There's no drug strong enough to get me through another movie like Love and Other Drugs.
The King's Speech has left me speechless.
You go away slack-jawed with shock and sated with the chilling bedtime-story elements of a great unsolved mystery novel you can't put down.
An absurd Freudian nightmare that is more wet dream than bad dream, with all the subtlety of a chain saw.
Mr. Carrey has balls of brass, but seeing him dressed flamboyantly in fish-net bikinis and high-heel Nancy Sinatra boots is an experience I hope never to repeat again in this lifetime.
These are characters so repulsive that it's hard to care what happens to them, but it's to the credit of a superb cast that you do end up caring.
The Company Men does a piercing job of making you feel the dehumanizing effects that losing a job can have on grown men, but it's more truthful and devastating than that.
Eschewing clichés, Rabbit Hole is disturbing yet refreshing evidence that for some people, redemption takes longer, and for others, the pain never goes away at all.
If there's one thing I don't need in my Christmas stocking this year, it's a sorry, lumbering and unasked-for remake of the 1969 sagebrush saga True Grit.
The latest calcified bore by Sofia Coppola is less pretentious than Marie Antoinette but every bit as inertly stupefying as Lost in Translation.
Movie intimacy reaches groundbreaking new heights in this shocking story of a young marriage on the rocks.
A true masterpiece of visual enchantment.
Burning Palms is too sick to attract the masses, but he's onto something subversively valid, and the film is never boring.
Every Day is too relentlessly depressing to recommend to the everyday audience. It seems to be on automatic pilot. Horrible, sad things keep happening, but it just goes on.
Portman is herself partly to blame. Nobody with an upwardly mobile career who is suddenly being taken seriously should co-star in a movie with Ashton Kutcher.
No one will go away disappointed or indifferent. It's a movie that sticks with you like Elmer's glue.
This crude aping of every hack from Judd Apatow to the Farrelly brothers represents the worst of what is happening in film today...

A codpiece-and-crossbow saga of relentlessly exciting battle sequences sandwiched between tedious, unconvincing chatter about cantankerous centurions, fiery feudal warriors and camera-ready six-pack abs modeled by hunky pinups...
Unknown makes no sense at all, so you not only worry about Liam Neeson's judgment in movies, but you begin to wonder if he's forgotten how to read.

As long as the poker-faced "Triple H" is the centerpiece, The Chaperone is not without moments of genuine sweetness. Best of all, he is the most unpretentious and least flamboyant human juggernaut to ever hit the screen.
Sympathy for Delicious is populated by so many good people who ought to be better that it's hard to ignore. But sympathy, for Delicious or anyone else, eludes me totally.
Nothing turns out as you might expect, and the plot twists provide unexpected suspense.
Romantic comedy has taken a shellacking lately in a series of stupefying flops, but they didn't have Ginnifer Goodwin.
Quite the most appalling piece of junk I have seen lately, Hobo With a Shotgun just lies there like an autopsy.

It's a stupid farrago of aborted ideas, misguided actors, lame direction, submental writing and follow-the-dots plotting that never comes anywhere within a 10-mile radius of what I used to call coherent filmmaking.
The actors are sincere (especially Ms. Fischer, who plays frustration well) and the direction has a complacent rhythm, but 1 hour and 48 minutes is too long for a movie in which nothing much happens.
The young director, whose day job is editing commercials, has never made a narrative feature-length movie before and shows no aptitude for it here.
movie_title: The Myth Of The American Sleepover (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Painful, blood-curdling and ultimately heartbreaking, Sarah's Key occasionally moves too ponderously for its own good, but its myriad elements are coherent and easy to follow.

Cowboys & Aliens is one of the silliest movies ever made, but so many otherwise serious people have attached their names to it that, as Arthur Miller wrote in Death of a Salesman, attention must be paid.
None of this is much fun to watch. The pace drags. The acting is without contrast or color.
Good Neighbors is a hotbed of twisted ideas with a straightforward yet novel approach to the Gothic horror in the hearts of mistakenly everyday people.
It's a great double stretch for an actor and Mr. Cooper plays both the smoldering Latif and the bombastic Uday with combustible energy.
The Whistleblower is a grisly, authentic, meticulously researched, pulse-quickening political chiller about a hot-button topic that will keep you on the edge of your seat from start to finish.
The Change-Up drags on endlessly, held together with scatology, flatulence and masturbation.
The writing is predictable and off the scale in terms of trajectory. The basic plot structure never follows one idea through to resolution.
Skillfully made and adrenalin-fueled, Warrior is nothing like what I expected. It overcomes inescapable boxing and martial arts clichés and leaves you thoroughly sated, energized and wanting more.
The two-handed duet at the center of Love Crime radiates, but the parade of easily parodied men who stomp in and out of their corporate offices just seem like script rejects from Mad Men.
Telling a complex story in a coherent narrative arc has never been one of Mr. Soderbergh's strengths, and chronicling the day-by-day panic of a killer virus jumps all over the place.
This is a subtle, elegant and altogether triumphant film about a subject I thought I was tired of, told with an artistry and freshness that is positively thrilling.
Winter is friendly, loving, emotional, playful, brave and intelligent. Before her Dolphin Tale is over, I dare even the most jaded cynic not to shed a tear of admiration and joy.
Like any good cautionary tale, Puncture tells a suspenseful story responsibly, creating food for thought and leaving the audience both enlightened and entertained.
I found it poignant, amusing and endearing. No need for marmalade. Just butter, and enjoy.
From start to end credits, very much an example of good work that doesn't translate.
There may be worse things in life than sitting through a 90-minute movie about Sarah Palin. At the moment, I just can't think of any.
My reaction to everything that happens in 50/50 was "Why don't they just walk out?" But nobody did, so I did it for them.
What fun to feel like a kid again. I had a marvelous time.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This is real movie making that packs a solid entertainment punch, proving it doesn't matter what the genre is if genuinely talented and dedicated people are pulling the strings instead of hacks.
The characters in The Ledge exist for the sole purpose of argument, and the script is too narrow to engage the viewer unconditionally.
Even if you wander into this congealed mess with nothing more demanding in mind than to spend a little time with two charming favorites, do not expect Forrest Gump or Pretty Woman.

Whatever you think of Mr. Gibson, whatever he has lost, he still has talent, and here displays acting of power and resonance. It's a pleasure, for a change, to see the best side of his split personality at work.
It's a quiet, contemplative film that reminded me of Mike Nichols' Closer, with too many shots of lighting cigarettes and looking pensive in train windows, but I liked it.

Mr. Ferrell holds back the comic condiments long enough to paint the portrait of a man lost in low self-esteem with nice pastels of realistic restraint. But the crossroads he faces are paved with potholes...
You go away wondering out loud (with merit) how and where they find the money to make any movie as brain-damaged, inept, unsupervised and moronic as The Big Bang.
Only the great Piper Laurie delivers dollar value. Otherwise, Hesher is to movies what graffiti is to a rotting fence.
Instead of preaching, why don't the nutrition Nazis figure out a way to make plant-based foods taste better? You are never going to force an entire population to live on spinach.
Not perfect, but vastly superior to most of the Hollywood dreck we've been getting lately, Lebanon, Pa. is a thoughtful and perceptive film well worth recommending.
Hey, Boo solves the mystery of Boo, and also, to some degree, the mystery of Harper Lee. It's a fine film, well worth seeing.
movie_title: Hey, Boo: Harper Lee and 'To Kill a Mockingbird' (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Its impact is special and inescapable.
[Malick is] a meticulous visionary who knows where to place a camera, but he hasn't a clue about how to tell a story with simplicity and coherence.
Beautiful Boy is a haunting, deeply disturbing but beautifully made film with depth and range about a dark subject...
Even the clichés in this warm mood piece seem unpredictable and without contrivance.
Jumpy and desperate to eschew restless boredom, the whole thing looks like a series of rock videos.
Sorry to dash your hopes, but it's just more of the same junk. Junk for children, with an estimated $45-million budget. There oughta be a law.
Like the folks who dreamed up lycanthropy, the Trollhunter writers either have an abundance of imagination or they've been smoking a controlled substance.
Bride Flight is the most lavishly entertaining Dutch film since Paul Verhoeven's fabulous The Black Book.

Even in the brainless world of cinematic comic books gone bad, it's as bad as it gets -- a dumb, pointless, ugly, moronic and incomprehensible jumble of botched effects, technical blunders, and cluttered chaos.
Unlike most recent coming-of-age movies, this one gets by on more than capricious eccentricity and sentimentality. It has something called heart.
The Best and the Brightest should be called The Worst and the Dumbest.
The power in this movie is the way Chris Weitz trusts us to discover the facts for ourselves.
This is bargain-basement moviemaking, and looks it. Here's wishing Mr. Pierce a vigorous movie career, and better luck next time.

It's one of those revolting, raunch-fueled movies churned out in their sleep by the Farrelly brothers and Judd Apatow that I usually hate, but with real cleverness, off-center wit and edgy imagination.

Speaking lines they cannot possibly understand, not one actor makes any attempt to be believable. So manufactured and synthetic that they eventually lose all sense of reality, they're like reconstituted orange juice and processed cheese.
In a film so ripe with temptations for posturing, exaggeration and satirical overacting, nobody is anything less than natural, unpretentious and funny as hell.
The movie is sweet, but it's a lollipop of whimsy. Lick it and it's gone.
Although Enough Said never really surmounts its TV sitcom style and structure, the director provides a nuanced entertainment that is enjoyable.
What passes for a plot has been done a thousand times before-in much better films than A Single Shot.
Prepare to be electrified! When it comes to thrillers, Prisoners is the must-see sensation of the year.
It means well, but finally, it's a lighthearted film that is ultimately weakened by too much star wattage. Thanks For Sharing would have been better as a documentary.
[Gordon-Levitt] can act, and there's a possibility he can also direct, but there's no evidence in Don Jon that he can do both at the same time.
Mr. Orser is a director worth watching. His work behind the camera-as well as in front of it-is clean and direct, unsentimental almost to the point of austerity.
Accept Gravity as pure, popcorn-munching show business fun and nothing else, and you won't go away disappointed. Leave logic at the concession stand.
Does anybody connected with this cinematic Valium know what they're supposed to be doing? The alleged "comedy" is too lame to make you laugh, and the poignancy is nonexistent.
It's one of the most powerful films about the Arab-Israeli conflict that has ever been attempted on the screen.

Mr. Slater, the only real name on view, looks embarrassed to be slumming in something so cheesy. But I liked the simplicity of the narrative structure and the lack of extraneous background information you get among most movie flight crews.
An absorbing new footnote to a history lesson that will never fade.
Under the trigger-ready direction of Paul Greengrass, everything pays off handsomely in a series of well-timed encounters that keep you on the edge of your seat.
If the best films hold you in a captive vise, entertain you, keep you spellbound and teach you something at the same time, then 12 Years a Slave is outstanding-brave, courageous and unforgettable.

From the incense-soaked bohemian off-campus parties to the source music by Jo Stafford and the Andrews Sisters, the period atmosphere evokes style. But something is missing here, like a clear perspective.
Timely but sluggish and confusing, The Fifth Estate will be a hard sell. Corruption in cyberspace should be a helluva lot more entertaining than this.
Goodness knows what this movie would be like without the brute force of Mr. Redford's intelligence, focus and self-confidence.
A dull, confusing movie for which nobody bothered to provide a script.
Aims for satire and settles for stale shtick.
The movie goes nowhere, and Ms. Cody's screenplay is relentlessly talky while standing still.
You don't want a sequel to this one.
Imbued with a sense of constant calamity that is never a surprise, the movie becomes the same slaughterhouse of clichés it pretends to poke fun at.
movie_title: All the Boys Love Mandy Lane (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Nobody in this movie is really appealing enough to be much fun. The state of New Jersey should sue.
I do not consider Jasmine a typical Woody Allen comedy. It's better than anything you might imagine.

Still Mine is Mr. Cromwell's film from first scene to closing credits...he is always present, alive and real, with a wealth of understated feelings. This is the greatest performance of his rich career.
Under Craig Zisk's frisky direction, the entire cast is superb and wrinkle-free. The screenplay, by husband-wife team Dan and Stacy Chariton, is thin as a poker chip but as clever as it is contrived.
The East suffers from the same weakness as the cult members Sarah works so hard to understand: a questionable definition of morality that overpowers an ultimate sense of reason.

The movie eventually wafts into a detective story, which would be doubly effective if only we could hack our way through the thickly coated Irish brogues that render so much of the dialogue incomprehensible.
The acting is uniformly dreadful. The level of incompetence in both writing and direction is a scream.
Artsy-fartsy gibberish executed with a staggering incoherence that smacks of desperation.
A slick, suspenseful adrenalin rush disguised as unexpected, nerve-wracking fun.

Despite an obscene budget that could have made a giant stride in the cure for cancer, there isn't much originality, and the whole endeavor appears to be the work of grown men who never outgrew puberty.

DeMonaco clearly hopes to make a significant moral statement on the level of Shirley Jackson's literary masterpiece The Lottery. Alas, his aim at political conservatives who support the gun lobby falls flat before he can pull the trigger.
As a man working against the clock while trapped in a vehicle out of control, Paul Walker never wastes his time-or yours.
Eventually it collapses in a gore fest of nauseating brutality that makes you wonder why they bothered at all.
In the end, director Paul Andrew Williams fails to resist sentimentality, but classy acting and distinguished production values never sink to the level of soap opera.
Robustly mounted, magnificently photographed and bone-crunchingly terrifying, World War Z towers above every other alleged summer blockbuster. It's the real deal.
It's not perfect, but when it works, Byzantium towers above all of the romantic vampire slobber we've been getting lately.
Petunia augurs more titillation than it delivers and only works occasionally.
A diabolically psychotic, sub-mental and completely unwatchable disaster ...
For his deeply affecting role that haunts the viewer long after the film ends, Mr. Mikkelsen won the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival.
You could make another film for half the budget in the time it takes to roll the end credits for CGI imaging. There's stuff to look at, but doesn't anybody care that it doesn't make a word of sense?
A harrowing film worth seeing and honoring for boldness and insight.
Part schlockfest, part campy fairy tale, this is a movie that begs you to bring your own barf bag.
Awkward music cues and choppy camera work add baggage to a film so overwrought that its excesses seem more unintentionally silly than bleakly disturbing.
If every war has more than one side, this story of one man who dares to stand against the tide of history has a contemporary relevance that remains uncontested.
Dallas Buyers Club represents the best of what independent film on a limited budget can achieve-powerful, enlightening and not to be missed.
Don't worry if you don't connect. There's nothing to connect to. The characters are never developed, and nothing ever happens.
In a movie without adults, the children are spontaneous and natural. And Ms. Ronan is captivating throughout.

If your own expectations are not too high, you crave period-costume drama and you're one of those unfortunate people who refuses to watch anything in glorious black-and-white, this Great Expectations is worth the time and effort.
Odd Thomas has high-speed chases, explosions, narrow escapes and masses of special effects-none special enough, I'm afraid, to save it from mediocrity.
Aside from some nice autumnal shots of Ivy League college campuses, there's nothing in HairBrained to sustain much interest.
Unfortunately, better movies have already been made about the subject, from the underrated film The Joneses to the current Wolf of Wall Street.
It takes just under two hours of tedium before you find out what's in the bag, and you might be sorry you waited.
I amaze myself by liking this latest lunatic cocktail as much as I do.

It sounds turgid, but it's a fine example of how two great actors can lift questionable material beyond its limitations. The premise is unlikely, but every time it edges uncomfortably in the direction of soap opera, they rescue it, making you care.
I've had bigger scares from the windows at FAO Schwarz.
For his directorial debut, Mr. Bateman acquits himself nicely, promising even better things to come.
Smart, substantial and enchanting.
The end result of this stoned-cold picnic is both haphazardly successful and somewhat disappointing, but it's worth seeing, thanks enormously to the tremendous charisma of Sam Rockwell.
Overrated, overexposed and overindulgent, James Franco is all over the place, like cow chips in the abandoned pasture of a derelict farm.
The only reason to suffer through a grim wack job called McCanick is to see the late Cory Monteith in his last film role.
Disappointingly tedious, On My Way is a contrived vehicle for Gallic icon Catherine Deneuve.
The May-December romance is an overworked genre, but steady hands guide this one with intelligence to a sad but satisfactory conclusion.
This is not a movie for everybody, but that assessment is not exactly intended as a thumbs down. Alarming thrills are guaranteed.

[It] focuses on unspoken adolescent feelings instead of familiar puerile events, with clichés held at arm's length. Unfortunately, Hide Your Smiling Faces is so slow it could use a few action sequences to speed things up.
Dream girl Scarlett Johansson digs for oil and hits a dry hole in Under the Skin.
It's so elegant and dreamlike-such a departure from most vampire epics-that you won't be bored. It also has a wicked sense of humor you usually don't find in the genre.
It's an inspiring and unforgettable story about cruelty, endurance, courage and making peace with the past.
John Turturro is a gifted and charming actor, but he has a fatal desire to be a film director and is cursed with no talent whatsoever for the job.
Under the circumstances, even first-rate New York stage actors like Thomas Sadoski and Justin Kirk seem uncertain and tentative.
Ms. Stritch is sharp, funny, brittle, caustic, demanding, exaggerated, critical (especially of herself) and infuriating. She is also elaborately unique and awesomely brilliant.
The writing tanks while the actors try to stay above water, but nobody leaves a trace on the radar.
The generic title In Secret is as uninspired as the movie itself.
Oblique, unstructured and demented, Winter's Tale aims to cast a dreamlike spell, but it's more like a nightmare.

Mr. Nelson's observant, detailed script flawlessly captures the mood of what American ennui has done to both old and young men on their way to becoming losers, lending a look and feel that seems like the Great Depression.
Be forewarned: The depression is inescapable.
Movies don't get any worse than Charlie Countryman.
One of the most eloquent, powerful and perfect movies I have ever seen.
I wouldn't call American Hustle my kind of movie, but perversely, I have to admit I enjoyed it, primarily because of the twisted logic and wicked cleverness.
The screenplay, by Kelly Marcel and Sue Smith, seamlessly captures two different eras with overlapping story lines that never intrude or confuse.
A sad example of what sometimes happens when a writer of gripping stage plays controls his own independent movie to his own selfish, labored self-satisfaction.
The sets are ravishing. The cinematography dazzles. There's so much going on that you don't blink for fear that you might miss something.
There's great acting in every frame, but by the end of the ordeal, the viewer may be too exhausted to care.
Mr. Fiennes admirably humanizes the characters while exploring their contradictions and emphasizing their feelings.
It is the galvanizing force of Vanessa Hudgens who catapults Gimme Shelter above the heartbreaking level of soap opera with a lancing effect.
Unpredictable, with a twisted surprise around each corner, Big Bad Wolves is a clever and arresting shocker.
The dim star wattage in this fifth rehash is palpable from the start.
I guess I've seen worse teen sex comedies, but it's rare to encounter one this stupid.
It's sensitive and winsome, like a modestly budgeted independent film should be.
A wrenching, riveting and richly rewarding experience at the movies.
The movie loses some of its focus and turns both silly and implausible. Still, the stars' chemistry works, and so does At Middleton.
I could no more tell you what it's trying to say than I could successfully stow away on the first space shuttle to Saturn, although I promise you that trip would be half as long.
The good twin/bad twin conceit in 2014 doesn't have a shred of the original surprise, and Zoe Kazan doesn't have the chops to carry it off anyway.
The Outsider is so far-fetched it redefines the word "preposterous" and is made doubly untidy by the star's clotted accent.
It is true. It is history. As a film, it is riveting, suspenseful, harrowing and exciting, and somehow, it also manages to be something rare among war pictures-a big-scale entertainment.
This is the kind of cheesy, sketched-out idea for prurient adolescents that gives indie-prods a bad reputation.
You may be shocked by your own reactions to "what Richard did," but you won't soon forget the movie in which he did them.
The jungle scenes were shot in Hawaii, so at least they all got a paid vacation.
Just when you think it can't get any more sentimental or tack on any more plot detours, the film attempts a clumsy cultural détente as the Chinese children's choir sings "Waltzing Matilda."

Ms. Prasad is a director whose previous experience has been limited to documentaries, and her limitations are obvious. Still, she's a good enough filmmaker that we can hope she has better luck next time.
Bond is back, and so is high-octane entertainment.
In all, there's too much material, too little revelation and almost nothing of Spielberg's reliable cinematic flair.
James Joyce once wrote that [Tolstoy] was "never dull, never stupid, never tired, pedantic or theatrical." He might change his mind if he saw Anna Karenina.
Plummer is the one-man show at the center of this one-man vehicle. He will leave you stunned and cheering.
There's nothing wrong with the overrated Jennifer Lawrence that some serious acting lessons couldn't improve. The rest of the actors are pretty much on their own.
Mr. Audiard has style galore, but he suffers from the same elephantiasis of the ego as almost all of the current American directors.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: One of the best movies of 2012.
The point of this vile, cynical and ultimately preposterous film is that America is reeling from spiritual numbness and ethical paralysis, and optimism is a game for fools.
The movie sometimes gets stuck in its own awkward groove like a needle on a warped phonograph, but it has its moments.
The star is vibrant and touching in every scene, often providing character revelations where none appear in the script.
The camera work is as beautiful as it is terrifying, with Quebec standing in for northern Michigan in the dead of winter. And the performances are resourceful, superbly etched and expertly nuanced.
Funny, believable, historic and hugely entertaining.
I urge you to share its sweetness and wisdom, and learn something.
An unforgettable film that combines epic spectacle with the intimacy of loving relationships in a celebration of the invincible human spirit.
Movies must move, and this one just lies there like a stack of paper from a classified government filing cabinet.
Bold, original, mesmerizing, stylish and one hell of a piece of entertainment.
Eight days in a car with these two is like eight weeks with shingles.
This film is deader than the corpses that litter the screen.
Despite the flaws and the occasional corn, this is still one of the most exhilarating and entertaining action films in recent memory.
As a writer, Mr. Burns has forgotten to make the characters likeable, and there are so many of them you need a diagram to both connect them and tell them apart.
The impact of Barry Levinson's eco-apocalyptic nail-biter is undeniable, especially when you realize some of it is based on fact.
Here is a unique fright flick that sets out to terrify and does it to capacity, eschewing fangs and claws to find chills and thrills in the unquenchable evil of human madness.
You will not go away unmoved. See it, and learn something.
It sends you home reeling, but wondering what the point of it was, and why so many worthwhile people bothered to do it in the first place.
The only sure way to avoid the loss of any more I.Q. points in the world today is to stay away from movies like Erased.
Mellow, but very much a work in progress, Goats has a bland but overcrowded menu that could benefit from a little feta.
For mature audiences who have forgotten how to smile, it takes up where The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel left off.
137 minutes of Joaquin Phoenix's nose hairs is not my idea of appetizing.
Half domestic family drama, half gentle sports saga with the saga part missing, Trouble with the Curve is less riveting than it ought to be.
It's pornography bathed in the tangerine glow of fruit-scented candlelight.
It is the remarkable Logan Lerman who negotiates his journey to Charlie's self-discovery with so much dignity and vulnerability that he steals every scene and carries the picture.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: As a message picture, its heart is in the right place. Too bad it doesn't always manage to rise above a swirl of predictable Hollywood clichés.
Ms. Jovovich displays such a keen awareness of her strengths that she brings out magical elements I never believed possible.
You start squirming early and end up feeling you desperately need a bath.
The first movie in history that makes Hugh Jackman look repulsive.
Wake in Fright is the closest a movie can get to a primal scream.
In the end, The Oranges does not quite deliver the goods.
To me, the movie is genuinely humor-resistant. Any cult it develops will be chewing gum and wearing Halloween costumes.

Argo is a triumph. It has tension, sincerity, mystery, artistic responsibility, entertainment value, technical expertise, a narrative arc and a thrilling respect for the tradition of how to tell a story with minimum frills and maximum impact.
The film's weakest link is Rufus Sewell's rumpled gumshoe, inarticulate and mumbling to the point of madness.
The actors are all completely wasted in this dumb travesty of fumbling, unfocused, oversexed numbskulls who work in the movie business.
The acting is solid, and the maturity of vision mixed with humor should appeal to the same audience that turned The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel into such an unexpected runaway hit.
The Sessions is fascinating, informative, engaging and heartbreaking stuff.
A trash heap of rubber noses and implausible high school accents that give new meaning to the word "pretentious."
A worthless farrago of noise, dirt and senseless violence ...
The result is a movie of enormous intelligence.
Mr. Zemeckis has forgotten nothing about how to stage the kind of breathtaking live-action fireworks display that keeps an audience paralyzed.
Quote not available.
It's far superior to what usually comes out of the British slums in the genre of gangland thrillers.
Empty, pointless and stupid, the barrage of gunfire called Welcome to the Punch is another unappealing entry in the overworked British gangster genre.
Mr. Cianfrance's artistic vision catapults it above the limitations of contrivance and into a realm of constantly evolving shifts of tone and mood.
A sad, wrenching but admirably unsentimental film about the bravery of the human condition that truly deserves a bigger audience.

The disparate elements in The Company You Keep are robustly collated by the keen, well-crafted direction of a master filmmaker at the top of his form. It's only April, but this is one of the best films of 2013.
Far from the offbeat satire on the American dream gone sour it aims to be, The Brass Teapot is more like a dark flirtation with the American nightmare that backfires.
The end credits, which seem almost as long as the movie itself, dementedly thank everyone from the citizens of Pennsylvania to William Wyler, Howard Hawks and God. What an insult.
With 42, [Helgeland] expands his skills to turn a mountain of research into a cogent life story worth retelling.
Years seem to pass between scenes. To be honest, years seem to pass during scenes.
The heat turns chilly before it ends, but for the most part, François Ozon is back in the catbird seat with In the House.
So bad it's hilarious.
Flawed but different, well-crafted and consistently powerful, At Any Price is the best film about impoverished farmers in the economic agricultural crisis since Jean Renoir's The Southerner.
The resolution for both characters, in a finale that turns disappointingly conventional, is so sad that it left me depressed beyond hope.
One of the goals of a great outdoor epic is to keep you breathless with wonder. Technically, dramatically and cinematically awesome, Kon-Tiki delivers in spades.
Poignant and exemplary, this is one of the best films of 2013.
Michael Shannon is so fascinating that I was honestly rooting for him to survive. The point of The Iceman is "Even monsters are human," but it takes a great actor to make a dubious theme convincing.
Just what we need-another sophomoric, oversexed vampire movie.

I love the publicity quotes by Baz Luhrmann stating that his intention was to make an epic romantic vision that is enormous. Also: overwrought, asinine, exaggerated and boring. But in the end, about as romantic as a pet rock.
It never hits the high notes of Mr. del Toro's own films or successfully weaves between reality and fantasy as it should.
Merely lurid slice-and-dice junk put through a Cuisinart.
A morose, unsettling blend of pathology for sport and murder for laughs.
Everybody learns something about the illusion of love and the power of honor. It's hard to believe it wasn't written by Nicholas Sparks.
Color it inspirational.
Responsible, riveting and intense, it's a film about cybercrime that left me shaking-the movie equivalent of sticking a wet finger into a hot socket.
Plods along with dialogue just above the level of crayon scribblings, and the direction by the usually reliable Lasse Hallström is dismayingly sluggish.
Hunky Dory has some pleasant things in it, but unfortunately, the funereal pace makes a snail look like a jackrabbit.

With so many characters and so many issues, Knife Fight seems overlong, but it's still above and beyond most movies that try to puncture the balloons of political hypocrisy. The writing is sometimes awkward, but the actors are uniformly convincing.
For an old-fashioned crime thriller, you need real pros. Mr. Statham is to acting what Taco Bell is to nutrition.
It's a deserving subject that should be explored in a more viable film, but Identity Thief is so bad it's hard to believe it wasn't directed by Judd Apatow or the Farrelly Brothers.
Steven Soderbergh keeps giving interviews confessing that he is bored with movies and promising that Side Effects will be his last one. Not a moment too soon, if you ask me.
I like the fact that Would You Rather has no stumbling zombies, werewolves with pecs or romantic vampires. The monsters are real people.
It's a remarkable accomplishment.
More laughs are expected in the next two installments of what threatens to become a trilogy. It's early, but I'm already making plans to be out of town.
The camera work is beautiful, and the script is mostly crisp even though the spoken English without subtitles is sometimes as confusing as the Mandarin.
The fight scenes are repetitive and the plot meanders, but the acting is superb.
I doubt that they had Strike Anywhere matches in the 14th century, and I'm pretty sure nobody said things like "Whatever happens, stay cool."
There are some lovely and moving things here, but over the long haul it's more like watching an hour and a half of someone's weekend trip to Knott's Berry Farm.
Clearer heads will find it absurdly pointless.

To sustain tension, you need the kind of claustrophobic camera movement, high-strung talk and gritty character development that are badly needed in any submarine movie and are sadly missing in Phantom.
The Girl enlightens with an unusual insight into the courage, durability and struggle of the Mexican people while taking the viewer on a guided tour of a piece of the country tourists never see.
Call it old-fashioned filmmaking, but you learn a lot and come away feeling an impact all too rare in movies today.
People just can't get enough of this stuff. To paraphrase Sam Goldwyn, include me in.
True originality is so rare that it's a treat to welcome a movie as completely different and provocative as Upside Down. It's unlike anything you have ever seen.
The people responsible for a hapless load of bunk called If I Were You can only be described as delusional. They think they have made an actual movie, when nothing in it qualifies.
Viggo's performance is the only payoff for the patience you will need to get through Everybody Has a Plan.
Most of the roles are so ambiguous you end up scratching your head in the final reel, and some of the loose ends are so irrelevant they seem to have ended up on the cutting-room floor.
Sermonizes in the manner Wilde satirized; the movie bends over backwards to assure the audience that marriage and monogamy, the butt of jokes throughout, are just and right.
No matter who's talking, the audience's attention will be on the images wrapping themselves around them.
The actual images from the barren surface of our solar neighbor don't fill the giant screen.
As much an old-fashioned potboiler as it is a political morality tale.
A moody, quirky movie that, although flawed, is worth a walk to the theatre in a gentle rain.
A difficult film to watch, but one that speaks to our own invidious world.
Quite literally, a delightful surprise.
Hasn't the brightness of a romantic comedy nor the tristesse of melodrama.
The rare film that stays within itself, mocking its obvious targets with the cool insouciance of mentholated tobacco.
An ambitious movie made on a modest budget, its intention is better than its execution.
One of those smart pictures that transcends genres, a costume romance inspired by Restoration comedy, French farce and vaudevillian slapstick.
This resonant fable proves again that art flourishes in unlikely places, under the most restrictive conditions.
Has more to recommend it than arty graphics--as befits a movie made from one of Philip K. Dick's most acclaimed novels.
Perhaps the adversity of making the movie allowed the filmmakers and actors to empathize more fully with the subject and characters of Water.
[Altman's] trademark techniques...lend themselves perfectly to the setting, but his ability to coax remarkable performances from an array of actors has rarely served him better.
Gripping, boring, disturbing, amusing, enlightening and frustrating.
All but devoted cineastes will be disappointed.
Rewards those who stay with it...at least those who use terms like deconstruction.
No doubt will end up one of the most popular and successful sequels in cinema history, but like the small act that grows too big too soon, the initial enchantment has faded.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The characters are one-dimensional, the plot makeshift, and the jokes unrelentingly cruel.
Factotum isn't for everybody, certainly not the abstentious. But there's no denying it, Chinaski appeals to our inner anarchist.
Svankmajer continues to push at the boundaries of convention, juxtaposing blasphemy and torture while mocking the possibility of transcendence.
Despite a superb cast, artful set design and seductive cinematography, Asylum remains a lovingly lensed missed opportunity.
A well-wrought if modest movie that lingers with you longer than many more ambitious pictures.
As entertaining and uplifting a film as we'll get all year.
IMAX 3D may be a gimmick, but it's a good one, perfectly suited to a film like Beowulf.
Rapaport intersperses her reflections and those of people who knew her with dramatizations.
[Jieho] doesn't know what to do with actors, however, and the film's impressive ensemble is wasted.
Hard to beat a good crime story lightened up with honest laughter and existential angst.
Foreign film buffs who enjoyed Lost in Translation may find it worthwhile to revisit Japan with a native guide.
Public policy is played for laughs rather than dissected in spite, and for 90 minutes we bask in escapist entertainment.
The film promises gnarly B-movie goosebumps but delivers an unctuous salve on noisome human nature.
A ragtag tour de force, a low-budget, high-drama independent marvel that reinvigorates cinéma-vérité.
The filmmakers know their audience and spin a good story, the cast is wonderfully diverse and engaging, the production first-rate.
A movie as gritty and shocking as anything [Lumet] has done in his remarkable career.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Shepard insists that we feel Simon's pain and empathize with his righteous indignation, as though The Hunting Party were a morality tale or revenge play. It's not, and there's the rub.
Owes a great deal to [Sideways], in terms of style and theme, but the plot and characters of Cahill's fable are fresh, and their capricious charms wholly their own.
Amusing, yet not what we expect, or want, in a Bean comedy.
The resulting cinematic chimera isn't remarkably pretty, but it's pretty remarkable.
Deserves praise well beyond its budget.
movie_title: 12:08 East of Bucharest (A fost sau n-a fost?) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A film that testifies to the multicultural mood of our own moment in time.
Day Watch, like Night Watch, doesn't take itself seriously, one of its chief charms.
A crisp and clever hour and a half that, like the best screwball comedies, barely pauses for laughs.
Jindabyne is that rare film mixing suspense and melodrama, social commentary and spirituality.
Michael Apted channels history, but Grace is amazing for the modern sensibilities of its 18th-century saints.
An appealing film, a window onto a part of the world passed over by history.
Does what it sets out to do--celebrate the good nature of those people who, despite life's difficulties, remain true to their loved ones, their friends, and themselves.
Overly long and literally unfocused documentary about the wine industry.
As an exercise in nostalgia...Inside Deep Throat is amusing
The film's extended debates on the ethics of science, government and personal responsibility would recommend it to critics of a medium that too often panders to audiences.
As lovely to watch as it is painful to contemplate.
A poignant reminder that social issues, in the end, are personal matters.
Salvadori and his fellow screenwriters invent clever complications to keep us amused.
A fun-filled, action-packed, uplifting film, entertaining for the entire family.
The film is as cliché-ridden as a rickshaw ride through Central Park, which is to say it tries hard to teach a tired formula new tricks.
Harsh Times is dark and brutal, not the kind of film that lures a large audience or garners awards, although it deserves both.
Agga emerges as an endearing ingenue with enough personality to carry the film through its set-pieces.
An ambitious, indeed audacious, film, as clever a piece of filmmaking as we'll likely get this year.
The movie is limp-loined and lame-brained.
The movie loses dramatic tension, its thrills and terrors enervated by the burden of didacticism.
As a work of psychological horror, In My Skin succeeds creepily, evoking comparison with Repulsion.
