Gwyneth Paltrow delivers an affecting, understated performance as the overwrought Plath.
In the end, The Cooler succeeds not because of its script (clever enough) or its direction (surprisingly skillful), but because of its cast.
Engaging and fair-minded.
Luther would have been better served had the filmmakers, like Protestants, kept things simple and straightforward.
Watching the movie is like attending a meeting of the Masons: It all seems silly unless you decipher the hermeneutics, numerology and theosophy.

Gibson's obsession with the pain and suffering of Jesus, sublime and terrible, does not transubstantiate into spirituality; rather, the brutality of his film at first repels, then numbs, and finally titillates.
OT is inspiring, but abstractly so, like a six-part series on arts and education in the L.A. Times.
If the story is predictable, the performances are nuanced.
Full of biblical and mythic parallels, but the film is rescued from such earnestness by whimsical performances and the sheer beauty of the landscape.
Mixes together the right portions of mayhem, morality and mortality, spices it with dark humor, and serves it up without pretense.
Lounguine has taken, if not an original story, an amazingly real one, and turned it into a spaghetti eastern, reducing a Dostoyevskian saga to a Leonean melodrama.
Frears manages to sustain the suspense required of an engaging thriller while drawing a believable portrait of real people we care about.
Watching an actor perform with his cell phone is about as interesting as staring at your dinner companion jabbering on his. It's rude, and aesthetically unsatisfying.
Entertaining and occasionally unsettling, but we never get under the skin of the protagonist, never learn what drives his addiction.
Taut and witty, in terms of direction as well as dialogue.
Fiennes carries the film, somehow managing to metamorphose from human to arachnid with all the creepiness and none of the camp that often characterizes Cronenberg's work.
Clever if calculated, sentimental and silly, a sweet, unpretentious romance...in a phrase, old-fashioned.
Despite its identity crisis, The Dancer Upstairs is eminently entertaining -- if a film about murderous terrorists and corrupt bureaucrats can be said to amuse.
Rarely does a filmmaker emerge so wholly formed, creating a miniature masterpiece first time out.
The lavender fields of Provence, captured in full bloom, leave more of an impression than any actor in the movie except Whishaw.
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Kári captures the contradictory sense of claustrophobia and emptiness that is both real and metaphoric. And Lemarquis is very watchable, as is Hansdóttir as Iris.
Achbar and Abbott would have had a first-rate film had they stuck with their conceit -- corporations as inmates running the asylum -- but they dilute their case in an attempt to make it irrefutable.
[The Nolans] could not have conjured a more chimerical story than this transcontinental thriller about two men selling their souls to destroy each other.
Earnest to a fault and depressing beyond reason, the film is unrelenting in its attempts to wrap the world in a shroud of fatalism.
More than an hour-and- a-half in length, the movie fizzles out before anything can explode, its characters incapable of sustaining narrative interest.
movie_title: Looking for Comedy in the Muslim World (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Winsome in the tradition of The Dark Crystal and Labyrinth.
It can't decide if it's a bloated TV program or a truncated feature.
Polanski is the perfect director for the project.
Ed Burns, Catherine McCormack and Ben Kingsley aren't aiming for Oscars, or even accolades, with their performances, but their choices make this over-budgeted B-movie fun to watch.
The film's style ... makes up for its difficult story.
Up and Down establishes its own personality, managing to remain ambiguous while neatly tying together the two narratives.
movie_title: Up and Down (Horem Pádem) (Loop the Loop) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A notable film in numerous ways.
Who Killed Bambi? is fun to watch, and newcomer Quinton has big, beautiful eyes, but the movie's contrived plot, forced conclusion and sentimental denouement rob it of real suspense and meaning.
movie_title: Qui a tué Bambi? (Who Killed Bambi?) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Exciting and perplexing at once.
Condon would like the audience to identify with his protagonist, despite his flaws, but he might have elicited greater empathy by focusing more on his subject than his subject's message.
A character study that benefits from the slow build-up of small but telling scenes.
Entertaining and appalling at once, an exercise in aesthetics that replaces the traditional unities with paradox, irony and cynicism.
Compelling but elusive.
Talky and mawkish.
[McElwee's] moviemaking skills and beguiling personality more than make up for his egocentric explorations.
Those who give themselves to this film, beautifully lensed with a fine performance by newcomer Howard, will have the pleasure of rewinding the early reels in their mind.
Noujaim's viewers will learn little new about the inner workings of Al Jazeera, its philosophy, or its influence on its 40 million viewers.
Fry, in a rare instance of a filmmaker fleshing out a novel, treats the characters far more sympathetically than did Waugh himself.
A remarkable achievement.

Bukowski would be better served by a critical examination of his life, one which gets past the sentimental façade of an artist who played the roué to keep from tasting the bitterness (as Stephen Crane once put it) of his own heart.
More thoughtful, but still entertaining.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Refreshing, unpretentious and genuinely affecting.
An arty, cerebral film, Alexandra nevertheless speaks to the heart like a symphony.
A companion piece to Certified Copy but reminiscent of Taste of Cherry, it falls somewhere between those celebrated Kiarostami signature pieces, yet his new film has a sense and style of its own.
Brantley and Reilly keep their story moving nimbly, melding period and genre like old hands, despite this being their first screenplay.
Like pineapple raita, The Lunchbox is sweet and savory, although its ending invites anxiety, like a too-spicy curry.
...Goldsman tends, like many successful filmmakers, to wax effusive, so an affecting love story inflates into an overwrought passion.
An original and endearing documentary from Penn & Teller asks the question: How did he do that?
Here's a movie that needs no review. Last Vegas doesn't live up to its tagline -- "It's going to be legendary" -- but it delivers the shtick promised in the film's ubiquitous trailers.
McCarthy has a Biblical sense of evil, palpable in his dark novels, but his attempts to shock us in The Counselor fall as flat as his studied dialogue and contrived characters.
Sam Rockwell delivers another outstanding performance in this saturnine meditation on greed set in backwoods Appalachia.
It's all good for having a laugh, for Wasteland, despite its ponderous title, gives us a likeable bunch of rascals we can root for, increasingly rare in the genre...
The Look of Love stays on the surface, and since decadence no longer shocks or even titillates, that surface has lost its luster.

Jay-Z meets Jay G in this hyperventilated version of F. Scott's eloquent novel about an enigmatic self-made millionaire-the film isn't for purists, but Baz should generate a buzz with young audiences.
Danny Boyle reworks familiar tropes--stolen art, expedient amnesia and the ever-titillating love triangle--into a stylish, diverting thriller.

Garrone is exploring weighty matters in Reality, questions of spirituality alternating with those pertaining to living a good life in the world, but the filmmakers seem to be having so much fun, the movie never grows ponderous.
Fraught with anxiety and callousness, Beyond the Hills can be hard to watch, although the severe sets, adumbral cinematography and wintry landscapes lend stark poetry to the proceedings.
Pulpy Brit actioner for die-hard fans of Ray Winstone, whose close-to-camp turn as '70s TV hero Jack Regan isn't enough to warrant a booking.
Short, easy-to-like and informative movie is refreshingly upbeat, as bright as its subject, and at just under 45 minutes, a perfect entertainment for restless youngsters.
An intimate meditation on freedom set in East Germany at the end of the Cold War, but this time, it's personal.
This modest coda to Ross McElwee's autobiographical trilogy will interest fans of this eccentric documentarian but bore those less familiar with his work.
An uplifting documentary about perseverance and determination reminds us that the national pastime still offers old-school heroes.
Wry drama adapted from a the novel by Australia's Nobel Prize-winning author Patrick White showcases outstanding acting, good writing and an excellent score.
Klown is funny, the characters inexplicably appealing, and its portrait of Denmark an unexpected "reveal." So why do we feel icky having laughed and learned?
A paean to pulp fiction, this gruesome but thoroughly entertaining Geek tragedy features a son plotting to kill his mother and prostitute his sister, with his father a willing accomplice.
Imaginative, evocative adaptation of a classic Victorian novel is fresh and compelling, with Freida Pinto delivering a moving performance as the tragic heroine.
A portrait of a denigrated people disguised as revenge tragedy, Gypsy is a window onto a way of life rarely glimpsed by outsiders.
Endearing and exuberant comedy about unlikely friends who help each other overcome handicaps-physical and otherwise.

Other than Tavernier's odd decision to draw Taillard de Worms with broad strokes, while sketching the remaining ensemble with considerable nuance, The French Minister has one big barrier to audiences who don't speak French: There are too many words.
It's all in good fun, the movie doesn't outstay its welcome, and even wallflowers will vouchsafe the feel-good ending.
Locke is everything most of [Steven Knight's past films] aren't, with an identifiable character struggling with real problems, but compressing time and place to concentrate emotion and heighten mood.
Here [Wong's] found-art sets appear cluttered, his still-life tableaus clichéd and his beauty-shot close-ups unglamorous.
The characters are stock but the cast is appealing.
Cristian Mungiu reflects on guilt and social responsibility in this Miller-like portrait of a man haunted by his own mendacity.
Tom Ford's fashionable thriller, cut on the bias, will appeal to loyal audience.
More fumarole venting than magma opus.
Alex Gibney sounds the alarm on cyber-warfare with this compelling, disturbing documentary that employs state-of-the-art graphics and innovative dramatic feints.
A self-indulgent muddle. Audiences will be hard-pressed to comprehend the characters, or even follow the plot.
A trio of fairytales for adults, Tale of Tales is painterly, theatrical and provocative, although, typical of anthology films, the parts are greater than the whole.
movie_title: Tale of Tales (Il racconto dei racconti) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Resplendent and reflexive, gritty and silly, 'Francofonia' is much like its title, suggestive of rock concerts and recondite lectures.
While there are smart lines and amusing sequences, the whole business becomes tiresome, then distasteful and, finally, a tad repugnant.
Taut, provocative and timely, Eye in the Sky has the all the right elements.
Macabre comedy featuring Emma Thompson as a besotted (but somehow beloved) harridan should attract fans of cheeky British (er, Scottish) crime dramas.
movie_title: Barney Thomson (The Legend of Barney Thomson) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A movie made by women for women, Elles will find a sympathetic audience among those who identify with the woman-in-crisis. The rest of us will be perplexed, if not flummoxed...
Faithful adaptation of Patricia Highsmith's love story features two moving performances in a wonderfully realized production.
Interesting but uneven.
In the end, [director Myroslav] Slaboshpytskiy pushes his story beyond plausibility, or it may be that he was striving for allegory all along...it's unclear.
Charming comedy handles weighty ideas with a light touch and winsome soundtrack.
The film fails to engage the audience in the action onscreen, and [its] laughs aren't jolly enough to compensate.
[John Malkovich's] performance reminds us that good acting transcends mediocre material.
[Director Andrey] Zvyagintsev spins a compelling story with unexpected twists and turns and startling cinematic moments.
Entertaining if cerebral fable will appeal to fans of Italian cinema but otherwise struggle to find an audience.
Whiplash is one of the most affecting and enjoyable movies of the year. Young director Damien Chazelle turns out to be a natural-born filmmaker with impressive chops.
Making his directorial debut, versatile screenwriter Hossein Amini...has crafted an entertaining, evocative drama in The Two Faces of January.
No, the performances are good enough, the story engaging enough, but The Drop never convinces us that the events unfolding on the screen are more than a filmmaker's conceit.

Calvary, however, offers no redemption or even catharsis - at best, some talk of forgiveness - and McDonagh's crude drollery, if that's the word for it, feels forced, fake, as though anger is acceptable if delivered with a punch line.
Mr. Holmes will delight Sherlock fans weary of seeing the imperious investigator reimagined as an action hero.
Aardman's first stop-motion feature in 3D doesn't overdo the now-ubiquitous special effects, but the added dimension refreshes the studio's signature chases without dampening its endearing drollery.
A rom-com that knows its demographic -- boomers coping with the heartache and natural shocks that flesh is heir to -- Words and Pictures is too earnest for its genre.
Margaret Thatcher as you've never seen her...This imaginative, entertaining biopic is as unconventional as its subject, and as clever as the actress who plays her.
Terrific cast enlivens this theatrical production that channels the sensibility of the late, great Dennis Potter. Prepare for a fusillade of a four-letter word that still shocks Americans.
Jeff Bridges channels Hank Williams, Jr. and Kris Kristofferson for his portrayal of an alcohol-addled outlaw country star hoping for one more chance.
Funny and poignant tale similar to director Jason Reitman's two earlier efforts, Thank You for Smoking and Juno, but more mature, less snarky.
We cannot tell a lie: This one is missable.
Anxious and amicable, Paris is in the eye of the beholder, like the city itself.
Coming-of-age story offers an ageless lesson in life, but An Education is ever fresh, never didactic, and very entertaining.
Rated R for rude, raw, ribald, and repetitive, Brüno delivers Sacha Baron Cohen's brand of commando comedy, but little else.
This surefire summer hit might even get Vegas back on a winning streak.
Adaptation of Noel Coward's 1925 comedy reminds us that time has marched on.
Roll up, roll up, for Béla Fleck's harmonious heritage tour, satisfaction (more or less) guaranteed.
British biopic about Dylan Thomas, his wife, Caitlin, and their relationship with another couple is as maudlin as a poet after too many pints.
You've seen it, but it's still entertaining...a well-made genre-blender by professionals who know how to coax tears, deliver thrills.
Alternating between the saturnine and the saccharin, Is Anybody There? brings sweetness and light to a depressing subject.
Sincere but stilted adaptation of the 1980s stage play dissecting a German intellectual's embrace of the Nazi Party.

Embellishing his trademark Dirty Harry snarl with exasperated grunts and growls, a fusillade of racial epithets, and discharges of contemptuous expectoration, Clint Eastwood redefines what it means to be a grumpy old man.
Retro comedy about doo-wop singers hoping for one last score has great harmony, but lacks a catchy beat.
For a film that looks and feels au courant, Ghost Town could slip seamlessly into the rotation at Turner Classic Movies, an observation meant to be a compliment.
Will disappoint viewers who know Waugh's writing or the Granada production, while a younger audience unfamiliar with either won't care enough about rich Brits between the wars.
A well-made, high-spirited movie that (rare indeed) never takes itself too seriously... a perfect summer escape.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Gavron coaxes good performances from her cast, and she captures the look and feel of council housing in East End London...
The Fall is meant to celebrate the restorative power of imagination, but it leaves viewers burdened with a sense of despair and impending doom.
Manages to be flippant and darkly provocative at once.
Intermittently funny, fitfully engaging and occasionally enlightening.
movie_title: Where in the World Is Osama Bin Laden? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Cirkus Columbia is not as clever or complex as Danis Tanovic's masterpiece, No Man's Land, but it has its charms, not least its beguiling depiction of Balkan life before the war.
Yet another small but sweet film featuring a dysfunctional family comprised of quirky characters caught up in curious circumstances.

A thriller unfolding in an isolated bunker on a deserted island (well, a posh beach house on Martha's Vineyard) might seem a perfect vehicle for Roman Polanski, but it's too geopolitical for a director of his predilections.
Theatrical tale, well-acted, heavy on mood but light on meaning.
Whatever charges might be leveled against this young director's worldview, his in-your-face approach to filmmaking is refreshing and provocative.
Director Tomas Alfredson's ability to establish mood and place turns out to be an effective way to tell a complicated tale.
Screenwriter William Monahan trades in South Boston for South London, only to discover he forgot to pack his A to Z.
Cynical and sentimental by turns, Mammuth takes a ride on the wild side, but well within speed limits.

Dramatizing executives at their labors, even those privileged to bask in sexy industries like Major League Baseball, shouldn't make for scintillating cinema, but Moneyball, like the team it celebrates, finds a way to win.
If nothing else, the 2010 Death of a Funeral proves that, in Hollywood, you get a second chance.
A paean to a way of life that, regardless of Dylan Thomas' furious injunction, is going gently into that good night.
Can a Hollywood movie be highly derivative and refreshingly original at the same time? Would Indiana Jones and James Bond make a good buddy flick?
Bad teacher, worse movie...this summer comedy is an underachiever that should have been held back.
Steve Coogan and Rob Brydon pair up again, ostensibly for a culinary tour of northern England, but really to win bragging rights for the best Michael Caine.
Notable as the first feature-length film produced and shot in Congo, Viva Riva! should attract audiences interested in international cinema, plus fans of the '70s blaxploitation phenom.
Deliberately paced drama of adultery depends on nuance and subtext, the latter holding far more meaning than the subtitles.
An incongruous mix of fable and realism, giddiness and gloom, The Beaver gnaws off more than it can chew, but Mel Gibson's earnest performance and Jodie Foster's able direction shore up the dam.
John Landis returns with a macabre spoof of Enlightenment Scotland, starring Simon Pegg and Andy Serkis as entrepreneurial serial killers furthering the cause of science...and the arts.

Those so disposed can think deep thoughts as they ponder the perennial mysteries of nature and the cinematic gaze, but the strength of this pantomime depicting the stages and states of life is its simple beauty.
Hanna starts out edgy and fresh, but runs out of steam and imagination, ending up, after many obligatory chases, in the same old place.
Another frothy frappé from the ingenious French auteur Jean-Pierre Jeunet, this one pitting his beleaguered Everyman against avaricious arms dealers in a Paris more beguiling than the actual city.
Charming and cynical, violent and sweet, well-made and offbeat...Perrier's Bounty is an entertaining film that doesn't take itself seriously.
Haunting, heartbreaking adaptation of the Ishiguro novel features a superb cast and inspired direction and cinematography...and a unique comingling of genres.
The final film of French auteur Claude Chabrol was his first collaboration with legendary actor Gérard Depardieu, the main reason to see this enigmatic mystery.
Steve Carell is convincingly Gru-some as the world's most vulnerable super-villain, and his lovable yellow minions are incorrigible scene-stealers.
Brassy burlesque careens between droll humor and slapstick stunts until it implodes upon itself during a prolonged and extremely uncomfortable climax.
Feste could do with less cowbell.
The story is inspiring and the filmmakers' intentions noble, but The Way Back too quickly loses its narrative direction.
There's a whole lot of swearin' in this otherwise sweet film about conventioneers gone wild, with producer Alexander Payne further establishing his comic brand.
Can an overbaked soufflé still be too "fluffy"? Morning Glory's catch phrase gives new meaning to chick flick.
Although the ending is unsurprising, Henry Poole remains an interesting character.
Traitor delivers plot twists but few real surprises.
Elliptical, sweeping, lovely and thoroughly confusing, Ashes of Time Redux is not a film to rent. It's well worth paying to see it on the big screen.
Some jokes work, some don't and, frankly, I can't remember either, but it leaves a sweet aftertaste. Slight, but sweet.
This modest and lovely film is a welcome reprieve after the explosion-filled slate of summer movies.
movie_title: A Thousand Years of Good Prayers (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The film tastefully yet unenergetically chugs along.
The characters in Battle in Seattle are often crudely drawn, and the able actors struggle with canned lines.

Man on Wire, the delightful documentary about French tightrope walker Philippe Petit's incroyable early-morning trip between the World Trade Center towers in 1974, is an interesting film to watch from the front row.
Like the smart weapon technology it mocks, War, Inc. aims at the right targets but misfires so severely that even the clever details get obliterated in the resulting mess.
1000 Journals has a catchy hook, and Kreuzhage showed tenacity in following many difficult trails, but the movie plods.
The film tries to tell us that money hasn't spoiled the fun, but I was much more curious about the black shorts than the Quicksilver brand board shorts.
Reilly jumps into his role with the zeal of a Method actor -- no fear about sporting tiny underroos for the bulk of his screen time -- but he sometimes comes off as more scary than funny.
It attempts no improvements on the basic suspense formula. It just does everything really well: perfect pacing, lovely camera work, spot-on acting and an ingenious plot.
movie_title: Ne le Dis à Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Bell posits that their disillusionment is a side effect of being American and he may well be right.
There is nothing wrong with taking inspiration from actual events, but it's a tricky business, and Dark Matter does no one right by sticking to the shocking conclusion.
Its biggest mystery is how it was financed (by Texas trillionaire and Dallas Maverick owner Mark Cuban, no less) and selected for distribution.
It lacks the character and depth of a product whose value increases with age. In other words, it's no Chateau Montelena '73 Chardonnay.

The film sets just the right tone: with inventive music choices and wonderfully piquant moments plucked from what must have been hundreds of hours of footage, Frontrunners is consistently entertaining.
Rory Culkin does more than hold his own in this high-powered cast. He shows the angst of a teenage boy, but also the resilience. There is a sweetness to this film that keeps the darkness at bay.
It's frightfully formulaic, with nary a twist or turn on the patented mockumentary form.
Fear(s) of the Dark is a feast for the eyes, even if it doesn't always get the pulse racing.
movie_title: Peur(s) du Noir (Fear(s) of the Dark) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: At no point did I feel bored or condescended to, and even though the ending may be overwrought, it had me gripping my chair.

The movie starts fast and the pace rarely relents. Goodbye Solo is almost frighteningly alive: Other filmmakers must wonder exactly how Ramin Bahrani packs so much personality in what could have been standard indie fare.
It's horrific. But Hunger displays uncommon intelligence and visual panache, transcending the goal of making the situation seem real. It feels more than real. It's art.
The overall project succeeds at offering three tantalizing films for the price of one movie ticket.
It's an entertaining journey, and director Sascha Paladino injects humor and pathos into the musical sequences.
Makes for a lovely hour and a half of old-fashioned storytelling.
Oceanic movies in actual science museums are far more interesting and nuanced than this documentary -- not to mention the wildly popular Planet Earth series, which even in 2-D looks better.

Tokyo Sonata is a bit overwrought, especially in the final act, but it is beautifully shot, features moving performances by the well-chosen cast and has the unity of vision that is the hallmark of an auteur.
Uninspired and only faintly funny.
Yonkers Joe is incoherent, succeeding neither as an exciting gambling ride nor a touching family story.
In these recessionary times, it's not just misogynistic to assume that intelligent women turn into feral dogs at the sight of a Tiffany gift box, but it's also beside the point.
It's fun to see attractive people get together and fall apart.
Light as air, My Name Is Bruce is good for a mild chuckle, not a belly laugh. As any Campbell fan knows, managing expectations is key to getting the most from his work.
Were the World Mine follows the teen musical formula but renders its material with admirable lushness and intelligence.
Could there be a worse time to revisit the indulgences of the '00s?
Let the Right One In strikes a surprising array of notes: scary, sad and hopeful.
It's a delight to see Alice escape by the skin of her teeth more than half a dozen times, with each of those close-shaves being truly thrilling, and the 3D makes them all the more exciting.
You end up following illogical plot points, and want to see just how the story ends. The pay-off is goofy, sure. But it's still a good film to catch up on a late night with friends over.
[The] performances make the human characters far more interesting than the demonic ones.
Trolls is a fail-safe film that young parents can take their kids to, and hopefully enjoy a few chuckles themselves.
The play on the term 'collateral damage' fails to hit home as the movie takes a long-winded route to get there.
The mark of a good documentary is that you forget that the events unfolding on the screen are not fiction. An Insignificant Man achieves that and even surpasses it.
Quote not available.

Most animated movies try to deliver a message and end up sounding preachy. Sing too, has one -- once you hit rock bottom, there's nowhere else to go but up. The sheer heart with which its characters live and convey the sentiment, is incredible.

A disturbingly intimate portrayal of Jacqueline Kennedy, 'Jackie' is a film that unmasks her in such a tender yet objective manner; you feel like an intruder who is tailing the first lady of America and a widow in her most trying time.

Since it's Tupac, the music being brilliant is a no-brainer. However, unlike biopics on rappers in the past like Straight Outta Compton or 8 Mile, viewers who aren't aware of the legacy of Tupac, won't quite be able to connect with the film.
If you're a dog-lover, the makers will have you eating out of their hands in no time. If you're a cat-person, there is still enough humour and heart in it to enjoy it with family.
You may just zone out in this very ordinary story that has very little to offer adults.
The entire film is about maintaining the legacy of a princess, but a weak execution coupled with lackluster performances and choppy editing make it a dreary watch.
As far as thrillers are concerned, some essential elements are a tight story, an unexpected twist and a couple of nice frights. In this one, all three are missing.
There's a very interesting and topical twist at the end, but you have to endure a lot until you reach there, which is a poor bargain.
The biggest irony is that the big Geostorm that everyone is so afraid of doesn't really happen. However, the 4D vibrations and halogen-flickers kind of make-up for it.
It's a rare, mature thriller that delivers the goods and keeps you engrossed. Don't let this small film slip under the radar, because this will stay with you long after you leave the theatre.
Philip Ng as Bruce Lee is well cast. The early swagger and the transformation later are portrayed quite well.
In the acting department, almost everyone gives an over the top performance. There is hardly a semblance of screenplay and the music is generic.
A formulaic film, there are no real surprises here and it fails to cash in its chips as far as holding your interest is concerned.
The chemistry between Ranveer and Sanjay is darkly entertaining. You may even feel guilty while enjoying a moment of black humour in scenes between the two actors.
This colourful joyride is one that we insist you make and see the world through the eyes of a little boy.
movie_title: Boy and the World (O Menino e o Mundo) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: With weak performances, forced VFX and a badly structured script, Tera Intezaar is a film where you will be waiting desperately for the end credits to roll. To say it's a long wait for that is no understatement.
While the filmmaker is asking the right questions when it comes to teen suicides, but the manner in which she says it is not that interesting.
From a Clint Eastwood directorial, one expects better. Alas, this one is relegated to being merely an experiment in casting.

Kuch Bheege Alfaaz successfully manages to show how love in the time of social media can stay relevant. The Kolkata of trams and bridges, fish markets and open parks is shown in a stunning manner by Onir.
Go along with Jackie with this ride. He may not come out as a super hero always, in every scene, but its heartening to watch him try.
A clear case of riding the wave of women-centric films, Jeena Isi Ka Naam Hai has an overly simplistic approach at dealing with serious issues that concern women.
A lowbrow slapstick comedy, most gags in Jattu Engineer are centered entirely around the characters stuttering, stammering and passing wind loudly.
The production values are top notch and so is the music. While the narrative may get a bit repetitive, like how birthday songs can get, maybe that's what the director intended.
Even if you are weak-hearted, this one will not scare you for too long.
While it dithers in what it wants to eventually say, it is certainly a fun watch.

With stock MMA fight shots taken, there are a total of three fights shown in the film. The sound is so unsynchronised, that you hear punches which Jeetu didn't even throw. The performances are more comical than serious, and not in a good way.
With a completely guessable end, this film actually leaves you with an actual, live hangover. If you are looking for a funny flick to catch on the weekend, this is not it.
Almost all actors struggle with even delivering their lines. With a weak story and a choppy editing, this is definitely not the film that can define Prime Minister Modi.
A film with a wonderfully complex first half deserves a second one that matches. The banal simplicity is what is off-putting. Still, Suburbicon is worth a watch for the spectacular performances.
It could have been good film, but the undoing of Coffee With D is its post-production. The film is let down by shoddy editing and a bad dubbing job where entire sentences are muted and out of sync.

Farhan Akhtar and Ritesh Sidhwani with director Mrighdeep Singh Lamba have created a successful franchise, and there is ample scope to make a Fukrey 3, but this time, we hope it doesn't take them four years to do so.

With insipid performances, a very slow pace and a plot that you can smell miles away, Viraam is a film that could have been better if it avoided the cliched treatment that is often given to Hindi films.
Heavier on visuals than emotions, it delivers no message nor answers any questions. Too thin to be a slice of life, this one.
Ihere is no real drama and it comes out a bit flat. If you're a follower though, this one is for you.
movie_title: Hare Krishna! The Mantra, The Movement And The Swami Who Started It All (2017)

movie_review_blurb: While there is a semblance of a story, there is nothing in the film that supports it. When it comes to the screenplay, the film baffles you.

The film belongs to the nineties, which was a simpler time when audience may have bought such an absurdist premise. But with a script that suffers from a serious case of ADD, you will just be mildly amused.
movie_title: Ek Haseena Thi Ek Deewana Tha (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Older viewers will find plenty to smile at, even if it is simply recognising that you would have absolutely loved this movie when you were twelve-years-old.
While not without its merits (the performances of Jennifer Ehle and Rahul Bose are particular highlights), Before the Rains ultimately suffers from a downpour of melodrama.
The performances are uniformly excellent, particularly from the women....
Though it offers many laughs and cringe-worthy moments of failed male/female interaction, in denying its own title the film becomes just another dream factory romantic comedy.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It is an undeniably slow film, but there is something enchanting in its pace, as it gradually immerses you in its imagery, its soundtrack and its otherworldly quality.
Any time...personal history is touched upon, it is quickly shoved under the carpet in favor of yet another sailing montage, complete with compulsory sunset.
Young actress Nerea Camacho is brilliant as Camino, showing a maturity in her performance that resonates strongly with her tragic character.
Though there are mistaken identity moments of mirth, the cheese factor unfortunately lets it down...
Director David Yates employs a deft hand with the series, achieving an exciting and dramatic result.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Though you may see the end coming somewhere towards the beginning, this is a highly enjoyable film with an excellent support cast, witty and fast-paced script and brilliant performances.

The film's only fault is that it lacks the driving narrative force that Marshall had with Chicago, which may be the fault of the original author of the libretto, but it results in the film losing momentum between the awesome musical sequences.
Impressively directed and finely acted, this film gives real insight into the life of a fascinating man.

If you're in the mood for a solid family story, Rock The Casbah should at least partially satisfy. Just make sure that you have dinner reservations for after the film -- you'll be hungry for something more.
Step Up All In is spectacle wrapped in story, but it's the juicy delicious centre which we all crave.
For fans of the book, this will be an enjoyable watch. For those who haven't read the original text, the film is a delight.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Kill The Messenger is a sturdy addition to cinema's esteemed investigative journalism sub-genre.
Most of the problems in My Mistress stem from the fact that it is steeped in cliché.
The strength of The Dark Horse lies in the conviction of its performances. The child actors are fantastic, but it's Cliff Curtis who carries the film.
The most amazing thing about this by this idiotic sci-fi thriller is that the actors do not crack up when delivering their lines.
Meeting the demands of justice whilst filtering out the thirst for vengeance is no easy matter; here, the distinction is a matter of primacy.
This film kicks butt, and in doing so it also manages to suggest that your need for it and for other butt-kicking films is a late capitalist symptom of contemporary psychosis.
Loquacious. Confounding. Asymmetrical. Never-ending. Cliched. Redundant. Logorrheic. Unfunny. Meandering. Blase. And frankly, downright boring, too...
American Beauty accomplishes in a mere two hours, what many movies and sequels all year long have not; it makes the viewer reason and empathize with the great American Family.
I shudder at the thought of several sequels to this flick.
movie_title: Pokemon the First Movie - Mewtwo vs. Mew (1999)

movie_review_blurb: A fascinating new film... about the wonderful life and premature death three years ago of one of sport's most charismatic artists.
Etta's story will be better told in another film, surely.
Ditches the expected route and comes out surprisingly original and endearing.
Little more than an exercise in pockmarked dialogue, lame stereotype riding and even worse pacing.
The foreshadowing is a bit heavy-handed, but the writers and director largely manage the tension and mystery tactfully.
A well-crafted introductory course.
This School is cool.
A film that is thiiiis close to nailing the whole suspense/thriller/ serial-killer genre.
It's great emotional fodder for old-school Metallica fans and smart, tugging drama for people unfamiliar with the band.
In a struggling music economy, the big screen can be big money -- for the right acts. And the Jonas Brothers are exactly that.
Lackluster.
movie_title: How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Yes, American Reunion is a juvenile outing. They steal jet skis and defecate in beer coolers. They cheat on their girlfriends and lie to their best friends. But what did you expect?
The disconnect between intention and final product is a head scratcher.
Allen's story moves along quite wonderfully, primarily because of his nuanced casting.
The rom-com/car chase back-and-forth doesn't always work, but a fun story and affable cast keep things moving fluidly.
This meaningful film keeps the laughs, giddy anxiousness and warm butterflies from the trailer and sustains it all through two full hours of a love story.
Apparently Apatow's penchant for if-it's-not-broke filmmaking isn't changing anytime soon. And it's a shame, because while This is 40 has plenty of laughs, it lacks decency and heart.
This film could have been -- should have been, even -- something special. But it's not.

It might sound like a stretch, imagining Penn playing that intense, indiosyncratic a villain. But the lauded, veteran actor pulls a left hook, then a right, and after a wild bodyshot at the tail end of the film, you see the true mania behind his eyes.
Money For Nothing lacks the rush of Rush, but you still might find your pulse racing and your blood boiling by the film's end.
movie_title: Money for Nothing: Inside the Federal Reserve (2013)

movie_review_blurb: While that sounds like a fantasy for rock aficionados, the scenes lack dramatic tension or cinematic enlightenment. It just kind of happens, and then the all-star jam fades to black, leaving few remnants of the filmmakers' initial intentions.
... the film enjoys itself and translates that joy to the spectator... [Full review in Spanish]
movie_title: Antonio One Two Three (António Um Dois Três) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Although this is a more standard horror film, the tone is witty and gleefully grisly.
Several parts of the narrative don't gel, feeling designed simply to look cool or sound funny.
movie_title: Arthur and the Invisibles (Arthur and the Minimoys) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Superb performances and elegant production values make it profoundly involving.
Starting as a lively adventure, this film slowly twists into a haunting and unforgettable thriller, using real life events to tell a devastatingly powerful story.
A terrific sense of style and wit, plus solid performances all around.
The dual story threads merge seamlessly in del Toro's elegant style.
These characters have enough conflicting relational issues to fill about a year on a daily soap; it's messy and passionate, murderous and lusty.
There's actually some serious subtext if we bother to look for it.
This internalised dramatic thriller makes the most of subtly perceptive writing, directing and acting.
Good freak-out fun for genre fans.
Deliberately quirky almost to the point of distraction, this offbeat comedy is an enjoyably puzzling film.
The writers and director get the balance right, never tipping over into either sentiment or preachiness.
It's technically well-made, but lacks the writing or acting skills to make it work.
This expertly made film is fascinating and gripping. And it's also so long that it feels like an entire TV series on DVD.
This warm comedy at least has the ring of truth in its remarkable tale of childhood expectations and disappointments.
In her feature debut, filmmaker Pratibha Parmar falls back on every cliché she's supposedly trying to undermine.
This stylish documentary cleverly examines one of the most influential artists of the past 40 years, telling his personal story and vividly showing his impact on the industry.
Nicely filmed and acted, it's an enjoyable, although superficial, look at relationships.
David Lynch again deploys his genius in all its infuriating impenetrability.
An enjoyably bad movie.
This ode to a bygone style of entertainment is a fitting swan song for Altman.
It's worthy and beautifully produced, but it feels like a fantasy rather than the truth.
Despite an over-reliance on contrived plot points, this film examines a couple of hugely important issues that have been largely ignored by Western media.
A strikingly well-made film that states its case subtly and without compromise.
It looks great, but without sharp characters it's both lifeless and pointless. And strangely unfunny.
Fits perfectly into the world created by the first five movies: sentimental, formulaic and effective.
Scruffy and rambunctious, this lively film takes on the personality of its characters.
A strikingly well-made film, highlighting a serious issue in a powerfully resonant way.
Silly and enjoyable, but superficial and formulaic.
While this film has a terrific story, and strong acting anchored by Swank's superb central performance, it's also a little slick and gimmicky
With a plot that could be set almost anywhere, Gibson recreates the ancient Mayan civilisation on screen for this deeply entertaining action thriller.
In the end, the script lets the film down with its obvious twists, its naggingly illogical narrative and a general pointlessness.
It's a completely unnecessary, ramshackle mess of a film. But it does keep you laughing.
Like a delightfully unhinged version of a 1960s Japanese monster movie, this Korean thriller piles on character detail, political comment and comedy asides.
Zack Snyder invests loads of visual style into this adaptation of Frank Miller's now-classic graphic novel ... but there's not much going on underneath the gorgeous surface.
Slow and steady, sure-handed and gripping.
A sensitive and moving teen drama about dealing with bullying, loneliness and grief.
Almost without cracking a smile, it's thoroughly hilarious.
There's more than enough material here to make an enjoyable drama about a mother and her adult daughters. But the writers and director fail on virtually every front.
It looks great, and touches on some important issues, but doesn't seem sure what to do with them.
Another British writer is given the worthy cinematic treatment, complete with an American actress in the title role and sentiment that overwhelms what should be a gritty story.
Devolves into a simplistic good-vs-evil thriller, but strong performances keep it interesting.
Expertly filmed and vividly well-acted, this true-life war thriller is remarkably understated and yet powerfully gripping and moving.
There's plenty to enjoy here, even though the film feels utterly fluffy and superficial.
Yes, this is strong stuff, but spoken in an articulate, measured, passionate West African voice, it's impossible to ignore.
The entire film is subdued, but film fans who are fed up with nonstop action will love it.
movie_title: L' Amico di Famiglia (The Family Friend) (Friend of the Family) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Taken as a whole, it's a remarkably textured look at the City of Lights.
Silly, sweet and sentimental, this French comedy is thoroughly engaging.
This story of rich teens way out of their depth is chilling and nicely played. But it feels like a cautionary after-school movie spiced up with sex and violence.
For a documentary, this film has one of the most gripping narratives of the year.
Intriguing to watch and well-played by the engaging cast.
Not only expertly captures a specific point in history, but also offers a bracing examination of human nature.
A fascinating public figure is reduced to an uninteresting, unlikeable cliche in this stylish but only fitfully entertaining biopic.
Sensitively and engagingly well written, directed and acted, this is a remarkable little film.
A little long and pushy, but very well-played and at times utterly harrowing
Gimmicky but effective, this claustrophobic thriller has such an intriguing premise that it keeps us entertained even as it gets increasingly contrived.
There's enough style, intrigue and plot twistiness in this thriller to keep us watching
A true story told in a deeply heartwarming style: there's never any doubt where this film is going.
Although it features the same improv-style hilarity, it feels like a more serious Hollywood satire.
The mind-bending story is enough to keep us interested, although the film is bloated and needlessly overcomplicated.
It may have a fairly standard adventure plot, but it's so fiercely witty that you just can't stop laughing.
An eerily effective little thriller that cleverly uses agoraphobia as its lynchpin.
Scott is clearly aiming for cute and wacky while hedging his bets with sticky nostalgia.
It strikes such a strongly resonant chord that it's often difficult to watch, but we can't turn away.
These four British guys (three from Wales, one from London) make the Jackass crew look like wimps.
Brisk, entertaining and, yes, intense.
A harrowing story straight from the headlines ... a gripping, engaging character-based drama.
While this film will indeed insult almost everyone, it's also genuinely hilarious.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A lot more money than when they made their first film. But no more sense.
Keeps a smile on your face even though there are only a couple of actual laughs along the way.
Progresses in a natural, unforced style that's increasingly creepy and ultimately emotionally shattering.
A dramatic movie that's engaging and provocative in a way a documentary couldn't be.
Moody and full of atmosphere, this film has a terrific premise, but no plot to speak of. It's an intriguing character study, beautifully filmed and acted but ultimately somewhat empty.
A gripping, provocative documentary.
Owes a heavy debt to the original version, but this is a masterpiece all its own.
A bracingly involving school drama that's lively, smart and extremely pointed.
The design is uninteresting, the characters are bland and the story is terrible.
A surprisingly engaging, provocative little film that's hard to get out of your head.
Snappy dialog and some prickly satire give it an edge most of these youthful romps lack.
The jet-black comedy has a surprising sweetness that counter-balances the profoundly disgusting plot.
A strong attention to detail with an impressionistic style ... breathes life into the story in unexpected ways.
This futuristic London thriller is so well filmed and acted that it grabs hold of us and never lets go.
Remains remarkably intimate, focussing finely on the characters as it weaves a fascinating tapestry of the meeting of cultures.
This tale of a brilliant sociopath is disturbing and often uncomfortable to watch. And it's also magical filmmaking.
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Amid the corny cliches, the writers have buried several genuinely hilarious throwaway lines.
The kind of entertainingly gonzo storyline that completely disarms us, simply because anything could happen.
A bristly, jazzy tone and a perceptive script that plays on the characters' flamboyance.
Besides the high-energy music, the story grapples meaningfully with intense human drama, racial issues and the theme of art versus commerce.
Has rather too much attitude for a simple tale about making peace with your past.
movie_title: A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It may be dry and sullen, but it's also smart and classy.
Steven Soderbergh recreates the style of a wartime noir thriller so perfectly that this film feels almost stilted and quaint by today's standards.
There are similarities to Saving Private Ryan ...but filmmaker Bouchareb has a much lighter touch than Steven Spielberg, never pushing the point or falling back on sentiment.
Exists in that fantasy Nancy Meyers universe in which a bunch of attractive, wealthy people talk cutely and smartly to each other and find love in all the right places
Feels like the cheerful lovechild of Moulin Rouge and March of the Penguins.
Lyrical and haunting, this film is a powerfully engaging examination of mortality and grief wrapped up in a sci-fi fantasy.
This film looks so good, and has such a strong cast, that some viewers won't notice how corny the script is.
This romp just isn't funny or original enough to become a holiday classic. Although the solid cast makes it watchable.
With a fresh approach to the birth of Jesus, Hardwicke (Thirteen) tells the biblical story with energy and spark, adding layers of meaning that give the film a bit of a kick.
We can really feel writer-director Murphy straining for both wacky hilarity and touching emotion. And never quite getting there.
A smartly written, tautly acted dramatic thriller, but it's so long that it feels like we've watched an entire trilogy.
It feels only half thought through--funny but stretching one joke far beyond the breaking point.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It may be slightly sentimental and melodramatic, but it also says something new and important.
A sharply clever script, witty direction and terrific performances across the board.
This raw and grisly film keeps the tension levels fairly high, even if it is thoroughly predictable.
Harrowing and strongly moving, this junkie drama beautifully explores the emotional core of its characters. It helps, of course, that the cast is this good.
Enough entertaining dialog and performances to keep us chuckling, even though it's not particularly clever.
So factual and earnest that it misses the chance to say something meaningful.
Meadows brings together the various elements perfectly, balancing sharp social commentary with realistic wit and humour.
This is gripping, moving and extremely thoughtful filmmaking.
A true story from apartheid-era South Africa, this moving and inspiring story has a heavy contemporary resonance.
The characters are vivid and often hilariously revolting.... Visually, the film is absolutely gorgeous.
Sprawling and fragmented, this multi-strand film comes together with a surprising punch in the end.
Tells a complex story from three perspectives, and has something important to say about one of the UK's hottest topics.
Witty dialog and a strong story keep it thoroughly entertaining, as do the sparky performances.
Iñárritu and Arriaga continue their three-pronged approach with this powerfully moving drama.
The cast just about escapes with its dignity after this derivative, predictable urban thriller.
A remarkably involving film--compelling and revolting in equal measure.
These are themes that everyone can identify with, especially when they're expressed with such intelligence and artistry.
movie_title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Affirms the raw talents of both David Mackenzie (Young Adam) and Jamie Bell (who's come a long way since Billy Elliot).
Despite a glacial exterior, this fine film holds us in its relentless grip.
A collage of emotions, shifting through scenes that are happy, silly, angry, sexy, even sad.
Subtle and off-handed, gentle and relaxed, and utterly hysterical.
Moody and rather pretentious, this drama at least has a handful of intriguing characters to keep our interest.
Greengrass maintains the edgy energy he injected into part two to give us the summer's most intelligent, satisfying blockbuster.
A gentle, self-contained drama about confronting uncomfortable truths.
Even though the story goes bonkers at the end, this teen thriller keeps us entertained--and on the edge of our seats.
The filmmakers have gone below the lowest common denominator, aiming a teenage story at 8-year-old girls. It's clunky, condescending and insulting.
Cast and crew maintain an engagingly snarky tone throughout the film, with raucous dialog and a gleeful willingness to crush teen movie stereotypes.
An astounding cast and high production values make this film worth seeing, even as turns into a girly melodrama.
An expansive visual style that makes it worth seeing on the big screen, even if the story feels like a specially extended episode.

A slick, sludgy, romanticised love story that's only livened up by a another wonderfully grounded performance by Breslin.

A blast of fresh air, from the vivid sets and costumes to witty directorial touches, funny cameos and spectacularly enjoyable production numbers.

It's thoroughly crowd-pleasing, although it's weakened by a relentlessly earnest tone.
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A fiercely personal and yet engaging--and often outright hysterical--look into a young man on the brink of adulthood.
Works beautifully both as an intensely personal family history and as an intriguing comment on today's global culture.
[In Death Proof, Tarantino] gleefully subverts the genre to keep us thoroughly entertained.
The strong performances and sharp dialog more than make up for some corny effects.
This modern-day Australian adaptation of the Scottish play is thrillingly deranged, although it's also rather pretentious.
It's one of the most astonishing, energetic, chaotic films you'll ever see. And best of all, it could make you decide to give up the diet forever.
While this film is rather talky and a long, it's also a wonderfully complex blend of wit and cheekiness, underscored by a surprisingly serious romance and a steely view of the battle of the sexes.
A strange concoction that will thoroughly entrance some fans while boring others silly.
It's a brilliantly well-made film that will thoroughly entertain fans of arthouse cinema. Although it's not for the faint-hearted.
movie_title: Je t'aime moi non plus (I Love You, I Don't) (1976)

movie_review_blurb: Warm and wry, funny and sad, cute and complicated.

It's overlong and repetitive, but it impressively gives us a full-bodied portrait of the icon.
Miller delivers her strongest yet performance in this offbeat black comedy, which [is] intriguing, but a little draggy.
So ridiculously over-the-top that it's best viewed as a wacky spoof.
Has a dark edge that's extremely well-developed by director Mangold, plus layered acting by Bale and Crowe.
This is a lovely little film about discovering your inner self, the passion that drives you, and then coming out with it.
Goofy overstatement, improbable plotting and an overwrought finale.
A skilful directorial touch and a refreshingly smart script. And the acting is good enough to carry us through the slightly dull patches.

Until it shifts into a thriller, this film is a provocatively involving drama

Like The Princess Bride meets Time Bandits with its quirky humour and unashamedly romantic plot.

movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

Pretty agonising, from the misogynist display of female flesh to a truly horrific musical number to the no-longer-amusing closing credits outtakes.

Strains so hard to establish some sort of rough street cred that it ends up feeling artificial.
