Superb acting and a willingness to be completely politically incorrect make the film work brilliantly.
It's still enjoyable, but never as strong as it should be.
Insightful and refreshingly open-handed, this ensemble drama taps into some painfully real emotions while maintaining an enjoyable comical tone.
Technically the film looks a bit like a TV movie ... but that's precisely the point.

First-time filmmaker Johnson intriguingly combines film noir with the American teen drama to create something truly engaging. Besides being almost pathologically gripping, it also redefines both genres in the process.

It plays out in such a shockingly authentic way that we feel like we're right there. And what makes this film vitally important is the way it challenges us to examine ourselves without ever making a big statement.
By keeping the parody and humour so tightly focussed, they've generated more laughter than any other filmmaker this year.
It's entertaining and sweet, and rather annoyingly fake.
This film proves that a superb premise and a terrific ensemble cast aren't enough. Writer-director Traeger simply gets it completely wrong.
Compelling, powerful filmmaking.
An illuminating examination of censorship and sexuality.
Makes up for both its simplistic animation and its similarity to Shrek by cramming the script with riotously funny dialog.
Powerfully authentic, gripping and emotionally shattering.
movie_title: The Wind That Shakes the Barley (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Looks fascinating but never quite springs to life.
Only an Australian could make such a warm, gentle comedy about how death is all around us.
Features strong themes about friendships and growing up. But it never quite gets the tone right.
Yet another trite, gimmicky rom-com.
This is urgent, important stuff that simply can't be ignored--or left to the politicians--any longer.
It fails because it neglects to create characters we care about.
Reunites the stars of Speed for a film that's beautifully shot but about as unspeedy as humanly possible.
A meathead movie with no subtext at all.
movie_title: The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift (2006)

movie_review_blurb: May feel a little aloof and dry, not to mention confusing, but there's a solid resonance within the story.
This is when my job feels like work.
Skilfully captures the most jarring truths of British social relationships ... But it's perhaps too quietly tense and ice cold to ever engage us.
Skilfully filmed but fairly dull, this drama paints a remarkable portrait of life in China's factory towns in the 1980s.
A lack of logic infects this film like a virus.
Solid performances make it work, even if the film seems slightly undernourished.
There's a raw, edgy power to this documentary, which takes a distinctly positive approach to a difficult situation.
This engaging film wins us over with its sharp humour and surprising warmth. And its brave timeliness.
The animation is jaw-droppingly gorgeous, and the characters are wonderful. But it's kind of odd, really.
For what's essentially a raucous, gross-out comedy, this is a surprisingly tame film.
Clearly, Hollywood was required to release an antichrist fright-fest on 6/6/06, but instead of coming up with something inventive, they pawn off this limp remake.
Undermined by an over-scripted plot and gooey sentiment.
Fast and fairly engaging ... but in the end it feels a bit pointless.
Far more silly than sublime, but it has its moments.
Nicely well-made, although it'll probably only appeal to young girls.
The premise may look like Four Weddings and Love Actually, but this film is really a Christopher Guest-style improvised mock-doc.

Based on the classic series of children's books by Margret and HA Rey, this gently comical animated movie perfectly catches the tone of the adventure tales. It's a charming little film that shouldn't be left to children.
Lively and energetic, and there are some very good performances, but it's rather hard going.
This moody thriller is fairly strong on gothic creepiness, but not so good with actual thrills.
This film looks terrific, and has some wonderfully eye-grabbing sequences.... So it's a pity the story's so bland.
Director Lee uses some very whizzy editing, maintaining our interest over the long running time.
Written, filmed and acted with real beauty and skill. And it has something powerful to say about today's celebrity-obsessed culture.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Based on Monica Ali's bestselling novel, this is an insightful look at a woman searching across cultural barriers for a place to belong. Not only is it a strong story, but it's great to see such an involving film set in London's Asian-Muslim community.
Clearly aiming to be a cult classic, this beautifully produced film never quite manages to grab hold of our imagination
A profoundly honest approach helps this important film go far beyond the headlines to look into a multi-ethnic big-city schoolroom
Even though the film meanders a bit, the skilful direction and camerawork combine with strong acting to create an engaging, insinuating thriller
It's actually an intriguingly level-headed approach to a hugely emotive issue.
Artful and intriguing, but ultimately difficult to connect with
This international conspiracy thriller is like a Robert Ludlum movie without Paul Greengrass
Despite a final surge of romantic sweetness, it's just not funny or engaging
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Most scenes have very little dialog, relying on the expressive faces of the strong cast
Energetic performances and a strong true story lift this rather simplistic movie into something watchable
Besides being hysterically funny it's also an emotional story of two men who find their passion in life and stick with it.
There are a few inspired lines of dialog and a couple of moments where the slapstick actually works, but this sequel to the surprisingly not-awful remake is strictly for kids.
Before giving in to sentiment, the film struggles to make us like this talented man who never quite grew up.
It's gripping and eye-popping, with terrific characters for the cast to sink their teeth into. But also feels rather overwrought.
Although it's not quite as consistently engaging or funny as it could be, this doggy adventure has moments that grab the imagination
Mendes digs into suburban life with a riveting and ultimately stark marital drama.... And it's the terrific acting that keeps us engaged.
Enjoyable and sweetly engaging, but never quite feels honest about its characters or situations.
This orgy of crazed effects, cheap scares and jittery suspense never remotely frightens us
Another astonishing true story gets the Hollywood treatment and ends up being rather flattened in the process
British filmmaker Hopkins throws out the rules and breaks ground with a significant new cinematic storytelling language
Silly beyond reason, it somehow manages to win us over despite our doubts, and by the end we're ashamed that we can't stop giggling.
Bustling and chaotic like most big families, this film really captures the outrageous collision of personalities in any gathering of relatives
movie_title: Un Conte de Noël (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A blast of raw, colourful energy elevates this gritty tale into one of the most enjoyable films of the year
An epic scope weakens what's actually a gritty, intimate drama about survival. But it's a terrific true story.
A lively tone and sharp performances help bring this rather thin comedy to life
An intelligent approach sets this intense drama apart from the crowd, recounting a morally complex story without telling us how to think
This film has a striking structure and powerful performances that bring the story to life and add provocative modern-day parallels.
Without a coherent central tone, this fantasy adventure feels like it drifts all over the place
Balabanov (Brother) writes and directs with an almost unnervingly naturalistic style, loading each scene with pitch-black humour
Full of intriguing details about Queen Victoria's early reign, although it only lightly examines the political intrigue and romantic melodrama
Even as a documentary, this is one of the most audacious and energetic films of the year
movie_title: Not Quite Hollywood: The Wild, Untold Story of Ozploitation! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Fully inhabits the Trek universe while pushing well-known characters into all-new directions
With his usual themes of memory and technology, Egoyan tells a provocative and deeply emotional story that centres on current issues. It's a little heavy handed, but still thoroughly involving.
It's a great-looking, action-packed adventure weakened by a superficial script that ignores logic whenever it's inconvenient.
A Tale of Two Sisters creates a strong atmosphere of mystery, but never quite manages to fool us with all of the red herrings along the way.
Filmmaker Daryl Wein throws us into the epicentre of this period, when three men matter-of-factly said the unthinkable
What's amazing about this loud, lazy film (they couldn't even be bothered to give it a title) is that it's still entertaining
Sorrentino brings a turbulent period in Italian politics to vivid life. Unfortunately, there's far too much on screen for it to make sense to anyone but a history student
Despite the predictable body-shifting premise and a heavy dose of sentimentality, this teen comedy is extremely enjoyable
The harrowing true story of a man caught in an impossible situation, this film gives intriguing insight into the Troubles in Northern Ireland. But as a movie, it's a bit hard to grab onto.

Starting with a pretty funny script, writer-director Hamburg lets his cast have a free hand with their characters, and the improvisational atmosphere is what makes this male-bonding comedy thoroughly engaging.
A quietly contemplative film about a man looking back on his life, this funny and heartbreaking film features several surprising twists that make it well worth a look.

It's a stroke of genius to play a tense political thriller as if it's a raucous satire. Slicing straight through any over-seriousness, this film keeps us laughing loudly as it tells a story that's probably far truer than we'd like to believe.
With very few words, it really gets under our skin
Seth Rogen's reliable charm finally meets its match in this strained, unfunny script
This completely revamped action movie is enjoyably watchable, even though there's not a moment of suspense in its squeaky clean plot.
This is bold, haunting filmmaking that pulls us all the way in.
The director struggles to inject much energy or spark into the story. Which is frustrating for a premise with this much potential.

Curtis ambitiously stirs action and tragedy into his usual mix of romance, comedy and politics, but the resulting film is all over the place. It looks and sounds great, but none of the elements come together.
A documentary that's definitely not made for true believers; it's clearly aimed at agnostics, atheists and cynics. And it's both intriguingly fair and very entertaining.
With a sharply funny script, vivid characters and eye-popping imagery, this is a raucously enjoyable animated film

A colourful script, gorgeously cinematic direction and blistering central performance by Sheen make this one of the most entertaining biopics in recent memory. And it's definitely not just for football fans.
There's a powerful emotional undertone to this film that overcomes its slightly thin structure and give us plenty to chew on, especially if we've experienced some sort of personal tragedy.

For a documentary, this film isn't remotely balanced, telling the story only through the eyes of the boxer himself, along with historical footage. But it's so expertly assembled that it's absolutely riveting.
A strong story is given weight and meaning by some especially vivid acting, but a too-mainstream approach to the edgy subject matter leaves the film feeling oddly flat.
Seductive and playful, this corporate espionage thriller has a breezy attitude that keeps us thoroughly engaged through all of the twists and turns of the plot.
Simply isn't smart or funny enough be a cult classic.
This isn't gritty realism; it's a morality tale, and it's made with quiet passion and real power
Based on the Neil Gaiman book, this is another refreshingly dark kids' movie from Selick that never undermines its creepy story to assure undemanding audience members. And it looks utterly fantastic.
This lean, mean British horror is just gonzo enough to overcome the limits of the formula and keep us entertained
Confident filmmaking, a fiercely clever script and a gifted cast wonderfully bring this set of complex characters to life
Quite possibly the first-ever feature animated documentary, this strong story of war and memory from Israel is essential viewing for anyone interested in film. Or in the Middle East.

While this film's themes seem to address issues of terrorism and CIA meddling, and the powerful cast suggests we're in Important Movie territory, the result is essentially just a routine spy thriller: entertaining but forgettable.
Disarmingly likeable characters and a genuinely engaging story set this gross-out romp apart from other Apatow-style adult comedies

Loud and completely devoid of wit or interest, this empty-headed action movie looks terrific thanks to its big budget and heavily stylised visuals. But it's impossible to care about anything that happens.

Pumped with energy and authenticity, this film recounts the tumultuous events in 1960s and 70s Germany with vivid detail and an involving cast of characters. It's breathtaking filmmaking, in every sense of the word.
movie_title: Der Baader Meinhof Komplex (The Baader Meinhof Complex) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: With World Trade Center and this film, it's clear that Oliver Stone has lost his provocative maverick sensibilities. This is a smartly assembled biopic with a powerhouse cast, but its toothless approach makes it feel a bit pointless.

There are several intriguing themes gurgling around this comical drama, but it's so rambling and loose that nothing really comes together. Even so, the solid acting keeps us interested, and the potent issues keep us thinking.
movie_title: Let it Rain (Parlez-moi de la pluie) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Snappy and enjoyable, this British class comedy has enough spark to keep us entertained, even though the plot never quite shifts up to full speed. But a few terrific performances make it well worth seeing.
Even with his weaker movies, Woody Allen is more astute than about 80 percent of filmmakers out there.
The tone is too uneven for us to get on board. And there are a couple of major plot points that are badly mishandled, leaving us feeling cheated.

But it maintains its connection with us through Williams' fiercely open-hearted portrayal of a woman losing her grip on her life. And this is just emotional and offbeat enough to make the film worth a look.
Yes, it's extremely choppy and not terribly well-developed, with characters appearing and disappearing at random. But the fights are so impressive that we can't help but be thoroughly entertained.
An intriguingly internalised central plot and outrageously exhilarating action

Korean filmmaker Won uses a startlingly in-your-face style for this outrageous examination of bullying at all kinds of levels. Both unsettling and entertaining, it also finds real terror and black humour in the least likely places.
All of the actors clearly relish the film's fast and busy pace, smart dialog and vivid characterisations.
A lyrical poem about his hometown, this is Davies' first movie in eight years. And his artistic approach gives us a moving, kaleidoscopic portrait both of a city and of the filmmaker himself.
Depp's staggering performance perfectly merges the story's humour, horror and romance into a serious punch to the gut.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Essentially a Will Ferrell Lite movie, this toothless comedy has a likeable central performance from Rainn Wilson and several hilariously spiky side characters. But it never quite hits its comical stride.
One of the most gripping and entertaining political dramas in recent memory.
Rather too hysterical to be coherent, but it's still jittery and thoroughly unnerving
There's a sublimely goofy tone to this profoundly inept film that keeps us smiling from start to finish
This lively comedy feels like about half a movie, as the inventive Borat-like hilarity runs out of steam after about an hour
A cheesy attempt to throw everything at the screen, this futuristic thriller would no doubt work much better as a videogame
It's an engaging story with strong characters that keep our interest even with the slightly too-fantastical design and under-explained script.
Makes up for its simplistic story with some demented humour
A low-key comedy with a high-powered cast ... it's a bit too mannered, but it's also thoroughly hilarious
Completely lacking a plot or actual characters, this colourful film is more like a musical revue about a sanitised, fantasy version of high school. It's lively and watchable, but painfully vacuous.
Eastwood directs and acts with remarkable restraint, skilfully getting far beneath the surface
Stronger animation and a textured story make this even more entertaining than the original
Van Sant may be preaching to the choir, but this is relevant, powerful filmmaking.
This screen adaptation of Will Eisner's beloved comic books is intriguing enough to be watchable, but is so chaotic that it doesn't work at all
A thoroughly engaging, slightly offbeat adventure with solid themes running through it
As the convoluted structure finally reveals the actual plot, it brings with it the unmistakable whiff of a vanity project
The central theme of this rather over-egged comedy is strong enough to keep us interested. Although the film itself is far too corny

The script for this childish comedy is genuinely witty, and nicely played by the cast, but it would have been much more enjoyable if the plot had been a bit more innovative. Or if it actually went somewhere.
Even if it's a bit mannered and over-constructed, there's plenty in here to get us thinking
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Based on a true story, this rousing caper adventure can't help but keep audiences engaged. It's an efficiently made, if not particularly inventive, old-style romp that works away at your cynicism until you find a lump in your throat.
With a wealth of archive material, documentary filmmaker Gibney assembles a remarkably astute and comprehensive look at the life of one of the most notorious journalists in American history.
movie_title: Gonzo: The Life and Work of Hunter S. Thompson (2008)

movie_review_blurb: In addition to the pungent writing and direction, the film features a truly stunning performance from Rourke
This involving film is weakened by a script that tries to create a formulaic thriller out of an important subject matter.
Veteran director Yamada continues to examine issues of duty and loyalty, sharply using matter-of-fact period detail and deep characterisations.
It's not easy to make a personal drama in Israel that doesn't quickly become overwhelmed in politics, but this film cleverly balances both elements.
A powerful true story makes this film worth seeing ... but Eastwood chooses to tell this as an over-produced, over-wrought melodrama.
This remake of the 1951 favourite is oddly botched, trying to combine some timely themes with the structure of a more conventional action thriller.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This lively animated adventure keeps us entertained even if the story and characters aren't particularly well-developed
A beautiful performance from Michelle Williams anchors this gentle examination of modern life
Besson and Kamen somehow make a film that's even dumber than part 2.... But they've still got the superbly watchable Statham at the centre, so the script is fairly irrelevant.
While this film is every bit as warm and emotional as it looks, ... the cast make sure things don't get too sugary.

Gritty and tough, this period thriller about brothers on opposite sides of the law has remarkably complex characters and a vivid sense of style. Despite a choppy approach, it really grapples with some strong moral dilemmas.
This straightforward crazed-madman thriller is trying to pass itself off as an insightful look at racial tension, but it's simply not strong enough to pull off the trick.

Taken from his own memoirs, Linson's screenplay has a zing of truth as it cuts through the layers of Hollywood mayhem to tell a thoroughly hilarious and surprisingly involving story of a man on the edge of a nervous breakdown.

The Dardenne brothers bring their straightforward realism to this haunting story set in a shady world where marriage is exchanged for European citizenship. But in the end, the story's too bleak to coalesce into something important.
Terrific performances elevate this extremely low-key heist thriller into something thoroughly intriguing. It may never crank up much excitement, but the 1960s vibe it generates is very cool.
This film is too fragmented to ever come together. Although terrific actors and some serious subtext make it enjoyable.
In the final act, an undercooked thriller plot threatens to take over, but is held in check to offer a more resonant kick
A riveting, harrowing true story that forces us to examine exactly what's involved in putting your life on the line for a cause
Luhrmann shamelessly indulges in the most sweeping style of filmmaking imaginable, filling the screen with expansive images, action and emotion, plus plenty of cheesy camp
Technically, the film is spotless, with gorgeous cinematography, colourful costumes, detailed sets and a marvellous Alexandre Desplat score.
Shying away from the big issue, Morrison leaves us feeling oddly removed from what is otherwise a beautiful, heartbreaking story.
This is a warm and very funny film that completely wins us over as it progresses.

This is an ambitious attempt to tell the story of World War I's most notorious fighter pilot. But while the events are truly momentous, with thrillingly rendered aerial combat, the film is let down by lacklustre writing and direction.

Clearly designed to give credit where it's due, this film spotlights the guys who broke new ground to create modern surfing. But while it's an important, interesting document, it's rather too detailed for non-surfers.

Shot like a doc but clearly dramatised, this British film about a rentboy is colourfully entertaining, and it definitely has its moments. But it also becomes preachy as it goes on, and struggles to keep its central character engaging.

With a relentless pace and seamless effects, this offbeat alien invasion thriller combines non-stop action with real emotion and provocative political themes. So not only is it thunderously entertaining, but it also makes us think.
This is one of the most entertaining, riveting docs you'll ever see.
A film that often makes us flinch from the screen, mainly because of a superbly layered performance by Renner.
Despite this film's sharp dialog and terrific story, its bloated, undisciplined editing keeps it from being a classic.

With a plot that's virtually identical to parts 1, 2 and 3, this fourth movie has one new gimmick that makes it worth a look: it's in 3D. And the filmmakers have a lot of fun with it, gleefully revving up the grisly carnage.
Perhaps not as dazzling as Almodovar's masterpieces, this film is still an involving and sleekly well-made melodrama.
Something more than just a thriller - a film as accurate and hard-nosed as it needs to be.
This is a thoughtful and provocative film unlike anything we've seen. It's also vitally important.
Even though it's long and indulgent, this is a deeply entertaining romp, crafted to perfection by Tarantino and his amazing cast.

Polish filmmaker Jakimowski taps into his own childhood for this engaging and warmly authentic slice of life drama. Blending comedy and a hint of magical realism, this beautiful little film really gets under the skin.
This pastiche never manages to find an actual joke. We're left with a painfully convoluted non-plot trying to link together a series of lead-ins to never-realised punchlines.
This drama shows the growing skill of 25-year-old writer-director-editor Campos. It's also packed with important themes that are addressed both artfully and hauntingly.
Based on the life of actor George Hamilton, this lively film is enjoyable but rather slight.

Scruffy and twisty, this honeymoon-from-hell thriller kind of unravels as it goes along. But before it succumbs to the formula, the actors manage to catch our attention, so we have to see it through to what'll surely be an outrageous finale.
Yet another example of a movie that's had all the life sucked out of it by the Hollywood studio system. In the end it isn't very funny, clever or engaging.
A thoroughly engaging film. The heavy emotional tone makes it feel a bit girly, but it's still a terrific story.
Gorgeously shot and edited, and performed with a gentle emotional openness, this gritty odyssey tells a deeply personal story while examining much bigger issues in Central America and beyond.

This warm Italian comedy takes a look at generational issues without getting preachy about it. Filmmaker-actor Di Gregorio's almost fly-on-the-wall style continually catches us off guard with its humour and insight.

High energy levels and some genuinely hilarious set pieces make this kids' alien-invasion romp a lot more fun than expected. It's not, erm, rocket science, but it's a thoroughly entertaining ride from start to finish.
Not only is it charming and funny, but it takes a strikingly original approach that leaves a big, stupid grin on your face
Graff ... stirs in some terrific moments along the way that subvert the genre just a little bit.
It's a thoughtful, moving look at childbirth, beautifully shot and edited, and sharply played by the cast
The filmmakers have harvested the coolest elements from blockbusters over the past five or six years
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This hyperactive adventure may keep children giggling at the sheer chaos on screen, but it'll wear out older viewers looking for something that actually holds the attention.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Richet recreates the period with a remarkable attention to detail, using coarse touches to ground the chaotic shootouts and heists in reality.
This film is too bland to catch our imagination. There are plenty of cheap thrills, plus some camp excess to keep us laughing, but it's never scary.

Ephron reunites with Streep for this slightly overlong and very girly drama based on two true stories, both of which are involving and well-played. The comedy is earthy and real, and the film looks good enough to eat.
Even MTV knows to use seasick camerawork, jagged cutting and colour/monochrome shifts sparingly.

Artistic and insightful, this sharply well-made film has an emotional resonance that becomes thoroughly haunting as the story travels to places we don't expect it to go. A sense of foreboding terror keeps us gripped, as does an underlying hope.
There are frequent pangs of sadness throughout the film that beautifully balance both the adrenaline-charged action and broad comedy. This keeps both our hearts and minds involved with the story.
Another dark, gloomy drama about home life during wartime, this film features some seriously great performances and a theme that will resonate powerfully with thoughtful audiences.
If anything, it feels even fresher, funnier and more thrilling in today's landscape of over-studied demographically correct moviemaking.

Varda brings a playful attitude to this whimsical stroll through her life, telling stories and showing photos and clips that chronicle both her career and her personal life. It meanders a bit, but it's also thoroughly engaging.
movie_title: Les Plages d'Agnès (The Beaches of Agnes) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A terrific true story, clearly elevated to mythical proportions, this film benefits hugely from the lucid fight direction by the master Sammo Hung, which gives the film a remarkable resonance.

Luc Besson and pals are back with another crazed action movie that, despite its ludicrous plotting, keeps us entertained with sheer energy and wit. And the central duo is turning into a pretty good movie team.

A vivid example of style over substance, this textured film creates an overwhelming sense of emotion and dread, but never manages to find a point to it all. It merely gives into the grisliness, leaving us shaken and unstirred.

An appalling script is only one problem with this loud, chaotic sci-fi thriller. It's also directed in such a deliberately confusing way that it's not only impossible to follow the action, but it's impossible to care about the characters.
There are plenty of solid laughs along the way, but Gervais should have been much bolder with the idea.
Without any real depth, the whole thing feels somewhat pointless.

Oscar Wilde's classic novel is turned into a schlock horror movie, totally engulfed by gloomy atmosphere and over-the-top filmmaking. It's watchably cheesy, but completely lacks Wilde's incisive wit or observation.

While there are some witty observations along the way, this tourism rom-com is so resolutely unromantic and unfunny that it feels like a package holiday during which you have to share a hotel room with the group clown.

A genuinely moving story is wrung dry by filmmaking that strains to punch every emotional plot point. Solid performances and some edgy insight can't quite rescue it, although the extraordinary true events retain real power.
Gentle and very sweet, this low-key romance takes some rather random turns as it drifts toward the obvious conclusion. But it's very nicely played, and it still manages to catch us emotionally.
The filmmakers offer a fresh angle on a controversial topic. And it's an imaginative, human approach that brings it vividly to life.
[An] ambitious multi-generational epic that, even at three hours, feels too brisk. We actually want more time with these fascinating people.
Even though it gets a little earnest, this well-assembled film is entertaining, lively and packed with scenes and details we've never heard before.

Beautifully shot and performed with the authenticity of a documentary, this involving drama has a lot to say about human progress in rural Brazil, although its off-handed story and slow pace might alienate some audiences.
movie_title: BirdWatchers - La terra degli uomini rossi (2008)

movie_review_blurb: It's sweet and superficial, but the meandering pace and lively characters make it just about watchable.
The film is a cacophonous mess without a single interesting character.
This film wavers between a sweet rom-com, a gross-out romp and a drama about diversity. Thanks to a strong cast, these three elements work on their own, but struggle to make much sense together.
Darker, more complex and less prone to the cutesy wow-factor, this is a gripping tale with a thoughtful message.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This colourful animated feature underscores its fantastical story with some intriguingly serious issues. But it never gets preachy, and a stream of warped humour will keep adults chuckling all the way through.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Locally produced in Bristol with an up-and-coming cast and crew, this drama is remarkably tough, constantly challenging our preconceptions. It also transcends its budget to create interesting characters and some truly harrowing situations.
Loosely based on a real person, this unhinged drama gets increasingly lurid and grisly as it progresses. It's riveting, inventive filmmaking, but not remotely easy to watch.
With a riveting performance by Cassel at the centre, it's definitely worth seeing, even if it never really gets beneath the skin.
movie_title: Mesrine: Part 1 (Killer Instinct) and Part 2 (Public Enemy #1) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: So simplistically done that it makes you feel like you could make a better movie than this on your home computer
Tony Scott indulges in his usual flashy pyrotechnics, which almost cover up the gaping craters in the plot.
This gentle romance is so wilfully quirky that it will drive some audiences a bit crazy. But if you can connect to the film's warmth and the humanity of its characters, it really gets under the skin.

John Woo applies his whizzing, sweeping visual style to Chinese history, making this film one of the most hugely entertaining battle epics in recent memory. Utterly riveting, we barely feel two and a half hours pass.
Brutal and contrived, this Scottish thriller just makes too little sense to hold our attention. It may be filmed with a lot of style, but it's also pretentious, full of cliches and nearly deafening.
It's far too cheesy to be either scary or funny.
An unusually warm, funny and slightly surreal drama about a man rediscovering himself. Even a rather overwrought plot can't undermine the engaging characters and insightful observations.

It's not very sophisticated, but this raucous comedy keeps us laughing with its sheer absurdity. The characters are very well-played and their interaction is genuinely hilarious, even if most of the jokes are pretty cheap.
Moon really gets under the skin as it probes the nature of humanity while keeping us on the edge of our seats.
A powerfully engaging coming-of-age immigration sports documentary-style drama. And this unpredictable genre mash-up is pure magic.
Even though it's sometimes picturesque and involving, it's also so achingly slow and indulgent that it will test even the most patient viewers.
Tense and brainy. And thoroughly entertaining.
Bruce Weber's distinct photographic style shines in this artful, offbeat documentary that on the surface is about a boxing coach, but observes much bigger issues along the way
Watching these scenes, which the leaders want to hide from the world, is pretty horrific. And the bravery of these young journalists is seriously inspirational
movie_title: Burma VJ: Reporter i et Lukket Land (Burma VJ: Reporting from a Closed Country) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Impeccably shot and edited, this harrowing drama digs into the mystery of the murder of some 12,000 Polish officers in the early 1940s, which the Soviets falsely blamed on the Nazis. It's extremely grim, but well worth seeing.
A watchable pastiche of A Christmas Carol, this rom-com resorts to corny slapstick a bit too often but also manages to find moments of real resonance
The film is so relentlessly fun that we're powerless to resist.
Doesn't really have a plot, but it cleverly traces the interrelationships in a family over several years, and really gets under the skin
So hammy and overwrought that it's actually hysterically entertaining.
Perhaps too slow-paced for mainstream audiences, but patient viewers will love the way filmmaker Troell looks at the world.
movie_title: Maria Larssons eviga ögonblick (Everlasting Moments) (Maria Larsson's Everlasting Moment) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: An intriguing blend of documentary, fiction and fantasy ... it's not an easy movie, but adventurous audiences will love it.
There's a slightly out-of-control atmosphere that makes this corny romp much more entertaining than the original
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Even if the plot is pretty simple, the characters and dialog are lively and unpredictable. And the cast really goes for it.
The problem is that, even with some very strong acting, we're never quite convinced to believe either the relationships or situations.
Thankfully the filmmakers get the tone right this time, with a lively romp that's not afraid to get a bit silly.

As a writer, Kaufman has used surrealism to humorously examine humanity. And now as a director he goes even further, creating something that feels like Woody Allen crossed with David Lynch. It's funny and emotional, but also impenetrable.
Witty and wilfully wacky, this offbeat adventure is good fun to watch, even if we can never quite get in sync with its peculiar rhythms.
This romantic pastiche is rather uneven and corny, but is packed with characters who are thoroughly intriguing. We may not like them very much, but we recognise ourselves in there.
Essentially everything here is macho-posturing eye candy.
In linking the legendary 1974 Rumble in the Jungle with the music festival that ran alongside it, we get a remarkable glimpse of the day's racial and political issues.
Quirky and cute almost to the point of distraction, the offbeat romance is only rescued by its likeable cast and an intriguing storyline
The people around Wintour are so colourful that we never want it to end.
This rollicking action romp has all of the chase scenes and car crashes you expect from a Jerry Bruckheimer movie
The film is well-made and benefits from a very strong cast, but it's both overly worthy and rather pushy about its perspective.
Skilfully and beautifully filmed and acted.
An almost unnervingly naturalistic look at a teen's life, anchored by a fierce central performance
A bloated action sequel so packed with special effects that it's virtually a cartoon
A remarkably engaging, observant approach to a prickly situation
Worms its way under our skin from the start, keeping us laughing as it explores love and relationships from a strikingly original angle
An entertaining addition to the evil child genre, simply for its over-the-top chills and nutty plot
While the cast is watchable, the film simply has nothing original to say.
Even though it's sometimes contrived, it's utterly gripping.
movie_title: Kærlighed på Film (Just Another Love Story) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The expert direction, editing and photography are all here, along with two amazing performances. But this warped Adam and Eve myth is seriously hard to stomach.
As brightly enjoyable as this film is, there's no escaping the fact that it's yet another formulaic rom-com.
Just too random and silly to make any sense at all. Although there are a few laughs along the way
Both sweet and tough, with vivid characters and an unnerving sense of danger.
The surprising twists and turns in the final act are both powerful and haunting.
Watching people live such vacuous, clone-like lives of privilege and decadence, it's impossible to feel anything for them.
Well-made and watchable, but feels like an intake of breath before the frantic finale.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This crotchety comedy generates consistent laughs through its sarcastic nihilism and colourful characters
A dark, grown-up story about an extraordinary friendship over 20 years
As a more emotional take on the themes examined in American Beauty, this internalised drama is subtle and unpredictable.
movie_title: The Private Lives of Pippa Lee (2009)

movie_review_blurb: As an anthropological document, this film has huge value for examining a form of music that's usually ridiculed.... Sadly, the film isn't sharp enough to win over many new fans.
Denis uses her typically moody, vague style to explore multicultural France with dark humour and warm emotion.
Baron Cohen is an astonishingly focussed performer; we have no idea how he doesn't crack a smile.
Broad and very silly, this comedy just about keeps us chuckling even when things get stupid and predictable
Mann approaches this film almost like poetry, using fine camerawork and editing to focus on internal emotions
The filmmakers and cast find a few great laughs in this flimsy premise, but the whole film is so underdeveloped that it hardly seems to be up there on screen at all.

A slightly more adventurous story breaks the trequel curse: this film is actually better than its predecessors. In addition to astoundingly eye-catching animation, this one also has a driving (albeit corny) narrative and some snappy new characters.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: This involving movie ultimately succumbs to a severe case of the weepies, as we know it must
Keeps our attention all the way through, even as the plot gets increasingly preposterous
Demme turns to Dogme-style filmmaking with this intimate family drama that's both funny and harrowing

A harrowing apocalyptic fable made with skill and invention, this film is so packed with ideas that it's nearly overpowering. And this depth and relevance makes up for the somewhat over-egged filmmaking.
Slightly too understated, but also thoroughly involving.
Cynics might find it precious, but open-hearted audiences will love it.
Washington punches every emotional and thematic point in Eisele's script, which undermines the raw power of the story.
It's easy to forget this is a documentary. The central character wouldn't seem out of place in almost any British crime drama--he'd actually liven most of them up.
Exciting and entertaining, although the complicated array of characters makes it sometimes hard-going.
Far too bookish and strange to fully engage us. But it looks terrific.

A sharply clever script and relentlessly kinetic structure keep us thoroughly entertained all the way through this corny zombie action-comedy. Although there's also the gnawing realisation that there's absolutely no subtext at all.
Adapted for the screen with sensitivity by Benioff and Forster, drawing raw performances from the cast.
At least this film, based on classic characters, is bright and energetic, because it's otherwise condescending, corny and utterly unfunny.
The demands of 21st century Hollywood strain the story. It's big and exciting, but not very smart.
A bit po-faced and unremarkable; more outrageousness and humour would have helped.
At age 83, Lumet proves he's at the top of his game with this expertly directed melodramatic thriller, relentlessly teasing us with a twisty story and provocative characters.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This operatic drama rivets us to the seat from the wordless opening reel and never lets us go.
The Coens load the film with realistic touches that add grit and meaning to the almost mythical plot.
It's a little sentimental, and the finale feels rushed, but along the way it's great fun.
Enjoyable fun even if it's not particularly original.
Digs into modern life in some very interesting ways, even though it's not always easy to see the point of it all.
With an almost Donnie Darko sense of apocalyptic mystery, writer-director August really gets our heads spinning.
What starts as a sensitive, involving drama about grief and guilt annoyingly degenerates into a trite thriller.
It's probably impossible to ever really understand what [Korine] is on about, but there are some accomplished sequences and terrific performances along the way.
The freaky finale kind of undermines any sympathy we might have built up, but it adds a level of classical storytelling that makes the film feel utterly timeless.
Douglas addresses rather serious issues with warmth and humour in this engaging football comedy, which doesn't actually show much football action.
DePalma takes a storytelling approach that's both utterly unlike anything he's ever done and remarkably effective at telling this particular story.
The film gets a little heavy handed, but it's an important message.
There's enough happening here to fuel an entire TV series, with melodramatic excesses, wild mood swings and sitcom-style slapstick.
The epic poem is brought entertainingly to life by an extremely gifted cast and crew. Although the motion-capture animation style leaves us with a couple of big questions. Mainly, 'Why?'
Knowingly examines romance, parenthood, grief and betrayal, but succumbs slightly to simplistic sentimentality.
Fans of soppy movies will probably love it, but everyone else should steer clear.
This film's sharp and funny script is somewhat undermined by a barrage of American Pie stupidity.
Even if there's nothing new going on here, the style and quality of this film injects a terrific sense of terror into the old monster movie formula.
Silly and sometimes even funny... but by the end, we're still waiting for it to spring to life.
This stoner romp is great farcical fun, even if it never seems to get anywhere.
With a script cut-and-pasted from every other dance movie, this film is shockingly corny.
Even though there's never a hint of either research or gritty realism, it's still good fun.
One of the finest sex-and-politics thrillers ever made, blending sharp humour with riveting suspense.
The cast is fine, clearly enjoying the 70s period and creating characters that are likeable but thin.
It's certainly funny enough for a late-night out, but it's just not nearly as good as die-hard Ferrell fans will think it is.
This film isn't as bracingly vibrant as Fernando Meirelles' City of God (2002), which featured many of the same cast and crew. But it's a grippingly entertaining story.
A jolt of personality and above-average effects make this kids' fantasy adventure entertaining enough to overcome the cliches in its premise.
Even though this film strains to be another Silence of the Lambs (tormented heroine chases nasty killer), it's still oddly involving.
A hodge-podge of random story elements that seem to emerge from the land that logic forgot, including a Bollywood segment.
With a fascinating setting against the momentous 1956 Hungarian revolution, this story keeps our interest even as the filmmakers throw every conceivable movie genre at us.
Despite its standard rom-com structure and relatively superficial story, this film entertains the audience with the sheer charisma of the actors.
The rock mega-band U2 has made so many concert films that it's hard to get excited about this one.... But the film is a revelation, redefining 3D live-action moviemaking.
There's an interesting idea here, showing a major political event from various perspectives until we finally get to the real story. The problem is that the real story is rather contrived.
Despite its almost painfully silly predictability, this film somehow manages to be engaging and rather enjoyable, thanks mainly to The Rock's on-screen charisma.
The teleporting premise is intriguing enough to hold our interest, but the screenwriters never make anything of it, letting the story get increasingly corny.
Despite an extremely uneven style, this modern-day fairy tale has plenty of charm.
It's actually fairly impressive how many cliches the screenwriter can squeeze into the script.
Wong Kar Wai's American debut is as gorgeously filmed as you'd expect, but it's also surprisingly mopey and downbeat for a story about love.
The filmmakers probably thought the truth would be too upsetting for children, so we get walrus farts instead.
An entertaining blend of dark comedy, gruesome suspense and tender emotion
Keeps us entertained with the sheer spectacle of the thing, rather than anything actually interesting.
A scruffy, likeable little comedy, even though it's not actually very funny or involving.
It's unsubtle filmmaking, laying out every nuance for us and playing around with some pretty serious ideas without digging very deep.
Despite a somewhat simplistic view of life ... an engaging examination of two men looking back at their lives without pity or regret.
A riveting depiction of combat-zone terror, this film's main strength is its understatement.
The script is a bit over-packed with secrets and revelations, quirks and wrinkles, but it's so vividly played out that we can't take our eyes off the screen.

The facts in this documentary are astoundingly sobering, and yet society continues to keep its head buried in the sand. By avoiding any political slant, the filmmakers forcefully get the message across.
movie_title: A Crude Awakening: The Oil Crash (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This raucously entertaining documentary about one of the silliest competitions on the planet actually has a serious message about the power of "airness" to change the world. Well, maybe.

This may just be a film of one of Waters' university appearances, but it's thoroughly entertaining as he takes a trip through his own filmography, hilariously revealing all kinds of truths about society along the way.
Gentle humour and earthy emotion give this film a wonderfully relaxed tone that astutely captures our imagination.
Insinuating and extremely clever, this insightful, low-key thriller takes a provocative look into the life of a man whose world begins to unravel around him.
Lively and watchable, but never as funny or astute as it should be.
While it's quirky and intriguing, this is the kind of wilfully nutty black comedy that treads the extremely thin line between inventiveness and pretentiousness.
South African director Hood (Tsotsi) turns what could have been yet another Hollywood potboiler into an edgy dramatic thriller.
Skilfully written and directed, the film is an involving drama, even if it's overly worthy and sentimental.
This is a beautifully made, involving film, but it would have been so much stronger with a bit of careful editing.
Has a strong story and engaging characters, even if it never really says anything terribly deep or meaningful.
Tricky and insinuating, this German drama has the subtle subtext of a thriller as it follows a woman caught at a crossroads in her life. It's a little aloof and dry, but very well made.
As lively as a slap in the face, this film struggles to connect with us due to an extremely unsympathetic central figure, but still wins us over with strong acting and a sweet romance.
Energetic and entertaining, but it's like a long episode of an over-talky, out-of-control soap opera.
The exquisite images are continually underscored with an almost Lynchian creepiness.
While playing by the rules--scantily clad women, sudden brutality, straightforward narrative--he also gleefully subverts the genre to keep us thoroughly entertained.
Berg struggles to blend rah-rah Top Gun heroics with spiky Bourne-style realism.
There's the germ of an interesting idea here, plus a terrific ensemble cast, but it's reduced down to a predictable story, simplistic script and only adequate direction.
Despite a strong cast, the filmmakers squander a clever premise for a series of unoriginal, cheap jokes.
After the slightly more sophisticated part 2, this episode returns to the more preposterous style of the original.
The playful dialog provides the best laughter, while the big set pieces feel strangely muted

Father and son Georgian filmmakers take an intriguing look at the collision between new and old, east and west in their home country. The film is colourful and almost shockingly vivid, with a refreshingly foreign feel that's thoroughly accessible.
With a strongly emotional tone, this low-key Australian coming-of-age drama is beautifully filmed and acted. Although it does lay on the nostalgia rather thickly.

With a thunderous pace and an outrageous level of violence and mayhem, this film blasts its way onto the screen, as the title suggests, dragging its reluctant hero into a series of increasingly ludicrous set pieces.
It's the sharp acting that almost makes us forget the over-familiar storyline.
A slow-burning thriller with an intriguing mystery at its centre, this film's tone is reminiscent of The Third Man, although updated to make some extremely provocative suggestions.
movie_title: A Few Days in September (Quelques jours en septembre) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The creepy child genre hasn't had a movie this much fun in a long time.
With a smart script, sure-handed direction and strongly internalised performances, this film astutely blends a personal drama with a revenge thriller.
The script focuses more on its over-egged punchlines than any genuine attempt to tell a story that might amuse us. And it feels like a one-gag sketch stretched beyond the breaking point.
The performances are great, but in the end it's far too simplistic.
This jet-black comedy has a surprising sweetness that counter-balances the story's profoundly disgusting plot points.
Entertaining and engaging, and also deliberately strange.
This wry, quiet comedy takes an enjoyably askance look at Israeli-Arab relations, using a small, gentle story to say something extremely profound.
Geysers of blood, insinuating camera angles and an extremely playful editing style add to the mayhem, keeping us gasping in horror and laughing at the gleeful excesses on screen.
movie_title: Planet Terror (Grindhouse Presents: Robert Rodriguez's Planet Terror) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Throughout the overlong running time, Suo keeps us gripped with a witty, insightful approach.
movie_title: I Just Didn't Do It (Soredemo boku wa yattenai) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Impeccable production design and searing performances. But the tale unfolds in a superficial way that makes it impossible to care about what might happen.
Combines a topical storyline with a thoroughly involving examination of grief that's never remotely maudlin or sentimental.
Overall, the film is freaky and gruesome enough to keep horror fans thrilled, especially as the monsters get stronger, faster, badder and nuttier.
As a whole, the film feels both too earnest and overly simplistic in its approach to the various moral dilemmas.
Lively and colourful, and also a little contrived. But it features a strikingly engaging performance from Tate.
This film has plenty of strong performances and provocative themes, but is too episodic to come together.
Danish director Bier focuses on themes and relationships in what's otherwise a rather contrived melodrama.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This witty romantic romp playfully spins its story with the required cuteness constantly subverted by a very sharp script.
An engaging portrait of a man who claims to eschew self-analysis and nostalgia, even as these are clearly his stock in trade.
An engaging, extremely well shot and edited film that draws on humour and irony to stir simple outrage.
There's a wonderfully adventurous tone to this Bob Dylan biopic that keeps us utterly gripped, even though it's hard to get a grip on.
This comedy about teen pregnancy is extremely entertaining, packed with dialog that's rather too smart and snappy.
Watchable but unnecessary.
Haggis draws sensitive performances from his cast while asking provocative, important questions.
The self-reflection is powerfully honest, and the landscapes are genuinely spectacular.
Linney and Hoffman deliver two more creatively textured performances in this story about the strain and comfort of family relationships.
Far more than another Holocaust drama; it's an examination of complex moral shadows that make us capable of cowardice and courage at the same time.
A raucously hysterical romp by some seriously twisted filmmakers.
Combining vivid characters with a fresh story, this is one of Pixar's best films yet.
It's great that scientists who have found so many fossils can piece it together in a way that's this entertaining.
One of those sniggering French farces that implies a lot of naughtiness but doesn't deliver much. On the other hand, it is rather a lot of fun.
It's not hysterically funny, but this British comedy is sharp enough to keep us chuckling right to the predictably sappy conclusion.
Emphasises the costumes, hair and sets over historical accuracy and depth of character. But it's still hugely entertaining.
Directed by Branagh as a stylish, nasty tug of war. But it's also murky and overwrought.
Has the ability to catch us off guard and make us think.
An intriguing setting and several witty, inventive directorial touches raise this above the average Hong Kong gangster thriller.
Probably not to everyone's taste ... but the lyrical filmmaking beautifully captures the elusive complexity of love.
With a sensitive, intelligent screenplay and extremely honest performances, this drama goes far beyond its issue-of-the-week premise.
Has some seriously haunting themes torn right from the headlines, giving us something thoughtful to chew on. Besides our fingernails.
Has riveting parallels with much more recent British royal family history. It's also an entertaining, emotional drama.
The style and energy, plus the terrifically memorable characters, make it mindlessly good fun.
Too surreal and symbolic to fully connect with mainstream cinema audiences, but lovers of challenging festival films will be captivated
Sporadically funny, and ridiculous enough to keep some fans happy ... but even a solid cast can't sustain one joke this long.
So full of attitude that it fairly leaps off the screen with claws bared
There's an especially important central theme to this striking teen drama that gives the film a potent urgency.
So overwrought and over-serious that it never really engages us, and all of the laughs feel unintentional.
With a surface like a trashy novel and the undercurrents of a social satire, Ozon's British period drama is a slightly odd mix, feeling both arch and astute at the same time.
The film doesn't have the sharp hysteria of the series, and it gets a bit over-serious at times. But it's still a thoroughly entertaining film with terrific characters all its own.
Tackles a serious theme with energy and what sometimes feels like too much hilarity. But as the story deepens, it really gets hold of us.

Sandler prefers to fall back on cartoonish stunt action, sleazy innuendo and bodily fluid gags. These things may satisfy his core fan-base, but everyone else will leave the cinema feeling a bit cheated.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Irrelevant, never-funny references to everything from Juno to American Gladiators
Bright and silly, with just enough wit and intelligence to make it watchable, this British-American teen comedy doesn't break much new ground, but is pretty entertaining while it lasts.
There's not a lot to it really--no deep underlying message other than an exploration of women's roles in society at the time.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Crump's film is a vitally important document in this respect, bringing out Wagstaff's personality and vividly capturing the stories of the people who knew him.
movie_title: Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Gorgeously scenery and a virtually dialog-free script lends this film an almost fairy tale quality that makes the most of the astonishing camerawork. And this almost makes it bearable as it heads into a rather cloying finale.
The moral dilemmas are gripping, but the film takes itself far too seriously to ever connect with us.
This beautifully directed film is packed with serious, provocative themes. But a mopey tone and some wobbly casting undermines the otherwise terrific acting.
It's a shame that the story itself feels like smoke and mirrors with nowhere to go, wanting to have its cake and eat it too.
An important, heart-soaring record of a group of incredibly brave people doing something almost everyone would tell them is impossible.
None of the action sequences generate any excitement at all and the in-between stuff is so wilfully nutty that it falls completely flat.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: After building a jangling sense of terror, Bertino doesn't take it anywhere.
It's like an especially gloomy episode of the series, stretched a bit too long. And we miss the ad breaks.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Silverman's full-on approach works because she unflinchingly examines these themes with a disarming sweetness.

Thought-provoking themes swirl around in this drama, brought to life by a skilled cast and a director who plays with Hitchcockian themes and imagery. In the end, it feels a bit undercooked, but the actors keep us glued to the screen.
With beautifully inventive animation, this latest chapter in George Lucas' saga is a frantic series of action scenes without a heart.

Cleverly assembled like a heist thriller, this film documents the 1974 wire-walking stunt between the twin towers of the World Trade Center. Not only does it have a remarkable resonance seven years after 9/11, but it's a cracking good story.
It's pretty pointless, really, but the characters are so engaging that we can't help but fall for them
Not very easy to follow, but the twists and turns are gripping and emotional
Sometimes a bit hard to stomach, but has such vividly realistic characters and situations that it can't be ignored.
The characters are sharp and their dilemmas feel honest, even if we never get all the information we crave.
Despite some astonishing visual sequences, a flimsy script and frankly awful character design ground this film before it can blast off.
One of the most beautiful things ever put on the big screen. On the other hand, the story is far too thin for adults, and far too dark for kids.
This new version of the Evelyn Waugh tale of conflicts in class, sexuality and religion is more about the sumptuous imagery than the provocative subtext.
The overwrought production, sieve-like plot and ludicrous characters merge into something genuinely hilarious. But that's clearly not what cast and crew were going for.
The filmmakers struggle to find the right tone, opting for wacky slapstick and then corny rom-com when they should have gone for black satire.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Tries to be a big smart action movie even though it's utterly ludicrous.
While it desperately wants to crossover to a mainstream audience, it is what it is: a movie for skiers.
This startling tale of redemption refuses to take an easy road through the material, revealing its secrets gradually and putting the characters in sharp focus.
Basically, it's a videogame masquerading as a movie, but the action scenes are so loud and messily edited that they're tedious rather than tense. If it weren't so incoherent, it would be a classic.
While there's nothing particularly original about the plot, the characters and the way they interact with each other are strikingly played
Danny and Oxide Pang [rework] the plot of their 2000 thriller to make way for Nicolas Cage and his Big Star persona
This cop drama is far too ordinary to live up to the hype. Spiky and watchable, it doesn't really stretch anyone. Especially the audience.
With a hilariously over-the-top B-movie vibe, this nutty gorefest keeps us chuckling all the way through. And underneath the outrageous wackiness, there's some playful thematic wit at work as well.

This comedy about movie-making that allows the cast to play knowingly with their careers and public personae. But the film feels only half as funny as it should be, falling back too often on big action sequences that are too ridiculous to work on any leve

This story of four brothers in São Paulo has a lively neorealist vibe that's utterly involving. And the characters are so vividly drawn by the filmmakers and cast that their mixture of hope and hopelessness really gets under our skin.
This is expert filmmaking at every level, continually adding engaging subtext that touches on family pressures, blind self-interest and warped justice.
Muscular filmmaking and a riveting central performance make this film worth seeing. Even if the plot itself becomes far too messy to really engage with us, the characters are edgy and enthralling.
A bittersweet combination of comedy and drama, this sensitive film has enough strong material in it to make it worth seeing, even if it sometimes feels under-developed and a little too heart-tugging

This straight-faced satire of American television raises important issues and is engaging enough to keep us gripped. But the astute commentary peaks too early, then gives way to a finale that's messy in more ways than one.
At least the actors are strong enough to keep us engaged, and they deliver their lines impeccably, from the spicy comedy to the teary drama.

Set in the years surrounding independence in India, this slightly melodramatic film has a strong emotional kick that manages to bring both the romance and the religious-political situation vividly to life.

Unnerving and emotional, this police thriller has an unnerving breadth and depth, as a murder case opens a decades-old inquiry that brings all kinds of dark creepiness with it. It's like an Icelandic twist on Seven.
This intriguing wartime tale has an otherworldly quality that draws us into a gentle and increasingly haunting story
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Wong reconstructs his 1994 film, a story of honour and regret in a surreal ancient China that resembles. It's a metaphysical Western, evocative and also a bit cold. But it's so beautifully filmed that we don't mind.
Yes, the film is wilfully odd, but it's also wonderfully entertaining and a true original.
Most jokes are centred around either genitalia or that Austin Powers-style of wink-nudge faux sexuality, which doesn't work at all with this character.
Charming and hilariously offbeat.
movie_title: El Baño del Papa (The Pope's Toilet) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The film's repetitive structure never quite resolves into something we can properly engage with, especially when a somewhat heavy-handed message rears its head.
The film's pace isn't quite enough to get our hearts racing, but it's still great fun.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A little too mopey and sexist for its own good. But the cast is engaging enough to keep us interested
With a script that only barely hangs together by the skin of its teeth, this romantic comedy survives on the considerable charm of its terrific cast.

This whizzy and outrageously colourful family action romp is a visually breathtaking hybrid of animation and live action. The story may feel about as gripping as a videogame, but the film is pure eye candy.
A bold script improves this drama about masculinity and bigotry in a small community. It also helps to have a terrific actor like Danny Glover on board.
This film is such an outrageously colourful homage to 1970s sexploitation cinema that it's impossible not to enjoy, even with the over-the-top performances and rambling narrative.
Argentine writer-director Puenzo invests this tricky story with real soul, bringing the characters and their situation to vivid life.
A bright and very silly film with solid, provocative themes that really stick with us.
When an action blockbuster comes along that actually bothers to create lively, memorable characters, you don't want to miss it.
This isn't the kind of flashy Big Issue movie that makes people stand up and take notice. It's quiet and moody, with outbursts of strong emotion and energy.
While it's slickly made and just about charming enough to keep us engaged, there's not much that's fresh or new in this formulaic rom-com.
The lack of a proper title is only the first sign that it's barely half-baked.
As it examines the point where sexuality and Islam meet in seven very different cultures, the film becomes far more universal than we expect.
Adds a manic spin that strains to convey far too many moral messages while overloading the film with wacky action.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Very funny and, despite the lack of a central plot, finds surprising truth in its characters.
A genuinely touching horror-porn movie.
movie_title: Otto; or Up with Dead People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: What starts as a thoroughly enjoyable screwball romp ... gets bogged down in some over-ambitious plotting and serious themes as it goes along
A lively, realistic tone helps make this Toronto-set comedy much more than we expect, stirring in some thoughtful themes and honest emotion.
This movie's script sticks so closely to formula that it could be a film school project.
There's nothing very suspenseful going on ... but the cast and the story will appeal to both kids and adults.
It's an odd mix that feels dumbed-down, but makes its point.
movie_title: Where in the World Is Osama Bin Laden? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Combines outrageously entertaining fight scenes with just enough of an ancient Chinese legend to keep us hooked
Extremely well-filmed, with terrific performances from the entire cast. But the plot feels underdeveloped.
Besides being hilariously funny, it's also rather insightful, with some very smart dialog.
The idiocy on display in this film is almost breathtaking ... but it's also far more entertaining than those slickly pretentious Hollywood thrillers.
If you think about what this film is saying, the superficiality is overwhelming.
A general emptiness nags as the story progresses, undermining the solid performances and weaving in a seriously ugly message.
Akin's visual style is both moody and fluid, catching the emotional layers of each scene without sentimentalising anything
movie_title: Auf der Anderen Seite (The Edge of Heaven) (On the Other Side) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Cuts across one of the West's most contentious political issues without ever getting political. And it features a terrific lead performance from Jenkins.
Intimate and emotional, with rather a lot of time focusing on the gorgeous young children as they laugh, play and, yes, cry
movie_title: We Are Together: The Children of Agape Choir (2006)

movie_review_blurb: This lost-in-the-woods thriller actually holds our interest thanks to good performances from the central duo. Everything else in this film is completely bonkers.
While the plot lends itself to pretentious blockbuster hysteria, del Toro keeps things grounded by focussing on the characters and their sardonic banter
