Holy Smoke juggles elements of comedy and psycho-sexual drama in its very intense story.
Despite the obvious origins as a play--only three characters in one room--this startling film manages to keep us utterly gripped.
Such a lyrical, moving independent film is a rare thing to find; Songcatcher is gorgeously made, perfectly cast and thoroughly engaging.
Adults will enjoy it more than they expect.
Efficiently made hokum.
It just seems to go on and on, never arriving at either a point or a satisfying conclusion.
Just what we need: another Dracula movie!
It's absolutely brilliant--a terrific little thriller that takes the genre and turns it inside out.
Capraesque. Hitchcockian. Add Wootastic to the Lexicon.
Lacks the subtlety and subtext to make the story really work on screen.
It's impossible to guess what the Coen brothers will come up with next, and little could prepare us for this offbeat 1940s noir drama shot in full period style. But it's a complete and utter triumph.
A fascinating, deeply entertaining film about a man who was impossible to define.
It's very, very talky, and more than a little like a Jane Austen novel in its society-versus-happiness theme. But we're kept intrigued by the characters and where they're heading.
Quote not available.
Gentle and cute, chatty and smart, the film at least holds our interest, mostly due to the sheer charm of its cast.
The ending makes us catch our breath not because it's so clever, but because there's so much to the film even without the final revelation.

Strikingly directed by Glazer, a veteran of Guinness adverts and Radiohead videos, Sexy Beast is a slightly above average British crime comedy because of the insightful wit in its script, direction and performances.
Does anyone really think they have an original satanic thriller up their sleeve?
Visually the film is riveting, using the setting with real style and emotion.
An astonishing true story about injustice on a grand scale ... and trust on a small one. Yet the film itself never quite rises above a standard movie bio.
The story not only stands strong half a century later, but it continues to show up today's formulaic Hollywood films for the vacuous use of celluloid that they are.
The pedestrian, predictable plot isn't really important; the film seems to exist merely as an excuse to string together gross-out sequences.
Now here we go, a resolutely B-movie thriller with delusions of grandeur.
This is the first Godard film released in the UK in 14 years ... and on this evidence we can see why.
movie_title: In Praise Of Love (Éloge de l'amour) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: The real problem is that there's nothing particularly original or entertaining about the film. Which makes us wonder why did they bothered to make it.
Obviously, the novel's sprawling, multi-strand structure has been streamlined here, but Madden and screenwriter Slovo have included so much subtext that it's still a remarkably complex film.
Douglas is superb, playing his age for once and finding rhythms and humour in the most unexpected places.
The period is intricately recreated without a single cliche, while the performances are all honest and open.
A thoroughly watchable fable about life, the universe and everything.
You never care about anyone as they give their lives to save humanity. Ho hum. That's the worst crime in this otherwise so-bad-it's-good mess.
Could have been worse I suppose. At least there are no Pokemons or (shudder) grinning purple dinosaurs around.
It's a small, offbeat, extremely well-crafted little film that's full of terrific touches. It's also the funniest mob comedy in years.
movie_title: Ghost Dog - The Way of the Samurai (2000)

movie_review_blurb: A stunningly made film, raw and authentic, with the ability to get way under the skin.
This grisly werewolf film is actually a black comedy about a teen girl encountering menstruation. Yes, really.
An extremely sure-handed filmmaking debut from Coppola, daughter of Francis. Her script alone is a marvel of subtlety and intelligence.
In short: It's everything you could hope for from an Aardman feature.
This film is a rare thing of edgy beauty and substance in a summer of sheer emptiness.
There are astute observations along the way, more than enough big laughs and, in Zellweger's capable hands, a terrific look at a singleton on the verge of a nervous breakdown.
Thoroughly engaging yet nothing new.
Definitely worth adding to the Christmas movie pantheon, but not at the expense of the original.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas (2000)

movie_review_blurb: A low-key, naturalistic coming-of-age drama.
Quote not available.
It should be mandatory viewing for absolutely everyone ... especially those involved in the war on drugs.
Welles' outlandish visual talent is on full display as he puts noir movie conventions through the wringer and creates one of the most terrifyingly seedy yet utterly compelling films ever made.
Not only is the story reed thin, but it's also undercut by continual anachronistic dialog that's funny but alienates us from the adventure and characters.
The people at Pixar outdo even themselves with this high-energy action comedy.
Yes, it's very stylised and mannered, it tries far too hard to be funny, and it's still rather beguiling. It's also just a bit to odd to really work.
From the opening moment we know we're in the hands of gifted, assured, focussed filmmakers.
Directed with a real sense of visual assurance by Zwigoff, the film looks great and is full of clever little touches that make it come to life.
There's not much at the end, really, but it's quite a nice journey while it lasts.
The film just uses the scattershot approach to parody: Throw constant jokes at the screen and some of them will stick.
Jarring, uncomfortable, surprisingly moving and ultimately unforgettable.
All the clever visual effects in the world can't hide the fact that this is just a nasty piece about women in torment.
The film maintains its story perfectly from the beginning, creating a gorgeous atmosphere and layering the story with hints of thriller, mystery, romance and psychological drama.
Would it have been too much to ask for just a tiny bit of interest for the grown-ups?
movie_title: Pokemon the First Movie - Mewtwo vs. Mew (1999)

movie_review_blurb: A thoroughly entertaining little film, full of terrific performances and some hilarious moments.
Quite possibly the funniest spoof of all time.
A far-above-average teen comedy that's both wickedly funny and dead-on insightful.
Underneath it all, there's a decent story, fine acting and astonishing production design.
One of the all-time greats is back on the big screen where it belongs.
movie_title: Nights of Cabiria (Le Notti di Cabiria) (1957)

movie_review_blurb: Despite astonishing camera work and editing, it just gets duller and duller even as the story is supposedly heating up.
Yet another long, meandering, talky French film may not be your first choice for escapist entertainment. But there's some terrific stuff in this one.
With a surprisingly good script and a very able cast, The Best Man is far better than it has any right to be.
It collapses into a heap of ridiculously over-the-top stunts, movie cliches and surprisingly sappy dialog.
movie_title: Gone in 60 Seconds (Gone in Sixty Seconds) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: This one isn't nearly as gut-wrenchingly awful as the first one -- the animation is better. But it's still so bad it hurts.
The raw honesty here is startling -- these people open themselves up to the camera in such a candid way that we can't help but be drawn into their world.

Brett Easton Ellis' controversial and violent novel American Psycho is about as black as comedy gets, and Harron captures the tone and themes perfectly here, highlighting the vacuousness of 80s consumerism without pulling any punches at all.
It seems like the filmmakers got equally caught up in the idea of Jolie as Croft, so much so that they forgot to build a credible movie around her.
This eerie thriller grabs hold of us and never lets go.
movie_title: The Devil's Backbone (El Espinazo del diablo) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: It's essentially just a bit of entertaining, thrilling, heroic fluff.
This film does at least feature superior acting and a solid script.
The dinosaurs are back again, but this time without Steven Spielberg at the helm...and it shows.
It's the story itself that makes the film so endearing -- we actually start to care for the characters, even though we know from the start how it will all end.
It's a very clever story, intriguingly written and superbly played by its cast, even as it crosses a couple of lines and gets rather too violent.
A surprisingly vicious little film, filled with indiscriminate, un-PC killings and a rough-edged feel that makes it utterly compelling.
This is that rare children's film that works perfectly for grown-ups as well with its witty story, sharp performances and astonishing special effects that never draw attention to themselves.
It's Hornby's original concept that makes the film so wonderful, weaving Rob's musical obsessions and love for top 5 lists into an honest, meaningful, very funny look at the male ego.
Even if the ending seems a bit tidy, the film is still effective and nicely creepy -- definitely worth seeing.
This freewheeling war comedy is deeply entertaining due to the crazy-but-believable premise and wonderfully outrageous characters.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Hollywood films have a tendency to fall apart in the final reel (due to studio pressures and those notorious audience preview comments), but we hoped Van Sant would avoid this pitfall. Alas.
With a witty script and a cool sense of building dread, Pitch Black is a surprisingly entertaining sci-fi thriller.

An audacious tale of addiction and self-destruction that starts as a quiet examination of normal life and then builds to a crescendo of unspeakable horror. It's a remarkable film in every way, worthy of any kudo heaped upon it.
Quite a bit more intelligent than most films in the genre.
n unusually artful teen thriller, this film has a terrific combination of both light and dark touches from start to finish.
Quite simply one of the finest comic romances ever made.

One of those movies 'they don't make anymore,' Gladiator is a guts and glory epic with swords and sandals, spectacular action sequences, a seriously good hero and a cast of (digitally enhanced) thousands.
As a historical document the film is fascinating, examining the shifting political tides in Eastern Europe. But as a movie, it's oddly uninvolving ... and a bit forced.
It's big, bold, inspiring and spectacular ... but it's also mind-numbingly stupid.
A surprisingly enjoyable kid's movie.
There's enough intelligent wit and physical goofiness to keep us smiling, and the occasional shift to serious drama, sentimentality and romance isn't too clunky.
Breezy, efficient fun ... nothing more.
Coppola's direction is impeccable, capturing both the intimate detail, overarching spectacle and layered depth of meaning, often all in one shot.
One of the best scary movies in years, full of deadpan humour, red herrings and some very good jolts.
From the outlandishly stylish imagination of Jeunet and Laurant (City of Lost Children) comes a simple, warm, deeply wacky Parisian romance.
All in all a thoroughly enjoyable romp with echoes of familiarity ... and yet unlike anything you've ever seen or are likely to see again.
movie_title: Fah talai jone (Tears of the Black Tiger) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Disney's animation team cuts loose with a wild and wacky tale that makes little real sense ... and knows it ... and doesn't care.

After a series of clever but unexceptional "little" movies, Altman emerges with one of the best films of his career (which is saying a lot), juggling a complex plot and a huge cast in a thoroughly entertaining British comedy-mystery.
Quote not available.
It's funny and violent and occasionally quite entertaining, even if there's not a single convincing moment.
Each person and event is so peculiar that as it goes on the warm humour begins to grate on our nerves.
By relaxing and opening up his approach just a little he could have said much more.
This is pleasantly much less insulting than most films in the genre ... and far more entertaining than it has any right to be after its dire predecessor.

A cleverly written spoof-adventure that more than rises to the occasion. Not only are the jokes dead-on, but the story and characters actually work as a decent sci-fi movie, complete with superior special effects, a grisly villain and even romance.
A far-above-average comic book movie.
It's an adrenaline-fuelled film full of big jolts, black humour and a nicely building sense of foreboding and dread.
One of the most fiercely original films about adults coping with their pasts.

A hilarious and beguiling comedy-adventure-mystery-romance hybrid. And it's not just the jaw-dropping oddity of the thing that makes it work; the film has a wonderfully involving -- and even moving -- storyline.
This is exhilarating, vibrant, bravura cinema.
It's fascinating, tense and grisly... but a bit of a muddle really.
Bullock has such excellent timing, and such a superb sense of physical comedy, that we would happily watch her (and we have!) in much worse films than this.
Beautifully well made, intelligent films like this don't come along very often.
It feels more like an artificial fable than a story we can sink our teeth into.

Fascinating enough to hold our interest, even as it drifts away from its early promise and tries just a bit too hard to bring all of the plot threads to a happy, tidy conclusion. But then, believability isn't an issue here.
One of the most influential films of the past 40 years gets the spit and polish for a reissue -- and it still hasn't aged at all.
Mexican director Del Toro takes the reins for this followup to the successful 1998 vampire thriller, and the result is considerably better. Which isn't saying much.
It makes a few fundamental mistakes along the way--mostly due to Willis' star power--but it's still thoroughly entertaining
This is Spielberg's masterpiece, a near perfect film directed with astonishing skill and unafraid to get sentimental ... without crossing the line into syrup.
One of the most enjoyable and genuinely funny animated features [Disney's] ever made.
Sinise is quite good as the guy trying desperately to prove that he's innocent, even as he has nagging self-doubts.
OK, so we never have much doubt about what will happen, but Fincher pulls out all the visual stops to crank up the heat in this tale of five people in a Manhattan house on one dark and stormy night.
It could have been a much meatier film in less insipid hands.
Yes, it's sweet and enjoyable, but it's also a bit plodding.
There is one terrific twist at the end that just about redeems the lazy plot, but by then we've been subjected to so many preposterous set pieces that we've stopped caring.
It's loud, garish, very stupid ... and thoroughly enjoyable rubbish.
Unforgettably good stuff.
This unassuming comedy-drama catches you off guard with its astute observations and detailed characters.
The result is surprisingly effective -- excellent performances, character based comedy and even a few serious moments.

This is not your average low-brow university comedy; these filmmakers have a much more twisted sense of humour, pulling laughs from the most surprising places to liven up what is essentially just a sweet romance.
The inventive look of the film and a sporadic stream of funny gags keep us watching, even if the characters and plot aren't exactly ground-breaking.
They had three years to make this sequel to the original, which was a surprising critical and box office success in 1999. So why does this film feel so rushed?
It's blunt, controversial and never takes the easy road through its themes and situations. It's also profoundly moving.
Pity it doesn't bend many cinematic rules along the way.
If there's any complaint, it's that the whole film is almost too perfect.
Without ever touching on a cliche (except to poke fun at it), Shyamalan skillfully builds the film on several layers -- personal redemption, family drama, community-in-crisis, world on the brink.
You've really got to wonder sometimes how talented people end up in hopeless misfires like this film.

movie_title: Spy Kids 2: The Island of Lost Dreams (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
This is much more than the average making-of documentary.

There are lots of odd sequences that add texture (abstract ballet sequences, an extended silent movie scene that goes very surreal), and so much going on beneath the surface that you can hardly take it all in.
There's something wonderful about chaotic ethnic comedies, and this film taps straight into that vein.
It's extremely well-made, even though all the guts have been sucked out in an attempt to make it politically correct.
Twists and turns keep the story increasingly complex and gripping, even if director Liman doesn't really pump up the adrenaline.
This is one of those juvenile American comedies that's not quite sure what it wants to be: goofy farce, gross-out mayhem, sweet rom-com, what-I've-learned TV movie.
Seeing as how it's based on a weepy Nicholas Sparks novel, it's not surprising that this teen romantic drama is an almost unbearably weepy film.
Subtle and more than a little offbeat, this is the kind of movie the Farrellys might make if they (a) made intelligent films and (b) weren't obsessed with gross-out humor.
Agent 007 is back in his 20th film adventure, and things are darker and more serious now.
Columbus overcomes several of the first film's problems with this much darker, slightly more edgy sequel.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

movie_review_blurb: It rings with the truth of real-life experience, based of course on Szpilman's account and mixed with Polanski's own life.
Harsh and extremely shocking. And also one of the most moving and forceful films of the year.
The songs are rather forgettable and sometimes downright painful.

This gruesome plotting combines with the gritty visual style to make the film an unsettling, creepy experience, complete with very strange sound editing and eerie musical choices that accent the offbeat post-apocalyptic imagery remarkably.
The plot is very clever, but Boyd weighs it down with too many characters and events, all intertwined and far too complicated to keep track of.
Fantastic -- strange and bold and unlike anything you've ever seen.
movie_title: Dracula: Pages From a Virgin's Diary (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
Quite frankly, this is must-see cinema on various levels -- superior filmmaking and themes that scream out to be considered, talked about and acted upon right now.
This is strong stuff, but Frears avoids the soapbox by concentrating on the personal drama.
By never deciding what it wants to be -- wacky comedy or action thriller -- this film fails miserably on both fronts.
The film is forceful, perhaps a bit too tidy, but thoroughly accessible, moving and ultimately devastating stuff.
A very stupid film that's almost watchable but doesn't really have any reason to exist.
Sure, there's plenty of wacky energy, but if you look even a little closely there's nothing else at all.
It remains one of my all-time favourites.
So forced and strained that it's painful to watch.
It certainly feels like a cheap cash-in!
It's a lot of style over very little substance. But there are just enough twists in the tale to make it far more satisfying than almost any horror film in recent memory.
Manages to be a complete winner on every level.
Everything explodes into a massive ball of flames for no reason at all. And this overblown fakery makes it impossible to buy into the film at any level.
There are several disturbing twists and turns as the film progresses, but it sometimes feels like a checklist of teen issues, not truthful storytelling.

This sprawling generational drama features fantastic performances and examines some very strong themes. But it's also surprisingly thin plot-wise, with a convoluted and indulgent structure badly in need of a dispassionate editor.
movie_title: Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood (2002)

movie_review_blurb: If only the filmmakers had resisted the urge to go down the well-worn Hollywood thriller path.
Williams gauges the performance perfectly, starting out as a kind of Forrest Gump character but getting deeper and richer as the plot turns until we are both terrified of him and worried for him.
Leconte directs with style and colour, drawing us in with humour and a spark of suspense.
movie_title: The Man on the Train (L'homme du train) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Even if the film isn't nearly as clever or insightful as it thinks it is, at least it has the courage to go for a chillingly offbeat conclusion.
Just sit back and laugh. A lot.
Ang Lee's Eat Drink Man Woman is faithfully adapted into Los Angeles' Mexican-American subculture in this enjoyable ensemble film.

The film is so carelessly made that every surprise in the story is given away very early on--we know from the beginning exactly what will happen, and scenes are so badly staged that any comic or dramatic potential is lost.
It's so badly botched that it's entertaining ... for all the wrong reasons.
The script has just enough clever jokes to keep us chuckling, even if it never scales the heights of classic comedy.
Quite possibly the most gruesome film I've ever seen, this live-action manga thriller at least has a vicious sense of humour amid the gore.
Combined with the rather touching romance that's trying to bloom between rivers of blood, the film is more than a little unsettling ... and unsuccessful.
First-time writer-director Serry shows a remarkable gift for storytelling with this moving, effective little film about life in the USA for Iranians during the hostage crisis in 1979.
Cinematic junk food.
Dumb and noisy ... and totally watchable.
It's just terrible, with long stretches in which the sea of writers don't even try to insert any humour, followed by an attempted joke that doesn't work on any level.
The blending between Spielberg's childish sentiment and Kubrick's cold, hard stare is remarkable. It's so expertly made that it takes the breath away.
With a kind of eerie beauty and simplicity, David Gordon Green captures a slice of American life in this truly original film.
Perhaps with another 20 minutes of footage the story and characters could have been fleshed out with some depth, meaning, originality and, most importantly, grit.
While not particularly well-directed, the film still looks fantastic and bristles with humour that keeps us laughing from start to finish.

It's not perfect ... but it's still fantastic.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace (1999)

movie_review_blurb: A true groundbreaker. And it's also the best IMAX movie ever made.
Like many sequels, it's a slick, well-crafted film ... with no soul.
Intriguing ... but the film is too busy being hip and preachy to notice the irony.

Quiet and atmospheric, creepy and grisly, drenched in both equatorial sunshine and scarlet blood -- the film is startlingly powerful as it subtly examines themes of imperialism, corporate greed and ultimately personal madness.
movie_title: Aguirre, the Wrath of God (Aguirre, der Zorn Gottes) (1972)

movie_review_blurb: The film gets both funnier and scarier by the minute.
In the end it's simply empty-headed fun, nothing more.
There are also nice themes about bravery, honesty and trust, the animation is astonishingly good, and the constant mayhem makes the very obvious plot bearable.
I guess it wouldn't have been enough to just make an intelligent and gripping drama about Ivy League secret societies. No, we had to have a murder, coverup, good guys, bad guys, and so on.
In the Mood for Love is a touching romance that brings to mind Brief Encounter as it slowly, intricately tracks a love affair in 1960s Hong Kong.
Ballet meets hip-hop in this warmly enjoyable yet unambitious teen romance.
One of those cruel-yet-very-funny crowd pleasers.
This is breathtakingly good filmmaking -- thoroughly entertaining, deeply moving, warmly funny and profoundly evocative.
Goofy adventures ensue.
movie_title: Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Great fun, even if it's not a particularly good movie.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (2001)

movie_review_blurb: If you think a documentary about the birth of modern skateboarding sounds like something worth missing, think again.
Director Ridley Scott is back with another very well-crafted, thoroughly entertaining film... that only hints at what's going on beneath the surface.
While not in the same league as either This Is Spinal Tap or Almost Famous, this rock-band movie is at least thoroughly entertaining.
In the end it might be a little too nice for its own good, but by then we've fallen for these people hook, line and sinker.
The natural rhythms of the (largely improvised) script create characters and situations that are authentic, hilarious and engaging.
A bright and breezy caper flick without any pretensions at all.
This is one of those rare blockbusters that satisfies both in its big spectacle and in the small, intimate moments.
Jack the Ripper gets another cinematic outing with this rather creepy and violent thriller from the Hughes Brothers.
After seeing this, I can understand why it has been gathering dust on a shelf somewhere for the past two years.
Based on a true story, this creepy drama effectively gets under our skin ... and most importantly never makes the typical mistakes of a Hollywood thriller.
Sheer style and energy make the film work, with its kinetic editing and enthusiastic, physical performances.
Yawn.
There's an edgy, authentic rhythm to this gritty undercover cop drama that's boosted by strong performances ... and then undermined by an appalling ending.
The first part of the long-awaited trilogy is here, and Kiwi director Jackson somehow manages to exceed expectations with one of the most astonishing action epics in memory.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring (2001)

movie_review_blurb: As the story gets darker and heavier, the film really grabs hold in a powerful way, as long as we can let ourselves be carried along until the complex conclusion.
This is a lovely film, crafted with attention to detail and assembled with real skill.
The animation is breathtakingly beautiful, and the story isn't bad at all. But the film is so infused with its own self-importance that it will annoy adults immediately.
The story is utterly devastating, but it is lifted and made accessible by the combination of cinematic ingenuity and astonishingly real performances.
Woo simply seems lost in all the emotional claptrap, war movie cliches, cornball dialog and mumbo jumbo about bravery and patriotism.
A franchise is born.
There's a general lack of subtlety -- the filmmakers try too hard to be zany or meaningful and rarely get either right.
Yawn! As if the premise wasn't trite enough, the film fails to deliver a single decent laugh, although it tries on every level (mostly gross-out, it must be said).
Christensen shines at the centre.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Nothing about the story hangs together, the characters become increasingly stiff and unbelievable, and the incessant red herrings finally become too much to bear.
It's astonishing to think that this is Ray's first film.
Loud, grisly, action-packed and profoundly un-scary.
With genuinely astute observations, this New York rom-com features a good script and an engaging cast that keeps us laughing.
How this otherwise talented crew managed to make a film that feels this amateurishly low-budget is anyone's guess.
The script, which simply doesn't work at all, and reduces the characters to lumpen, uninteresting blobs, despite the handsome cast.
Underneath the smooth cinematography and score, there's a gritty little indie trying to get out.
All in such extreme close-up that you think the birds will whack the camera with their wings at any moment.
Tim Burton atones for the disastrous Planet of the Apes 2001 with this lyrical and involving family drama.
One of the most startlingly effective political films in memory--gripping, entertaining, devastating.
Not only is it hilariously funny, but it's also a fiendishly entertaining (albeit somewhat cartoonish) action movie.
What this comedy lacks in cleverness or originality it more than makes up for with charm.
Bracingly engaging--simply because Bichlbaum and Bonanno are so likeable, hilarious, smart and provocative.
Another staggeringly strong performance by Javier Bardem.
movie_title: Mondays in the Sun (Los Lunes al sol) (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Those who stick with it will be rewarded with a lovely story about people picking up the pieces of their shattered lives.
Not easy to watch, the characters are all strongly abrasive, and yet we are emotionally gripped.
Not an earth-shattering film by any means, but it's thoughtfully and beautifully made.
It's thoroughly engaging, especially as it begins to twist and turn into a kind of warped Alice in Wonderland.
not awful, but getting there
It's visually stunning, but [James Cameron] can't resist going slightly too far with its premise.
Cruz is astonishingly determined to make us believe she's a dumpy slag... but frankly, she's more like a comedy sketch character
Amelio tells the story with a silent stillness that belies the intense emotions that churn under the surface.
A disarmingly enjoyable movie with a lively cast of characters and an action-packed plot based (very roughly!) on real-life events
Every jolt in this film involves crash editing and deafening noises, while nothing is made of the premise or the characters.
The film starts promisingly ... but our laughter stops the moment the special effects kick in.
Genuinely funny, realistically romantic and extremely well-played
A superb story is drowned out by Kusturica's zany and chaotic style
Funny, telling and more than a little frightening
There's an amusingly askance approach to the whole coming-of-age process that keeps us engaged.
The only thing that keeps us engaged is the cute factor.
Besides a nice sense of visual style, there's nothing to this creepy-child thriller.
At least it's hilariously awful.
Wit, energy, heart and soul!
Almost bad enough to be a guilty pleasure, except that it takes itself so seriously.
A fairly edgy thriller that's not too demanding, but thoroughly entertaining.
Features some fine performances and a nicely offhanded production style, even if it all feels a bit dull.
Entertaining ... but you do wish they'd tell the tale without funnelling it through Hollywood's inspirational movie assembly line.
A gorgeous setting and ferociously charming cast add unexpected depths to this scalding saga of manipulation.
A silly fantasy that goes for broad strokes where a more finely tuned satire might have actually hit a nerve.
Bailey and Barbato assemble their material with a sharp eye for detail and bracingly hilarious wit.
The footage is astonishing, revealing the events of 30 years ago and some scary truths about where the world is today.
movie_title: Guerrilla: The Taking of Patty Hearst (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Tackles a seriously important issue without losing the vibrant energy of everyday life.
This isn't a slasher horror film at all; it gets deep into the characters' heads.
Offers a refreshingly strong and lucid examination of the issue, even if it's edited a bit chaotically, cross-cutting between its various strands.
A series of hilarious moments along with some astute insight.
This documentary will either be a life-changing experience, or it'll drive you nuts with its new-agey tone.
movie_title: What the Bleep Do We Know!? (2004)

movie_review_blurb: This is a big, lively romp, filmed in a lushly expansive epic style even though it's basically low-rent James Bond.
Beautifully shot, with natural acting and sensitive storytelling that honestly grapples with difficult themes.
There's a sharp sense of honest rock-chick energy that draws us into this film, even when its story takes a few overwrought and melodramatic turns.
This intriguingly well-made documentary tells us just about everything we could possibly want to know about the mesmerising 1970s singer.
Artful and stylish, Argento's acting and filmmaking are edgy, authentic and rather nuts.
movie_title: The Heart Is Deceitful Above All Things (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A stylish energy sustains this film even when it begins to drift into draggy incoherence.
Even though it's worth seeing, it could have used stronger actors to make it really work.
A fresh and surprisingly insightful look at human interaction, from the way we create families around us to the cruel realities of the world.
They really don't make 'em like this anymore: tightly wound thrillers with a political relevance that adds newsworthy urgency to the drama and suspense.
These characters hilariously circle around each other ... tentatively reaching out to each other with surprising results.
Has an authentic tone that makes its simplistic quest-for-redemption storyline surprisingly engaging.
Labours to recapture the magic and ends up both getting the tone wrong and making its central character rather unlikeable.

The actors play it straight, clearly aware that the tigers are the stars.
A powerful film that should have been much better.
We actually begin to laugh at the inanity of it all, wanting to yell at the screen: 'Just shut up and dance!'
The film's real joy comes in its camp performance pieces, which outrageously poke fun at the guilty pleasures of musical theatre.
Has a gimmicky, inventive style like Amelie, but the comedy has a very nasty edge.
With its warm humour and gritty realism, it's like a combination of the two extremes in the prostitute genre: Nights of Cabiria meets Pretty Woman!
This strikingly beautiful film from Alexander Sokurov (Russian Ark) captures relationships in an ethereal way that gets way under the skin.
The central relationships are compelling and intriguing, and Greyson is so good at freshly telling a story that we are pulled right in.
Deliberately shocking, yawningly plodding and almost mind-bogglingly pretentious -- and its message is laid on with a trowel: Men are idiots.
This solid thriller only works if you're unfamiliar with the 1962 original, one of the best films ever made.
This is serious storytelling that rambles badly, slips in some humour here and there, and cleverly brings out the harsh realities of the Reagan era.
Nothing really works here, from the ludicrous traffic choreography to the deeply irritating Fallon.
The filmmakers drift into sentimentality too easily and badly shy away from the provocative issues they raise (like sexuality).
movie_title: A Home at the End of the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The best thing is that director Witt actually manages, amid the chaos, to centre on the characters and create people we can cheer for.
This disturbing and violent movie gleefully plays with our minds as it twists and turns through its tricky, menacing plot.
Constantly opts for contrived cheesiness, slathering on the cuteness with a trowel.
A s******ing style of humour that might have seemed funny in theory, but virtually nothing sparks on screen.
there are some amazing standout performances (Cate Blanchett, Alfred Molina and Steve Coogan). Otherwise, it's just a bit of diverting fluff.
This unapologetic B-movie works simply because it has no pretensions at all.
Features a magnificent central performance by Bening to go with its engaging and raucous storyline.
Obviously the cast and crew don't care that this makes no sense--they got a great holiday in Fiji.
movie_title: Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)

movie_review_blurb: After a garbled and jumpy opening this settles into a rather enjoyable action movie.
Amid the insane goofiness there's some serious stuff happening that actually speaks to us.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Even if details are strangely careless, we still get caught up in it, cheering for both victory and true love even though we know exactly what will happen.
It's heart is beautifully expressed through humour, dry wit and honest emotion that never gets sappy at all.
Extremely well written, acted and filmed with edgy life and humour that keeps it from turning mawkish.
A superbly well-structured screenplay and an unhurried, sure-handed directorial style. Otherwise, alas, there's not much to it.
The period vibe is basically the whole point to this charming and often very funny film.
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Gratuitous action, ill-defined characters, goofy plot. And moments when it's great fun.
Amid the farce there are moments of lucidity and informative dialog that's both telling and historically important.
Looks like yet another gross-out farce, but it's actually a genuinely engaging comic adventure.
This gender-bending romp is enjoyably witty, even if it feels rather long and pointless.
Brainy, intelligent, emotional filmmaking that just happens to be in the thriller genre.
Nothing too deep and meaningful, just a thoroughly entertaining trip through the past 50 years of surfing.
Solondz continues ... to venture into more surreal, twisted territory with his intelligent but often baffling approach to storytelling.
So full of heart and soul that you can actually feel it becoming a classic while you're watching it.
It's beautifully made and very well-acted, tantalising us with its central mystery even if it's rather mopey and dull.
It's simply a silly bit of undersea fluff ... jammed to the gills with pop culture references and fishy puns.
Feels very cheesy due to its awkward, period-style acting and directing. But it's also chillingly informative.
While it's visually striking, with superior acting, it's also cluttered with a bewildering collection of characters and plot threads.
Even though the central stories are compelling, dividing the film between them means we never have anyone to grab hold of.
The Wayans brothers are gifted actors-filmmakers, so why is it that they continually make lazy, unchallenging movies?
Radford that draws out the cultural context of the period and the emotions in the story.
movie_title: William Shakespeare's The Merchant of Venice (2004)

movie_review_blurb: One of the most beautifully moving wuxia films you'll ever see.
The production design is overdone on several levels... If it weren't such a compelling story we wouldn't stick with it.
A delicate story, intricately balancing its characters on a knife-edge of compassion and obsession
Introspective, subtle performances work beautifully with the film's graceful sense of movement and the fiercely relentless fighting styles.
The ending feels like a desperate attempt to inject some emotion into the film. And it just doesn't work.
Mike Leigh is still making films that bristle with honesty and life, fearlessly tackling issues that other filmmakers won't touch.
Stylish, moody, gripping and utterly nonsensical--what else do you expect from the director of Sleeping With the Enemy and the writer of Instinct?
Thanks to a few wacky set pieces, it's not quite as excruciating as it could have been.
Yet another inexplicable American remake that adds nothing new to the original.
Boyle and Boyce bring a seriously askew sensibility to their work that never talks down to the kids.
Such an entertaining bundle of chaos that you can't help but love it.
Cleverly turns Jane Austen's classic story into a colourful Bollywood epic that's thoroughly good fun, even if it doesn't live up to the promise.
About halfway through this offbeat horror comedy you realise you're watching a cult classic.
This film is so all over the place that Spike Lee drowns out his own argument and sabotages the story.
A powerful tale of isolationism, a desire for innocence and hope, and a fear of the unknown.
A misguided clunker that borders on being offensive.
Simply gorgeous to look at, and it packs an undeniable punch--strange, silly, inventive, devastating, inspiring.
Inventive and insightful look at relationships, although it suffers the flaws of Allen's more recent films.
In throwing out wit and intelligence for mindless action, Twohy ends up with a noisy, chaotic, over-serious mess.
It helps to have energetic and gifted actors, but you really need to give them funnier things to do and say.
With a few hilarious exceptions, the jokes are bland and unfunny, and the fairy tale reinventions aren't creative or witty enough.
Somehow I doubt we'll be seeing 'The Whole Eleven Yards'.
While the sentimentality is pretty oppressive, Cassavetes leaves enough space for the cast members to shine.
Builds cleverly as the mystery deepens, then struggles to bring it all to a conclusion.
We are powerfully gripped by Lou's life and work, but we're never as moved by Nathaniel's quest as we clearly should be.
While it's not terribly original--it never takes the premise or characters anywhere new--you'll be so busy laughing you won't care.
Haunting presences, inexplicable cutaways, overwhelming suspense, deeply disturbing sub-themes and a general willingness to leave things unanswered. Fantastic!
A minor masterpiece--a moving and economical story that profoundly examines the raw truths of fundamentalism.
Darker, edgier and more artful than its predecessors. What's even more surprising is that it's actually very good!
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Filmmaker Love brings these characters to vivid life, but they're all so hateful, racist and idiotic that we don't like them at all!
Filmed in a zany, colourful style reminiscent of the Spy Kids movies, this is enjoyable fun until earnest lines of dialog bring everything to a shrieking stop.
Anderson's remarkable achievement here is to treat such a sensational subject with such a steady hand.
As it gets more spiritual and internal, it makes less and less sense.
Beautiful, complex, deeply engaging filmmaking
The whole film feels stingy and vacuous. And it's only barely trashy enough to be fun.
Blessed with sharply written dialog and vivid characters, even when the plot drifts into a swamp of mushy cliches.
There's nothing terribly new about this animated Disney feature, but it's still engaging good fun.
Pure fairy tale, but it's also charming enough to win us over in the end.
If only Petersen and Benioff had stayed truer to the original tale and resisted Hollywood's tendency to dumb-down the story and big-up the production design.
Shiny, undemanding and deeply fake.
Some genuinely jumpy scenes, but it's so vacuous that it almost doesn't register at all.
Reid is especially amazing, taking us way beneath May's skin without any obvious cinematic stuff about grief and sexuality.
There's only one problem with this thunderously entertaining action romp: The budget is two times too big!
Asks us to justify sadistic brutality simply because the central character is the designated 'good guy'.
The purest form of documentary: It simply presents its subject, lets the people talk and does no moralising or manipulation at all.
It's a great idea, even if it's far too smug for its own good.
This global thriller seriously plays with your head ... refusing to resolve itself into something clear-cut. But the approach is assured and intelligent.
The comedy is so bone-dry that it hardly feels funny at all. But it is. Kind of.
Spurlock constructs the film brilliantly, maintaining a darkly hilarious tone while continually jolting us.
A slick movie with a nice-looking cast and a script that strips away everything that made the original so elusive and involving.
A bawdy, rude film that wins us over with sheer energy.
So cute and sweet that any insightful observations will be lost to real-world audiences.
A strikingly different film from the original: with a slower pace and a much less enigmatic tone.
Works as both a detailed examination of urban marriage and a creepy road movie.
Best of all, this is a story that's actually about something.
While it's a bit awkward and self-indulgent, it also creates two extremely vivid characters and one of cinema's more believable romances.
This real-time reunion is entertaining, engaging and strongly emotional.
With its smart script and dead-on comic performances, it actually works.
If you have no knowledge of Peter Sellers' acting genius, it's difficult to engage with this artfully inventive biography.
movie_title: The Life and Death of Peter Sellers (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Feels like a stage play with two characters in a single room, but the way the story delicately unfolds keeps us gripped.
movie_title: East Palace West Palace (Dong gong xi gong) (Behind the Forbidden City) (1998)

movie_review_blurb: There's a solid message here about wealth and hypocrisy, but it's watered down by the opaque storytelling.
The main problem is that the narrative is evasive...; we can't trust Mamet as a storyteller!
This extremely well-assembled film has value on so many levels that it simply demands to be seen.
Raimi handles it effortlessly because he keeps his focus tightly in the characters' hearts and minds.
Ignore the fact that this film should have been made at least 15 years ago and you might enjoy it.
Great fun to watch even though it's completely preposterous.
There's a sharp, knowing tone to this film that will perhaps be lost on audiences unfamiliar with the American Christian subculture.
We know exactly what the filmmakers are trying to do, and with the exception of the truly awful dialog, at least they do it efficiently.
In a word: Confusing. But this is still fascinating filmmaking.
This film is so endearing and entertaining that it's hard to understand why it hasn't gone on to take the world by storm ... igniting a ping pong craze in the process!
There's an eerie creepiness about this psychological thriller that really gets into your head.
Thoroughly entertaining and deeply moving--a vital historical document with something important to say.
This micro-budget suspense film generates more actual tension than nine out of 10 Hollywood thrillers.
Unsettling, but it's also fragmented and repetitive.
What is essentially a fairly standard kidnap drama takes on extra interest due to its superb performances and an intriguing structure.
The performances are all raw and natural, and they are filmed in a close-up and often very intimate way.
The film delights in playing with the audience, dropping little clues here, red herrings there, while unpeeling each person slowly before our eyes.
The film will engage a much broader audience than just Metallica fans.
Hart and Roache are astonishing--raw and exposed, bristling with anger and fear, righteous outrage ... and years of religious and political prejudice against each other.

The script for this comedy is so half-baked that we begin to wonder why it was made at all. Not only is it resolutely unfunny, but it never dips beneath a superficial examination of relationship cliches.
A wonderful blend of sharp characters with running gags galore, outrageously inspired visual imagery and a plotline that feels both familiar and otherworldly.
movie_title: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (2004)

movie_review_blurb: An effectively disorienting premise that consistently keeps us both unsettled and unsure what might happen next. It may be a bit vague for some viewers, but others will love it.
Complex emotions and a gentle exploration of interpersonal connections make this Paris-set drama worth a look, especially since it's so nicely played by the eclectic cast.
Melissa McCarthy is clearly in a rut: the title character in this film isn't very far removed from her previous roles in The Heat and Identity Thief.
his adaptation of Joseph Conrad's 1909 short story ambitiously twists the premise to add a bit of sexual tension, although the plot can't quite sustain itself right to the end.
Despite a tough and rather bleak story, this Central American drama is bolstered by strikingly beautiful cinematography and involving characters.
movie_title: The Golden Dream (La Jaula De Oro) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: With a stripped-down, bare-faced performance, Juliette Binoche is utterly wonderful in this tense French drama.
With a loose, rambling style, this documentary starts as a backstage glimpse of a rock tour before shifting into an exploration of brotherhood and finally into something much more self-reflective.

Like comfort food, this movie has very little nutritional value, but it sure goes down smoothly. This is one of those shamelessly delicious-looking films that makes our mouths water at the tasty dishes that are lovingly created on-camera.
Even fans of chillingly oblique new Greek cinema (see Dogtooth and Alps) will find this pitch-black drama utterly terrifying simply because it doesn't look like a horror movie.
With improv-style performances, using stories based on real-life experiences, this film has a strong blast of authenticity to shine light on a big issue.
French filmmaker Cedric Klapisch keeps the tone light and the serious themes just under the surface as he revisits the lively characters from The Spanish Apartment (2002) and Russian Dolls (2005).
Music-lover Clint Eastwood adapts the long-running stage musical for the big screen with mixed results: it recounts a terrific true story but has an uneven pace.
French filmmaker Luc Besson continues to combine family themes with intense violence (see Taken), but at least this film has a wry sense of humour about it.
Simplistic and sometimes painfully goofy, this Australian musical comedy only holds the attention by occasionally touching on some real relational issues.
Based on the beloved novel by John Green, this film is so squarely slanted toward teen girls that it is likely to annoy everyone else.
Yet another found-footage thriller, this chilling horror film at least has some solid roots as a fictionalised version of real events.
The French don't always get the balance right in their farcical romantic comedies, but they usually win us over with goofy charm. Alas, the plan never quite comes together this time.
As he did in Amelie, French filmmaker Jean-Pierre Jeunet tells a simple fable with witty visuals, colourful characters and a warm heart.
movie_title: The Young And Prodigious T.S. Spivet (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The plot feels like a Jane Austen novel infused with a hot-potato political issue, but this is actually a true story.
While using every horror movie cliche in the book, this film cleverly tells a bracingly original story that will have genre fans squirming in their seats.
It's extremely rare for a low-budget mock-documentary to come together as well as this scruffy little British comedy.
Comedies don't get much more pitch-black than this fiendishly clever film, which will shift into horror for everyone in the audience, although that tipping point varies for each person.
With his debut feature, writer-director Ryan Coogler recreates a real-life event with remarkable artistry.
A consistently hilarious stream of in-jokes keeps the audience in fits of laughter even if there's virtually no plot to this follow-up to the 2012 hit 21 Jump Street.
While the tone is all wrong, this fantastical version of a momentous year in the life of Grace Kelly is still entertaining, and not just unintentionally.
As in his Golden Globe-winning 2005 drama Paradise Now, Israeli filmmaker Hany Abu-Assad takes a complex, personal approach to a touchy political-religious situation in this Palestinian love story.
Expert writing, directing and acting help this offbeat drama discover some powerful new themes in a novella that has been scandalising Western society since it was first published in 1870.
Based on the events documented in West of Memphis and the Paradise Lost trilogy, this drama takes an almost clinical approach to the story.
After the success of Ted, Seth MacFarlane gives himself his first leading-man role in this hilarious but overlong comedy-Western.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Fans of the Oscar-winning 2006 Irish film Once (and its more recent stage-musical adaptation) may find this American drama a little derivative, but it's a strong story in its own right.
With echoes of Forrest Gump and Zelig, this jaggedly funny Swedish adventure traces the life of a centenarian who interacts with key figures throughout the 20th century.
movie_title: The 100-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared (2015)

movie_review_blurb: With his first romantic-comedy, Daniel Radcliffe proves adept at delivering snappy dialogue and generating strong chemistry with his costars, so it's frustrating that the film is never remotely believable.

It's taken nearly 10 years for filmmaker Robert Rodriguez and graphic novelist Frank Miller to get around to making this sequel, but it was worth the wait because the technical advancements make this second triptych of stories even more visually stunning.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Luc Besson gleefully combines two of his favourite movie elements - fit women and wildly insane action - in this raucous guilty pleasure.

With an approach so saccharine that it makes Eat Pray Love look like an edgy thriller, this heartwarming meaning-of-life odyssey is so relentlessly schmalzy that it quickly annoys anyone with even a tiny spark of cynicism inside them.
movie_title: Hector And The Search For Happiness (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Cleverly assembled to tell a complex true story from a hugely engaging perspective, this documentary can't help but spark a sense of righteous rage in the audience.
While the story centres on twisted moral dilemmas, this 1970s-set thriller takes such a hesitant, internalised approach that if never lets viewers under the characters' skin.

Striking a tone somewhere between the po-faced original and the silly Part 2, this rampaging action nonsense is badly overcrowded and chaotic, but there's plenty of comedy and whizzy stuntwork to keep the audience entertained.
Fiercely original and wildly ambitious, this provocative drama is often thrilling simply because it's like nothing ever put on-screen.
While this atmospheric Australian Outback thriller has plenty of edgy action, it's also meandering and arty, refusing to fill in the details until filmmaker David Michod is good and ready.
Despite the fact that this too-soon spin-off feels like a mere cash-in on the Disney Cars/Planes marketing machine, this sequel is actually a lot more fun than expected.
With a low-key pace and extremely loose plot, this introspective drama gets deep under the skin as it explores a pivotal summer for two brothers.
Step Up movies are known for their trite, formulaic plots and eye-catching dance set-pieces, and this instalment in the series certainly won't disappoint the fans.
With sensitivity and a strong sense of humour, this documentary profiles both a strikingly eccentric man and an unusual mental-health issue.

For a comedy that so desperately wants to be rude and sexy, this movie is remarkably timid. It does a great job putting up a front as an anarchic laugh riot, but the genuinely funny moments are few and far between.
After a string of projects in America (including the masterpiece Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind), French filmmaker Michel Gondry returns home to let his manic imagination run wild.

By refusing to follow the usual formula, filmmaker James Gunn has made Marvel's best-yet movie, a summer action-adventure that provides more cinematic fun than the rest of the year's blockbusters rolled into one.
Actor-producer Gael Garcia Bernal takes a strikingly complex look at the timely issue of human migration from Central America to the United States, which is rarely depicted with such honest humanity.
Nicolas Cage gives a rare internalised performance in this atmospheric drama, which has a stronger sense of its location than it does of its story.

After last year's break-out hit thriller, writer-director James DeMonaco is back with the flip-side of the story, which jettisons the irony and and thematic subtlety in favour of in-your-face brutality.
Far more entertaining than it has any right to be, this is a big, messy blockbuster retelling of the Greek myth that thankfully has a sharp sense of humour and some surprising twists up its sleeve.
Refreshingly avoiding the usual romantic-comedy formula, this low-key British film has an enjoyably loose tone even if it sometimes feels rather random in its approach to the story.
With an appropriate explosion of humour and colour, this documentary traces the life of a fiercely individualistic actor, digging beneath the surface to explore both his origins and his legacy.
Nicolas Cage acts his socks off in this thinly plotted thriller, which is set in the same moral universe as the Taken movies, where mass murder is excusable if your daughter's been kidnapped.
Bigger and even richer than the terrific 2010 hit animation, this sequel is also quite possibly the best action-adventure movie of the year.
With each film in the Transformer saga, Michael Bay makes it clear that all he's interested in are massive metallic special effects bashing into each other and usually exploding.
By shooting this film over 12 years, writer-director Richard Linklater is able to explore family dynamics in an intensely involving way that's never been seen on-screen before.
When a French filmmaker travels to Belgium to film a German story in English, it's hardly surprising that the resulting movie feels somewhat awkward.

With bouncy pop tunes and a breezy tone, this Scottish musical sometimes feels so weightless that it seems to float right out of existence. At other times it's startlingly dark and moving, touching on earthy emotions and important themes.

As she did with Alice in Wonderland, screenwriter Linda Woolverton uses simplistic plotting and clumsy dialogue to turn a children's story into an eerily dark Lord of the Rings-style effects extravaganza.
Despite substandard animation, this brightly coloured sequel has a strong enough sense of both its story and characters to hold the audience's attention.
Based on a true story, this Brazilian drama has a lush authenticity as it tells a story that has strong historical relevance even as it sometimes slips into heightened melodrama.
An old-school caper comedy, this goofy romp struggles to surmount its badly contrived screenplay.
A riveting performance from Tom Hardy makes this pseudo-thriller utterly riveting, turning even the most contrived plot elements into punchy drama.
As with the too-early franchise reboot in 2012, this sequel struggles to balance the demands of a teen romance with a superhero blockbuster.
Deliberately disorienting, this stylish Belgian horror movie will delight fans of Italian giallo as it finds an odd emotional connection even though the surreal plot never quite comes into focus.
movie_title: The Strange Color of Your Body's Tears (2014)

movie_review_blurb: After the linear kick of 2011's surprise Indonesian hit The Raid, Welsh filmmaker Gareth Evans is back with an epic-style sequel that sags under the weight of its ambitions.
When this South African animated adventure embraces its unique setting and characters, it's visually stunning and a lot of fun.
After the 2011 black comedy The Guard, Brendan Gleeson reteams with writer-director John Michael McDonagh for a darker comical drama grappling with issues of faith and forgiveness.
There's such an important issue at the centre of this British thriller that the film should not be ignored, even if filmmaker Shan Khan strains to turn it into a formulaic thriller.
After his acclaimed drama Submarine, actor-turned-filmmaker Richard Ayoade applies his considerable visual skills to this striking blackly comical adaptation of Dostoevsky's novella.

After the snappy, clever 2011 original, this sequel feels rather lazy by comparison: it's still visually colourful and sometimes witty, but the overcrowded story is all over the place, mixing wacky slapstick and corny satire with a political message.
Filmmaker Neil Burger is more interested in whizzy visuals and a thorny plot to pay much attention to the characters or larger underlying themes, which leaves the film feeling eerily superficial.

Swedish filmmaker Lukas Moodysson returns to the improv-style charms of his earlier films (like Together and Show Me Love), a welcome break from his more recent grim experimental dramas (see Mammoth or Lilya 4-ever).
Darren Aronofsky continues to ambitiously experiment with genres in this Old Testament blockbuster, but this is his first real misstep as a filmmaker, as the impressive parts simply don't add up.
There's basically just one joke in this scruffy British comedy, and it's dragged out painfully for the better part of an hour before the script finally clicks into gear.
There are some very dark corners in this cheeky comedy, which explores relationships and sexuality in unusually realistic ways.
Entertaining and uplifting, this Oscar-winning documentary tells the unknown story of the back-up singers who made classic records so memorable.
This is the Marvel movie that divides the fans from the casual filmgoers, as the movies become more like a TV series in which the world is saved from disaster every week.
Where the 2011 reboot felt effortless in the way it recaptured that warmly anarchic Muppets humour, this sequel feels like it's working every step of the way.
Rising star Jack O'Connell delivers a ripping performance as a young convict with more baggage than you'd think humanly possible.
With a darkly serious theme and a corny rom-com filmmaking approach, this film never quite comes together into something meaningful.
There's enough charming energy in this loose London music scene comedy to keep us entertained, but the plot drives us round the bend by refusing to go anywhere.

With one of Kate Winslet's most layered, resonant performances, this film is definitely worth a look, even though the indulgent filmmaking style pushes it perilously close to Nicholas Sparks-style sappiness.
Like Coco Before Chanel, this French designer biopic is far too respectful of its subject to come to life properly as a movie.

While this sibling comedy makes some sharp observations about the push and pull of family relationships, it's also one of those deliberately wacky movies that wears us out with nonstop gags that are utterly unconvincing.
Despite some dark edges, this crowd-pleasing Laotian drama is far too heartwarming for its own good.

After black comedy (I Killed My Mother), ethereal romance (Heartbeats) and gender-bending drama (Laurence Anyways), eerily gifted 25-year-old Canadian filmmaker Xavier Dolan turns to Hitchcock for inspiration.
A smarter-than-expected script turns this noisy sci-fi action movie into something remarkably entertaining.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Even if the premise is tired, this grim thriller holds the attention by focussing on the raw intensity of the characters' personal lives.
While the story isn't particularly original, and the movie tends to drift over the top into broad slapstick, this comedy wins us over due to the camaraderie between the characters.
Even with its inane script and limp direction, this film is watchable simply because Drew Barrymore is present to humanise Adam Sandler.
With energy and insight, this documentary races through the life of one of the most influential musicians of the 1990s, feminist punk artist Kathleen Hanna.
With a witty observational script, amusing characters and a jazzy sense of life in New York, this feels like an old-fashioned Woody Allen movie, even though Allen merely costars in it.

Continuing to be the most original and resonant of the Marvel superhero franchises, the X-men return in the capable hands of director Bryan Singer, who again stirs plenty of meaty subtext beneath the thrilling action.

The most surprising thing about this comedy is that it's not very funny, but then it's not meant to be. This is a trippy odyssey into the mind of a drug-addled guy who thinks the world is falling apart around him.
A sharply observed odyssey of middle-aged self-discovery, this strikingly offbeat film may feel a little vague in its approach, but it carries a strong kick.
After a couple of gimmicky transgressive comedies (Humpday and Your Sister's Sister), writer-director Lynn Shelton takes a more observant approach this time.
This sun-drenched thriller is much more than a pretty picture: it's also a slow-burning story about moral compromises that worms its way under the skin.
For a blockbuster about gigantic radioactive monsters, this is a remarkably humane movie.

Reuniting with filmmaker Philippe Claudel (I've Loved You So Long), Kristin Scott Thomas delivers yet another brittle, understated performance as a woman who isn't always likeable but is hugely sympathetic.
Arnold Schwarzenegger gets one of his most complex roles yet in this messy, violent thriller, another trip to the dark side for filmmaker David Ayer.
By mashing up so many genres, filmmaker Jerome Sable has made a thoroughly entertaining romp that's impossible to categorise.
Far too slow-paced to work as a thriller and too shallow to properly challenge us as science fiction, this film is unlikely to please many audience members.
While this comedy-drama is sometimes wilfully absurd, it's also exhilarating cinema, telling its story with conflicting amounts of warm emotion and prickly abrasiveness.

This is one of those little films that proves that you don't need a blockbuster budget to make a high-concept movie. McDonald and Burgess create a mass-chaos apocalyptic thriller with essentially just three characters in a windowless room.
There's a blast of raucous energy to this lively comedy that sets it apart from the pack; aside from a willingness to get deeply rude and incorrect, the movie is actually very funny.

Lazy filmmaking undermines this sparky caper thriller, from paper-thin characters and convenient plot points to limp direction and corny editing. This is a real shame, because the bright rising-star cast brings real energy to the weak material.

The central joke in this low-budget comedy should have been a springboard to something either blackly hilarious or more amusingly complex, but the filmmakers seem to have run out of ideas after coming up with the title.
Like an ancient Roman version of 2012, this disaster epic is a pure guilty pleasure, sparking plenty of laughter along with the massive effects-based carnage.
The 90th film based on the books by Edgar Rice Burroughs, this German-made animated romp adds little to the century-old canon besides some motion-capture action and an eco-friendly message.

This documentary about the worst World Cup competitors in history is much more than a football movie: it's an engaging and hugely uplifting exploration of people with real passion for their community.
Too prickly for mainstream crowds and rather emotionally sentimental for arthouse fans, this drama may have trouble finding an audience.
Eurovison fans will find this Israeli comedy to be sheer cinematic joy. Not only is it a hilariously astute satire of the music competition, but it's also packed with deeper political meaning.
Dark and freaky, this brutal, low-key revenge thriller throws a bunch of relatively simple people into a moral quagmire, and drags us in as well.
The true story behind this movie just about makes up for its oddly flat tone, which never quite captures either the grandeur of the Australian Outback or the deeper emotions of the people on-screen.

This offbeat British drama shows real promise for new filmmaker Justin Edgar, although his relentlessly gimmicky filmmaking style is so attention-grabbing that it makes it nearly impossible to engage with the story or characters.
For what he has said will be his final film, animation maestro Hayao Miyazaki tackles a controversial biopic that could just as easily have been shot in live action.

Much more than an unsettling horror movie, this film gets under the skin to play with the audience's emotional response, eliciting dark sympathies with the killers. It's an uncanny trick that Belgian director Fabrice Du Welz does extremely well.
The Dardenne brothers consistently make compelling dramas that win awards, from Rosetta (1999) to The Kid With a Bike (2011), and this drama might be their best yet.
Based on a true story, this is one of those relentlessly uplifting Disney movies that mixes comedy and emotion to inspire and move the audience.
It may not be very clever, and the plot may be full of holes, but this sequel's clammy atmosphere is so unnerving that it manages to keep us squirming in our seats.
movie_title: The Woman in Black 2 Angel of Death (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Be warned: this is a movie meant only for hardcore fans of the 1994 original, and other moronic comedies in which plot, character and filmmaking coherence aren't important.
A solid cast bodes well for this unnecessary remake of the 1982 movie (based on the 1970s musical), but the filmmakers' decision to turn the catchy songs into bland pop numbers is the real mistake.
With a true story that's almost hard to believe, this inspiring biographical drama is made with attention to detail and a remarkable resistance to sentiment.
Now in its third instalment, it's clearer than ever that this franchise is based on one joke that has been stretched far beyond the breaking point.
movie_title: Night at the Museum: Secret of the Tomb (2014)

movie_review_blurb: While this ambitious Norwegian historical adventure sometimes dips into melodrama, it's a riveting, fascinating true story about passion and tenacity.

Aside from impressive 21st century digital effects, this new take on the Moses story pales in comparison to Cecil B. DeMille's iconic 1956 version, The Ten Commandments, which is far more resonant and intensely dramatic.

An intriguing combination of drama and documentary, this Swiss film tells a simple story that's compelling and still timely, addressing issues of equality and prejudice from an often startlingly personal perspective.
A gimmicky observation of life in Nepal, this is one of those documentaries that offers the audience an experience rather than any actual information.
With an artful aesthetic that will please fans of ambitious independent filmmaking, this British drama struggles to match its lush imagery with an oddly simplistic script.
Middle-aged romances are rare on the big screen, so it's frustrating that this one is so badly compromised by a series of contrived plot points.

Peter Jackson's expanded take on J.R.R. Tolkien's The Hobbit comes to a conclusion in a battle epic packed with enormous action sequences that oddly distract attention from the much more engaging central plotline.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: An unusual point of view prevents this from ever turning into the standard biopic, but it's Eddie Redmayne's staggeringly committed performance as Stephen Hawking that makes the film unmissable.
While this submarine adventure starts out as a brainy thriller with superior production design, it eventually gives in to the demands of the genre: silly plotting and corny melodrama.
Solidly entertaining Christmas movies are so rare that when one comes along it feels like the best gift ever.
Leave it to Hong Kong maestro Wong Kar Wai (In the Mood for Love) to reinvent both the historical biopic and Chinese kung fu action movie in one fell swoop.
There's a fundamental flaw to this multi-strand social media-themed drama: it's told completely from the perspective of older people.
Bill Murray shines in this story of a cynical grump whose life is changed by his friendship with a bright young kid.
A suitable portrait of one of Britain's greatest living painters, this artful documentary offers wonderful access to David Hockney, his family, friends, colleagues and of course his artwork.
Like The Hangover, Horrible Bosses was a movie no one really wanted to see a sequel to, but here it is anyway: the same film, but even more inane.
Packed with never-released material, this documentary tells the life story of Muhammad Ali from angles we haven't seen before, even as it has a tendency to drift into hero worship.
It's difficult not to go into a movie like this with a sense of dread, as the beloved children's book becomes a live-action movie with a digitally animated, eerily realistic-looking bear.
A bracingly audacious approach to storytelling sets this film apart from the crowd, as it recounts an unnerving series of events in an inventive way.
Aside from being flat-out hilarious, this vampire-themed reality TV spoof actually has some pungent things to say about friendship in the 21st century. Not that it's ever trying to make a point.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Every threat of sentimentality and melodrama is averted by a seriously strong cast working from a snappy script.

This four-part franchise, based on the Suzanne Collins novels, turns very dark with this strikingly bold third film, which once again makes the most of perspective to recount a parable about normal people rising up against oppression.
An extremely topical theme and unpredictable characters hold the audience's attention even when this French drama takes some rather implausible turns.
Strong characters and a vivid sense of life in frontier America give this film a kick of authentic energy that makes it a gripping journey.

It's taken a long time for this stage musical to make it to the big screen, and while director Rob Marshall once again fails to give the story a sharp focus (see also Chicago and Nine), he at least lets the music and characters shine.
Mexican filmmaker Alejandro Gonzalez Inarritu continues to reject traditional narrative structures with this whizzy, ambitious exploration of celebrity, art and commerce.
Life-changing moments feature in each of the nine short films in this Australian anthology, and each is told with remarkable artistry and sensitivity.

Even without a single word of spoken dialogue, this film has more charm and energy than most Hollywood blockbusters. But then the voice cast supplies all manner of moans, chuckles, grunts and sighs to let us know what the characters are thinking.
One of the finest biopics in recent memory, this drama manages to present someone as iconic as Martin Luther King Jr. as a normal man anyone can aspire to emulate.
Filmmaking siblings Lana and Andy Wachowski never do anything by halves. The Matrix was a genre-changing blockbuster followed by two head-scratching sequels that ramped everything up a bit too much.
There's half of a great satire here, as Seth Rogen, James Franco and Evan Goldberg combine that freewheeling mayhem from This Is the End with some more pointed political comedy.
Despite a superior cast and terrific-looking production values, this mystery romp is a misfire on every level.
With clips from more than 200 teen movies made in the decade after 1995's Clueless, this lively kaleidoscopic documentary entertainingly traces how America has depicted the teen experience on screen.
Slick and seductive, this exploration of artificial intelligence may essentially only have three characters, but it's complex, provocative and thoroughly engaging.
With a strangely simplistic screenplay by William Monahan (The Departed), director Rupert Wyatt and his cast struggle to dig beneath the surface in a meaningful way.
With this confident drama, J.C. Chandor (Margin Call, All Is Lost) continues to evolve as a filmmaker, giving the mob movie a remarkably thoughtful twist with vivid characters and situations.

Romantic comedies depend on the sympathies of an audience, but in this scruffy movie actor-filmmaker Simon Helberg (The Big Bang Theory) plays a character so relentlessly naive and self-absorbed that it's impossible to root for him.
It's hard to think of another film that leaves us quite so out of breath.
Director Bennett Miller continues to skilfully probe around the edges of true stories with this follow-up to Capote and Moneyball, although this is a much, much darker tale.
Reese Witherspoon gives a beautifully stripped-back performance in this epic journey based on the memoir by Cheryl Strayed.
For a film about early onset Alzheimer's, this is a remarkably wry, honest and even hopeful drama, anchored by another staggeringly sensitive performance by Julianne Moore.

With a strikingly unflinching eye, newcomer Sara Colangelo astutely adapts her 2010 short into an evocative feature, beautifully capturing the impact a series of random tragedies can have on a community.
Once again, director Clint Eastwood lurks in the background, springing a stunningly atmospheric thriller on audiences when they least expect it.

As with the first two films in this dumb but bombastically watchable franchise, writers Luc Besson and Robert Mark Kamen seemingly put no effort into writing a script that can even remotely hold water.
Refusing to settle down to focus on its intriguing central story, filmmaker Greg Francis whirls around through a series of whizzy flashbacks that layer in all kinds of subtext and interest.

At three and a half hours, this documentary sometimes feels both overlong and far too detailed, but filmmaker Claude Lanzmann knows that this material is vitally important, and by putting it all out there he challenges the viewer to understand the truth.
With sometimes unnerving honesty, this multi-strand Mexican drama explores male sexuality through stories set at four stages of life (or four phases of the moon).
This may be a thriller starring Jake Gyllenhaal, but mainstream audiences should also note that this is an artful film that refuses to tell its story using the usual formula.

Nigerian filmmaker Jeta Amata clearly feels passionate about the problems in his country, but despite the presence of Hollywood stars the movie is made in a style that will feel amateurish to Western audiences.
Bright and flashy, with enough energy to keep the audience entertained, this animated action-adventure movie is far too formulaic to become a classic.
Gentle and almost overwhelmingly bittersweet, this drama is packed with such engaging characters that the weaknesses of the plot don't seem too distracting.

Tim Burton combines his sunnier filmmaking style (Big Fish) with his more deranged impulses (Dark Shadows) for this amazing true story about both the nature of art and how easy it is to slip into an unhealthy relationship.

A classic British memoir gets the full costume drama treatment with this beautifully crafted World War I drama, although it never quite transcends the "beloved book" tone, remaining so worthy that it only rarely springs to life.

With an appropriately jarring sense of energy, this James Brown biopic acutely captures the Godfather of Soul's iconic musical talents, although the fragmented script undermines any emotional kick in his story.
Expanded from Cyril Gely's stage play, this film remains finely focussed on a history-changing dialogue between two men on the day Paris changed hands from the Nazis to the Allies.
