Paul Walker remains behind the steering wheel, but this action thriller has a whiff of the arthouse about it, simply by being set in South Africa.
Blackly comical writing and direction add a playful slant to what could have been a typically over-serious British crime thriller.
The most impressive thing about the sixth entry into this noisy franchise is that it's both more preposterous and more self-important than ever before. Which is no mean feat.

Baz Luhrmann (Moulin Rouge) is the perfect director to take on F. Scott Fitzgerald's iconic novel about the American dream, simply because he's an expert at showing the emptiness of hyperactive excess.
Wheatley playfully bends genres in this romantic-comedy road movie so we never know what might happen next.
Adept filmmaking and a clever two-perspective approach make this film urgent and involving, even when the narrative structure falters.
This is masterful, unsettling filmmaking that moves us deeply. It also has the power to save lives.
Without missing a beat, Abrams continues with his reimagined Star Trek universe, offering satisfying nods to the past and a fresh surge forward.
With a focus on messy family relationships, this thriller's deranged comical touches almost make up for its contrived plot and annoyingly thin characters.
Some meaty themes and complex performances add badly needed weight to this somewhat simplistic British comedy-drama.
Marion Cotillard delivers another raw, devastating performance in this beautifully made drama about two badly damaged people who adapt to a new life together.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: There's plenty of potential for jagged black humour in this suburban comedy-drama, but the filmmakers never take a single risk.
Sharp digital photography makes this Antarctic documentary worth a look for nature-movie fans, even though it's both childish and unoriginal.
Taking the found-footage thriller to a new level, this film throws real-life teens into an extraordinary story while deepening the characters and providing exhilarating action.

This startling documentary explores a part of America few even want to admit exists: a place designed as a paradise that has instead become an almost apocalyptic wasteland populated by people who have fallen out of society.
It's a very well-made film, but not very easy to engage with.
Not much is happening of any real interest. At least the sparky collection of characters helps overcome the film's corny tone.
Sadly misguided from the start, this violent war-zone adventure suffers from both a very low budget and a script that seems to have been written by someone who has never been outside Great Britain.
Fractured into two narratives that take far too long to come together, this stylish boogeyman thriller never convinces us that anyone is in actual peril.
There's so little to this film that you've almost forgotten everything about it by the time the closing credits start to roll.
What makes this film stand out from the crowd is its insistence on making sure that the action is grounded in human physicality, internalised drama and the laws of gravity.

More like a cinematic poem or art installation than a movie, this swirly collection of imagery - some new, some found - loosely traces the nine muses from Greek mythology. And it's for adventurous filmgoers only.
An intriguing idea and inventive visual approach is let down by a script that runs out out of steam before it ever reaches full speed.
A smart script and vivid characters make this rowdy hockey comedy much more engaging than we expect.
An excellent ensemble makes the most of a multi-strand female-centred film that drifts very close to melodrama as it explores various aspects of motherhood.
It's an enjoyably ridiculous romp with far-fetched action for the kids and a few deranged gags for the grown-ups.
Solid performances and an accessible script make it resonate.
While it has the same comical energy, it's not quite as fun as the first go-round.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: [Bird] takes an eye-popping approach to the genre, creating a guilty pleasure romp that balances corny plotting with muscled-up fun.
There isn't much on the surface of this prickly comedy, but the sharp script slices through American culture so astutely that we continually see ourselves in characters who are clearly losers.
A remarkably honest and sometimes rather grim look at the dark side of love and sex.
The stories and filmmaking overdose on ill-conceived schmaltz.
Even though it's rather corny and sentimental, this colourful comedy-drama holds our interest mainly because it's about a subject we'd never imagine watching a film about.
It's a powerfully involving exploration of guilt and self-discovery. It's also packed with astonishingly complex characters and situations.

This skilful narrative documentary vividly captures the urgency of Ghana's precarious 2008 presidential elections. The people are terrific movie characters, and the sense of a nation moving forward is remarkably gripping.
The grounded approach and honest performances are provocative and unsettling. As is the fact that it's based on a true story.
Based on Michael Lewis' nonfiction book, this film is written, directed and played with both intelligence and emotion.
Based on Colin Clark's memoirs, this film sometimes feels a bit too warm and nostalgic for its own good. But the performances are strong, and it's packed with terrific moments.
There's an intriguing idea here, but this thriller feels like it has been compromised in the test-screening phase, resulting in a badly muddled plot.
A fairly straightforward character portrait without any real analysis or message, this biopic succeeds because of the translucent performance by Meryl Streep.
It's a great idea, and the filmmaking is sensitive and complex, although it's never as exciting as it should be.
this film seems to exist only to showcase tough women in various states of undress being tormented by vile men and then getting even.
A grounding in the real-life story makes this film much less sentimental than it looks.
It's a slow build until the final act, but it remains gripping thanks to a snaky plot that gets nastier and scarier as it develops.
Its increasingly preposterous narrative and hysterically over-violent action makes it something of a guilty pleasure.
Through interviews with family, friends and colleagues, it provides an entertaining, telling look at both the man and his beliefs.
Zac Efron isn't a bad actor, but this kind of sappy movie will do nothing to build his credibility.
The script for this horror romp is almost too inventive, cleverly combining clashing genres and playing hilariously with a range of cliches while thoroughly grossing out the audience.
While this sequel is just as loud and chaotic as 2010's Clash of the Titans remake, it's also considerably more fun due to some exhilarating action and a refreshing sense of humour.

Reissued to tie in with the 100th anniversary of the Titanic's ill-fated maiden voyage, it's astonishing how timeless the film looks. And as a true classic, it doesn't lose our attention for a moment.
Funny, fizzy and packed with astute observations, this endearing film can't help but make us smile.
While it's too uneven and corny to be a classic, it's still a lot of fun.
It not only forces us to examine our opinions, but it moves us to tears.
It's rare to see a blockbuster with such a sharp political sensibility. And the actors are terrific in complex roles.
There isn't a single moment in this film that feels authentic...
This jagged, meandering exploration of a Scientology-style movement is hauntingly mesmerising and packed with meaty performances.
Dr Seuss' eco-fable is transformed into a raucous adventure comedy in this colourful animated feature. And it's a little embarrassing really.
It's engaging enough to keep us watching, but never finds any real focus.
An unusually sharp script makes this silly comedy thoroughly enjoyable, even when it tips over the top.
There's not much resonance, which is a shame because the film has a thoroughly engaging premise and the actors are charming.
It's sharply well-made and acted, but nothing about it remotely scratches beneath the surface.
Shamelessly enjoyable, this raucous Aussie movie keeps us laughing - and ultimately sniffling back the tears - as it recounts an urban myth.
A lively pace and a nicely warped sense of humour help make this paper-thin action-comedy a mindlessly enjoyable romp.
This relatively standard nostalgic teen drama holds our interest through its colourful settings and characters.
It veers rather widely through strains of comedy, melodrama and crime-thriller, but it's very well made, consistently engaging and surprisingly moving.
What the film lacks in subtlety and finesse it makes up with sparky characters and meaty songs.
It's an engaging, personal story full of moving details.
It's a little too vague to be satisfying, but it's thoroughly haunting.

This film is watchable mainly because of the extraordinary events, which are genuinely involving and moving. Although typically, Hollywood has ramped up the emotions while avoiding subtlety at all costs.
It manages to achieve a balance between the action and spoofery due to sure-handed direction and a cast that really dives into the mayhem.

Made as a 1920s-style silent movie, this hugely enjoyable film is already a classic. And while it's far from mainstream, it's also packed with more wit, passion and invention than all of the films in any given multiplex combined.

Harrelson reunites with The Messenger writer-director Moverman for this grim drama about police corruption in late-1990s Los Angeles. But while it's sharply well-made, the film doesn't really offer anything new to the bad-cop genre.
A surprisingly entertaining romp.
Soderbergh applies his brainier brand of filmmaking to the global outbreak thriller genre, and the result is a hugely gripping blockbuster that never talks down to its audience.
The story and characters have nowhere to go beyond bleak acceptance of the inevitable. So it's difficult to care what happens.
Relentlessly heartwarming, this film can't help but move us to tears.
It's not hugely consistent or clever, but this one's at least amusing.
Claims to recount true events but is frankly very hard to believe.
While the elusive subject of this documentary is fascinating, filmmaker Sudler-Smith us almost as interested in his own celebrity as in that of iconic fashion designer Halston.
In the end, the platitudes take over completely, but the inspirational story is still worth telling.

JJ Abrams and Steven Spielberg team up for this enjoyable alien thriller, which feels exactly how we nostalgically remember Spielberg's late-70s movies. But it's not nearly as earthy or thrilling as they actually were.
It's effortlessly honest, with edgy humour balancing the dark themes.
It's very silly, but also thoroughly entertaining because it gives us exactly what we want.
There are plenty of skilled people behind this female-empowerment movie, but the film badly botches its core message.
movie_title: I Don't Know How She Does It (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Renowned architect Norman Foster has created some of the world's most iconic buildings, and this documentary explores the ideas that link them. Although it only barely scratches the surface of his talent and skill.
movie_title: How Much Does Your Building Weigh, Mr. Foster? (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Films about cancer aren't generally this funny. And while this movie isn't a comedy, beyond its generous dose of realistic humour, it has a smart, personal script that dares to face a difficult situation head on.
Based on the James Sallis novel, this lean, stylish thriller is confidently assembled to pull us into an outrageous series of events.
It's rare to see a film in which writers, director and cast all respect the intelligence of their audience. So when it happens, it's something to savour.
Thoroughly enjoyable, with the zing of real crowds and musicians overcoming some very corny plot turns.
There's a lot of talent both in front of and behind the camera on this gripping, low-budget London drama, so it's frustrating that the script doesn't give everyone more to work with.
It makes virtually no sense if you think about it, and the writing and direction are mostly incoherent. But it's also guilty good fun.
Exceptional acting and a smart script add spice to what's otherwise a fairly low-key political thriller that feels somewhat dated in its subject matter.
The bright cast holds our interest, but the corny, too-cute plot will only be of interest to pre-teen girls.

Wheatley follows up his terrific debut Down Terrace with another genre-bending film that continually catches us off guard. This time we're watching a freak-out horror movie wrapped in a thoughtful exploration of the tides of relationships.
This inventive horror film plays to our deepest childhood fears. It's like a demented variation on The Borrowers, and first-rate acting and effects work combine to thoroughly creep us out.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Feels more like a cheap kids' TV series than an actual movie.
movie_title: Spy Kids: All the Time in the World in 4D (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A strongly issue-based story gives a terrific cast plenty to play with in this hugely engaging drama about the American South in the 1960s. And while the film kind of skims the surface, it's a story that still needs to be told.
The Glee phenomenon hits the big screen with this oddly conceived movie, which documents the social phenomenon but reveals nothing about the series or actors beyond the songs they sing.
This film is painstakingly detailed in its recreation of iconic events and images. It's also beautifully played by a superb cast, although the story is undermined by unnecessary sideplots.

Fans will love this energetic documentary tracing more than two decades of the infamous grunge band. But while the film is packed with terrific footage, it's too worshipful for non-fans to take seriously.
The plot is somewhat theatrical, but the stellar cast brings it to life.

Shannon reteams with Shotgun Stories writer-director Nichols for another exploration of one man's wobbling mental state. But this time the story is much more introspective, and watching it is thoroughly unnerving.
Solondz takes another hilariously pitch-black exploration of human behaviour with a film populated by excellent actors playing seriously messed-up characters.

This Shrek spin-off continues the theme of mashing up fairy tales with movie genres, and while there's a slightly stale odour lingering through this prequel, it's also witty enough to keep us laughing.
This British rom-com has enough energy to keep us watching even though it's not particularly funny or romantic.
movie_title: How To Stop Being A Loser (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Exquisitely designed and directed, with finely tuned performances that shine even through some heavy make-up, this true story never quite succeeds in conveying its central relationship.
Observant writing and direction make this exploration of grief surprisingly uplifting.
The camera work on this nature documentary is so staggering that it really is worth seeing on a very big screen.
Like Logan's work, it's entertaining while also making an important point.
movie_title: The British Guide To Showing Off (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Despite some crazy antics, the film takes an earnest, slightly too-faithful tone that makes it strangely leaden.
Even when the plot stalls in the middle, it's difficult to stop chuckling at the filmmakers' deranged sense of humour.
With a high concept and a lazy script, there isn't much to this caper comedy at all.
As with Sideways and About Schmidt, Payne finds clever ways to blend sharp comedy and warm drama to create a seriously involving and entertaining film.

Herzog departs sharply from the quirky tone of his recent documentaries to offer a startlingly astute and sensitive exploration of a horrific murder case. But more generally, he's looking at the use of the death penalty in the United States.
This beautifully assembled film is easy to watch. But that's the problem: the subject matter should be much more difficult than this, as it's about having the courage to make unexpected choices.
The worthy story is packed with scenes that are suspenseful and inspiring.
Yes, this film looks amazing. It also borrows enjoyably from Spielberg's entire back catalog.
With a deliberately wistful style, this romantic drama never quite convinces us that its central couple is actually in love.
With its deliberately quirky characters and meandering series of events, this mumblecore movie is enjoyably ramshackle, constantly catching us off guard with spiky humour or warm emotion.

With a disturbing tone and skilful filmmaking, this insinuating drama completely unsettles us as it delves into the mental life of its central character. And it has a lot to say about how relationships affect us.
Jack Black delivers one of his strongest performances in this rather outrageous true story from East Texas, which Linklater tells with a witty blend of comedy, drama and documentary.
In the end, the film is watchable mainly because the plot is so outrageously contentious.
Riveting performances hold our attention even when this dark drama starts wallowing in the messy lives of its central characters.
The film radiates intelligence through clever direction and strong performances.
Beautifully filmed and acted, but lacking a central perspective.
Witty filmmaking and Penn's quirky performance keep it watchable, even though the story and themes are vague and elusive.

This unflinching, thoughtful drama about sex addiction is made with such skill and honesty that it continually takes us aback. It also features two bold, raw performances that are among the best of this or any other year.

Actor-director Fiennes sets Shakespeare's military tragedy in a modern-day war setting, which gives it a meaty kick of recognition. But it's such a bombastic film that it's difficult to find much emotional resonance in it.
This strange dual-strand structure leaves the film feeling a bit aimless and unfocussed. But it's so luridly colourful and full-on that we can't stop watching.
A contrived script and clunky direction undermine this British film, which veers from silly comedy to harsh drama to dark tragedy.
It takes a while to get going, but once writer-director Whedon hits his stride, the film rockets through a series of frantically entertaining set pieces.

Important documentaries like this one can spark a range of responses: righteous anger, informed action or exhausted hopelessness. And we experience all three in Jarecki's lucid, engaging, staggeringly urgent film.
This documentary takes a remarkably frank look at the fashion business, using the unusual perspective of a young Russian seeking work in Japan.
Most remarkable is the way the entire film seems so effortless, carrying us off on an adventure we never want to end.
Will Ferrell's funniest movie in years, this is a silly comedy with a terrible sentimental streak, but the political satire running through it is dead on
Despite some big set pieces, it's the smaller emotional moments that get us thinking
Gritty and claustrophobic, this British horror-thriller holds our interest with well-played characters rather than the wobbly plotting.
Contains some effective jolts and engaging characters. But after setting up the premise, it doesn't really have anywhere to go. Kind of like the characters themselves
Shot in 1986 and only just now remastered for release in the West, this documentary captures Queen in all their glory both on stage and behind the scenes
movie_title: Queen - Hungarian Rhapsody: Live In Budapest '86 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The musicians' thoughtful comments add a layer of meaning to their high-energy performance. And on stage, Mercury is simply mesmerising
movie_title: Queen - Hungarian Rhapsody: Live In Budapest '86 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: There's probably a fascinating, complex story behind the invention of the vibrator in 19th century London, but this silly farce isn't it
These are gifted actors who have a decent sense of timing, so they're able to add a hint of gravitas beneath the surface while avoiding most of the stereotypes
Preteen girls will find this soppy romance unbearably romantic, but everyone else will struggle to sit through it
Dominik keeps us off-balance with an unexpected structure, which gives the film an exhilaratingly offbeat rhythm
Oliver Stone takes a stab at returning to a nastier, more edgy filmmaking style, but simply can't escape his moralising ways
The plot has promise, and the sharp, clever actors make the worst dialog sound almost snappy. But the script is a real problem
Indescribably insane, this outrageously inventive French drama is so bracingly strange that we can't help but love every moment.
While much of the humour feels eerily dead-on, the over-the-top antics rely on shock value for laughs. Which is kind of a con when the movie turns out to have such a gooey centre
Documentaries are rarely as hilarious as this one. Well, the first half of it at least
Anyone tired of seeing the same old movies over and over again should rush to find this remarkable Portuguese film, which defies genres and continually surprises us
Will have a much stronger resonance for fans than for those unfamiliar with the band's music. But even newcomers will find the exploration of fame and artistry unusually personal
movie_title: Shut Up and Play the Hits (2012)

movie_review_blurb: All of the slapstick makes it feel nonsensical, but it's grounded in likeable characters we can root for
Tolstoy's iconic novel may have been filmed several times, but you've never seen a version like this
Bursting with energy, this ensemble drama from Iran is raucous, chaotic and packed with strong emotion
While it's playfully inventive, it's also aggravatingly elusive
Although the film isn't much more than a stretched-out television episode, its characters are lively and engaging
Allen spins four separate tales into one frothy romp that's thoroughly enjoyable to watch even as it only barely breaks the surface
Like Monster House, this animated feature taps into horror movie history to tell a story that's both genuinely creepy and a lot of fun
We just laugh at every ridiculous twist and turn. But it's shot with real energy, putting us right on bicycles speeding dangerously through the New York traffic
Streep and Jones are masters at subtext, conveying everything the lacklustre script and direction miss
Carax weaves in a variety of film genres, creating scenes that are hilarious, sigh-inducing, thoughtful, terrifying, hyper-violent, absurd and darkly emotional
Yes, it's a bombastic action thriller. But it's great to finally watch one that doesn't treat the audience like children.
It's a bit low-key and simplistic, but the photography is beautiful and the human stories are riveting.
Based on the true story of an unlikely odd couple who give each other a new lease on life, this French comedy-drama is almost irresistibly engaging
Most intriguing is how the writers and director have transformed what's essentially a rather dark, bleak story into something involving and emotionally resonant, all without ever turning sentimental.
There are moments of inspired black comedy in this Irish slasher spoof, but the movie is undermined by its obviously miniscule budget.
A muscular tone and non-stop action draw us into this Bollywood thriller, which then surprises us as it explores some complex themes about ethics and loyalty.
It's great fun to explore geeky theories about Stanley Kubrick's iconic horror film The Shining, even if most of them are too spurious to take seriously.
Things get very personal for 007 in this high-quality thriller, which keeps us gripped even if it never gets our pulses racing.
It's impossible to understate the importance of this documentary in helping us see exactly what life is like in occupied Palestine.

Instead of developing the characters or situations for comedy gold, the filmmakers instead just crank up the chaos. So while some scenes are both funny and visually impressive, this second sequel is simply too inane.
An extraordinary cast lifts this grim British drama into something watchable, even if the script ultimately gives up trying to make any sense.
Lushly imaginative filmmaking and strong performances more than make up for newcomer Benh Zeitlin's indulgent flourishes as a new writer-director.

Watching the Rolling Stones' home movies while they reminisce on the soundtrack is thoroughly entertaining, although this documentary is such an inside job that it doesn't really tell us anything we don't already know.
With a snappy sense of childish curiosity and lavishly skilled animation, Tim Burton makes one of his most endearing and enjoyably offbeat movies in years.
Audiences out for a bit of mindless fun will probably enjoy this raucous road movie, but only if they can look past comedy that relies on jokes about racism, sexism and homophobia.
The screenwriters started with a great premise and then ran out of ideas, abandoning the more risky, inventive procreation comedy for corny slapstick

Eye-catching animation and non-stop jokes make this animated monster movie a lot more fun than we expect. It's packed with gross-out gags that will keep kids laughing, plus clever character-based humour for the grown-ups.

The filmmakers tell this World War I story beautifully, but they never quite bring it to life as a proper movie. By taking a gently simplistic approach, it never feels like anything new as it deals with the usual topics of battlefield camaraderie.

This film may look sleek and urgent, but it never feels like anything more than a run-of-the-mill London drugs thriller. The cast is good, and the imagery is striking, but it never adds anything new to the genre.
A romantic comedy with a dark twist, this film gets under the skin as it knowingly explores both the writing process and the nature of relationships.

This lively doc is an entertaining race through 50 years of the 007 franchise. The fast-paced narrative skips over a few things here and there, but focusses nicely on the relationships that have sustained the films over the decades.

Clearly intent on being a British Hangover/Bridesmaids hybrid, this comedy romp doesn't contain a single laugh. It doesn't help that all of the characters are deeply unlikeable, or that the humour is literally centred in the toilet.

There wasn't really anywhere for the story to go after 2008's surprise hit Taken, and this movie quickly proves that. Not only does it have that same appalling moral vacuum at the centre, but the plot becomes increasingly absurd as it progresses.

An energetic cast and some terrific music make up for the rather hackneyed plot of this Dreamgirls-style drama. Remade from a 1976 film, the story is that familiar trajectory of musicians who achieve fame only to fall into a string of ugly problems.

Spikier than the average coming-of-age movie, this astute comedy-drama is packed with memorable characters and resonant situations. It's also strikingly intelligent, refusing to accept Hollywood's fake moralising. And even better, it's funny and sexy.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: There's a wonderfully observant tone to this comedy that holds our attention even when the film begins to drift into smugness
This moody, nasty little ghost story is packed with chilling moments that are augmented by a particularly haunted performance from Hawke
Has such recognisably realistic characters that we can't help but be taken back to a pivotal time when the future looked bright. But it seemed impossible to get there
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: You can call this Glee meets Mean Girls if you want to, but this riotously intelligent comedy is much better than that
Despite the skill behind and in front of the camera, a badly constructed script flattens this film version of Jack Kerouac's iconic 1957 novel.
Takes an even-handed approach that never preaches, presenting a resonant side of Iran's society that we have never before seen on screen
What starts as an insightful, bracingly straight-spoken comedy about infertility falls apart in the final act when it diverts into a wacky, under-developed adventure
A mixture of documentary, mystery and thriller, which recounts an astonishing true story that gets more outrageous with each revelation
As the brittle humour quietly transforms into something remarkably emotional, the film gets under our skin in ways we never expect.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It's corny, but it keeps us laughing all the way through while stirring in some genuinely sweet moments.
This film's unhinged plot constantly catches us off guard with its bizarre twists and turns, all of which are grounded on the hapless characters.
If only writer-director Graff had injected the film with half as much earthy energy as he puts into the terrific musical numbers. And let the cast out of the box.

With a hilariously smart script and a terrific cast, this romantic comedy rises far above the pack, engaging us emotionally and intellectually while offering some telling observations on the state of modern relationships.
Like Kevin Smith's blistering Red State, this film scythes through the mindless degradation of the American media.
The film is a bit indulgent and downbeat, but it speaks so eloquently that we can't help but be moved.
It rewards patience with a moving story about the collision of family and political values.
Artful, intelligent and wilfully obtuse, Cronenberg uses his skill to hold our interest through this oddity of a film.
This raucous trawl through 80s power ballads, rock anthems and gigantic hair is a lot of fun, partly because it throws so many big stars into against-type roles in which they get to sing and dance.
No matter how stylish the film is, the lack of a central plot or an original theme make it difficult to care what happens.
Not only is this documentary warm-hearted and thoroughly entertaining, but it has a lot to teach us about how families can rise to the challenge of mental disability.
Aside from the first-rate cinematography and editing, it's is so disappointingly arch that we struggle to believe anything, even as it touches on important themes.
Strikingly designed and directed, this offbeat film feels like a one-man stage show as the entire story's told through an internal monolog.
While it's fascinating, it feels a bit heavy-handed.
If it weren't for the engaging cast and thrilling aerial combat sequences, the film would be hard to get through.
There's an oddly over-serious tone to this fairy tale, as if the filmmakers thought they were making a massive action epic on par with The Lord of the Rings.
Even if the plot is full of holes, it's utterly mesmerising.
Fast-paced and colourful, this documentary chronicles the astonishing story of a gifted artist who never found the success everyone knew he deserved.
Oddly structured like a whisky tasting, this film cycles through moods from the first taste to the full flavour to the final kick.
This gently engaging adventure is his warmest, wittiest film since The Life Aquatic. It keeps us smiling all the way through.
One of those resolutely bland Hollywood star machines that bears no resemblance to the real world at all.
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: There are some hilarious moments and sublimely silly asides, but the film never shifts into full-speed.
All of the swaggering attitude is just too much for a film that has absolutely no point to it.
The script is an odd mix of smart dialog and random plot-strands, and while Burton gets the style right he never quite finds the tone.
With such a range of vivid sights and sounds, the film is a stunning, often mesmerising experience
The plot is genuinely clever, and there's a continual stream of knowing gags that'll keep fans of B-movies chuckling.
Plying his trade in pop culture references and surprising punchlines, MacFarlane jumps the adult-oriented comedy bandwagon with a film that's smarter and funnier than most
The performances are excellent, and the filmmaking is mesmerising.
The plot's layers keep us gripped to a tale in which the police are snarling villains and the criminals are likeable and loyal
With a sour tone and jokes that have no punchlines, this is a relentlessly unfunny comedy that shifts into an unexciting alien invasion thriller
Plaza sends the franchise into yet another direction with this lean, scary zombie thriller, punctuating scenes with both humour and emotion
The genius of Shaun of the Dead haunts this London comedy-horror romp to such a degree that it's almost impossible to enjoy it on its own terms
The script has some very funny moments, and the cast is terrific, but the film is too inconsistent to be a classic
Has no speaking roles and no clear through-line, but it's so sumptuously shot, edited and scored that it holds us in rapt attention
Allows us to interpret scenes on our own terms, including cleverly jarring images like a woman in a burkha standing in front of a billboard of men modelling underwear
This Australian Hangover-style ensemble comedy strains so hard to be funny that it barely raises a smile
Director Elliott (Priscilla Queen of the Desert) tells this story with an odd combination of tourist-bureau style backdrops and full-on slapstick mayhem
Director Wiseman invests this sci-fi action remake with plenty of visual whizzery even as he seems to miss the point of the story
The style is cut and pasted from other movies, and without a stronger sense of the characters and story, there's not much else to see here
It's directed and acted with enough sensitivity to stir our sympathies.
The detail in the characters makes each of these people utterly riveting
The Farrelly brothers return to the vacuously silly style of Dumb and Dumber for this gently idiotic comedy
Freed from the constraints of Iranian censorship, Keshavarz authentically portrays young life in Tehran with parties, drugs, underground art and a defiant sexuality
The comedy is based on the 'hilarious' notion that these men act like 12-year-olds, talking about sports and sex in the most simplistically rude ways imaginable
For filmmakers who are good at finding pathos in the most unlikely places, this film is more like a return to the vacuous idiocy of Dumb and Dumber
The Step Up franchise has never been noted for its astute screenwriting, but this instalment sets the bar so low that even its bendy cast members would have trouble limboing under it
When the credits roll at the end of this overlong action epic, it feels like we've just turned the final page of an immersive novel
Although there's been no attempt to tone down the first film's bloodthirsty hyperviolence or dim-witted plotting, this sequel is a massive improvement simply because they have fun with the premise
It's watchable, but doesn't have enough sense of character or purpose to make us care about anything that happens
A skilful mixture of comedy and drama makes this the kind of film that keeps us off balance from start to finish.
The film's real strength is in the central relationship, which pays off in a way that's far more delicate and complex than most animated films would dare
Soderbergh lets scenes develop in a raw, natural way that makes the stripping scenes hilariously entertaining to watch
Fritz Lang's suspense masterpiece starts with a kick and then piles on the subterfuge, suspense and terror.
Sure, this is a slightly different mythology, but it's impossible to engage in a story that can't surprise us. Fortunately, the rom-com subplot is thoroughly involving.
It's not very clever, but it's still good fun.
Not only is the story riveting, but the film explores huge issues that really get under our skin
It's a Wonderful Life is about hunger. It's about greed. It's about the many ways a good man is stymied. Finally, it's about George Bailey, whose decency prevents him even from killing himself.
As buried truths come to the surface, director Lodovichi confidently steers the story through some of the blunter contrivances in the plot.
movie_title: Deep in the Wood (In fondo al bosco) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Ultimately, Immigration Game reveals itself to be nowhere near as insightful or subversive as it would like to think it is.
The brilliant conceit is that the group have to negotiate through woodlands in which the risk is manifest but invisible, making for some fantastic "running from something unseen" moments.
Despite its daft premise, Anti Matter offers a cerebral and intelligent take on what is a genre perennial: something going amiss in a newly-developed matter transporter.
It's an odd amalgamation of cinematic tropes that never properly gels.

Held together by a singularly, focused performance by Xi Liao as humanity's steely, would-be saviour, The End of the Lonely Island is an exercise in extraordinary filmmaking, in every sense of the word.
movie_title: The End of the Lonely Island (2016)

movie_review_blurb: There's too much exposition and too many plot strands battling for attention as the much darker endgame unfolds.

The Answer leaves too many questions hanging.
This movie feels like the project of an enthusiastic group of young friends, and was probably way more fun to make than it is to watch.
Besetment has never once risked deviating from the derivative.

There's the obvious risk that the film's languid, dialogue-driven tempo, and the paucity of gore, will disappoint horror fans; while arthouse aficionados will skip the movie because of its fright-flick associations.

While the movie sometimes strains at the limits of its own internal credibility (especially as characters switch loyalties and romantic affinities with unconvincing speed), this remains a landmark entry in the modern Russian sci-fi film canon.

There's plenty of mileage left in the famous story.

The repressed passion of the main character is all too representative of this repressed movie.
Great Streep, iffy movie.
Fun, low-tech action with a starmaking turn by Gina Carano.
Terribly uneven, moving in places but very frustrating in others.
Sure, it's derivative, and sentimental. But it still made me laugh more than once.
Clooney is remarkable in Alexander Payne's film about loss, confusion and getting by.
Harrowing portrait of ordinary kids being assaulted verbally and physically, and a social system that does not protect them.
Intense presentation of the limitations of passion and the depth of real love.
A funny, sorrowful, sharp-witted look at ambition, ego, and fathers and sons.
Entertainingly gritty until an ending that seems to go against all that has preceded it.
Often funny, good in dramatic moments, but lacking consistently tight control of pace and scenes.
A flawed first part is forgivable thanks to the exhilarating action sequences climaxing the movie.
The superb cast still cannot save a weak story.
Some big laughs and an air of sweet melancholy get you through the slow spots. But enough is enough.
Bland lead actors, blah musical arrangements and an attempt to make '80s LA PG-13 add up to an unconvincing, overlong and often humorless spectacle.
Though not on the level of the best of Pixar, it's still an entertaining movie.
Some good effects, but takes its potentially amusing premise way too seriously.
Funny, smart and blood-soaked use of an old horror trope. Fans will spend much time freeze-framing the eventual video release to catch all the details.
A middle-ground Marvel adaptation, but one with a good sense of humor.
Another excellent turn by Ryan Goslin in George Clooney's savvy, cynical political tale.
In IMAX form, at least, it's thrilling, with a strong cast fighting a silly plot.
While the ads are selling it as a romp (and crowds include Girls' Night Out groups), the movie turns in some grim but too obvious directions.
Excellent performances by Kevin Spacey and Barry Pepper in a movie that does measure up to its real-life story. And Jon Lovitz nearly steals the movie.

It's not just that the movie appears to find Greene far more charming than he was in Porrello's book. It's that Kill the Irishman never brings either freshness or energy to its tale. In the end, even the many explosions seem tired.
Wastes a good Will Ferrell performance by elaborating on Raymond Carver's short story in ways that go very wrong.
Not only is it funny, it has enough regard for its characters to acknowledge some real emotion without overdoing the pathos.
A marvelous film. The highlight is the performance of Hailee Steinfeld as the young heroine, Mattie Ross, but also boasting strong turns by Jeff Bridges and Matt Damon.

A rebound from the third film, with Depp in good form, but a disjointed story.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Excellent performance by Javier Bardem lifts a movie that often drags.

movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Cedar Rapids is at its best when it pushes Helms into uncomfortable situations and makes him figure them out. But the movie remains less than completely satisfying
Excellent performances and a fine use of detail counterbalance a somewhat weak storyline.
Good effects and themes overcome a glaring plot hole.
Often exciting and entertaining.

A satisfying wrap-up of the series, with an especially effective performance by Alan Rickman.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Well-told and touching, with Oscar-worthy performances by Viola Davis and Octavia Spencer.

movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The raw and realistic look at love and marriage overcomes occasional overly artsy flourishes.

Slicker than the original, it is also less satisfying, erratic in pace and tone.

Sadly effective, with two standout performances.

Amy Acker, Amy Acker, Amy Acker.
If Raymond Chandler wrote a mutant movie, it would look a lot like this.
A summer pleasure.

ike Harry and Sally, the movie is hardworking, spot on; it winepresses its conversation into epigrams.
