This 3-D, black-and-white "family" comedy is the year's most inventive, endearing animated feature.
A fanciful film with the patina of hyper-realism, Looper is well served by actors who behave not as if they were dropped carelessly into the future but spent their whole desperate lives there.
If the modest and moving Trouble With the Curve won't overwhelm anybody, it's still an engaging winner, like a junk-ball pitcher who stays in the bigs on grit and heart.

It's all frightfully familiar - as if teens sitting around the campfire need to be told the same story every night - until the last 15 mins., when this Cocoa Puffs movie reveals an underlayer of arsenic.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Director Roger Michell's movie is, pretty consistently, dreadful.
The performances of these actors are reason enough to go.
The feeling persists that Tykwer and the Wachowskis made the picture to prove they could.
There's a point at which movies become only merchandise, and the Paranormal franchise may be heading for that nexus, that nadir.
Painful, and not in a good way.
If there were an On the Road museum, this could be the elaborate diorama at its center.
The movie slogs along like a Grant Wood farmer behind his plow.
For all its astronomical body count, Sin City is brazenly, thrillingly alive.
Burton, once an animator at Disney, understands that to go deeper, you must fly higher, to liberation from plot into poetry. Here he's done it. This Batman soars.

The 3-D process adds not just dimension but depth - a technological extension of cinematographer Gregg Toland's deep-focus innovations in The Grapes of Wrath and Citizen Kane. The change in perspective creates greater intensity.
Retaliation is less a sequel than an antidote to the calcified mound of crap that ostensibly inspired it.
Unlike its grittily romantic predecessors, Flashdance is pure glitz.
In the rich umbers of Haskell Wexler's cinematography, Matewan does look great.
The family-dramedy genre that the film inhabits demands a bit more narrative ingenuity than is on display.
Absent any emotional grounding, the film is a gorgeous, sterile construction, like a dream city unoccupied by humans.
The 3-D effects are plentiful - hats, lions, and baboons jump off the screen and into your lap - but the characters rarely lodge in the moviegoer's heart.
It's not pure Park or pure Hitchcock but a muted, mildly mesmerizing blend of the two. You might want to take a careful stroll in this Hitchpark.
[A] very entertaining, densely layered, just-short-of-fabulous melodrama.
Chicago has so much razzle-dazzle that viewers may end up both raised and dazed. It's remorselessly inventive, trying anything fast and sassy to keep you watching.
A grand movie entertainment.

A movie like A Good Day to Die Hard ought to either hire someone who can write catchy dialogue and at least superficially plausible characters or just let the real artists, the stuntmen, run the whole picture. No Humans Allowed.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Side Effects virtually demands a three-word review: Just see it.
The whole kidding trope, which you can bet was ordered by McKay and Ferrell, is pretty lame, and defeats the leads' attempts to bring shadings to cardboard cartoon characters.
The Woman in Black is a welcome addition to the old canon; renouncing innovation, embracing anachronism, it's almost The Artist of ghost movies.
When any film works, it's a miracle; when it doesn't, it's this.
Slapdash in its character portraits, the movie is slambang in its action scenes; it springs to life whenever it promises death.
The film has fifth-act problems, as did the play, but Fiennes' bleak overview should leave receptive viewers feeling daunted and haunted.
The performances here are so sharp that viewers may wish End of Watch has been shot by someone who knew how to find the right point of view for a scene and leave it there.
Knightley embodies Anna as a girlish woman who has never felt erotic love; once smitten, she is raised to heavenly ecstasy before tumbling into the abyss of shame.
Argo is just so-so.
Whether you're mindless or Mensa, you'll find stuff here to challenge and trouble you, the way a good piece of speculative fiction should.
A ramble through the ecstasies of the natural world as experienced or ignored by little people on a giant, gorgeous planet.
Despite enough pummeling to flatten Rocky Balboa in all six movies, the only thing that truly rewards your attendance is Pitt in another effortless star performance.
Lawless tries to be flawless; as a movie, it's often listless - lifeless.
[A] sometimes engrossing, sometimes exasperating romance.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Cheers for a Cannes director who has infused his technical mastery with radiant life. In the Museum of the World of Wes Anderson, the dolls are dancing.

Fans of the nasty Baron Cohen may regret his being borderline nice in The Dictator. But we should welcome his decision to stop being the best at something few others dare try and instead to inhabit a more familiar comedy style.
If the film is to work at all - and it eventually does - the two 27-year-old leads must radiate enough star quality to obviate the ramshackle plot. They just about do.
Until The Raven almost literally loses itself during a chase in the city sewers, it nicely balances its literary gamesmanship with a R-rated thriller's mandatory gross-out tableaux.
The movie ... is a cheerful entertainment, suitable for kids and parents of the brighter stripe. It's just not Nick Park great.
The movie guarantees fast-paced fun without forcing anyone to think about what it all means, which is nothing.
An ensemble piece that packs more easy enjoyment than I was expecting or, even now, care to admit to.
The purpose of the entire enterprise seems to demonstrate the superiority of slapstick sadism from 75 years ago to the wan attempts at PG-rated roughhouse today.
The Lady is ... tilted away from the churning melodrama of Suu Kyi's country and toward the intimate dilemma of a loving couple forced apart by circumstance.
The movie's message is that the way to face impeding maturity is to embrace your inner teen idiot.
Even if you're as annoyed by the movie as I was, you'll come out laughing the costumes.
Wrath radiates the straight-forward, straight-faced pleasures of the mytho-muscular epics, like Hercules and Jason and the Argonauts, produced in Europe a half-century ago.
A documentary as vivid as any horror film, as heartbreaking as any Oscar-worthy drama.
Can The Hunger Games, in the movie version directed by Gary Ross, successfully navigate the crossing from page to screen? Our answer: Eh.
21 Jump Street earns my genial nod because of its limber, 120-IQ take on the whole notion of movie revivals.
Proceeding in fits and starts, and flats and stops, John Carter has some zesty set pieces but no rooting interest.
Fighting is a learned skill; so is acting. And the SEAL stars are plausible only when on maneuvers - performing as their own stunt doubles.
Spring Breakers is all surface and sham; it's trash about humpers.
Not a great film but a warm one that pushes the viewer's emotional buttons so deftly it feels like a massage.
[A] vapid, claustrophobic drama...
Attention must be paid to movie allure, in a star like Depp and his current harem.
I saw Prometheus without my trusty guide-wife next to me to describe the creepy stuff yet watched every second of the movie. And not once did I jump out of my skin.
The problem with The Master is that it doesn't extend or expand Anderson's artistic journey.
Every anti-Obama argument D'Souza makes from the right could be made, more forcefully, from the left.
Sleepwalk is oddly soothing, like a cup of camomile tea before bedtime.
Brody's performance won't earn him a Oscar to place next to the one he earned for The Pianist nine years ago, but it's the only thing that makes High School marginally worth catching.
A work of power, nuance and daredevil craft, Langella's performance is a reminder that giants still fill the stage, and the screen.
Peters brings a magical energy to the movie's most laggard moments, infusing a so-what drama with a must-see performance.
The overall tone is familiar, refried, redundant.
Like the fork that usually comes with your airplane meal, 360 is plastic.
Questions, questions nip at Len Wiseman's Total Recall like so many rats at the feet of a sleeping hobo. The big Why is Why bother?
You're unlikely to laugh much, and you may get an unexpected case of the non-art-imitates-bad-life creeps.
Ruby Sparks tries its damnedest to make a picture that seduces moviegoers into accepting it as their best imaginary friend forever. But the sweat shows more than the sparkle.
So appealing is Gordon-Levitt that, for great stretches of his new movie, I suspended my disapproval of his character and just went with the nonstop flow.
Well acted and acutely observed, the film doesn't try to be a conventionally satisfying coke-land action film.
After a decade or so of suppressing his more lurid instincts, Oliver Stone is back in the bat-crap-crazy mode that made his Oscar-winning rap-sheet rep.
Treat yourself to the experience of this perfect storm of a film, and the tiny force of nature that is Quvenzhané Wallis.
I have to give props to a movie that ascends from eccentricity to insanity without losing its footing.
The historical epic and the monster movie run on parallel tracks, occasionally colliding but never forming a coherent whole.
Safe House plows through its familiar twists with efficient brio and a distinguished supporting cast.
Dick's films often strut with a lilting impudence, but his new work is dead-serious, as suits the subject.
This pensive, seductive drama is full of devious strategies, which begin with its protagonist's name: T. Ricks. Tricks.
So willfully bad that not even Cruise's valiant CPR can help.

For once a melodrama with pulp origins convinces viewers that it can be the modern equivalent to Greek myths or a Jonathan Swift satire. TDKR is that big, that bitter -- a film of grand ambitions and epic achievement.
Deftly directed by Stephen Frears the film boasts both a great soundtrack and a wonderful cast. Definitely one of the best comedies of the year!
Quote not available.
Over-funded, bloated, self-important and virtually immobile, The Last Jedi bears more than a passing resemblance to Jabba the Hutt.
It's as likely to thrill more casual horror audiences as it is to satisfy long-time aficionados of the genre. Given the time of year, I couldn't recommend it more.
This film isn't as bad as the initial backlash would imply but nor is it anywhere near as good as its own hype promised.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: There are quite a few science-fiction movies scheduled to come out in the next year or so. We shall be lucky if even one or two are as absorbing and as beautiful as The Man Who Fell to Earth.
movie_title: The Man Who Fell to Earth (1976)

movie_review_blurb: A soggy attempt at a post-Civil War western epic.
The good ideas are marred by awkwardness; the terrible ideas are redeemed somewhat by being, at least, unpredictable.
It is part fable and part satire, but it is much more.
Every Man is a superb movie because Mr. Herzog has managed to treat the fable in stunning human and dramatic terms.
movie_title: The Enigma of Kaspar Hauser (Jeder für sich und Gott gegen alle)(Every Man for Himself and God Against All) (1974)

movie_review_blurb: The episodes in this second part go on endlessly, loosely, obviously. They lack the revelations of the winter scenes and they do little but belabor at length the points already made. They wreck the film's balance and make its achievements dull.
The Black Bird is an enchanting half-hour spoof of Humphrey Bogart and The Maltese Falcon. Too bad it lasts over an hour and a half.
People who pay money to see this effort to find knee-slappers in the 55 mile-an-hour speed limit will also make amiable fools of themselves.
It is sometimes funny in a puzzling kind of way, it is generally overwrought in an irritating kind of way, and once in a while it is inappropriately touching.

Walt Disney started by making movies in which animated drawings played the parts of people or animals who stood for people. Later he turned to making movies in which people or animals play the parts of animated drawings.
Ambiguity takes the bone out of the movie and it collapses.
Instead of every hour or half-hour, the cuckoo pops out every minute and a half.
movie_title: End of the Game (Der Richter und sein Henker) (The Judge and His Hangman) (1975)

movie_review_blurb: Length is part of its problem. A much greater problem is that the political message that is only one of the threads in the first part thickens into hawser dimensions, strangling the film and the audience along with it.
An interesting, rather slick and excessively long documentary about the small but intensely competitive world of body-building.
It excludes all life that is not within the very narrow intentions of its author. Its pores have been painted over.

Two Minute Warning, about a mad sniper in a crowded football stadium, has the suspense, the compassion, the human vision and the individual nuance you would expect in a movie about a foot stepping on an anthill.
The script, put together by Samuel Gallu, is beautifully articulated and balanced.
There is nothing very original about Hester Street except its loveliness.
A member of the Exorcist family, it is a dreadfully silly film, which is not to say that it is totally bad.
Peter Bogdanovich knows a great deal about movies, including how they are made. Perhaps he doesn't know why they are made. In any case, knowing how something is made isn't the same as making it.
Toward the end there are some amusing car-chase scenes. Elsewhere the humor is clotted by the feeling that the jokes are chasing the reactions, instead of the other way around.
Sam Peckinpah knows how to make movies but perhaps he has forgotten why.
This complex and sometimes very beautiful film is about humanity but hardly at all about politics.
It's as if someone had put pillow springs, power-steering and a tape deck into a classic racing-car. It is still handsome and it still goes, but it is a handsome mediocrity.
It is so cool it is barely alive.
There's plenty to like in a film that proves Richard Kelly's touch hasn't deserted him after Southland Tales' critical and commercial battering.
Despite a rollicking opening half hour that leaves you wondering whether you're about to watch the SF film of the year, the movie is unable to deliver on the promise of its set-up.
Alice In Wonderland may look fantastic, but there's little else going for it. It's emotionally cold, utterly predictable and there's never any sense of peril.
It's a magnificent technical achievement, a movie of such vast scale and ambition that you have to watch it on the big screen.
The sort of brainy, twisty thriller that keeps you wondering what the hell's going on while still managing to keep you engrossed.
If you're going to make a movie that doesn't quite add up to the sum of its parts, you might as well make sure those parts are beautifully formed.
The finest interstellar horror in years.
By turns Revenge Of The Fallen is spectacular, funny, cringeworthy, edge-of-the-seat exciting, tedious, incomprehensible, dumb and very occasionally smart -- sometimes all at the same time.
Sometimes it's nice when movies do things you never saw coming. Knowing is an exception.
About as subtle as being punched in the face by an angry Norwegian, it delivers everything you could possibly want from a movie about Vikings and alien monsters.
Jack Sparrow really has become a parody of his former self. He may get some decent gags and Depp still plays him with admirable relish, but he's simply going through the motions.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Look past the odd shortcoming in the storytelling, and there's a brave movie here, one that's prepared to tackle some weighty issues about religion and obsession.
A film that's laugh-out-loud funny, occasionally touching and often borders on coherent -- a rarity for Gilliam, even when he's on top form...
For big kids, a chance to relive the classic films that forged their love of sci-fi. For the kids of today, it's a film they'll want to show their kids another 30 years down the line.
A small but perfectly formed tale with plenty to say about the nature of friendship.
A wonderful piece of cinematic engineering, story and character in perfect harmony.

Beyond the history, stunning archive footage and talking heads, the film gets deep into Cernan's mind to reveal the sacrifices the Apollo guys - and their families - made to ensure they had the right stuff.
movie_title: The Last Man On The Moon (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Jupiter Ascending is everything you'd expect from the siblings' first trip into orbit, a fun, inventive, visually stunning piece of space opera.

While it's not up there with his Tolkien cycle's best, this is a fitting end (or should that be middle?) to Jackson's saga, one that manages to mix blockbuster spectacle with some intimate, tender character moments.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Crushed under the weight of its own pretentious ideas.
That it all makes sense and is up there with the best X-movies is actually quite uncanny.
If it sounds like a glorified toy commercial, well, there's no denying it is. But it's an advert packed with invention, humour and charm - the kind you'd skip through TV programmes to watch.
There's a sense of fun here that lifts the film above the standard talking heads-plus-footage brew.
Successfully translates most of the book's more pertinent themes to the screen, while making enough storytelling fumbles to hint why it was considered unfilmable for nearly three decades.
The fact that Elysium comes close to greatness - classichood always feeling tantalisingly within reach - only makes its failings more frustrating.
A meticulously and ingeniously crafted scare machine.
Both the jokes and the narrative flag long before the excessive running time is up.
Frankenweenie's biggest crime is that it's a comedy that isn't funny. There's no zip to the script, few jokes that stick in the mind.
Though only eight minutes shorter than its predecessor, it's an altogether leaner beast that rarely pauses for breath over the course of more than two and a half hours.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Although the message does not get delivered with crystal clarity, the movie is fast-moving, attention-holding and even thoughtprovoking.
A beautiful study of the need for heritage.
The most intellectually stimulating and emotionally provocative piece of European cinema of recent times.
movie_title: Code Unknown (Code inconnu: Récit incomplet de divers voyages) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Kim Ki-Deok seems to have in mind an (emotionally at least) adolescent audience demanding regular shocks and bouts of barely defensible sexual violence to keep it interested.
Emmanuelle Devos, veteran of a number of relationship dramas directed by Arnaud Desplechin, is terrific in subtly impressing on us Carla's outsider status.
A film which presses familiar Herzog tropes into the service of a limpid and conventional historical fiction, when really what we demand of the director is to be mesmerised.
Run Lola Run sets new standards for the cinema of hysteria.
A witty, thought-provoking and ultimately moving tragicomedy.

Cronenberg's masterful, intelligent and gripping meta-thriller leaves us pondering about our enduringly perverse desire for alternative realities, in which surrogate violent alter egos run righteously and preposterously amok.
[It has] a terrific sense of place, something missing from much contemporary US cinema.
Nightfall makes almost tangible a nocturnal urban world of utter desolation, one that's far removed from Hollywood's prosaic cityscapes.
Less sentiment and more peculiarity would have limned a richer, though probably less audition-tape-worthy, reflection of Burning Man's 25,000-strong community of the absurd.
Jim Henson Pictures happy meal.
Frustratingly, Dridi tells us nothing about El Gallo other than what emerges through his music.
Guess which filmmakers didn't have the smarts to license 'Who Let the Dogs Out'?
A typical Disney knuckle dragger.
A hybrid, an ambivalence, an alternation of achievements and collapses, an attempt to have both ways something not clearly enough seen in either.
You need a deep grounding in Potter-lore to make the slightest bit of sense out of it, but that won't be a problem for most people who see this film.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It could - it should - be appalling. Actually, as pure entertainment it's a joy, and will be adored amid Heineken bottles and Papa John's boxes for years to come.
It's as if the whole Marvel thing got in the way of the indie movie everyone secretly wanted to make - a squeamishness that does no one any favours.
It's at least 20 minutes too long. But Banks marshals things with such cheery uplift you're all too happy to spend time in the Bellas' company.
This endearing movie's mottoes are: never stop caring. And: the best way to make friends is to be a friend yourself.

Renoir, who invokes so skillfully these terrifying images of disintegration, offers in contrast only the old ideal of man's brotherhood, and his film does not tell us whether it is illusion or reality.
Little more than a 90-minute chase scene, this film is targeted directly at the Fast & Furious crowd, but it has only one expensive car to smash up instead of many dozen.
As a technical experiment in real time cinema, Silent House is fascinating, but it fails as both an interesting story and a visceral experience.
A sensational opening makes the disappointing final act hurt all the more as American Mary falls in a heap in its final act.

The Oranges dabbles with transgressive ideas (for a moment it felt like the film was implying that infidelity could be a positive force in everyone's lives) before retreating into stupefyingly predictable and safe rhythms.
Not every film needs to reinvent the wheel, and nothing here is particularly ground-breaking, yet this is one of the more satisfying horror jaunts in quite some time.
As we follow the increasingly frantic Gere down his nightmarish rabbit hole, the picture takes a satisfyingly cold, amoral stance - less critique and more cynical observation.

It's made for - and presumably by - people who haven't ever seen a horror movie. What's even more frustrating is that its inherent ineptitude doesn't ever become entertaining in a "this is hilariously horrible" fashion.
movie_title: House at the End of the Street (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Day Of Reckoning is one of the most ambitious, experimental, and downright fascinating B-movie genre pieces I have seen in years.

Sushi Girl is intermittently stylish and relatively technically competent but so painfully derivative that it's at times embarrassing to watch. Saxton really loves his Tarantino and if you do too you may marginally tolerate this violent piece of fodder.
Director Tony Krawitz certainly can't be faulted for his ambition, yet, despite some magnificent technical credits, his cinematic adaptation of this controversial book ends up muddled and misguided.
A Haunted House is technically inept, monotonous, and stiflingly cheap-looking. How this cost $2.5 million dollars to produce is beyond me.

There are a multitude of sordidly fascinating directions a biopic on Alfred Hitchcock could take. So, when Sacha Gervasi's flat and frothy Hitchcock concludes, it's inevitably frustrating to find this film takes such a conventional path.

It's bold, brash, and frequently successful, but also repetitive and ultimately arduous. There simply isn't enough story here to justify the inflated running time and, for many, Laurence Anyways will wear out its welcome.

Uncomfortably lurching from broad slapstick to dark and sharp gore - often in the space of a single scene - Sightseers adds up to a rather jumbled whole, despite the punchlines hitting as often as they miss.
The final result, however, is a complete oddity that is less an interesting political satire and more the piercing examination of butter carving competitions that no one ever asked for.

... intricately designed to not offend any subset of its audience. It's as impotent as Milius' original was ballsy, and despite a brief running time and passable action, it ends up a frustratingly pointless experience.

Fundamentally, it seems the big joke of Casa de Mi Padre is that it was produced at all, and as a weird Dadaist joke it is indeed satisfying. It's hard, however, to recommend a film that feels like a giant prank.
It manages to not only contort itself into a form that is simultaneously convoluted and stupid but it also skilfully avoids any audience engagement despite a tumultuous whirl of spectacle and noise.
Stolen knows what type of movie it is and has resolutely low-ambitions, but it succeeds on its own terms as a fast, fun, B-grade piece of junk.
Those who miss the days of Gibson's hardened movie characters will be in for a treat with Get the Gringo, a genuinely gritty, hard-boiled action-noir tale.
Violent, coarse, perverted, and sickly hilarious, this is highly recommend for those who like their entertainment on the nasty, demented tip.
Seeking Justice is like mediocre pizza; It won't change the world but it should satisfy those hungry for a well-made, generic meal.

Chris Nelson's Ass Backwards certainly doesn't aspire to being anything more than passing entertainment. But sadly, this listless, flat, and exceptionally derivative movie doesn't even achieve that modest goal.
1911 meanders through its interminable two-hour running time with a collection of scenes that feel more like liner notes from a history book than an actual screenplay.
Liberal Arts is a resolutely vanilla-flavored concoction but still pleasant, amiable, and a little more thoughtful than your average rom-com.
Derek Martini's second feature - after the competent Lymelife - is a confused mess of awkward tonal shifts and boring narrative tangents all encased in the discomforting shell of a Lolita fantasy.

You may not ultimately agree with Valée's big spiritual pay off (it may be interpreted as a mere excuse for a middle-aged man to have an affair) but it's undeniably gripping, creative, and brash cinema.
Beyond The Hills is a frighteningly precise, gut-wrenching piece of cinema that shows a degree of formal assuredness that left me genuinely awestruck.
The Sessions is a tender, well-intentioned examination of a disabled man exploring his sexual identity, but sometimes a film needs more than just good intentions.

Unlike the cloying contrivances of It's Complicated, Hope Springs is audacious in its commitment to subtle authenticity, never artificially upping the dramatic stakes but instead staying true to its small yet relatable story.
Return is a commendable, genuine, and simple drama that effectively highlights the intrinsic trauma soldiers face when trying to come to terms with the reality of life back home.

Miss Bala is a tremendous cinematic achievement; both a stunning technical exercise in sustained tension and a rich allegory highlighting the hopeless scenario facing an entire society caught in the crossfire of a futile drug war
Holy Motors is visionary, absurd, melancholy, ecstatic, confounding, and ultimately transcendent. If 2012 spawns a better film I will eat a bouquet of flowers.
Elles is undeniably challenging, courageously delving into some immensely messy issues surrounding sexuality and the ways men and women barter in relationships.

It may seem like this is merely an exercise in style and to be honest, it is. Soderbergh's clearly fascinated by the physicality of Carano as a fighter and Haywire's sole reason for existence is to highlight those skills.
The Sitter is mediocrity at its finest; too boring to hate and too forgettable to get angry about. Save your money and rewatch Uncle Buck instead.
Glodell's debut is undoubtedly an immature work but it's such a genuine and energetic achievement that the flaws ultimately don't matter. Bellflower is an amazing mess.
...the picture never pushes the creepiness of Bloom's doctor far enough to make the experience wholly effective but it's fun to watch Bloom stretch his legs in a sinister role.
The picture's biggest sin (or biggest achievement) is the fact that it manages to be stunningly short yet still have several flat, boring stretches.
There is nothing creative, amusing, valuable or interesting about Sandler's work. That's My Boy isn't the worst film I have ever seen; it's just one of the saddest and most exhausting.

21 & Over is lifeless, forgettable, and bland. It's the type of film you can walk in on halfway through and not only figure out what is happening in 30 seconds, but become bored 30 seconds later. It's as close to fast food as cinema gets.

Ruby Sparks is an honest, entertaining, and insightful picture that, despite a very 'filmy' happy ending, offers up an amusingly frank deconstruction of the 'dream girl' idea that pervades much modern fiction.

It's rare to witness a film with such a profound disconnect between the director's intention and the final product. It's clear Coppola is striving for some kind of meaningful sublime statement but in reality he has created an interminably vacuous picture.
movie_title: A Glimpse Inside the Mind of Charles Swan III (2013)

movie_review_blurb: When Jason Statham stops to pat a kitten after MacGyvering up the bad guy's meth-lab to explode when the lights are switched on, you will either groan or giggle... if you are inclined towards the latter you may find quite a bit of enjoyment in Homefront.

Ultimately not much more complex than the moment in which two children yell "I hate Hitler" across a lake, it imparts the message that Nazis are bad, books are good, and Geoffrey Rush would make a great dad even in WWII Germany

The most pertinent take away from Tar is simply how influential the Terrence Malick aesthetic has become. A fascinating failure, it works better as a class experiment than as a watchable piece of cinema.

Every time the film teeters on the precipice of a generic plot point it satisfyingly withdraws into more subtle and nuanced territory that ultimately coalesces in a final act that is sentimental without being sugary.
Cutie and the Boxer is an often quiet, almost fragile piece of cinema that presents us with a spiky and unglamorous relationship, still full of love. It's a beautiful and humane documentary.
3 Days to Kill is a frequently bizarre, never boring mash-up that doesn't come together yet perfectly encapsulates everything both good and bad about Luc Besson's recent output
If you are going to make a B-grade exploitation piece you need to go for excess and insanity. Tokarev commits the ultimate movie sin: it makes a Nicolas Cage revenge thriller simply boring.
Sure, every character beat is hammy and predictable, but hey, not everything can be fine dining. Sometimes you just want a good cheeseburger and fries.
For a good 80 minutes, Non-Stop delivers exactly what the title promises - an escalating series of exciting set-pieces with a great, mysterious backbone. This is top grade Hollywood entertainment.
Life After Beth is an irritatingly undeveloped project. A charming cast and a few moments of inspired lunacy make it passingly worthwhile for genre fans.

A black & white Polish film about a nun in the 1960s exploring her family origins is about as tough as art-house pitches come. Yet, Ida has a remarkable lightness of touch and focus of vision making it impossible not to widely recommend.

The Armstrong Lie has several insightful moments but is most interesting in how it shows us a filmmaker usually committed to finding the absolute truth in his subjects, suffering when he comes across a story where lies and truth constantly intertwine.
This is nothing less than one of my favourite Australian pictures in quite some time
A Most Wanted Man concludes on a bleakly prescient note, not only in offering an extraordinarily trenchant critique of American foreign policy but also as a moody send off to Hoffman himself.

Transformers: Age of Extinction is as close to an incoherent mess of movement & noise as cinema gets. Michael Bay is slowly perfecting his brand of blockbuster, and to be honest it's getting quite compelling to watch him fall down this rabbit hole

Starred Up may cover familiar ground but it's executed with such arresting authenticity that it's hard to not be drawn in and ultimately excited. This is prison melodrama done amazingly well with sharp performances and visceral attention to detail.

With an obsession for close-ups of needles piercing skin, Antiviral leaves one with a OCD-style desire to wash ones hands... the overreaching success of the film lies in its believable depiction of a culture slowly rotting at the core.

Nurse is one of those modern, pre-fabricated cult movies like The Human Centipede or Sharknado, designed to be talked about amongst friends though never truly satisfying as a genuinely interesting piece of exploitation cinema.
If you're like me and enjoy horror films that make you feel odd, unsettled and generally unpleasant, then this is one of the best feel-bad experiences you could have.

If anything positive can be gained from Devil's Knot, it's that hopefully it will lead new viewers to the magnificent experiences that await them by watching the superior Paradise Lost trilogy and the conclusive West of Memphis
The idea of watching Ken Marino argue with a giant haemorrhoid monster that has just popped out of his butt seems like a crazy must-see moment. Unfortunately, it comes across as flat and uninspired.

It's not gory, but relies on ceaseless weirdness with scores of jump scares and even an odd Back To The Future 2-style subplot that's undeveloped yet still adds to the overall sense of crazy. Love or hate it, this is pretty effective modern scare cinema.

As the feature jumps backwards and forwards in time, and stories within stories coalesce, a striking tapestry is woven illustrating a world where eternal beings struggle with great change. Jordan's vampiric universe is bloody, adult, and melancholy.

With a nihilistic ending tacked on because hopelessness is seemingly cool, cheap special effects, clunky dialogue, a bizarre ten-second cameo from Selena Gomez, and some genuinely mediocre filmmaking, Aftershock is too amateurish to be truly awful.
...rich in anthropological specificity, Nguyen's film is unexpectedly sensitive and anchored by some amazing performances.

With I Spit on Your Grave 2, director Steven R. Monroe returns and reveals that everything he seemingly did right in his first remake must have been accidental, for this horrifically misguided sequel is everything you pray a movie like this would not be.

Shot with a lovely warm hue by Rob Hardy, Broken has enough great moments to make it worthwhile. Yet, the naggingly problematic final sequences leave a bitter taste. Do they undo a solid first hour? That's up to the individual viewer.
Mortensen's pensive, Gothic brooding makes this an entirely watchable but ultimately unsuccessful piece of art-house swamp-noir.

This is a gloriously gonzo trip packed with enough odd narrative tangents to fill half a dozen features. While not always successful, this energetic mash-up so genuinely wants to entertain that it's hard not to be won over by its barrage of absurdity.

From most vantage points, A Few Best Men seems like a real movie. It has a "story," "characters," & even scenes that superficially appear to contain "jokes," but many sketches are ultimately just that; sketches that stop short of offering moments of wit.
Let's be upfront. Olympus Has Fallen is dumb, violent, overlong, jingoistic, racist, predictable, derivative, and whatever other adjectives those with no sense of B-grade fun wish to throw at it.

In a perfect encapsulation of form and content, The English Teacher tells a story of an artist who reluctantly adds a happy ending to his play while the movie itself forces a happy ending into a story that is laced with underlying sadness.

The Frozen Ground is trying its best to act as a genuine tribute to the victims of a horrible crime. Unfortunately it falls short... Though still functioning as a solid genre piece, the chasm between intention and execution is embarrassingly apparent.

Reality is a little too thin to be truly satisfying. However, Garrone's elegant visual palette and Arena's remarkable central performance shift a potentially trite message into a gloriously warm and novel experience.

Contracted is an efficiently icky, gross-out exercise in body horror that should please fans of this kind of thing. Still, the lack of any substance below the surface is ultimately too frustrating to ignore.

Soloway teases rather than fully develops several different fascinating ideas in Afternoon Delight and while the flick doesn't ultimately cohere into a wholly satisfying single entity it's still an incredibly compelling experience.

Unlike almost all other English TV comedy adaptations (Bean, Guest House Paradiso, The Inbetweeners) Alpha Papa fulfils the comedic promise of a much loved icon and results in one of the funniest films of the past twelve months.

As a portrait of a generation that's almost collectively sociopathic, this is frightening. For the right audience it's also damn funny. If I wasn't so emotionally stunted and able to enjoy things unironically I'd say I loved it.

It descends into a series of mawkish, over-melodramatic scenes that are entirely unearned and often unpleasantly noisy. It's never especially funny or dramatic and leaves the viewer feeling unsure of what the filmmakers were really trying to achieve.
Highly stylized fashion-wise but awkwardly unfocused in its plotlines, it aims for the western iconography of Sam Peckinpah and Sergio Leone but never gets past its own directorial hurdles.

movie_review_blurb: It seems somehow entirely appropriate that the city of Las Vegas would be the place where writer-director Rifkin's film would earn its first Grand Jury Award.

Better looking than Shrek the Third, less convoluted than Pirates 3 and as satisfying as Spider-Man 3.

It's Philip K. Dick's worst nightmare.

Any film that casts Oliver Platt as an Arnold Schwarzenegger impersonator and takes the name of Dianne Wiest in vain gets my vote.
Haggis has taken a simple biblical tale and grafted it onto the complexities of the modern world.
If Divine were still alive today, he-she might well be wintering on the edge of The Salton Sea.

movie_review_blurb: A funny, touching and original coming-of-age tale with a big difference: the person coming of age is way past menopause rather than decades ahead of it.
Does for Carter what An Inconvenient Truth did for fellow Nobel Peace Prize winner Al Gore.
Gleeson inhabits the character in such a way that one cannot help but wonder how many Irish fathers like this he has personally known.
You half expect the CSI: New York characters played by Gary Sinise and Mila Karakanedes to show up at the first, second or third crime scenes.
Production is well done, although some plot twists and turns are pretty obvious.

Unmercifully unbalanced in story content but dramatically and emotionally rich, A Mother's Right: The Elizabeth Morgan Story, is a quality telefilm that should draw good ratings thanks to a powerful performance by Bonnie Bedelia.
movie_title: A Mother's Right: The Elizabeth Morgan Story (1992)

movie_review_blurb: Although Flushed Away is on a much bigger scale than its homely predecessors, it's still comfortably offbeat and funny.
The result is passable, though it's clear that his forte lies elsewhere.
A deeply thoughtful biopic of a legendary gaming master.
The ambitious staging of Jaa's lean and long-limbed Muay Thai fight scenes makes them look impressive. There is just too little happening in between to engage a wider audience.
An intelligently written piece that only falters during the finale, where Kon sacrifices the film's logic for an explosive ending.
Jaunty, likable and surprisingly relevant tale of one of the better scandals of the '70s.

The good scenes hit home, but the bad ones tilt towards melodrama and sentimentality.

It works as a funny and slicker-than-expected parody of the genre.
Social commentary elevates this light coming-of-age drama about a young British boy's university days.
Succeeds mainly because of its hell-for-leather exuberance.
Tremendously enjoyable.
movie_title: Taj Mahal: An Eternal Love Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Brasilia 18% ultimately succeeds as a good story well told.
This second film by Chinese director Lu Chuan is a solid and atmospheric drama.

A powerful political allegory.
Stylish flourishes hold things together in the absence of strong plotting.

movie_review_blurb: Toilet humor, jokes about paraplegics and serious overacting make this lowbrow comedy an irritating watch.
movie_title: Larry the Cable Guy: Health Inspector (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Marebito is a disturbing supernatural drama that leaves a sour taste in the mouth.

There's so little to go wrong that those who like their entertainment mindless and violent will find little fault.

movie_title: Three Times (Zui hao de shi guang) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A committed piece of agit-prop, which benefits from the passion of its protagonists.
[Eleven Men Out] thoughtful and funny characters, something that should give this droll drama appeal beyond a niche gay audience.
A moderately enjoyable affair which only drags in the middle.

A well-judged performance by Kevin Costner brings drama to this actioner.
It's a mellow film which, much like Lincoln, aims for believability rather than excitement.

It's nostalgic fun to watch genuine martial arts experts fighting each other on the screen.

A smart script peppered with genuinely witty dialogue and some nuanced acting by a young ensemble cast at least keep this coming-of-age story watchable throughout.

Director Damien O'Donnell has achieved a warm and uplifting movie which is marred only by a brief drift into melodrama in the middle.
This deliciously wicked slice of demonic horror from Italian master Dario Argento serves as a devilish antidote to bleak shockers like Saw.
movie_title: Mother of Tears: The Third Mother (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Although a little too open-ended to be wholly satisfying, Water Lilies is still an excellent directorial debut.
Infectiously enjoyable.
Clips from old television broadcasts make this space documentary entertaining.
The direction is uninspired, acting is lifeless, and the script borders on the inept. A PG-13 rating means that it's short on shocks, too.
[Director Nic] Balthazar's determination to draw a positive message from a negative situation doesn't quite fit.

movie_title: The Art of Crying (Kunsten at græde i kor) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It's a typically poetic film, rich in powerful imagery, which sees a bitter personal tragedy unfold against the major events of 20th century Greece.
movie_title: Trilogia: To livadi pou dakryzei (The Weeping Meadow) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Its tough but moving neo-realist approach make it one of the better British films of recent times.

...a well-observed slice of social realist cinema.

A cut above the usual dramas aimed at teen female audiences, not least because it's about more than shopping and romance.
A clever structure by director Seth Gordon means that The King of Kong ends up more engrossing than its bunch of geeky characters initially suggest.
movie_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A tough, engaging, extremely touching work of cinema.
This fascinating documentary details day-to-day life in the hard-line Communist state of North Korea.
Sun spends so much time on the mood and atmosphere that he forgets about the story.
This banal comedy is filmmaking of the lowest order.
A flawlessly executed character study.
It certainly stands as Tsai's most skillful work -- he manages to keep viewer attention for a full 81 minutes with a minimum of action and dialogue.

Original and thrilling martial-arts choreography, a lean, hard-driving story and solemn atmosphere make The Princess Blade -- a futuristic tale -- stand way above the pack.
An undistinguished affair.
Eighty-year-old Japanese director Suzuki Seijun has always been a gifted master stylist, and Pistol Opera shows that his unique vision has not dulled with age.
A deodorized beach romance that plays the unpretentious personalities of Clarkson and Guarini to the hilt.
Outperforms most contemporary live-action films at every level.

A fan-boy hagiography of a mean-spirited alcoholic rather than a serious examination of a powerful writer and his writings.

Swiftly runs out of story and becomes stuck on the sexual squabbles of its characters.

Formally ambitious and emotionally engaging.

movie_title: Comment j'ai tué mon père (My Father and I) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Sensitive ensemble performances and good period reconstruction add up to a moving tragedy with some buoyant human moments.
Will certainly appeal to Asian cult cinema fans and Asiaphiles interested to see what all the fuss is about.

The Tracker has the punch of a good Western with a clean and direct script plus an adventurous use of songs and folk paintings.
On the Run has some moments of excitement and is certainly uncompromising.
The sum is greater than the parts in this multifaceted trilogy.

An uneasy hybrid of horror, courtroom drama and true-life story.
The result falls somewhere between psychodrama and horror.
A film that's more exploitative than sympathetic.
The film's success is mainly down to its vibrant energy. Cinematography is zappy, making much use of tricky visual effects, and performances are manic.
It's a roller-coaster action film that thunders along with top-notch set pieces and studiously researched period settings.

Despite swaths of verbal exposition and a tendency to overdose on robot action sequences, the film has enough originality to interest demanding fans of the genre.
Although A Tale of Two Sisters has some excellent suspense sequences, it falters badly during the dramatic parts.
A powerful drama about a disturbed mind seen from a relatively objective viewpoint.
This low-concept slasher/horror film suffers from creaky direction, a tatty story line, and -- even worse, considering the genre -- a lack of suspense and shocks.
The new version is slightly less frightening than the original, but it's still a scary psycho-horror that effectively replicates its bleak and crisp shocks.
Those who like a smattering of history with their entertainment will be disappointed, as historical details are kept vague. Even those who turn up purely for the romance won't be satisfied.
A powerful, if one-sided, attack on the GM food industry.
A frantic piece of filmmaking that invests nothing in the characters and moves much too fast for its own good.
A mature and subtle film about how a community rebuilds itself after tragedy and disaster.

A good-natured Indian-American romantic comedy in the style of Bend It Like Beckham.

This too-sentimental drama does feature a sterling performance by Giovanna Mezzogiorno as a love-struck housewife dissatisfied with her lot, thus providing the only watchable element of an otherwise disappointing movie.
A classy and clever French thriller.
It's a thoughtful work that opts for careful observation and quiet deliberation over histrionics and drama.
Hernandez's desire to utilize all the armaments of the filmmaker hits the viewer with a visceral force.
Should rightfully take its place in rock history as one of the great performance films of all time.
Pallid acting and a general lack of spirit ultimately result in a bland costume drama.
The strongest film [of the trilogy].
Although the story often feels contrived, honest performances and smart direction keep the film just the right side of sentimental.
This delicate movie elevates itself from the usual run-of-the-mill schooldays saga with a script that is one part funny, one part tragic and all parts thoroughly human.

The plot has a surprising amount of holes for a release of this size.

A run-of-the-mill action film ... Still, there is some fun to be had from watching a spirited set of performances by Noomi Rapace.

Plummer puts in a terrific performance as the mean and mendacious billionaire J. Paul Getty, and it's now difficult to imagine anyone else essaying the role with such aplomb.

movie_review_blurb: Meyers-Shyer's debut is less of a tribute to her mum's work than a Xerox copy of it.
The best US indie film of 2017.
Below par on every front, even for a potboiler, it merrily chugs along from one cliché to the next, piling unbelievable scenes on top of each other.
George Clooney reworked the script for this version, and he has ironed out all the eccentricity and dark humour that characterises the Coens' work.

The film works because the characters act like real people rather than movie ciphers.

The filmmakers have tried hard to subvert the toys' outdated notions of femininity by turning the film into a celebration of girl power and female empowerment, and the idea works well.

An unusually smart film, Battle of the Sexes mixes humour with social observation, and makes its point in a more entertaining way than most message films would.
This is a dull watch made less exciting by the low budget: the bulk of it appears to have been shot in a basement, and the needed special effects are almost non-existent.
Gimme Danger is an upbeat affair which benefits from some stylistic touches from Jarmusch.
The plot locks together perfectly, leaving no loose ends, and teenagers might not be the only ones sobbing by the film's end.
A delicate, heart-warming film which touches on serious topics like discrimination and ignorance, without finding the need to raise the stakes with unnecessary scenes of conflict.
movie_title: Close Knit (Karera ga honki de amu toki wa) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Dreadful acting and ropy action sequences will likely doom this thriller to well-deserved obscurity.
In spite of the film's penchant to gloss over the evils of colonial times, a masterful, deeply inward-looking performance by Judi Dench ... makes it an enjoyable watch.

By skillfully avoiding polemical statements and scenes of high drama, ... the film sends a powerful message about the evils of racism.
Disney's take on the oceanic myths of the Pacific Islands could go on to become an animated classic.

The film steals elements from supernatural classics such as The Omen, The Exorcist, and The Ring. ... The elements don't add up to anything more than a muddle.
One of Robert Redford's occasional forays into political filmmaking, this small-scale drama is packed with ideas. ... Great performances by Redford and Blanchett inject the movie with dramatic brio.
An unexpected blend of apocalyptic science-fiction and serial killer styles, it is, for once, completely impossible to guess how the story will resolve.
The Captive revels in its own nastiness and makes for a highly unpleasant watch.

Held together by an effective, if downplayed, Chandler-esque crime yarn, it touches on Marxist theory, theology, hubris, and even synchronised swimming. Film buffs will find it a treat.
This unfortunate film dearly wants to be Thor set in ancient Egypt, but ... comes up way short of that unambitious aim.

This dismal attempt to spice up a romantic comedy is as crude and clunky as they come.
Even though it's a pulp western brimming with the director's usual blood, guts and wry humour, the racial politics are more contemporary in nature than in Django Unchained.

movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Irritating characters, little semblance of a plot, weak gags, and sub-par performances ... result in a film that doesn't even have enough going on to interest a five-year-old.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Road Chip (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Although it stars friendly dinosaurs, the theme of overcoming fear -- or, in fact, learning to live with fear -- is handled in a more mature way than many live-action features.
Brosnan has a good time hamming it up as a heartless assassin, but why Jovovich is forced to spend the whole film darting around with black smudges on her face is a mystery.
The script by former journalist Peter Landesman, who recently directed the medical drama Concussion, does a good job of simplifying a complex real-life chain of events.
Concussion is clever in the way that it criticises the NFL, a central part of American culture, and yet ... upholds the American dream of hard work being rewarded by success.
Those who've seen the mysterious original will find the remake plodding, and those who haven't will enjoy it as a modern-day film noir.
Aside from a bit of mild toilet humour, Daddy's Home is a traditional Hollywood seasonal comedy in the mould of National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation, and Planes, Trains & Automobiles.
Older fans of Charlie Brown and Snoopy need not worry: this is an extremely faithful rendition of the strip.
The storyline is so bland it wouldn't even pass master for a daytime soap, and the strangely off-kilter depiction of New York doesn't help.
While the chef's rock-star persona ... does seem excessive, an excellent script and an immersive performance by Cooper result in an interesting character study.
Riveting in an insidious way, this Italian drama continues the long-standing European filmmaking tradition of excoriating the bourgeoisie.
The story is stolid at times, but the dynamic shots of the crew working the rigging and maintaining the boat look accurate and keep everything lively.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Director John Hillcoat doesn't bring anything new to the table, but he's crafted such a genuinely riveting movie that the familiarity barely matters.
How a director could turn one of literature's most imaginative works into such a humdrum affair is a mystery, but that's just what James Bobin has managed to do.
'The Nice Guys' is anarchic, irreverent, juvenile and sometimes downright uncomfortable, but it's also occasionally hilarious. ... A provocative film that pretends to be more stupid than it is.
Anyone wishing to experience two hours of misery should buy a ticket for Fathers and Daughters.
An unusually delicate tale about how to cope with an alien arrival on Earth.
Although costumes and sets look suitably glorious, there's little on-screen magic between co-stars Brad Pitt and Marion Cotillard.
The producers of Collateral Beauty have done a marvellous job in managing to persuade so many A-list stars to appear in a thoroughly appalling movie.

[Non-Christians] will find this trudge through Jesus' childhood years laborious, even though it thankfully refrains from proselytising.
Brad Peyton would seem to have viewed The Exorcist more times than is good for him, and evidently has a desire to be a new incarnation of horror director John Carpenter.

This is a B-movie dressed up to look like something deeper, although that doesn't negate its potential to entertain.
Inferno proves to be as crude and unsophisticated as its source material.
