Beatles fans are in for an enjoyable, if unenlightening, viewing experience, while those who don't know much about them will find it a Fab Four 101.
movie_title: The Beatles: Eight Days a Week - The Touring Years (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Although Keanu Reeves has never been noted for his subtlety as a thespian, his performance as a captive husband in Knock Knock could easily be bettered by a stationary object like a chair.
Oliver Stone is a filmmaker first and a political analyst second, and he manages to make the story thrilling even if everyone knows the ending.
Though its heart is certainly in the right place, Storks doesn't hold much for anybody - and even its intended audience of youngish children might find it a bore.
A fully fledged romance whose characters are analytical rather than passionate, the film's made with the head, not the heart.
Writer and star Jennifer Saunders has kept all the elements of the show the same, and that's a good thing, as the original worked perfectly.
The only reason for this film's existence can be that some bright spark of a producer wanted to translate the appeal of cute cat videos to the big screen.
In spite of its crudity, Bad Moms shows just how conservative mainstream filmmaking has become.
The film presents a meek and mild story which emphasises a cloying niceness, and even brings a rosy hue to the extreme suffering of the poor in India.
A dumbed-down entry in an already dumb genre, this inane sex comedy is neither funny nor outrageous enough to interest any viewer with an IQ higher than zero.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: There's not a lot of screaming and pointless running around to fill time - it's a tight script in which everything adds up.
What starts off as an intriguing Kafkaesque story about a businessman waiting to meet a king in an unbuilt desert city in Saudi Arabia unexpectedly metamorphoses into a dull romance.
The intellectual subtleties of Ballard's book are rendered too obvious on the big screen, and it all deteriorates into an exercise in British misery and nastiness.
If there is a story to Central Intelligence, it's plain the scriptwriters themselves don't know what it is.
It has a breathless, often frantic storyline that doesn't add up to much. But the beautifully rendered undersea locations and a rip-roaring nail-biter of an ending make up for the slack.
This biopic makes [maths] seem exciting and necessary, and sets it in a wide human context to appeal to those who have difficulty adding up their shopping bills.
There's no excuse for the film's vile misogyny, even if violence against women is a staple ingredient of such films.
An exciting, thoughtful big-screen adventure that employs most of the same characters and actors as the television series.
I kept expecting the "Game Over" message to flash up, but it never did.
Despite its peculiar name and the fact it bears a strong resemblance to Jumanji -- another film inspired by a book by children's author Van Allsburg -- it's hard not to like Zathura.
It is a superior popcorn movie that deftly juggles action and emotion.
With it's likeable band of rogue heroes, comedic situations and standout performances is a great way to spend two hours.
movie_title: Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels (1999)

movie_review_blurb: Someone took their love of urban legends one step too far!
Nowhere near as bad as the nay-sayers would have you believe. If anything, it'll open your eyes and make you think, while simultaneously entertaining the hell out of you.
Very Bad Things is a well-constructed study of the human psyche and how it eventually cracks under intense pressure.
Even young fans of the online shorts will find the concept stretched perilously thin. And if your eardrums don't break, your spirit certainly will.
A none-too-challenging romcom saved from obscurity by a kooky supporting cast, smutty one-liners and Portman flaunting her funny side.
Bigger and better than the original, Panda 2 skilfully avoids the curse of the sequel with wit, flair and a 3D paw to the face.
Fusing spectacle and emotion into a thrilling final chapter, director David Yates ensures that the series goes out with a bang. Finales don't come much grander than this.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A starry cast, curious premise and well-crafted shocks make for an ambitious thriller that ekes - and eeks - out the tension to its iffy finale.
Combining laughs and thrills with plenty of verve, Ben Affleck continues his smart directorial career with a stylish, gripping hostage drama.
Manages to break free from its low-budget limitations but is hamstrung by its own love of the genre.
Bandidas directors Joachim Roenning and Espen Sandberg employ impressive production values and a blockbuster sensibility here, nailing the suspense.
A sequel that - narratively and visually - sets the standard for its summer-movie stablemates.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Nolan reaches for the stars in spectacular fashion, delivering a mesmerising sci-fi epic that, despite a testing running time and few too many flights of fancy, is grounded by an on-form McConaughey.
Interstellar contains its fair share of heart-in-mouth moments, the previously untapped corners of space providing ample opportunity to mine fresh spectacle.
Taking the original and successfully transplanting it into an ambitious new world, José Padilha's english-language debut is an exciting, pacey and thoughtful sci-fi actioner.
Hampered by thoroughly unlikeable characters that not even its talented young cast (Ed Speleers, Will Poulter, Alfie Allen) can make you root for.
An enjoyable treat that'll have you rolling out of the cinema experiencing a mild sense of déjà vu but ultimately feeling rewarded for your investment.
Terrific performances and the perfect brooding atmosphere make it a truly outstanding work.
Fincher and Sorkin, who clearly acknowledged that the meat of the plot was in examining the diverse characters involved, are to be applauded.
McKellar's only mistake was to craft the niggling central role of Patrick, and then play it himself.
An elegant rejoinder to a tired genre, a consummate work of screen adaptation, and further evidence that there is precious little Sean Penn can't achieve on film, whether before or behind the lens.
Rushmore is made to be treasured: it feels like an immediate American classic.
Greengrass' dramatic re-enactment, galvanised by documentary techniques, is so dense and alive with detail that it should be viewed attentively.
Cinematically speaking, Luc and Jean-Pierre Dardenne are a modern-day miracle.

Unfortunately it is no more informative, possibly even less involving, than umpteen pieces of print and television reportage that have set out similarly to chronicle one of the major humanitarian crises of our age.
Dramatic scene after dramatic scene fails to take flight: too many face-to-face quarrels, flatly blocked and bluntly written.
The drama is hung on a vendetta between a flawed-but-honourable man and a doggedly bad cop. Yes, it's Valjean and Javert, together again.

There's really nothing extraordinary to praise about this affecting but not particularly memorable little movie other than to point out that audiences hungering for cinematic fare outside the usual summer popcorn blockbusters will find much to like in it.

This lackluster, stereotypical movie attempts to update its shopworn formula with a stream of four letter words and sexually crude phrases in Judd Apatow fashion but ends up turning off everyone in the process.
This delectable, adorable movie - yes that's the proper word for it - definitely leaves one hungering for another helping.
Though it wears out its welcome as it teeters rather than rocks toward the finish line, there is something inherently enticing in the old "let's put on a show" formula it utilizes.
A funny, violently gross, and wildly enthralling addition to the science fiction canon.
A rousing, emotional roller coaster that's a must see not just for fans of rock musicals but those with an eye (and an ear) for something unusual - compellingly so.
In a field crowded with sharp, aggressive, edgy comedies it's much more gentle, rounded and endearing. Yet it's not altogether warm and fuzzy - there's plenty of bite here and wry insight, too.
Writer-director Mike Judge is never purposely mean spirited. He just loves pointing out stupidity when he encounters it and he does so hilariously here.
This vintage set road comedy has enough amiable charms to make it across the finish line for those who like their movies to stay out of the fast lane.
Grace Coddington, Vogue's Creative Director, is the secret weapon the movie needs. One sits through all the Anna Wintour stuff just to get back to her.
A fairly diverting "bromance" that's sure to be a crowd pleaser.
Wonderfully inspired - will probably be anathema only to vegetarians.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The movie has breathtaking visual sequences but is a little too familiar and thin in plot and character department to elevate it much beyond its animated forebears.
Kate Beckinsale, adrift in a blizzard of cliches, doesn't have enough star presence or her Stevie Nicks black leather vampire drag to keep audiences from drifting away. Bland and predictable.
Michael Moore has made what may be his magnum opus.
I wanted to love it because it's so damn literary and exquisitely put together but ultimately it felt like a very long two hours.
Drew Barrymore's directorial debut is slight yet charming.
As essayed by Audrey Tautou through Anne Fontaine's lens, this Chanel is dry as toast and the antithesis of her sensual sartorial creations.

When it's over you just want to sit there and sigh for awhile then go home and have a cup of tomato soup and a grilled cheese and be tucked into bed and cry yourself to sleep. As long as mom is nearby.
One of those tried and true coming of age stories enlivened by the performance of newcomer Carey Mulligan and a great supporting cast.
Terrifically fun - gleeful gore.
The filmmakers do a good job of humanizing their conservative subjects but eventually the rigid mindset of these folks cancels out any common bond liberals might feel.
Not just the best film of the season, it's one of the best of the year.
An assured, beautiful movie, a perfect crystallization of the endlessly fascinating story of the unconventional Beales.
An enormous schwanstucker of a comedy - hilarious, raw, shocking. Sign me up girlfriend. Two snaps up. Way up!
A beautifully observed portrait of a power gay couple that is as entertaining as it is illuminating.
Oh Sister, I have such doubt. Doubt about an audience getting conned into taking seriously such a rickety piece of movie junk like this.
For those that have tried repeatedly to watch the wretched 1985 film version of A Chorus Line hoping that maybe this time it somehow magically wouldn't stink, this is the movie...for us.
A pleasurable, old fashioned gay romance with a good measure of art and politics tossed in between the passion.
Such a blandly predictable sci-fi blockbuster that one can focus on different parts of Hugh Jackman's extraordinary physique without fear of losing out on a single plot point.
A slick, standard Hollywood studio produced romantic comedy that utilizes a clever conceit and some expert supporting comedic performances to help it squeak by.
Startling in its delightful originality, it heralds the arrival of a major new talent in filmmaker Nina Paley.
A chilling, brutal film that is a lot more than the sum of its one dimensional parts would suggest.
Reduces the story of this feminine icon into a typical Hollywood romantic triangle, albeit one with some beautifully staged aerial set pieces.
A political thriller that eventually loses its enjoyable thriller aspects as it meanders off into propaganda for the once mighty newspaper biz.
The latest in a long line of mean spirited, snark filled, low down comedies that while it lasts gives stereotyping a good name.
A stereotypical 'little' French film that nevertheless comes wrapped in an awfully sweet package.
Too many notes.
The Polaroids of the bachelor party shown during the end titles deliver the genuine laughs the movie has promised; they're better than the entire movie that preceded it.
A big budget, limp comedic exercise in male adolescence.
More machine than movie. Sleek, human-like but ultimately cold steel and unfeeling.
An inflammatory documentary that artfully skewers its subjects. Sic 'em Kirby!
A wistful masterpiece.
Biel's rather lumpen line readings aside it has enough stylish zest and laughs to make it an easy recommendation.
The movie, duly enjoyable, joins a long list of Bullock's previous audience pleasing romance-centric films. For fans of Bullock and Ryan Reynolds' spectacular abs only.
Depp makes for a smashing anti-hero who audiences won't mind seeing die onscreen. Mann's approach is old fashioned but emotionally satisfying.

Like last year's big summer masterpiece, The Dark Knight, this is one action spectacular that adds an undercurrent of unease to the witches brew as it's delivering one thrilling sequence after another.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A great addition to the Things That Go Bump In the Night movie canon.
An entertaining but strange hybrid -- part murder mystery, part gooey teen romance/coming of age story, part philosophy lesson, part family drama
An intensely moving underdog story that hits all its melodramatic marks and shoots over those, too.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A delightful homage to the simple pleasures that life can offer no matter the age.
A sexless, joyless remake of a trashy guilty pleasure.
Surprise: Calculation leads to diverting pleasure in this engineered from top to bottom studio movie.
Techine once again displays a masterful control ofall aspects of his movie, a typically rich character study.
movie_title: The Girl on the Train (La Fille du RER) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It seems to have been filmed and hermetically sealed yearsago and only now, belatedly found on a shelf and trotted out.
A testament to individuality and determination.
A bland, unncessary return to Freddyland
There's enough Downey and copious amounts of attendant razzle dazzle in this overstuffed sequel to make for a cautious recommendation.
It's a bath in schmaltz from beginning to end but it also has Redgrave who brings instant depth to even the most throwaway of lines.
The script's feminine perspective helps elevate the film from Egoyan's usual sexy (but satisfying) thriller into something a tad more insightful.
Queen Latifah has enough chemistry with her costar Common to make you believe that she's really falling for him
Among other problems, the material has maddening character and situation gaps that require one to suspend disbelief.
movie_title: The City of Your Final Destination (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It might be time for Carrie & Company to hang up the ManoloBlahniks.
The picture seems like it would be perfect Saturday matinee fodder but it's missing the exhilaration of many of its cheesier forebears.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The perfect synthesis of horror and the horrifically funny. My favorite film experience this year
A great cautionary tale.
It's like a deluxe episode of Kathy Griffin's reality show My Life on the D-List and it's just as galvanizing and dishy.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A cinematic repast so delicious that one can only stand back in awe at its sheer artistry and hail it as a masterpiece.
Familiar to the point of blandness. But then again, every time The Mirren walks into view ...

One of those small cinematic miracles that movie audiences hope and pray for. That it makes a powerful social argument in favor of LGBT families without breaking a sweat in the process is a wonderful bonus.
A supreme example of movie junk food.
Like the music of the group, this is best enjoyed in the moment as a guilty, irresistible pleasure without any pretense of depth to deaden its erotic charge.
calculated and ham handed
A stylish cornucopia of treats for dedicated Anglophiles and fans of crime procedurals alike.
The real nightmare before Christmas - way too scary for the kiddies and not nearly warm enough for audiences of all ages.

A sobering drama that at its core is a heterosexual love story between two men. To be clear, there's no homoerotic undercurrent here but it's a love story of opposites falling for each other nevertheless.
The end of the world movie to end 'em all, it turns out to be a sort of cross between the sci-fi camptacular When Worlds Collide and every previous Emmerich movie. Guilty pleasures galore.
When the world goes Boom! I want Viggo Mortensen to be my dad. Who better to keep your spirits up in the hideous post-apocalyptic after life as pictured here?
A nice piece of fluff that will be particularly enjoyed by those with a taste for the era when the theatre was rife with Teutonic personalities, both behind the curtain and onstage.
A masterpiece that's long been championed by film critics and archivists and should also be given its place as a part of gay cinema history.
A veddy proper film that wouldn't presume to misbehave with an ounce of unnecessary melodrama and abandon. We are amused and entertained but not terribly so.
Entertaining enough and stunning to look at but essentially an exceedingly detailed three hour video game -- without the benefit of remote controls
Daniel Day-Lewis' miscasting throws the entire movie off kilter and one is left to contemplate the holes in the material.
Not just the best queer themed movie of the year -- it's one of the best. Period.
A stylish, frisky film that sets up the franchise deftly
This is not the galvanizing, deep fried melodrama of Tennessee Williams at his height but rather, the low fat version.
movie_title: The Loss of a Teardrop Diamond (2009)

movie_review_blurb: An entertaining enough thriller, even filled with enough dumb dumb plot holes, to if not welcome the butt kicking, heart of gold Mel Gibson back into good graces, at least give him a temporary access pass.
Despite some dramatic implausibility and a misstep here and there, this is overall a very well told, well made historical romantic drama.
It will more than satisfy those with a predilection for old fashioned romance but cynics are warned to keep clear or be prepared to shut up and hand some Kleenex to their cow eyed better halves.
Both the audience and the characters are stuck in their chairs waiting and waiting and waiting and...
A perfect movie personification of the holiday -- crass, commercial and guaranteed to make a zillion dollars off the love struck masses. Ugh.
For the most part, a ripping good time -- literally.
You don't necessarily believe these are real folks but boy they sure are entertaining.
A thrilling exercise in Grand Guignol -- so operatic in tone one can almost hear the arias during the flurry of memorable set pieces.
It's the kind of enjoyable, junky melodramatic mystery/roman-a-clef that any script doctor would be proud to admit having written.
A profoundly disturbing movie, all the more so because it's so damned hilarious. I think it's a great film; one that is finally worthy of all the hoopla that usually attends the Cohen's movies.
Enthralling. A vivid portrait of a family seemingly involved in only their own problems who have been infected by the filth and enervation around them.
Let's hope this is the springboard for a biopic on the art world's dynamic gay duo - maybe by the time it gets made we'll even have some openly gay actors to play the parts.
movie_title: Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe (2007)

movie_review_blurb: I can't believe I'm writing this in a dumbed down age at the movies but Duplicity is a film that's too smart for its own good.
An energetic but whisper thin south sea adventure that borrows heavily from Home Alone and Jewel of the Nile.

The picture is mildly entertaining, aided strongly by the retro period and Caine's authoritative performance. As for Moore, the script doesn't offer her much - certainly not the intensity that brought her equal parts fame and derision.
A beautiful film - as flawed as its subject, and all the more fascinating because of its odd lapses.

Cinéma Vérité Godzilla - canny enough to have been designed for the YouTube generation as well as for those elder folks like myself that still like a good ride on the roller coaster every once in awhile.

For those who want to Believe, those who want to be cuddled by the fake laughter through tears emotions that only an expertly made piece of Hollywood toffee like this can provide - if only for the moment - get out your hankies.
An offbeat fairy tale for grownups that squeaks by on its visual panache and some major male eye candy.

The reunion is fun and predictably fabulous but the movie eventually totters on its expensive Manolo Blahnik's, trying to stay upright for too long, gorging on too much of a good thing. Fun and frothy as it is, fleet of foot it's not.
Though I much preferred the efficient, murderous simplicity of Them, the French original, for the uninitiated The Strangers is a nice little fright fest and perfect date fare to boot.
If Shyamalan wanted to commit career suicide he couldn't have chosen a more likely vehicle than this laugh inducing 'thriller.'
Marvel-ous!
Money, madness, incest, matricide, retro fashions - what could be more cinematic than this?
If there is anything that will save Get Smart from the same mindless fate as the rest of director Peter Segal's blandly funny oeuvre, it's the presence of Steve Carell.

Both the tissue thin character and the movie are hardly sustainable beyond an SNL sketch which makes the 90 minute running time almost as interminable as one of those Deepak Chopra sanctimonious self-help tapes.
A strange hybrid of a movie; a film that never congeals and is the first misstep that I can recall Smith making since he refused to kiss Eric Thal on screen in Six Degrees of Separation 15 years ago.
A very entertaining fiasco
movie_title: Mother of Tears: The Third Mother (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A very sweet family film, a cross between Annie and Nancy Drew
A perfect Saturday matinee movie.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A charming French spy farce replete with homoerotic undertones
movie_title: OSS 117: Le Caire Nid d'Espions (OSS 117: Cairo, Nest of Spies) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A sinister epic that manages to turn its pulp, comic book source into complex and thrilling art for the masses.
The movie gets by on sheer exuberance. Your appreciation of it, I suspect, will strongly depend on your mood and the enthusiasm of the audience members around you.
A great political satire - a Dr. Strangelove for the YouTube generation

Director Jean Jacques-Beineix's pop art pastiche is a glittering mix of artifice and genuine cool with its intricate yet effortless thriller plot enacted by some of the screen's most individual and eccentric characters; its combination of playful sexiness
A wonderful black comedy that has gotten a tad lost in the recent sea of excellent indie pictures.

The movie's run of the mill stuff - fairly entertaining but not particularly inventive - with the standard twists and turns. Yet another film featuring a cute but horrific serial killer fixated on a beautiful and intelligent female law officer.
After 19 years, Spielberg and company have unearthed the best treasure of all - another great Indiana Jones movie.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: If this is a movie for children than I can only guess the filmmakers had Donald Rumsfeld's grandkids in mind when they made it
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A welcome addition to a legion of AIDS related movies and the French perspective, so different from our own, never fails to intrigue
America the Beautiful is a great film - a provocative cautionary tale that fingers crossed, might also act as a wake-up call.

As Then She Found Me moves along it takes on some of the same sweet, loopy tone of Waitress and the story has a similar arc. It doesn't have the lush, dreamy look of Waitress (or its sounds) but it felt just as satisfying.

Baby Mama which was written not by Fey but by its director Michael McCullers is awfully familiar yet the movie - forgive me - delivers its laughs without audiences having to go into labor to get them.

The soothing, all encompassing power of music and song - its ability to unify, offer pleasure, fulfill the artistic bent, communicate, and much more - is vividly demonstrated in the documentary Young@Heart.
My Blueberry Nights at any length doesn't begin to answer the question why Jones, who seems nice in a bland, girl next door way, would ever be tapped to star in a movie.

Audiences who love seeing cranky, emotionally blocked characters find a chance to bloom will be happy to endure the withering onscreen insults but I didn't have much use for these dyspeptic folks and was happy to see them go.
The movie lives up to its title. How else to explain the random switch from such a dizzy set up with such promise to a typical, by the numbers relationship drama?

The war in Iraq has itself become the realization of the shameful "Don't Ask, Don't Tell" policy (it's not just gays and lesbians that are being told to look the other way). Stop-Loss reveals just one ugly aspect of such insidiousness.
Charles Nelson Reilly's one-man stage show makes for a terrific one-man movie.
Uncork the champagne you Noel Coward lovers, you passionate Cole Porter queens. Here is a movie that combines the effortless sophistication and lyrical cleverness of those two witty gay icons.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Penelope is a sweet trifle, a great kid's movie, and not surprising, given its subject matter a film gay audiences will find familiar and comforting. That's because, more than anything, this is a story of acceptance of one's true self.
In an earlier era this would have starred Bette Davis and Miriam Hopkins and in its way, The Other Boleyn Girl is just as trashy and enjoyable.
Director Michel Gondry delivers the first great film of 2008.
To fall for Vantage Point you have to throw away any connection to reality.
The fifth installment of Romero's zombie series is dark, creepy and funny.
At 97 minutes this not just a great Saturday matinee for 10 year-olds, but one for their indulgent parent(s) or handy dandy favorite gay relative/babysitter as well.

In Bruges has unforgettable moments of depth, lots of pitch black humor, outrageous, unbelievable twists that are nevertheless quite entertaining and the teaming of Gleeson and Farrell who jointly deliver an acting knock out.
An entertaining, sincere effort livened by the magnetic performance of Bratt.
A sumptuous romantic drama that honors its literary source and deeply satisfies.
As compelling in its way as Daniel Karslake's For the Bible Tells Me So.
A charming, loving portrait electrified by the inclusion of lots of terrific home movie footage. These relics of gay history are worth the rest of the movie.

Former Chicagoan Joe Gold wrote and stars in this not bad little comedy that is long on theatrical tradition and stereotypical characters (including a few gay ones). Not surprisingly, the material would lend itself very well to a stage adaptation.
Disney Lite - thin and familiar but love that digital animation!
A wonderful, full bodied movie that earns its tears honestly driven by an Oscar worthy performance by Penn.
A movie that needs to finally be acknowledged -- unsullied -- for the groundbreaking status that it deserves.
It's a very broadly drawn movie and being something of a rarity, I'm inclined to encourage you to give this continent-sized epic a bit of a go.
Tom Gustafson's musical fantasia is the gay indie of the year.
I've seen one too many movies about the disgraced president to find the material compelling.

Streep overacts the way Bette Davis did in What Ever Happened to Baby Jane? and its fun and scary and thrilling at the same time. It's the reason to see Doubt but subtle it's not - and there's no doubting that.
A rich character study; Rourke is a wonder to behold.
It's a movie about death and taxes (yes, really), a phony baloney tearjerker, one of those "noble" dramas that movie stars love filled with characters heavy with the weight of regret.
Stripped of the over the top special effects that have driven Cruise's most successful vehicles Valkyrie doesn't offer much in its place.
This year's Atonement, an example of tragic film romance at its sensual height.
The movie's really a psychological horror story in which the characters, especially the wife, are broken down as surely as the spinster Eleanor Vance played by Julie Harris in The Haunting.
Fincher's strange romantic epic has its greatest impact the first time around. Overall, the film seems more like a beautiful curio than anything else, a sort of artsy fartsy Forest Gump.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This silly hokum is so full of plot holes that it truly lives up to its title.
A charming winner - the 3-D effects have the frozen in place charm of antique stereoscope postcards.
Enjoyable in the easy, familiar way that many other variations on the original French La Ronde have been (think Love, Actually without the wackiness or British accents).
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The movie's documentary-like approach helps minimize the usual syrupy Hollywood dramatics inherent in these types of pictures.
The film could have easily lost an hour on its running time.
Isla Fisher does her best with a shopworn, shopped out premise.
A chilling, fresh addition to the mob movie genre.
Jay McCarroll is surprisingly endearing in a familiar fashion doc.
Basically Rebel Without a Cause with fangs -- except no one in it is nearly as talented as James Dean or Natalie Wood was.
Even with such a familiar story arc the characters - both dead and alive - leave behind vivid memories when the movie's over.
A clever variation on the classic underdog story with major elements of the Cain and Abel story and an eye opening travelogue to boot.
Wade's extremely low budget film is hampered by badly recorded dialogue and a script that tries to cram too many issues and characters in.
A spot on spoof that doesn't resort to the smarmy adult adolescence of the Judd Apatow movies for its laughs and is easily just as entertaining if not more so.
Grossman's movie never delves much below the surface.

It's such a rewarding movie going experience it's tempting to trot out all the adjectives generally used to describe a good wine. Not being a connoisseur I'll just say that it left me with a very pleasant buzz.

One might suggest audience members indulge in a little recreational activity before entering the theatre but I'm not sure that will increase your laugh intake all that much. So I'll advise you to just say "maybe."
What helps the film stand out is the less than melodramatic approach of director Isabel Coixet and the complex performances of Kingsley and Cruz.
Silly, inconsequential fun with enough laughs to make it worth a trip to the megaplex.

A delightful though somewhat predictable Woody Allen farce is enlivened by its beautiful Barcelona locations and the performances of Cruz and Bardem (who brings heart to the stereotypical Latin lover character).

Fans of the original should alter their expectations while those who haven't experienced the verbal sparring between Russell, Crawford, Mary Boland, et al, should take in this new version first, if only to give it a fair shake.
Here we are back on firm Coen Brothers bitter black comedic territory ala Fargo and The Big Lebowski and the laughs are aplenty in this aptly tagged "smart movie about stupid people."
Documentary filmmaker Chris Smith's feature debut is startling, original and quietly winning.
It's Gervais' picture from first to last and in one fell swoop the movies have found a successor to the late Dudley Moore.
A great film about a national disgrace and some remarkable 'regular folks' who refused to let it overwhelm them.
Greg Kinnear's performance drives an old fashioned and satisfying David vs. Goliath picture.

Though a bit too long it nevertheless has got the goods to speak to the FaceBook/MySpace/YouTube crowd in the way that Fame, Dazed & Confused, Billy Jack, and American Graffiti spoke to previous generations
Ed Harris' labor of love is a welcome return to the classic westerns of yore.
If you've ever dreamed of seeing Brazil, Dark City, City of Lost Children, or the Quay Brothers animated, Kafkaesque classic Street of Crocodiles reimagined for kids now you have your chance.
Captures what has to be one of the coolest and most emotionally enthralling wedding celebrations ever. It's simply a great movie.
Here after a long dry spell is an example of queer filmmaking at its best. Hallelujah my gay brethren!
A patently false but supremely satisfying Sisterhood Picture.
Guy Ritchie returns to form and whether a homophobe or not (as his soon to be ex-brother-in-law claims), this is the movie of a man who certainly appreciates the male form.
An extremely rare movie commodity -- a romantic comedy for guys.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Plenty of thrills, just enough bedroom action, and a smattering of witty retorts to keep things crackling.
The reality isn't quite as enthralling as one would hope.
The remake has the same jokey, snarky tone of the original mixed with plenty of genuine, delicious scares.
Not quite the four star comedic meal it promises at the outset, Dinner for Schmucks makes for a tasty repast, nonetheless.
A lot more entertaining than the majority of its critical raspberries would suggest.
A bittersweet winner-driven by the strong performances and sharply observed nuances in both McGowan's script and direction.
The standard action sequences pile up, interspersed with Wolverine's mooning about in a funk because he's lost the will to live.
Ironically, even a movie about Linda Lovelace's rather sad life uses her more for her body than her character.
Schrader's idea of a modern-day noir has promise but Ellis' script lets him down and leaves the actors adrift with no scenes to play.
A large-scale, middle-of-the-road work that is entertaining and moving in the way that many other movies about the struggle for race equality have been.

movie_review_blurb: Playing more like a highlights reel from an established franchise than a movie intended to launch it, G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra interrupts its barrage of CGI action for only the barest minimum of anything resembling character development.

movie_review_blurb: An affecting character study for mature viewers.

One of the most visually spectacular toons in recent years.

Pic upholds the series' trademark use of pacey action and well-defined characters struggling against oppression and seeking answers to spiritual questions.

movie_review_blurb: The 3D is terrific in Flying Swords of Dragon Gate, but helmer Tsui Hark's costume actioner -- the first Chinese-lingo movie shown in the stereoscopic Imax format -- is let down by two-dimensional characters.
movie_title: The Flying Swords of Dragon Gate (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Surfing meets sociology in Splinters, a compelling docu about the sport's arrival in the Papua New Guinea village of Vanimo.
Lengthy coverage of a murder trial involving Jai and Koby supplies the odd moment of meaningful reflection, but the overall impression is that of an unconvincing PR exercise.

A rare example of a mockumentary geared for family viewing, Aussie laffer Razzle Dazzle: A Journey Into Dance runs the world of children's dance competitions through the ringer and comes up with amusing results.
movie_title: Razzle Dazzle: A Journey Into Dance (2007)

movie_review_blurb: One of the most infamous miscarriages of justice in Indian legal history is dynamically dramatized.
The second stanza in this gargantuan Thai trilogy is a much more entertaining, if still confusing, proposition for foreign observers than the first, King Naresuan.
movie_title: Legend of Naresuan: Declaration in Independence (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Loaded with underdog heroics and bursting with youthful enthusiasm, Hula Girls may be utterly predictable but it sure is a lot of fun.
Heavy on CGI slapstick and light on meaningful emotional content.
This artsy romancer is well performed but suffers from muddled, meandering plotting.
Writer-director Patricia Rozema has made significant alterations to the original text and her instincts have worked superbly.
A well-observed study of outsiders distinguished by precise performances from a well-cast ensemble.
Hillcoat and Cave have here found their most fertile ground yet for allegory-rich examinations of life and death in remote, pressure-cooker environments.
A consistently involving character study.
An imaginative, humorous and truthful contemplation of human reaction to the inexplicable.
Kokoda is long on the muddy-bloody details of jungle warfare and short on fleshed-out characters.

Pacy, broad-based overview of the punk rock scene from 1977 to present packages a who's who of luminaries and rare performance clips into a vibrant proof-of-life statement underpinned by keen analysis of sociopolitical issues.
[A]n illuminating meditation on that deepest of Buddhist philosophical concerns -- impermanence.
movie_title: Journey into Buddhism: Vajra Sky Over Tibet (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Puppy has many intriguing twists, but, unfortunately, they lead to plausibility potholes.
This adaptation of Elliot Perlman's 1998 novel shifts uneasily at times around weighty themes, but its essential humanism still strikes chords.
The first feature in an Australian Aboriginal language feels authentic to the core as it tells a cautionary tale set 1,000 years ago.
The acting process is joyously celebrated in Casting About, a captivating documentary shot entirely in audition rooms during the search for three thesps for a feature film.

Centered on an ordinary young woman-turned-rescuer of victims, pic's integrity and committed performances should spark strong fest interest and generate discussion of a supremely ugly subject.

A finely chiseled drama about an unstable Chinese mother struggling to reconcile her desires with her children's needs in early '70s Australia, The Home Song Stories speaks bittersweet truths about life in the Chinese diaspora.

Plot and character rarely rise above functional, but the screenplay does have some intriguing psychosexual undercurrents, and [director Chris] Graham produces enough vigorous action to leave genre buffs satisfied, if not ecstatic.
A competent horror filmed in eye-catching Aussie outback locations.
Though occasionally too caught up with bold visuals and a complex audioscape, this mood piece has a suspenseful storyline and enough fleshed-out characters to maintain interest.
This film-school grad project does rep an arresting debut for British-based German helmer Laurin Federlein.
movie_title: Build a Ship, Sail to Sadness (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Oversupplied with particularly nasty bloodletting and underdone as an involving portrait of one of the Bard's mightiest and most psychologically intriguing tragic figures.
The result is a movie that can be admired in many respects from a distance but is progressively less emotionally engaging.

This moody item is an engrossing character study with potent commentary on the monumental social and economic changes in recent Chinese history, but it's less successful in bringing its mystery elements to a satisfying conclusion.
Offers a fresh, intimate and mostly successful perspective on Germany's traumatic transition from conqueror nation to occupied state.
Lusciously photographed and wildly uneven.
movie_title: The Tenants Downstairs (Lou xia de fang ke) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "Lady of the Lake" is light on plot but makes strong statements about human rights and the corrosive effects of living in a constant state of fear.
All the performances are tops, right down to the bit parts.
Exciting action partly compensates for the lack of scripting and thesping panache.

Beginning brightly with goofy slapstick, irreverent humor and a dastardly plot to overthrow the monarch, the film squanders its early success in a second half marred by pedestrian pacing and ho-hum action scenes.
Its deep compassion and intelligent examination of an especially terrible type of injustice will win the day for many viewers.
"Monsters" paints a disturbing picture of contemporary youth culture while delivering gruesome sights that'll have horror hounds howling in approval.

Stylishly decorated and generating all-important sympathy for a character living precariously in two worlds, director Kentaro Hagiwara's feature debut gets the drama right but is let down by visual effects that are sometimes unconvincing.
A gripping combination of police procedural and coming-of-age drama.

Spurrier crafts an intriguing and visually beautiful tale that taps into universal childhood experiences while painting a realistic picture of life in a community suffering severe economic and environmental hardships.
