Following [a] spirited set-up, the story never gains much propulsion or emotional weight.
With her striking face and a death stare of almost other-worldly intensity, Sveta's virtually impossible not to watch, no matter how appalling her actions become.
A gripping existential psychodrama by multitalented Thai filmmaker Prabda Yoon.
Clearly made with the utmost love and care, "The Portrait" is beautifully decorated and top-notch in every technical detail.
Anchored firmly in the emotional struggles and family relationships of its fascinating characters, this gritty slice of documentary-like drama neither condemns nor condones the porn industry.
Social realism is delivered with an impressively tough edge in "Old Beast," a compelling portrait of a selfish father whose reprehensible behavior drives his adult children to take drastic action.
There's barely a false note in "Passage of Life," an outstanding social realist drama about a Burmese refugee family facing an uncertain future in Tokyo.

As he did so winningly in "Priscilla" and 1997's unfairly overlooked outback comedy "Welcome to Woop Woop," Elliott celebrates Australian identity with genuine love while simultaneously roasting it over the coals of no-holds-barred satire and parody.
Has the potential to help bring kangaroo welfare and management into much sharper focus in Australia and internationally.
First-time feature writer-director Nic Gorman has delivered a suspenseful, engrossing and very well performed mood piece that marks him as a talent worth watching.
The revealing and frequently heartbreaking documentary is bound to create shockwaves on home turf and should stir up plenty of interest elsewhere.

Centered on a 14-year-old boy caught up in a murder mystery involving a part-Aboriginal suspect, this outstanding adaptation of Craig Silvey's novel will appeal strongly to teenage and adult audiences.
South Korean romantic fantasy-thriller hits the mark despite some minor bumps.
A penetrating, highly entertaining portrait of Lynch as an artist and single mother living through the despairing lows and exhilarating highs of filming on the subcontinent.
Tthe burning question of child safety and long-term physical effects of fists-and-feet Muay Thai boxing is all but absent.
Docu's only slight blemish is some repetitive testimony. Tech aspects are fine.

Much of the humor is driven by a savage near-hatred of everything suburban, which frequently undermines its own effectiveness, and poses a barrier to auds engaging emotionally with the central character.
There's never been a road movie quite like Paths of the Soul, an extraordinary chronicle of ordinary Tibetan citizens undertaking a 1,200-mile pilgrimage to Lhasa.
A potent combo of hostage thriller and high-impact morality play.

With their civilized discussion and amusing asides about the making and marketing of docus, the Makhmalbafs succeed in entertaining and engaging auds who are interested in the question of why people seek religion.
A gory and funny riff on the trusty standby of city kids being menaced by rural types.
Staple pulp ingredients -- a girl, a gun, a stranger, a crooked cop and a suitcase full of hot cash -- are neatly moved around a dusty outback town in the juicy Aussie thriller Swerve.
Eduardo Roy Jr.'s well-crafted drama explores Manila's transgender community with docu-like authenticity.
Although the pace tails off just slightly toward the end, the pic never loses its charm, and Habicht emerges as the funniest and most lovable Kiwi to hit New York since Flight of the Conchords.
Though it's a tad overcranked in the final furlong, the sheer energy on display and a devilishly compelling plot ultimately win the day.
Though it bogs down at times, Yoon Jong-bin's kimchi Western is a rousing, lavishly produced delight.
A marvelously entertaining combo of haunted-house thriller, murder mystery and domestic comedy, Housebound marks a mighty impressive feature bow for Kiwi scripter-helmer-editor Gerard Johnstone.
Armed with "Mad Max"-like design elements and a good sense of humor, this energetically executed bloodbath marks a promising feature bow for Australian brothers Kiah and Tristan Roache-Turner.
The anguish and guilt of a policeman whose young daughter has gone missing are powerfully conveyed in Sunrise.
This film from experienced Aussie documaker Jennifer Peedom packs an emotional punch to match its awe-inspiring imagery.

Anchored by a charismatic central performance by John Arcilla ("Metro Manila") and peppered with exciting action sequences, the pic has the all-around energy to overcome the odd moment of bumpy storytelling and prosaic dialogue.
Chinese heist caper starts out as a tasty dish, but turns bland before long.
This Aussie docu about an outback children's choir sings a winning tune.
This well-crafted remake of 1978's 'Patrick' is rich in gothic trappings and features a terrific central performance by Sharni Vinson.
It flouts convention in a number of ways in service of its genre-mash-up agenda while still contributing something original to the tradition of the zombie film.
Pascal Laugier's film illustrates the problem of class mobility with a dark, troubling premise that holds a harsh light up to our own assumptions and expectations.
Pixar's latest ultimately offers nothing more than a caricature of a well-worn conceit.
Ross offers something in his film adaptation of the novel that Collins, writing with Katniss's voice, never could: the experience of watching the Hunger Games, rather than being a contestant in them.
While we all have our variable thresholds for niche entertainments, there's usually a support group in a church basement somewhere willing to offer at least a sense of community.
Hilariously chronicles the missteps and triumphs-and everything in between-of four teenage guys in their efforts to get laid for the first time.
Red Riding Hood is sort of like a hook-up that you remember more or less fondly but still would never tell your friends about.
This is Beauty and the Beast for the Twilight generation; they've paid for abs and sparkles, and they insist on getting their money's worth.
I Am Number Four is a promise that the freaks will outlast the popular kids and that the aliens among us, the people with all the problems, are the ones who will still be around for the sequel.

This is a film which takes classic source material and imbues it on screen with a sense of wonder commensurate to its prior form, perhaps offering an even more visceral impression of the possibilities inherent to this beautiful, tragic world.
You might be left cold at the end of Stake Land when the question of what this particular variant is going to do differently is answered with a half-hearted shrug.
Francis Lawrence imbues the source material with visceral pleasure in well-wrought scenes vacillating between elaborate spectacle, breathtaking terror, and--occasionally--surprising beauty.
The half-hearted presence of these actors is the ultimate metaphor for the current tragedy facing the creative class.

A curious blend of our newly acquired taste for dystopia alongside a healthy sprinkling of Lord of the Flies, the film offers familiar pleasures without prompting the sense of having already been here before.
Women deserve a better vehicle for demonstrating the power of female solidarity than this empty money grab.
Bill Condon's Beauty and the Beast actually delivers a remarkably optimistic balm to a festering, existential wound.
Stacy Title's film ends up succeeding most deftly as an advertisement for on-campus housing.

It abandons its subtlety and sense of mystery en route to becoming a typically moralistic screed about the preservation of the nuclear family, alongside an obvious but never-quite-resolved cautionary tale about the importance of conservation.
The juxtaposition of courtship and violence is the film's one true coup, but Pride and Prejudice and Zombies still mistakes weaponry for agency.

Greg Berlanti's charmingly heartfelt film is a remarkably successful attempt to give shape to the experience of the closet by drawing an incredibly intimate portrait of a teenage boy about to leave it behind.
At its worst, the film dangerously repackages the queer experience using language invented by those originally deployed to break it apart.
Even stronger than its predecessor, which didn't quite go as far in terms of representing these young women in a wider context.
These films, and Tolkien's entire oeuvre, are most affecting in their depictions of friendship, and the performances here represent platonic male intimacy in convincing, often moving ways.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: As a metaphor for the way we respond to the media, and the way our politics are funneled through the media lens, the film succeeds most when it revels in ambiguity.
The film, based on the novel by Gayle Forman, is an almost deliberate confirmation of Alison Bechdel's claim that women in film are so often shown only in relation to men.
An arresting, quirkily structured film.
45 Years is a perceptive, subtle look at how a relationship, even so many years in, is at root an unknowable thing.
McCarthy's sharp, incisive, quietly moving drama tells a knotty story with boundless intelligence, wit, and insight.

As the film sprawls across nighttime Berlin, fluidly moving and moving and moving, it's impossible not to feel a giddy sense of awe. Which, various criticisms aside, is certainly one reason to go to the movies.
Though it's not likely to get the kind of awards attention that a performance in a more "serious" movie might, Sarandon's work in The Meddler approaches career-best territory.
The movie glides along at a low, comfortable arc, and as the credits roll you're likely to be neither blissed out nor buzzing, instead merely lulled into a kind of fuzzy cheer.
The Walk triumphs, even if it wobbles quite a bit in getting there.
Fassbender thrillingly commands Steve Jobs, a movie that takes care to entertain while also informing.
Its earnestness and wry, folksy humor seem to come moseying in from the past, from the film days of old, when politics didn't have to be so dang murky or pointed.
A smart, goofy delight.
It's a juicy, challenging role for an actress, one that the film's star, Brie Larson, handles with restraint and sensitivity.
A pure delight, a tense survival tale leavened by an abundance of geeky wit and an array of fine actors at their snappy best.

Told with simplicity but deep empathy, Baker's film sports a refreshingly sober, grown-up worldview that refuses to judge, sensationalize, or do anything other than show lives as they may be, and perhaps are.

We Are Your Friends takes a traditional trade movie -- the Cocktails, the Quicksilvers, the Boiler Rooms -- and infuses it with enough youthful, entrancing chiaroscuro to make it feel original, and vital.
Carol maybe isn't the sweeping, three-hanky melodrama I was ready for. But as it slowly seeps in, it transcends.
Vinterberg has made a gentle, unintrusive film, graceful and too refined to speak out of turn.
This is a rare comedy sequel that works, so let's hope they don't do a third.

The film is not quite as silly as Pacific Rim or his dreadful FX series, The Strain, but as del Toro does too often, here he takes what could be a winning homage to a genre he loves and smothers it in sensational, empty style.
[Magic Mike XXL] has an easy, engaging flow, at once natural and dreamlike.

Ted 2 strains to be the synthesis of... what made MacFarlane famous and his deeper creative temperament, and there are moments when that tonal zigging and zagging works. But they are ultimately warring impulses.
Maybe this is just glowing praise born out of basement-level low expectations, but I found U.N.C.L.E.'s bouncy vibe to be an utter delight.
After all this time, it's a pleasure to watch Meryl Streep sweat.
Southpaw may lack in narrative agility, thudding around from cliché to cliché, but when it gets in the ring, it knows just what to do.

You can see, especially in that final, hilarious mêlée scene, where Ant-Man could have gone right. (Where it could have gone Wright?) But the film is too timid to fully take the wilder turns, to become its own distinct creature.

While Genisys doesn't have the iconic heft of James Cameron's films, it's not surprising, to me anyway, that the film has earned the maestro's mild praise. Genisys isn't a future classic, but it'll do for now.

With its quite literally cerebral bent, I think Inside Out might have some trouble fully connecting with younger kids, but grown-ups are likely to shed more than a few tears and give some knowing nods as this wistful little film plays out.
Suffragette trundles along well enough, all noble and serious, but it doesn't get the blood up the way a protest movie probably should.
Bay chooses instead to just barrel heedlessly through the rubble, shooting off as many red, white, and blue fireworks as he can. Any illumination they provide is purely accidental.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's a rare film adaptation that improves upon the original text, highlighting its crucial themes while streamlining and shaping the action into something legible and gripping.
Personal Shopper is as cathartic as it is terrifying, as knowing and wise about the weirder mechanics of the grieving process as it is utterly confusing.
I left feeling ambivalent. There's much to admire in Nichols's film, but there's not enough to embrace. It's respectable, but it could have been ravishing.
It's not entirely without resonance. I just wish the film wasn't so fascinated by the least interesting character wandering around this whole crazy scene called life.
It's the most lively, engaging Marvel movie since Guardians of the Galaxy, and among the very best of the whole Avengers series.
It's a bright snapshot, a toothless but amiable comedy anchored by two chunky bits of acting.

In the hands of first-time feature director Cedric Nicolas-Troyan, who works with a slapped-together but serviceable screenplay by Evan Spiliotopoulos and Craig Mazin, all that silly stuff is plenty entertaining and, in fits and starts, even charming.

There's an air of performance here that wouldn't be a problem if this were an elaborately made home movie, but as a film meant for the public, airing on our most prestigious cable network no less, it comes across a bit indulgent.
movie_title: Nothing Left Unsaid: Gloria Vanderbilt & Anderson Cooper (2016)

movie_review_blurb: [B]efore too long, Snyder has shaken off the self-reflection and returned to ... an empty seriousness where, for a few inspired scenes, some actual thought has flickered tantalizingly.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Nichols achieves a lot by working around, and with, a relatively limited budget, the film tingling with a sense of realism as the story propels forward into increasingly otherworldly territory.
An overdone finale aside, there's much to enjoy and admire in 10 Cloverfield Lane, from its sharp performances to its economical, acutely realized sense of scale.
A small, syncopated movie that immerses, even if it offers only a glance.

Director Alice Winocour creates several scenes of unnerving suspense, coiling the film's tension stylishly and quietly. Schoenaerts is great at playing tough and haunted, and he cuts mesmerizing, almost menacing figure here.
A deeply depressing mess of a movie whose antic busyness drains at the center, all snap and energy sucked into a howling void where a decent joke used to be.

Mountains May Depart is a state-approved Chinese film that nonetheless seems to speak plainly and honestly about the confusion and alienation experienced by generations of Chinese people caught up in all this hyper-speed change.
movie_title: Mountains May Depart (Shan he gu ren) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Like life, much of what's funny about Hail, Caesar!, the new film from Joel and Ethan Coen, is also what makes it a little sad.

Airy and pleasant, a modest film that gets by on charm and aesthetics. We of course know what mighty things await these two young lovebirds, but for its brief spell, Southside With You's first blushes feel plenty big enough.

Parker generously calls to all with his rallying cry of a film, a weighty invocation of past bravery that charges its audience with the essential, nation-defining mission of fighting for a better and more just future.

Indignation is a dedicated, unadorned drama of ideas, but Schamus has filled the picture with subtle artistry, from his exacting period detail to his judicious placement of Jay Wadley's looping, foreboding score.
It's wonderful to see Lonergan back at work, illuminating small and unremarkable lives with grace, wisdom, and humanity. He's made what might prove to be the most artful tearjerker of the year.
Beautifully acted and sensitively written, Heder's film is a wistful pleasure. And there's a really cute baby, too.
In this fluid, artfully rendered film, we both fear and pity all these animals.

This is the kind of thoughtfully constructed movie that other summertime blockbusters should aspire to be more like, clever and cool and never giving you that ho-hum sense that you've seen it all before.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: These young people are a spirited bunch, led by Daisy Ridley and John Boyega, two bright-faced newcomers who lend the proceedings the appropriate sense of grounding and awe.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's a hairy true story, one ripe for the über-masculine film treatment, which is exactly what director Alejandro González Iñárritu has given us in the grueling The Revenant, as much a survival story for the audience as it is for the hero.

I just wish that everyone's glossy prestige impulses had been reined in some, so that we could leave the film with a true understanding of Lili, not simply a vague pity for her elegant museum exhibit of a plight.
There's been so much turgid, meta-talk in Craig's films about Bond's obsolescence; watching Spectre was the first time I actually started to agree with the idea.
The Tribe grabs you almost immediately.
Insurgent, half-baked as its universe might be, rattles and glimmers with an undeniable allure.
Jurassic World is not some brash upstart, tromping all over its ancestors with a witless, youthful swagger. Instead it's a carefully, amusingly reverent nod to what's come before it.
This is not exactly a profound film, but it addresses its weighty themes with striking clarity and narrative nuance.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: There is an air of fantasy to the film, but there's far less cheap sentimentality than one might expect.
It's hard to bear any ill will toward this peculiar movie. Its stumbling is almost endearing, and more than a few jokes land beautifully.
Something truly special, a unique and bracing science-fiction film that stirs both heart and mind.
In striving for nothing but "more"-more explosions, more robot slo-mo scenes, more up-shorts shots of 19-year-old girls-the movie becomes devoid of anything.
The sense that the director has written himself into all this moodiness only adds to the silliness.
It's an oddly factless piece of historical reenactment, and feels a bit mushy and insubstantial because of it.
The movie features a good, though eventually tiring and self-defeating, gag about the inherent lameness of sequels.
Look out for a mighty deluge of teen tears flooding multiplexes this weekend, which will be well-earned by this clever, attractive, sad little movie.
Whatever the cause, within the context of Neighbors, a raucous comedy with a sharp edge, Efron's newfound darkness works pretty well.
A warm and witty little comedy about appreciating the simple things in life, Favreau's new film is also the rare one to get the zeitgeist just right.
Aside from the sparkling Garfield and Stone, Webb's movies benefit from a fine eye for casting. Here, Foxx does a good stammering, thwarted nerd before transforming into the raging villain.
Melissa Stack's script is loose and improvisatory, and genuinely clever in a few places, allowing Diaz and Mann ample room to bumble around amusingly.
Transcendence is an engaging enough "What if?" that happily reminded me of days spent curled up with a good Michael Crichton book.
This is a movie that at its most sensitive is about loneliness, and at its bleakest and most searching is a look at the mechanics of sexual predation.
Isn't it wonderful that a director who was handed a $160 million studio budget had the temerity to aim for something this big, this sweeping?
The Winter Soldier isn't overly existential, but the way it teases at those deeper questions allows Evans to give his performance a welcome bit of shading.
With action scenes that can't raise a pulse, an expectedly chaste romance, and plodding, formulaic expansion of its mythology, Divergent has the drab sogginess of something reheated.
It's rare that a movie like this should be longer, but a little elongating might help this clipped, B-grade thriller resonate a little deeper.
All the cutesiness in the world can't really make what was beginning to happen in 1930s Europe remotely charming, as Anderson seems to want to do.
Frankly, I'm not really sure we need to see another straight cis man dissect female sexuality for us, at least not in these terms.
It's enjoyable enough at first, being back in Ron's wild world, but Anchorman 2 quickly begins to feel like too much of yesterday's news.

It's a well pedigreed and quirkily tailored film that will likely find its fair share of devoted fans. That said, a slight warning for those eager to run out to their local indie haus after work tonight: The movie's a total downer.
Though a heavily beefed-up version of what happens in the book, the scene still manages to conjure up some of the primal thrills that Tolkien's novel has provided for generations of young readers.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: I left Pain & Gain wondering how it managed to be both Bay's most off-putting movie and his most artistically successful.
Mommy is a heart-swelling, heartbreaking, breathtaking piece of cinema.
Even if you aren't an E.D.M. fan, there is much bliss to be found in Eden.
How I wish the film spent more time unfolding its particular mythology, building its conflict to an organic breaking point, rather than rashly pushing everything over the edge.
Smartly shot, detailed, and performed, it's a designer-made studio film that dares to be about big, difficult stuff.
Fury Road is the rare mega-budget movie that has both heft and playfulness; it's dark but fun, a churning orgy of sand and fire that pirouettes with balletic grace.
The movie is so free of irony, so quaint and earnest in its philosophy and metaphysics, that it's a refreshing alternative to this season's loud, marketing-approved, studio-built tentpoles.
Giddy good fun as the Marvel movies consistently are-Age of Ultron's many battles swoop and clang nicely-they're no longer novel.
The movie lumbers along a bit plotlessly, struggling to capture any real emotional resonance beyond a general feeling of niceness.
Those without a sweet tooth might be turned off by this saccharine-ish movie, but I was won over, seduced by its warmth and easy good looks, its quaint, modest proportions.
By the end of this weird and whizzing picture, the only resonant thing is the echo of a film that could have been.

Sure, the closer you get the more it has a cubic-zirconia feel, costume jewelry instead of the real thing, but, hey, it's a plenty breezy diversion here in the latter days of this seemingly unending winter.
Kingsman has a spastic verve that turns what could otherwise be gratuitous and rude into an act of spunky bravado, like it's making good on a dare. I'm surprised they got away with some of it.

Fifty Shades of Grey is not the lame, hot-and-bothered fantasy romance many, including myself, thought it would be. It's got wit and humor and a modest intelligence about human behavior that, say, the Twilight movies never had.
There is enough to like in Blackhat, if you don't mind sifting through a lot of bad code.

Without too much knowledge or preconceived ideas, it would make me an easy mark for a polemic about modern privacy -- but Poitras's bracing, galvanizing new documentary about the Snowden affair isn't that at all.
Given its pedigree, its roster of talent, Beyond the Lights is disappointing.
This isn't a thinking man's Godzilla, exactly, but it's certainly clever where it counts.
Witherspoon finds both a mature centeredness and a zen-like openness -- it's been a long time since we've seen her this fluidly expressive, this connected to good material.
I left the theater on Thursday morning feeling sad and happy and, maybe, a little wiser. That's about all we can ask of a movie, I think.

Watching the film, I wasn't exactly as moved as I'd hoped I would be, and that was at first disappointing. But then I remembered that Richard Linklater doesn't really do big emotional indicating, that you have to listen a little closer.
It's an obvious movie, but it's streamlined and clean, the movie ticks and whirs with precision.
There's no genuine heart beating at the center of the film. It's a dutiful but perfunctory adaptation, sapped of vim and spirit.
Exodus is, if still not necessary filmmaking, a plenty enveloping, even stirring, film, as Scott and his cast find interesting variation to play in small details and modest embellishments.
As transitional, franchise placeholder movies go, Mockingjay - Part 1 could be a lot worse. But it's still just a preamble to the big show. So let's get on with it.
I can imagine, in some other galaxy or dimension, a more exciting Interstellar, one that is more coldly curious about all that lies beyond human perception.
This is mostly a story of a relationship, and in that regard The Theory of Everything succeeds admirably.
If this movie was about the Iraq and Afghanistan wars it would be irresponsible. But because it has the buffer of a 70-year remove, it's just dumb.
It's a dizzying film, a swirl of sadness and humor and frantic thought. It's also deceptively simple.
Inherent Vice is a little too zonked, meandering and overly long, an ultimately pointless story told by a stoned person.
Guardians bounces with the energy of pure invention.
A few sequences in It's Only the End of the World-most of them dreamy, music-video flashbacks-are stunning... But they arrive amidst a hideous clamor of pointless yelling and shoddy character work.
movie_title: It's Only the End of the World (Juste la fin du monde) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Aside from its offensiveness, Stonewall is, plain and simple, a terribly made movie.
An engrossing, intimate character study that manages to encompass plenty of universal truths, Aquarius is a look at the end of things that is vibrant and bursting with life.
Worth a ponder. It's not earth-shaking cinema, but it does move the bed a few inches.
Its depiction of weary activism, both lost and renewed, is well-suited to our dark times.

But there's very little that belongs to the young in Home Again. The film instead seems like a sacrificial offering, dressed up in the old ways and carefully placed at the feet of an elder, in the hopes that it will please them. I sure hope it does.
The Glass Castle is a slapdash construction, all shards crudely fused together.

It's all too easy to spot where the edges have been sanded, you can trace the scars where things have been rashly excised. If you close your eyes, you can almost see that more ideal movie, its fuller form, robust, gripping, and, yes, shining.

Logan Lucky is easygoing entertainment that, on occasion, gently brushes up against its stiffer real-world framing. I'm not sure the film is as successful in doing that as Magic Mike is, but it still makes for an intriguingly toned film.
Detroit is such a gripping and ultimately shattering piece of cinema that it merits seeing-albeit with a skeptical eye.
There's an increasingly perfunctory quality to the film as it goes on. Besson exhausts his neato pictures and is left to limply entertain us with the noodliest of plots.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: In a summer starved for quality comedy, Girls Trip is a welcome blast.
A lyrical and bitterly sad drama about boys ruined by war, Alexandre Moors's film succeeds on style while falling short on plot.
Despite some clumsy flaws, Sheridan's stories have a somber gravitational pull. And with Wind River, he shows that he can probably handle them himself from now on.
Thoroughbred is light on story, and could probably use a little padding out... but it nonetheless impresses with its mordant humor and grim, gliding style.
It's the kind of big, meaty storytelling that can feel awfully invigorating amidst a sea of wispier indie fare.
[A] personal, finely realized comedy-drama.
We should praise Caesar, and all the other apes, as often as we can. Theirs is a moving story told with skill and sincerity, rarer commodities than we humans would like to admit.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Homecoming's sweet-natured hero and its ragtag group of cheery kids project a radiant optimism.
To my mind, It Comes at Night traffics in a fatally depthless cruelty.
Jenkins has succeeded where DC had thus far failed, and in that sense, Wonder Woman should be (and is being) hailed as a triumph.
Coppola has made a swift, gorgeous chamber thriller, an efficient and refreshingly straightforward film that crackles with wicked humor.
It's a vital contribution to queer and political cinema, a testament to crusaders of recent history whose nobility does not preclude their complicated and individual humanity.
movie_title: BPM (Beats Per Minute) (120 battements par minute) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The film is a nice resume line for all involved, a technical feat that announces the arrival of talents both new and newly recontextualized. If only all that solid stuff had a stronger gravity to it.
It's fascinating to grapple with Happy End, a sly and elusive film that features some of the most innovative, and unsettling, depictions of social media I've yet seen on screen.
The film's desolate and mannered tone proves more frustrating than it does provocative.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Okja is a buoyant, messy delight of a film, clever and rousing and full-hearted. I laughed; I cried; I chose to forego meat at lunch.

Carter Burwell's utterly captivating, wholly necessary score. It's the true star of Wonderstruck, a strange and varied piece of work, swells of orchestral strings giving way to electric guitar, alternately soaring and lilting.
Sorkin has made a canny, disjointed thriller of process and exposition, a sort of Goodfellas riff with a nerdy twist.
... a squicky melange of sloppy plot mechanics and potentially problematic stuff...
What's getting in the way is Allen's stilted, hoary script...
... the movie is fun enough, and Waititi shows enough moxie and goofy wit throughout...
Maybe A Wrinkle in Time will sufficiently captivate kids, in which case it's mostly done its job. My old eyes were mostly tired.

Both cloying and clever, gassy and game-faced, these Academy Awards did the best they could to address difficult things, short of canceling the whole thing and airing some kind of P.S.A...it was good to at least see the Academy thinking things through.

My point is, Red Sparrow is perfectly O.K., a handsomely mounted espionage drama that never really gets the blood up but proves to be passable, if graphic, entertainment here in the doldrums of late winter.

Without a baseline assumption of canned male toughness and bravado, the characters in Annihilation are freer to have more a more interesting dynamic-their steeliness and sorrow, their fear and flintiness, intriguingly commingle and inform one another.
It's a good time, but it maybe could have been a great one.

Despite familiar action-scene wobbliness, it's easily the most engaging Marvel film in a long while. Because-finally!-it has something new to say. More like this please, Marvel. Oh, and, of course: Wakanda forever.
... a simultaneously harrowing and sweet look at early adolescence.
... cool, fun tribute to a group of real-life skater teens.
Hereditary is a terrifically unsettling look at the howling despair of grief, combined with that good, old-fashioned fear of what demons we may have inherited from our parents.
[Director Debra Granik] made a film of grace and power, a story of people lost and found in America that often shows us at our noble and humble best. How rare and refreshing that is these days.
Still, Blindspotting, which was the heralded opening-night film at the festival, has an undeniable presence.
... Monsters and Men gestures to the vast scope of what's really being spoken about here, and yet still maintains its arresting immediacy, its particular beauty.

While it is a bit of deus ex(calibur) machina, it's still satisfying, like finally figuring out that intricate combo move in Street Fighter or whatever. At its best, King Arthur conjures up those base and visceral pleasures.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Lizzie isn't a bad film, but it doesn't accomplish all that it wants to-and all I wanted it to.

[Jennifer] Fox has done something courageous and generous, offering up the complexities of her story, all her pain and growth, to, yes, say "me too." But also, maybe, to show others how they may assess and tend to the wounds of their own pasts.
All my general affection for a musical trying to make it in the world can't quite cover up the stink of what I think is lying at the heart of this film.

What a pleasure... that Driver not only delivers-giving a quiet, soulful, kindhearted performance that's my favorite thing he's done thus far-but that Jarmusch's film is as wise, winning, and surprisingly moving as it is
... Phantom Thread is something else, quite welcomely.
The Force is, to me, still silly Star Wars mumbo jumbo, but Johnson finds a way to underscore it with humanity, with a classical Greek rumble of true pathos.
Spielberg's film is rousing and cannily made.
The film has a crisp British comportment-a dutiful, cheerio resolve-that serves it quite well.
Del Toro has said that this film is a long-gestating labor of love, a devotion that shows in every frame. It's so carefully done, but still thumps with a genuine, visceral heartbeat.
The film is, plainly stated, terrible, and I'm sorry that everyone wasted their time and money making it-and that people are being asked to waste their time and money seeing it.
... Christie's characters deserve a Poirot who knows when to step back and just quietly watch.
Lady Bird is, instead, episodic and rambling, a ruminative look back at a crucial, defining period in its creator's life.
... an eerie and effective portrait of serial killer and cannibal Jeffrey Dahmer in his beyond-troubled teen years, a quick hop into the mind of a loner kid who was about to become a monster.
Colette isn't intense on process, but it does illustrate well what might motivate a writer, how her unique spirit is stoked and developed.

Snatched begins as an amiable, amusing story about rekindling a familial bond. Then, alas, the movie decides it needs to get to its plot, which is a dull kidnapping farce that comes laden with some cultural ugliness.

Scott has made simply a competent thriller that dazzles only in the ingeniousness of its lightning-quick and proficient re-staging.... The annihilating indifference of the 1 percent will just have to wait until next year.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's still a whirling good time. But maybe the next film should pare things back, return to those simpler pleasures: cars and Coronas, the baking California heat, a simple backyard cookout.
What a vibrant, lively, yet understated joy Queen of Katwe is.

I'd still urge those curious about Snowden and what he did to watch Citizenfour and read The Guardian's striking reporting on his massive disclosure. But as a straightforward, accessible overview, Snowden sturdily does its part for the cause.
It's a character study that projects its subject's inner turmoil onto the whole map of the movie. A final cliché: it's as if we're inside Jackie's head. It's a thrill to have Portman give us a tour.
It's introspective and deliberate, a movie that gets to its point slowly, all its meandering and scene-setting doing the good work of priming us for a grim little payoff.
Throughout all this, Hathaway is outstanding. She's funny and poignant, the perfect kind of underdog champion. It's my favorite performance of hers since, gosh, I don't know when.
A triptych illustrating the tidal ebb and flow of identity, Jenkins's film is awash in dreaminess, while still examining the life of one young man with piercing clarity.
Arrival has the heft of a literary airport novel, with enough poetry and pathos to elevate it above Michael Crichton.
La La Land begins with such an ecstatic rush of joy -- and ends with such a gloriously bittersweet flourish -- that you kinda can't blame the film for sagging a bit in the middle.
The Light Between Oceans seemingly yearns to be a lush, ravishing prestige drama. But it also doesn't seem to know what to do with the, y'know, drama.
Ben-Hur is made with enough conviction and thoughtfulness that its messiness, its grandstanding, its occasional bouts of clumsiness can't crack its admirably sturdy foundation.
A film of uncommon warmth, decency, and humanity.
David Ayer's super-villain team-up is dull, uninspired, and perhaps worst of all, forgettable.

Beyond, which sees the previous two Trek films' director, J.J. Abrams, handing the reins to Fast and Furious franchise favorite Justin Lin (don't worry, there are still lens flares), has a plucky, engaging panache.
It spends so much time doing battle with its legacy that it forgets to be its own movie, putting a talented cast to waste and marking another disappointment in this dreadful summer movie season.
Roland Emmerich's new movie relentlessly coasts on its legacy, not realizing it's in a stall.

I don't feel qualified, as a non-historian, to weigh Free State of Jones's merits in terms of accuracy or fairness. But as a moviegoer, the film teases a rich and varied meal -- only to ultimately give us the same old meat and potatoes.
Think of the film instead as the jellyfish that Nancy encounters in one fraught scene: lightweight, translucent, by turns graceful and awkward. And occasionally capable of a surprisingly potent jolt.
Having sat through this baffling movie's grueling two hours, I can't in good conscience even recommend it to Warcraft devotees. There's nothing here for anyone --neither man nor orc.
Sharrack picks the perfect wistful final shot, Craig Armstrong's score swells with ache and possibility, and everything is bathed in the golden light of bittersweet resolve. It's potent stuff.
I love these conflicted misfits, even when they're fighting a supreme being who seems imported from a far inferior, less interesting world.

I don't necessarily trust The Neon Demon, and am uncertain it's a force for good in the world. But its slow-burn, glam sleaze builds gradually to a payoff that's as memorable as anything I've seen at Cannes. Which has to count for something.
Ade's film is odd and captivating and speaks many truths and boasts probably the best final shot of the festival.
Starred Up director David Mackenzie helms with muscle and panache, in both bracing action scenes and quieter moments of introspection, all framed gorgeously by cinematographer Giles Nuttgens.

An intelligent, funny erotic thriller, The Handmaiden seems destined for some kind of American remake... that isn't likely to live up to Park's invention, wit, and daring. See this one first, if you can.
Gunn has made an invigorating, overstuffed light show that hones itself into something rather striking by the end. And, yes, Baby Groot is pretty cute.
It's an earnest but not cloying film, one that seems wise about the world and its alternately grim and encouraging complexity.
Even when the film is horrible to look at, it's beautiful, a strange and grim portrait of an annihilating American frontier.
The worst thing about Now You See Me 2 may be its name: the film itself is a game, goofy improvement on the original.
Butler tells a perky and entertaining little story, albeit one we've seen some version of many times before.
Gray's film is breathtaking in its scope, but all the more remarkable for how intimate it feels, how oddly relatable.
By the end, A Monster Calls certainly provokes some tears, but they're coaxed out by a manipulative hand.

I think there is something genuine and thoughtful and non-aggrandizing about Their Finest, a humble movie that nonetheless hits some big chords-ones we've heard many times before, sure, but only rarely played so deftly, so gently.
Life is tense and unnerving and a total bummer. But it's still worth it.
Peele has made a movie about the black experience in white America that does not appease or accommodate, that enjoys itself while still speaking to a troubling and pervasive truth.
Mangold gives our grumpy old friend quite a send-off, a blood-drenched stab-a-thon that frequently hits bone.
It's quite something to watch, and watch it you should. Be warned, though, that Beatriz at Dinner is a bit of a bummer. But there's still something cathartic about it.
The film does, with great artistry and sincerity, the kind work of saying what so many of us have been thinking. It's our common late-night worries made manifest, then carried beyond our imagination.
A swirling wonder, a film about coming of age, about the secrets of youth, the magic of summer, the beauty of Italy.
Those final 30 or so seconds do a lot of work to cover up what is otherwise a mostly engaging piece of hokum, a grim kidnapping tale that makes a silly hash of psychology.
Live by Night is by no means a wash of a film. But there's a clunking in the machinery.
[Washington] tells a big story that is comfortably, convincingly set in a humble backyard -- albeit a backyard cluttered with the heavy stone of human drama.

I still kinda dig this weird, embarrassing movie. It's got good actors in it -- everyone is great, really -- it looks real nice, and I'm brave enough to admit that, yes, reader, I got a little teary in parts.

Director Ritesh Batra (best known for The Lunchbox) does a remarkable job of making the movie's mystery seem much more transgressive than it is, and he is aided by an outstanding performance from Jim Broadbent.

Moana will be a big, happy hit, and I'll forever want to live in its glorious and vibrant environs. But hard as she may paddle, Moana can't quite get past the cluttered reef of merch and other branded interests that keeps her film penned in.

A clever and poignant character study whose navel-gazing scope belies some big truths, The Edge of Seventeen is one of my favorite films of 2016. And it's exactly the kind of movie I wish I'd had in my own Nadine years.
Fantastic Beasts is forlorn and captivating, a rare blending of cheery, witty entertainment with a troubled worldview.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: By the time Hacksaw Ridge reaches its necessary messianic finish, it's hard to not be moved by the boggling heroism of this dutiful man.

[Moore is] an excellent weaver of outrages and injustices, cruel ironies and boggling oversights, when given the space to build a tapestry. That sprawl and style is missed in TrumpLand, which has a hasty, scattered feel to it.
Leveaux's film occasionally risks stuffiness, but he cuts that with a few truly sexy sex scenes, and enough tension and intrigue to deliver a satisfying, cathartic payoff.
The Accountant mulls autism and a little art, and there's a sentimental pull that, I will admit, got me, just a bit, right at the very end.
The writing is weird, and never all that natural, but Hunter and Coon still glow, and in that glowing, they sell it.
In the end, the film uncomplicates its once-interesting characters, either exonerating them or distilling their villainy into something rather banal.
Rogue One, directed by Gareth Edwards with a sharp script by Tony Gilroy and Chris Weitz, is a bracing and dizzying marvel, propulsively pitched and even, I dare say, moving.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Berg's cornier tendencies win out at the very end of the film, slightly marring what is otherwise a crisp, admirably unadorned movie. Despite those bobbles, though, Deepwater Horizon immediately enters the canon of great disaster films.
Burton's artistry has been so misplaced for so long that it's just really nice to thoroughly enjoy a movie of his again.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The story may be predictable, ham-fisted and saccharine, but that's why kids (and softhearted parents) will like it.
They're certainly no Aykroyd and Belushi, or even Myers and Carvey, but Farley and Spade manage to wring humor from a series of juvenile setups and predictable pratfalls.
The movie's a shipload of coming-of-age blather, supplemented with enough rolling-sea footage to make the audience yearn for both Dramamine and a decent drowning scene.
Rife with rotting corpses, severed heads and massacred children, Screamers is one of the most horrifying movies I've ever seen.
Although at times tedious and repetitive, Meeting Resistance is nonetheless an important journalistic document about the Iraqi insurgency.
A picture with heart. You shouldn't leave feeling soiled or bruised. Just touched.

It's uneven and the relationship between your sense of taste and your sense of humour will determine whether you enjoy it, but at its best, Jesus Is Magic doesn't look out of place alongside the best stand-up concert movies.
Blaustein, Foley and Funk layeth the smack well and truly down.
Had Billy Bob Thornton not been so good in so many films, people would be talking about this as his greatest role.
The presence of old lags Martin Sheen and John Heard just beggars belief. What were they thinking?
A film we could live without, inspired by an original that was anything but essential.
Hysterically funny, genuinely cinematic -- and you get to see Bart's doodle, too.
It'll be an odd viewer who doesn't come to the end of the film wanting to know more about Kennedy or his untimely passing.
movie_title: RFK Must Die: The Assassination of Bobby Kennedy (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Far from a cheap spin-off, The Transformers: The Movie is an entertaining feature-length animation that's both handsome and well realised.
A convincing case can be made for this being Lynch's finest film to date.
movie_title: Twin Peaks - Fire Walk with Me (1992)

movie_review_blurb: A likeable, highly entertaining film that endears in spite of the odd spot of Disney-esque schmaltz.
The greatest children's movie of all time. Probably.
Doctor Dolittle might be a little woolly at times but it's impossible not to be impressed by Rex Harrison and his marvellous menagerie.
A sharp, smart movie peppered with A-grade performances from its B-list cast.
Frankly, Murray, Sigourney Weaver and even Aykroyd deserve much better.
If all kids' movies were like this, you wouldn't need to drag parents to the multiplexes.
One of the funniest family films of the 1970s.
A film as deserving of respect as its subjects.
At the heart of everything there's Yauch, directing with remarkable authority for someone who's pretty new to the director's chair.
A decent enough documentary albeit one about an appalling person.
movie_title: Stoked: The Rise and Fall of Gator (2003)

movie_review_blurb: It does, however, have some decent scares, a lot of good lines and a memorable villain.
A damn fine mess of a movie.
Norway may be wonderful for many things but feature-length animation currently isn't one of them.
It's not a very faithful adaptation, it doesn't make great use of Simon Pegg and Kirsten Dunst has still got those teeth, but there's little here that's offensive and more than enough that's amiable.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Sums up all that's wrong with contemporary cinema: unsubtle to the point of obviousness, it reeks of MTV and relies on volume to get its point across.
Total Recall is fine entertainment, complete with breathtaking action sequences and special effects that impress even in these computer-generated times.
There's nothing particularly special about An American Tail, save for Bluth's slick animation.
Arguably the greatest sports movie since Hoop Dreams and When We Were Kings.
A beautifully realised animation, Watership Down ultimately works because it doesn't dilute the violence and drama of Adams' book with a rose-tinted lens.
A great, misunderstood man forms the basis of a fine, easily misinterpreted documentary.
Swan songs are seldom as sweet or melodic as A Prairie Home Companion.
A fine movie musical and a nice reminder of the time when Streisand was a talent rather than a 'phenomenon'.
Long may they continue to walk in Ronnie James Dio's short but comforting shadow.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A consistently entertaining, sometimes uproariously funny film.
It's far from remarkable but there's enough about Strays to convince you Vin Diesel's more than a bald guy with a funny voice and big ol' biceps.
Perhaps the studio hoped they could cash in on the return in 2008 of Indy. Whatever the thinking, a third Mummy film is here - and right damn average it is too.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: You'll have seen a lot of this before but that won't be a problem for lovers of 'big' comedy and die-hard Ferrell fans.
Go on, give in to temptation.
The least satisfying of Steve Martin's early movies.
The horror of Jar Jar Binks aside, there's plenty in Episode I to keep us entertained.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace (1999)

movie_review_blurb: In Which We Serve is not only one of the greatest of all British war movies but also marks the mighty David Lean's first major contribution to cinema.
The Karate Kid belongs so irredemiably to its time that you can't feel anything other than affection toward it.
A fine thriller, Looking For Mr Goodbar is a reminder that Richard Brooks was a writer-director of rare talent and Diane Keaton is capable of a lot more than being ditsy.
A dark, bleary but often quite touching story.
A fascinating study of an era that now feels so remote, it might as well have occurred on another planet.
Rush's movie can be enjoyed as kitsch, but it plays better as an early stab at a Lethal Weapon-style movie, effortlessly combining violence and humour.
It's amongst British cinema's finest crime dramas.
One can only hope this re-release awakens people to the true power of Basil Dearden's film and the extraordinary bravery of Dirk Bogarde's performance.
Cutter's Way feels like a B-movie, but while its problems are readily apparent, a career-best turn from Heard and a typically charismatic performance from Bridges raise it above the crowd.
Shakespeare's finest hour on the big screen to date.
movie_title: Henry V (The Chronicle History of King Henry the Fift with His Battell Fought at Agincourt in France) (1946)

movie_review_blurb: Although it's well-handled by Attenborough and features decent supporting turns from Ann-Margret and Ed Lauter, the key source of Magic's terror is the fact that ventriloquists' dummies are and always will be disturbing.
An unnecessary addition to the cannon of cinematic Shakespeare.
Wells' movie is more content to rip off Tomb Raider than remain faithful to his great-grandfather's book.
Just when you think films have got as bad as they're ever going to be, along comes a picture that takes cinema to a whole new level of shoddiness.
You'll find more self-involvement and cod philosophising here than in all the world's coffee houses.
An unlikely choice as director and producer, it's thanks to Eastwood's relatively thin sentimental streak that the film doesn't fall headlong into a lagoon of schmaltz.
It's still entertaining, but New Jack City now feels about as edgy as an old razor. And it's just as disposable.
An exciting second-tier action flick.
A minor masterpiece from a major artist.
Raimi has once again crafted a blockbuster that thinks as hard as it thwacks -- in a word, amazing.
The Conformist isn't just a triumph, it's one of the greatest movies ever made.
A funny, sharply-written film more pertinent in the Noughties than it was upon its first release.
Weird Science is an odd mix of risqué shenanigans, puerile pranks and dubious gender politics. It also happens to be very funny.
If you haven't seen Taxi Driver, your education in film hasn't even begun.
For many, this remains the definitive big-screen Romeo And Juliet.
Shane isn't just one of the best movies of its genre or decade -- it's one of the finest films ever made.
Kitsch, stylish and a little on the empty side, Shampoo is mirror image of the decade that spawned it.
A true classic of Italian cinema, Rossellini's confrontational film breaks new ground with the same ease that it shatters hearts.
Cronenberg's most conventional film prior to A History Of Violence, The Fly is also among the finest of his American movies.
"Ogre and out" say the critics, but the Shrek series still has laughs and legs.

Succeeds as a summation of America's shaky grasp of freedom. And while the footage of the girls at work and play sometimes seems inconsequential, there are moments that are as unexpectedly pleasing as the band's soft country sounds.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Crass, obvious and largely unfunny - in fact just about everything the original film isn't.
Who'd have thought PC comedy could be so much fun?
It's uneven but when Bobby's at its best it's unbelievably good.
A strange one this - Capote is a superior picture but Toby Jones is the superior Capote.
Even 30-odd years on, the picture still has more than a whiff of rebellion about it.
Among the greatest films of the 1980s, but not Scorsese's best.
Stone's best film in years and one of the decade's great political pictures.
One of cinema's greatest ever advertisements for pure entertainment...
movie_title: Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid (1969)

movie_review_blurb: A fine example of the form. Cliched and sentimental it might be, but in the case of The Express, these criticisms almost count as plus points.
A comedy classic that only misses out on the Python canon's top spot because the talented swines also made Life Of Brian.
movie_title: Monty Python and the Holy Grail (1975)

movie_review_blurb: While many biographical documentaries reduce their subjects to museum pieces, American presents the erstwhile Goat Boy as a force of nature, as vital and essential as he ever was.
Ultimately as welcome as a letter bearing that introduction
For with time running out on 2009, it's wonderful that one of the old year's last gifts should be a reminder of the superb possibilities of blockbuster cinema.
It's slight but it more than satisfies whenever Christian McKay's Welles is to the fore.
Put simply, this writer would take any number of bad movies over one nasty film. And make no mistake about it, Law Abiding Citizen is a very nasty movie indeed.
Possibly the brothers' most consistently amusing film since The Big Lebowski.
Kids' entertainment with absolutely nothing to offer those with ages in double digits, the only shocks are that some of those involved have gone on to enjoy decent careers.
movie_title: Mighty Morphin Power Rangers: The Movie (1995)

movie_review_blurb: Harry Brown's no Get Carter, but thanks to Caine, this not-so-big movie's still in reasonably good shape.
It'll be a strange person who doesn't find An Education entertaining, and a stranger man still who denies it the success it's sure to enjoy.
The Cove stands out from the crowd due to the readily apparent awfulness of the event it depicts.
Jack Said is another okay film enlivened by a typically spirited Dyer performance.
The Crimson Wing is a Disney nature film. Be aware of this and all that goes with it and you might yet discover the ennobling documentary hidden beneath the wretched excess.
Flawed as it might be, Creation is still Amiel's best movie to date. Wonderfully mounted, the picture successfully dramatises key moments in Darwin's life.
Its gentle charm and effortless eloquence personified by its winning lead, Adventureland is only marred by a rote final reel.
A pretty successful European co-production strengthened by a charismatic title performance from Matthias Schweighöfer.
It's a little uneven but at its best Bedknobs And Broomsticks rivals the joy and wonder of Mary Poppins.
If it can't compete with the best surf documentaries, Bustin' Down The Door is never less than diverting - the thrill of conquered waves eclipsed only by the picture's educational value.
Not a career high for anyone involved, rarely has 90-odd minutes felt more like 48 hours.
The ultimate road movie and one of the great American movies of the 1970s.
Like Syriana without either the balls or the brains, Body Of Lies is perfectly presentable. You just expect better from the likes of Leo, Russ and Ridley.
Featuring a great turn from Kurt Russell, Used Cars is both a brilliantly funny comedy and a good reminder of just how interesting a writer-director Robert Zemeckis used to be.
Hugely entertaining in all the ways it isn't meant to be.
A hugely underrated crime drama, Fresh is worth discovering both for its air of authenticity and Sean Nelson's remarkable performance.
One of the finest family films ever made.
[Tierney is] exceptional in the part, and far better than the legions of actresses who've subsequently set down the rolling pin and bouquet in favour of the ice pick.
Light Sleeper remains a superior picture from one of America's more stimulating filmmakers.
The book's so good it deserves a better movie, but Rourke's performance is such that Angel Heart stands out from the necromancy movie crowd.
A pleasant comedy with a good heart and amiable characters.
For a picture big on in-camera special effects, few of the explosions and set pieces can eclipse the parade of cracking performances.
With such incredible subject matter, March Of The Penguins cannot help but hold the attention. It's impossible not to warm to the penguins.
It might hold some appeal if you're as teenager with a thing for dirt bikes.
John Ford's last great film, The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance is also one of the last classic Westerns to come out of Hollywood.
movie_title: The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance (1962)

movie_review_blurb: A controversial satire and a contemporary classic.
There is so much of modern movie life here that the picture, like Brooks' beauty, defies the ravages of time.
A fine film that almost lives up to its mouthwatering title.
Entertaining less as a Bibilical epic than as an epic exercise in extreme camp.
Big River Man is up there with the very best modern documentaries.
A good film and a fine introduction to Cagney's otherwise explosive oeuvre.
Occasionally funny and often audacious, but this is too smug to satisfy and too much like Ashton Kutcher's 'Punk'd' to be considered cutting edge.
movie_title: The Yes Men Fix the World (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Spree killer thrillers, experimental rockumentaries, adaptations of unadaptable books and now supernatural dramas - is there anything Michael Winterbottom cannot do?
Another man-of-the-match performance from Sheen saves this from mid-table mediocrity.
Strewth, it's a bloody ripper!
movie_title: Not Quite Hollywood: The Wild, Untold Story of Ozploitation! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A breathtaking piece of entertainment, 20,000 Leagues Under the Sea is amongst the finest live-action films to come out of Disney Studios.
Gun Crazy is less an exposé than a hugely exciting crime thriller. And since he's as polite as he is intelligent, Lewis doesn't beat us about the head with his philosophies.
Carrey remains an acquired taste but Under The Sea is a fine example of the 3D form and Hall's mastery of it.
More of a TV documentary than a movie, but there's enough good stuff here to keep you from cussing.
If only he could have satisfied himself with this area of expertise, people would still talk of Steve Martin as one of the kings of comic cinema.
One of the very best teen movies.
A captivating film with a superb understated, genuinely affecting performance from Jean-Claude Van Damme.

Thought Ron Howard was going to stuff it up? Think again - Frost/Nixon's a great advert for stage-to-screen adaptations. And if you'd forgotten the power of the close-up, prepare to be dazzled by dapper Dave and Tricky Dick.
Aronofsky has pulled off that rare feat - he's made a great film about a niche subject that will delight wrestling fans and cineastes alike. And Rourke's performance is a knockout.
Put bluntly, don't be afraid to say 'no' to Yes Man.
Much like the man himself, it's quite a piece of work.
movie_title: Gonzo: The Life and Work of Hunter S. Thompson (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The sentiment gets a little sticky towards the end, but many will consider this the perfect antidote to traditional Christmas fare -- especially those with a fondness for Ferrell's comedy.
A highly enjoyable hi-tech thriller.
A great movie? No. Great entertainment? Not arf!
Pleasantly surprising - providing you're not put off by all the gore and dismemberment.
The first essential surf movie since Riding Giants.
Now if only it was even slightly better than those examples of Hollywood at its laziest.
Fortunately for filmgoers, the sight of Bill Maher laying the smacketh down on God is, to quote Homer Simpson, truly "sacrilicious".
Leaves you wondering whether there really is a God.
No, it's not the worst film ever made, but it is a sickening exercise in smugness and self-love.
Christmas With The Kranks is the sort of film that leaves you thinking Ebenezer Scrooge might have had the right idea about the festive season.
From Philip Glass's glorious score to John Bailey's rich cinematography, Schrader's movie is never less than ravishing.
movie_title: Mishima: A Life in Four Chapters (1985)

movie_review_blurb: Fired Up is big on stereotypes (hello, gay Indian guy), overstatement (if you didn't already realise, loud = funny) and borderline homophobia. To paraphrase Repo Man, the longer you watch this, the stupider you might become.
Mann's best film since Heat is arguably the best movie anyone's made since Heat.
Revenge Of The Fallen isn't only louder than Transformers, however. It's longer, it's more explosive, it's more directionless, it's all the proof you'll ever need that more really isn't always more.
Inglourious Basterds is as much fun as you can have in a cinema without embarrassing an usher or making your popcorn too salty.
A film featuring free-running that makes this most bizarre of extreme pursuits appear positively pedestrian.
It's perhaps a little too polite at times, but Rønning and Sandberg's well-crafted picture does a good job of celebrating a man whose endeavours ought to be recognised by all of the Allied powers.

While 12 Rounds is well above average for an action movie, it's important not to get too carried away. This is, after all, a picture in which leading lady Ashley Scott is less appealing than her pet pug.
Fine in the 'rather more than adequate' rather than 'really rather wonderful' sense.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The dialogue deficiencies are less easy to forgive, but neither these nor the sadly missed subplots can detract from the fact that State Of Play in any form is a damn fine yarn.

If writer-director Jody Hill provides Rogen with pretty slim opportunities, the biggish man remains a gloriously robust talent. Heck, he's even able to ring laughs from such fundamentally unfunny topics as bipolar disorder and alcoholism.
Not for the first time, great theatre makes for a merely adequate film.
Perhaps the defining Chaplin film, and certainly his funniest.
The script has the substance and the slacker leads have the chemistry, but the execution fumbles the tourniquet, failing to find any rich vein of wackiness.
Gaudy, goofy and too busy for its own good. For every idea or sight gag that sticks, there's 10 that don't. Best for DVD, when you'll be in control of the pause button.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The fact that [it] isn't very funny and, like its 80-year-old heroic, long outlives its necessary life, is less important than the fact that the characters frequently react gently or like credible human beings to the script's impossible notions.
Not only lacks clarity but also any spark of real verve.
Well-served by a varied cast.
Although the subject matter may not seem obviously appealing, it's amazing what finely attuned directorial talent, script-writing finesse and superlative acting can achieve.
movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Handsomely shot and astutely cast, My Brother Is an Only Child should achieve the same attention and success accorded to The Best of Youth, whose scriptwriters worked with Luchetti on this one.
movie_title: Mio Fratello è Figlio Unico (My Brother Is an Only Child) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The moral dilemmas marshalled by Austrian director Stefan Ruzowitzky prove absolutely gripping, and the whole film is alive with style and intelligence.
By turns lyrical, serious, funny and acerbic, Persepolis raises the bar for animation and illustrates the true power of storytelling in illuminating the world and its conflicts.

With stunning landscapes around the Tex-Mex border shot by Roger Deakins and the elements of pursuit and retribution, the saga draws from the Western tradition in which the characters become dwarfed by nature.
The survival of the human spirit against almost insurmountable odds is nowhere illustrated more clearly than in The Diving Bell and the Butterfly.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A rambling and incoherent vision of the near future, Southland Tales proves a major disappointment from the talented Richard Kelly.

With a madcap script by Dylan Haggerty and a bubbly and inventive performance from Anna Faris, as well as a succinct running time, Smiley Face manages to sustain itself, and only the hard-hearted and humorless would feel that it overstays its welcome.
The pace may be a shade plodding at times, and the dialogue frequently does disservice to the subject matter. Yet the performances lift it out of the rut...
