In a quick 80 minutes, we get the back story, we meet the four core characters (all of the young actors do fine work), get the wits scared out of us about a half-dozen times and wind up with a VERY creepy ending.

Davis (who was an executive producer on the film) gives a strong performance, as if she were acting in one of those many prestige projects lighting up her resume. It's a noble try, but this dreck is beyond saving.
Inside Out [is] a bold, gorgeous, sweet, funny, sometimes heartbreakingly sad, candy-colored adventure that deserves an Academy Award nomination for best picture.
It's one of the best movies I've ever seen about the art and the science of newspaper reporting
Mockingjay - Part 2 is a grim, dark, trippy, violent and sometimes just plain bizarre journey, which makes for a fitting if uneven conclusion to a film series that's always been weird.
What DOESN'T get lost in translation is what made "El Secreto De Sus Ojos" so effective: the visceral, devastating empathy we feel when a horrible injustice is committed and it ruins multiple lives.
Vardalos is wonderful, and 88-year-old Michael Constantine casually pockets every scene he's in.
When it sings, Dawn of Justice is a wonder. When it drags, it still looks good and offers hints of a better scene just around the corner.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Pee-wee is still a startling and original and strangely endearing creation. He just deserved a funnier, more intriguing holiday.

Mr. Rickman was never nominated for an Academy Award and it's probably a long shot for a posthumous supporting actor for this film -- but his work here is a reminder of what a special talent he possessed.
The problem with The Bronze isn't that Melissa Rauch's Hope Ann Gregory is such a nasty, foul-mouthed, terrible little human being. It's that she's not as funny as the film thinks she is.
A ponderous affair, never taking 30 seconds to make a point when four minutes is available.

Like the original, London Has Fallen features a top-notch cast and some crackling good action sequences. And, alas, like the original, this is a cliché-riddled, aggressively violent, laughably plotted exploitation flick.
The imperfect work mired in storage all this time gets a well-deserved spin.
If this role isn't remembered as THE signature moment when we came to think of Tina Fey as an award-level dramatic actor as well as an iconic comic force, it's a substantial step in that direction.
This is a great documentary about a great man.
movie_title: The Last Man On The Moon (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Director Dexter Fletcher paints Eddie's story in broad, bold strokes, never missing an opportunity to milk a suspenseful dramatic turn or go for the relatively easy laugh -- but it's a style well-suited to this wonderfully ridiculous story.
If you're in the right frame of mind for a lurid, blood-soaked B-movie with an A-list cast, Triple 9 is just the ticket.

For longtime fans of Paul Newman, "Winning" provides valuable insight into the sport he loved. For millennials that might be only vaguely familiar with this old-time movie star, it's a lesson in how one should live a life.
movie_title: Winning: The Racing Life Of Paul Newman (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "Race" tells the story of a brave and gifted and determined man who accomplished great feats during a pivotal moment in world history - but it's a by-the-numbers sports biopic with little nuance and a penchant for saccharine-soaked dramatic moments.
Fiennes sticks with the brooding, stoic performance, even when Clavius is undergoing some major changes. It's not his best work.
On balance, "Rolling Papers" is more about marijuana journalism than the big picture, and as such it's a worthwhile endeavor.

Zootopia is one of my favorite animated movies. Not one of my favorite animated movies of the last year or two, or of the last decade, or in recent memory. It's one of my favorite animated movies, period.
Occasionally poignant but ham-handed and only semi-funny.

Even when I Saw the Light is giving us standard-issue concert scenes or simple interior sequences such as young Hank and his band playing live on the radio, the saturated colors and the subtle camera moves make every scene pop.
It's refreshing to find yourself immersed in a film that zigs and zags between genres -- and occasionally zaps your senses with an electric charge of shock and awe.
Even when The Family Fang stretches credulity, we stay with it. Bateman knows how to tell a story.

Kudos to co-directors Anthony and Joe Russo and the team of writers for juggling more than a dozen comic-book characters and nearly that many plot lines, and only occasionally getting us (and by us I mean ME) lost in the Geek Weeds.
Taken as a whole, Sarandon's performance is something to behold.
Like just about everything else in Mother's Day, the nod to the earlier movies are clumsy and pointless and obvious.

Save for a few scenes that feel like overkill just to give us a little bit more intrigue and suspense, Confirmation feels true to the spirit of the events, which were bizarre, unsettling - and undeniably entertaining.
This is one smart chiller.

Elvis & Nixon is one of the most entertaining movies I've seen this year - a whip-smart slice of strange history bolstered by pitch-perfect period-piece references, two excellent, offbeat performances and a brisk sense of pacing.
Richard Linklater's non-sequel of a sequel to Dazed and Confused has pitch-perfect tone.
Writer-director Tykwer skillfully presents a series of fantastical scenes in a way that has us thinking: Sure, that could happen. This is quite simply a beautiful film to behold.
Just about everything else clicks, thanks in no small part to the wonderful performances from the deep cast.

Given the lurid, stupid, loony and unintentionally laughable nature of this espionage thriller, I found some measure of entertainment studying the vastly different approaches taken by Costner, Jones and Oldman.

Thanks to director Jon Favreau's visionary guidance and some of the most impressive blends of live-action and CGI we've yet seen, The Jungle Book is a beautifully rendered, visually arresting take on Rudyard Kipling's oft-filmed tales.
Atom Egoyan's bold but often ludicrous Remember plays a like a mash-up of The Terminator, Marathon Man and Memento, as filtered through the lens of an old Twilight Zone episode.
It's just early April, but I have an early contender for the most loathsome, ill-advised, horrible executed, most spectacularly unfunny movie scene of the year.
This is one of those movies made by smart people about smart people that gives the audience no credit.
In a rousing, beautifully shot closing sequence, Davis shares the stage with modern-day jazz musicians. Like most of the film, it's a bit loopy and a bit trippy, but pretty damn cool as well.
The Adderall Diaries comes across as an incomplete jumble of colliding plot lines.
Although Bad Hurt traffics in tough material, it is filled with little moments of heart.
Some people find Derek Zoolander funny and likable and endearingly dumb. I don't. I find him grating.
Lovely stuff all around.

The Force Awakens pops with memorable battle sequences, gives us chills with encore appearances by stars from the original trilogy and introduces more than a half-dozen terrific Next Generation characters.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Concussion is a sobering, sometimes infuriating look at one doctor's discovery of chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE), and his crusade to tell the country its favored game was causing the deaths of many a former hero.
[Lawrence gives] a wonderfully layered performance that carries the film through its rough spots and sometime dubious detours.
Thanks for nothing, Netflix.
With Mission: Impossible - Rogue Nation, we're getting the best Bond movie since Casino Royale in 2006.
Not that I was expecting much out of a movie based on a line of dolls, but this is an amateur production that should have gone straight to basic cable.
How much better is it to experience a film overflowing with so many elements than one that has to stretch its content just to get to the finish line?

It's with no small reluctance I report Sisters is a depressing, overlong, repetitive slapstick disaster in which two of the most appealing stars around wallow in the muck AND the mire, figuratively and literally.
Some movies contain one or two scenes you always think about when you think about that movie. With The Big Short, there are a dozen such scenes.

I loved Ben Kingsley's over-the-top work as studio head Jack Warner, who in one scene explains the lay of the land to Mr. Dean in a manner that would inspire envy from Don Corleone. This guy isn't messing around.
Tab Hunter Confidential is a well-crafted if not particularly deep bio-documentary of the genial actor, who is now 84 years old and provides a number of on-camera recollections.
There's a lot of raucous humor, some chilling moments and some insightful glimpses into the lives of special people navigating everyday life in neighborhoods where survival is always on one's mind.
Legend is a bad title for a film that doesn't quite succeed in relating how these brothers became legends.
Inconsistent and weird, The Good Dinosaur is second-level Pixar all the way.

It's a shattering, thunderous wake-up alarm, a call to lay down arms, a gutsy social satire and a highly stylized work of fiction that sometimes feels as accurate and sobering as the crime reporting you see on the front page of this newspaper.
Once again, I find myself saying if this is the last time we see Rocky Balboa, it's a worthy encore.

Movement and Location has some clear-cut parallels to the stories of immigrants who are in the States illegally and are trying to live quiet, productive lives... But it also works as a Rod Serling-esque sci-fi adventure of the mind.
This is one of the best movies of the year.

Haynes directs with a subtle precision, the script by Phyllis Nagy is a well-crafted gem, and Cate Blanchett and Rooney Mara make for one of the most intriguing and memorable movie couples of the year.
It is a pinpoint-accurate encapsulation of some of the most banal AND some of the most exhilarating moments virtually all of us have experienced at some point in our lives.
If only Deadpool were as clever, dark and funny as it believes itself to be.
Just when we think we've got it all figured out, Southbound serves up another deliciously bloody twist.
Director Burr Steers... does a nifty job of rocketing from period-piece romance to gory bloodshed, with sprinkles of dark humor here and there.
This is one of my favorite movies ever made about making movies.
A grand gesture going nowhere.
The heroism of that small-boat crew from 1952 deserves a special film. This is not it.
You will never shake this film off, ever, and that is a powerful and enriching thing.
Monahan gives Hedlund and in particular Isaac dozens upon dozens of rich, intricate lines, and they're both up to the task and then some.
It's about the boundless talents of Maggie Smith, sometimes chewing up the screen, sometimes saying volumes simply by sitting very, very still, with a perfectly perfect expression on her face.
With an eclectic soundtrack, well-timed editing and crisp cinematography - and of course that terrific cast led by the great Del Toro - A Perfect Day is a rough-edged gem.
Gere delivers a performance so self-consciously ACTORISH it often takes us right out of the film.
Hart has the talent and the charisma to take it to the next level and do stellar work in more challenging fare. In "Ride Along 2," he's on cruise control all the way.
Lacking in nuance and occasionally plagued by corny dialogue, "13 Hours" is nonetheless a well-photographed, visceral action film, and a sincere and fitting tribute to those secret soldiers.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: [A] cheerfully insane, comically violent, often confounding, sometimes tedious but ultimately entertaining trip through the looking glass.
It's a well-photographed story with an intriguing setup, but soon we're mired in a meandering, stilted story with forced dialogue and some surprisingly subpar performances from the talented cast.
That's one problematic comedy.
The enormously talented Alejandro G. Iñárritu ("Amores Perros," "21 Grams," "Birdman") strikes again with this 19th century American fable, one of the most brutally beautiful movies I've ever seen.
Ruffalo does a magnificent job of conveying Cam's charm and undeniable love for his wife and children - as well as the devastating effects of serious, incurable mental illness.

A sweet, quietly funny, fascinating and contemplative study of 10 character actors and extras, none of whom had any idea back in the 1970s they'd forever be defined by the one or two days they spent on the set of a sci-fi movie.
"Big Game" never once feels credible, and that's why it's so entertaining. Almost nothing that takes place in this movie could occur in the real world, and there's something comforting about that.
Mostly though, "Ted 2" feels like far too many other sequels: born of box office expectations more than a bona fide reason to return to the characters we loved the first time around.
Somewhat sanitized and over-directed biopic saved by Boseman's electric performance.
A fun, lighthearted confection that knows exactly what it wants to be and how to execute that mission.
This being a Woody Allen film, there's some pretty sharp dialogue.
This film is the cinematic equivalent of comfort food.
"One of the best spy thrillers in recent years."
This just might be the most engrossing, the smartest and the most daring "Apes" movie ever put on film.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: One of the most remarkable moviegoing experiences I've ever had.
Food porn with a sweet albeit predictable menu.
Deserves an Oscar nomination for Best Documentary.
movie_title: The Internet's Own Boy: The Story of Aaron Swartz (2014)

movie_review_blurb: At times the movie version of "Jersey Boys" captures the electric excitement of the musical, but for every soaring moment, there are 10 minutes of bickering or brooding.
You want eye-rolling moments? This movie will detach your corneas.
'Maleficent' is an admittedly great-looking, sometimes creepy.
One long joke about much it would have sucked to live (and die, at a relatively young age), in the Old West.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A mind-bending thrill ride with great special effects.
A colorful, great-looking film, with an infectious soundtrack.
Edwards and his team produce consistently stunning visuals.
It is one of the most relentless movies I have ever seen. It just refuses to end.
Comes across as a cinematic, slightly dramatized Cliffs Notes edition a story that's been told often.
A more sophisticated version of "Sharknado."
A wasted opportunity.
'Exodus: Gods and Kings' is spectacular.
At times "Reach Me" is undeniably intriguing, mostly because it's just so weird and disconnected. Eventually, though, it just becomes tiresome.
Written and directed by Alex Ross Perry, Listen Up Philip looks like the kind of movie film classes would study in the 1970s.

The adult supporting players are all excellent, but next to Murray, the key casting is Jaeden Lieberher as young Oliver. The kid is a natural in the sidekick role, never once playing it too cute or too actor-y.
This is a stylish and smart thriller.
What a wasted opportunity.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Chastain delivers a brilliant performance that could earn her another Oscar nomination.
movie_title: The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby: Them (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The magic gets lost in translation.
This is a smart movie. Wiig gives maybe the most impressive performance of her career, and Hader is equally good.
James Gandolfini's final film role: quietly magnificent work.
The movie is DOA from scene one and is never resuscitated.
A character study of an ultimately pathetic man.
To Be Takei is a celebration of a man of great resilience, infectious humor, a voracious appetite for the richness of the human experience, and the best laugh in the history of laughing.
Thanks to Leonard's source material and the outstanding cast, it works.
This is one badass movie.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Plays like a high school version of 'Ghost.'
Completely ridiculous. And entertaining as hell.
A seriously funny, semi-autobiographical film that might be the most accomplished work Chris Rock has ever done for the big screen.
John Slattery's direction is skilled and steady... Great actors at the top of their game working with rich material.
This movie was doomed from draft one of the script.
Writer/director Jason Reitman continues his string of first-rate filmmaking.
Writer/director Strauss embraces the spiritual elements of this story.
Over all this is further indication Hudgens is carving out an interesting, productive career path as a film actress.
This is one of the more disappointing efforts of the holiday movie season.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A sometimes wickedly funny but ultimately sour, loud, draining tale of one of the most dysfunctional families in modern American drama.
This is the very definition of an OK thriller.
Lone Survivor' hits home and hits hard.
[An] engaging, shamelessly corny and entertaining World War II adventure inspired by true events.
This is a live-action cartoon.
Ralph Fiennes does a marvelous job as Dickens and as the director of this film.
Can't wait to see what Lake Bell the filmmaker does next.
This is good but not great Scorsese.
The Coen brothers have crafted another unique period piece.
One of the more original, hilarious and even heartbreaking stories of the year.
One of the funniest movies of the year, and in its own loony way, it's a sharp, dead-on satire.
This film works as its own lovingly rendered story.
Social importance aside, In the Heat of the Night works as a buddy film and as a tense thriller.
movie_title: In the Heat of the Night (1967)

movie_review_blurb: There's a lot of stupid stuff here, but I have to admit, some of that stupid stuff made me laugh hard.
This is a solid albeit slow-building film with few dull moments.
Pure trash but it's entertaining as hell.
One of my favorite movies of the last couple years. Great script, Tom Hardy is f*!&ing brilliant in role.
Overstuffed plot and too many villains, but the visual effects pop, and Garfield/Stone are still better than Maguire/Dunst.
Brutal.
A plodding and clunky drama that never misses an opportunity to embrace a cliché.
One of the most polarizing movies in recent years.
A human drama sprinkled with a number of laughs.
"Reaches right through you and chills you to the bone."
Cynical, boring, PG-13 retread.
"Kristen Wiig's performance in "Hateship Loveship" is so beautifully muted it takes a while to appreciate the loveliness of the notes she's hitting."
Bold, beautiful, sometimes confounding flight of futuristic speculation firmly rooted in the potential of today's technology.
We not only get an edgier, more complex, more compelling storyline, we get the most badass 95-year-old the world has ever known.
A modern-day, Georgia-set version of a spaghetti Western.
One of the most dazzling and unforgettable Biblical epics ever put on film.
It's like watching someone ELSE play a video game for more than two hours. That gets old real fast.
Bateman's directorial debut is a brisk, brutally funny and pitch-black comedy.
A triumph of production design, costumes, brilliantly choreographed battle sequences and stunning CGI.
A prestige film that sometimes feels more like a history assignment than entertainment.
A solid lead-up to the finale.
'Horrible Bosses 2' is so lazy it's not even about horrible bosses.
A big, gorgeous, consistently funny and touching animated adventure.

This is one of those movies that have you wondering: Long before the actors signed up and the locations were chosen and the sets were built and the filming began, how did someone not say, "Um, we have a big problem with this story"?
Indeed, this is the 51-year-old Crowe's first time as a movie director, but he's hardly a novice actor stepping behind the camera for some sort of vanity project.

What is happening! If you check out "The Forger," you might well find yourself saying that time and again, as the entertainingly terrible performances keep piling up while the plot dares you not to chuckle at the audacity of it all.
In other words, we're getting a nice, well-written, solid movie about people we believe would actually exist in real life.
Few actors in the world are better suited to play a gluttonous pig than Gerard Depardieu, and I mean that in the best possible way one can make such an assertion.
Perhaps director Gabriadze and writer Nelson Greaves intended to create a Social Media "Scream" and a commentary on cyber-bullying, but "Unfriended" comes across as disdainful of millennials.
The Swedish actress Alicia Vikander ("The Fifth Estate") infuses Ava with the just the right mixture of iciness, vulnerability and mystery. It's a star-making performance.

"Avengers: Age of Ultron" is a sometimes daffy, occasionally baffling, surprisingly touching and even romantic adventure with one kinetic thrill after another. It earns a place of high ranking in the Marvel Universe.
Stewart's blazing, blunt, pitch-perfect performance in this film serves as a reminder she's actually one of the best actresses of her generation.
"Marfa Girl" was filmed in 2012 but is only now reaching theaters, and as we've seen with the recent "Serena" and so many other delayed releases, that's almost never a good thing.

"The Longest Ride" treats us to a twist that's so ridiculous I think we're almost supposed to laugh. It's not quite on the "Are you KIDDING ME!?" level of awfulness as the big reveal in "Safe Haven," but it's close. It's close.
"Furious 7" could have come across as ghoulish, but it's not until the very end that we're reminded of Walker's fate, and the filmmakers handle it with taste and respect.
For about an hour, "While We're Young" was one of the most exhilarating times I've had at the movies in many a month. It played like razor-sharp Woody Allen in his prime.

Simon Curtis' "Woman in Gold" is a shamelessly sentimental fictionalization of this true story, but it's a fascinating story nonetheless, beautifully photographed and greatly elevated by a brilliant performance from the invaluable Helen Mirren.
Anyone who can challenges faith healers, psychics and mediums who claim a special bond with the dead - and often wins those challenges - deserves a standing ovation.
Rarely, though, have two Academy Award-winning actors been so stunningly off the mark in the same movie.
It's as good as any work I've seen in a film in 2015, and "True Story" is one of the better movies to come along this year.

Anyone over 10 will see the plot twists a mile away. Kids will probably enjoy the goofy Boovs, the rainbows of colors and the music. Call me a traditionalist, but I still say the world was a better place before those darn Boovs invaded.

It's a tricky business playing someone who is mentally ill and perhaps should be confined for observation, especially in a dark comedy. Wiig manages to make Alice funny as hell, endearing, sad and sometimes a little frightening.

"Hot Pursuit" features one of the worst and most forced performances of Reese Witherspoon's career, an irritating performance by Sofia Vergara(whom I love on 'Modern Family') and a seemingly endless parade of lazy and arbitrary plot twists and turns.
Heaven Knows What feels like an authentic, sometimes painfully accurate portrait of life in New York City as experienced by the homeless, ever-hustling teenagers.
"Jurassic World" is pure, dumb, wall-to-wall fun. When they hand you your 3-D glasses, you can check your brain at the door and pick it up on your way out.
After seeing "Love & Mercy," you'll find it nearly impossible to resist the urge to download (or re-listen to) a dozen Beach Boys classics.
Some movies practically dare you to give up. "Aloft" is a beautifully shot, frustratingly vague and deeply ponderous mystery/spiritual journey about terminally unhappy souls.
What does work, in every scene, is Melissa McCarthy's performance. She's as funny and as winning as anyone in the movies these days.
It's like catching up with an old friend and remembering why you don't hang out with him anymore: He's stuck in a rut and he has nothing new to say.
Although Cooper succeeds in resembling and sounding like the real Kyle, this isn't some cheap impersonation trick. Cooper gives maybe the best performance of his career.
Nothing about "The D Train" feels the least bit authentic, and worse, little about it is funny. That's a deadly recipe for a dark comedy.
Aloha is a great-looking movie with just enough bright spots to get us past the cloudy moments.
But the visuals pack a visceral punch. Every time Tom zeroes in on a target, every time he pushes that button, what we see on those monitors is brutally authentic.
This is the first major disappointment of the summer movie season. (Box office aside, I wasn't really expecting "Pitch Perfect 2" to be the "Godfather 2" of a cappella musicals.)
These sobering moments aside, the great bulk of "I Am Big Bird" is a Sunny Day, Sweepin' the Clouds Away, brightly colored tribute to the man and his art.
movie_title: I Am Big Bird: The Caroll Spinney Story (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Despite those credentials from the filmmakers and an excellent cast that includes Diane Lane, Elizabeth Banks, Nate Parker and Dakota Fanning, "Every Secret Thing" feels flat and unfocused.
For a movie about the cheerfully bizarre world of competition a cappella singing, "Pitch Perfect 2" seems just as obsessed, if not more so, with characters who seem to be sexually confused.
It speaks volumes for the sheer ferocious awesome insane greatness of "Mad Max: Fury Road" that I'm not even ticked off about Tom Hardy getting stuck wearing a face mask for a good chunk of the film.
Sometimes you see a play and you can imagine it being a movie. Sometimes you see a small movie like this, and you can imagine it working better as an intimate stage play.
"Animals" is a stark, brilliant, uncompromising, beautifully acted piece of work.
Hunter King is believably despicable as the prototypical Mean Girl, but we DO feel empathy for Avery as she begins to realize the depths of the destruction she caused.
In other words, a lot of people realized they had an epic clunker on their hands.

From its juvenile double entendre title to its fascination with prison rape and homophobic humor, "Get Hard" practically announces itself as an offensive, tired and unimaginative comedy in nearly every scene.
As soon as the credits rolled on "Predestination," I wanted to watch it again. It was even more of a mind-dance the second time around.
​I'll tell you what got "Taken." A hundred and twelve minutes of my life got "Taken."
Joaquin Phoenix is perfectly cast as the perpetually befuddled Doc, a private detective of sorts who immerses himself in pot in the Los Angeles of 1970.
One of Glen Campbell's final songs was Not Gonna Miss You, dedicated to his wife. I can't imagine anyone listening to it and not being moved.
Led by the unforgettable work from a young actress who's among the best of her generation, "The Fault in Our Stars" is a lovely work.
Pitt is at the top of his game, playing a man who has forgotten whatever he used to be and has wholly embraced his role in this war.
Screenplay is tight, funny, smart and insightful, and [the] direction has just enough indie feel without becoming too self-conscious or preachy.
A deeply warped, darkly funny and thoroughly depraved horror comedy. Ryan Reynolds gives one of his best performances.
Selma is an important history lesson that never feels like a lecture. Once school is back in session, every junior high school class in America should take a field trip to see this movie.
This is a nutty film, and for the most part I mean that in a good way.

As someone who has developed a pretty thick Critic's Shield from years of watching standard haunted house/possessed human/mythological-creature fare, I have to say I was genuinely freaked out by some of the passages in The Badabook.
This is a strange and beautiful and unique film, one of the best movies of the year.
In a well-made, but one-note film.
Rumbles on for too long and has some dry patches here and there-but just when we're growing fidgety, we get another rousing musical number or another dark plot twist, and we're back in business.
A well-made, well-acted but unexceptional film about one of the most exceptional figures of the last half-century.
Jessica Chastain deserves Best Supporting Actress consideration for her work. One of the most beautiful films I have ever seen.
It would be an insult to call Chazelle a "promising" filmmaker, as this movie doesn't indicate mere potential - it is evidence of authentic, sometimes blazing talent.

Smith and Robbie are terrific together. At various points along the way, he's playing her, and then she's playing him, and then we're almost positive they've let their collective guard down and they're really in love ... Or are they?
Yes, "McFarland USA" has the obligatory coda where we found out how everything played out for the coach and the key members of that 1987 team. You should stick around for that.
It's a dull, lazy, scattershot would-be comedy about a group of mostly unlikable characters who have all the depth of the Three Stooges in the Curly Joe era.

Legendary as Al Pacino's skills are, he wouldn't be the first actor I'd cast to play a 70ish pop star who still fills mid-sized arenas some 40 years after he last charted a hit single. Yet Al Pacino sells the heck out of his performance as Danny Collins.
The world didn't need yet another "Cinderella" story, but the one we got is one of the best versions ever put on film.
Vince Vaughn, continuing his decade-long streak of mediocre comedies plays another variation on his fast-talking, slightly oafish but goodhearted regular guy.

I'd love to see a third "Marigold" adventure. Better yet, a "Masterpiece Theater"-type TV series, where we get to spend an hour every week with the regulars at the hotel and various newcomers who stop in.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This isn't a lousy film; it's a mediocre, ugly film about lousy people.

The truth is, I found "Road Hard" to be a low-key gem, a consistently funny albeit conventional story about a guy who's almost always the funniest person in the room, and is almost always his own worst enemy.

The true story of Freddy Heineken's kidnapping is fascinating, but "Kidnapping Mr. Heineken" is a disappointingly superficial film in which neither the kidnappers nor their captives are particularly interesting.
This is Woody Allen's signature film, arguably his best and certainly his most popular.
"The Lazarus Effect" is nothing but a cheap horror film cloaked in scientific mumbo-jumbo.

Where were the Guardians of the Galaxy when we needed them? If only they had prevented the disastrous atrocity that is "Jupiter Ascending" from infiltrating Earth's movie theaters before it was too late!
"Seventh Son" moves at a fairly quick pace and has a sense of humor about itself. That doesn't mean it's thrilling, or funny. Just that it's a quickly forgotten pile of junk.
A full two decades after "Four Weddings and a Funeral," Hugh Grant still does that stammering, understated, witty and dashing thing as well as anyone in the business.
On Day One of filming, they must have thrown away the moral compass and taken a group vow to splatter our sensibilities with stylish, gratuitous violence and one "Wait, what?!" moment after another.
"Da Sweet Blood of Jesus" is a bold but wildly uneven, bloody mess of a film, sunk in large part by the subpar performances by nearly every major character in nearly every major role.
Basically, they made a lousy, mid-2000s-era Katherine Heigl romance with a handful of explicit sex scenes spliced throughout the familiar clichés.
It doesn't help that the songs, while solid, become repetitive in melody. And there's not a home run in the bunch. I walked out humming ... nothing from this movie.
This is a well-intentioned and sometimes quite sharp high school movie that falls just short of the mark due to a few way-off-the-mark scenes and too much heavy-handed preaching.

The delivery is unorthodox. You might think you know what's coming, but then comes another curveball that catches you by surprise. You're kept guessing throughout - and it's a real kick when you're wrong yet again.
The best time I've had at the movies all year.

As Sokurov examines a pivotal point in the Louvre's history and gives us a virtual tour of the magnificent museum, he makes larger points about the vital importance of art throughout human history. This is one of the most beautiful films of the year.
High-Rise keeps hammering home the same points, and not even the wealth of strong performances from Hiddleston, Miller and Irons are enough to salvage the day.
If you're looking for something different - and mean it when you say so - Dave Made a Maze is a joy.
Whatever the intentions of the filmmakers, Good Time is a promising but flawed final product.
Director and co-writer Matt Spicer displays just the right touch as the story gets crazier.
There's nothing and no one to like in The Hitman's Bodyguard. This is one loud, generic, forgettable late summer action flick.
Logan Lucky is great fun and one of the most purely entertaining movies of the year.
Patti Cake$ belongs to writer-director Jasper, who makes good use of his New Jersey upbringing and his music-video background to create a memorable feature debut - and to Danielle Macdonald.
For all the character studies and moments of reflection and lament, Wind River never loses its identity as a gritty thriller.
The exchanges feel slightly redundant at times. The stagey origins of the material surface occasionally. Minor bumps, though, in a unique psychological journey.
A film that presents overwhelming evidence of Rex and Rose Mary as appalling human beings for 90 percent of the journey, and then asks us to give them a break? No sale.
Whitney: 'Can I Be Me is a nearly joyless and melancholy piece of work. Because we know how it ends.
This is one rough-and-tumble medieval Irish religious adventure, my friends.
What a strange and lovely road we travel with Brigsby Bear.
A great actor giving a terrible performance as the lead villain is but one of the many, many, MANY unfortunate elements in The Dark Tower.
Directed in disjointed and sometimes unfocused fashion by Bonni Cohen and Jon Shenk, An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth to Power is nonetheless worth a viewing.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Even clocking in with a running time short of 90 minutes, the movie spins its wheels (in more ways than one) and repeats itself to the point of becoming ridiculous.
Score: A Film Music Documentary is a celebration of the artists who create the musical heartbeat of the movies we love

It's likely not even the most well-intentioned and determined news crews could gain the kind of access and give us the unfiltered viewpoints provided by the smart-phone visuals and home video camera footage shot by residents of Ferguson.
Landline is a very funny film about people dealing with very serious situations. Better the Jacobs family than us.
The anachronistic pop songs actually work quite nicely with the scenes of classical dancing, and will most likely help hold the attention of the little ones.
Even though this movie was made nearly 30 years ago, almost nothing about it feels dated.
The directors of Woodshock are Kate and Laura Mulleavy, the sibling founders of the Rodarte brand. They clearly have an eye for fashion. As filmmakers, they clearly have an eye for fashion.
Mostly, there's Cruise, who at 55 looks a decade and a half younger, and can still fill a cockpit with star power some 30 years after Top Gun.
We knew this guy was a forgettable jerk not worth our time five minutes into this movie.
Emma Stone does the best work of her career. Her Billie Jean King is a champion on multiple levels.
If a white towel had been handy as I screened the punishingly long and dreadful Kingsman: The Golden Circle, I would have thrown it at the screen and made a wish: Please make it stop.
What makes Stronger stand out is the pitch-perfect feel for the dynamic of a loud and constantly bickering and dysfunctional but fiercely loyal and loving extended family.
With Rebel in the Rye, we get a solid, well-acted and basically standard biopic.
What could have been a great B-movie winds up being merely solid.
Sorry, but no sale.
This is an accomplished and moving and solid drama from a director who seems on the verge of giving us a great movie sometime soon.
... this nasty little Victorian London horror film has more than a few blood-soaked charms of its own.
It's loud and dumb and irritating and forgettable.
It's ... hard not to feel a constant sense of disconnect from these characters and their so-called "crises."
When a film of this magnitude has so many young characters front and center in the lead roles, so much depends on the casting -- and in this case, there's not a single misstep.
William H. Macy is great. William H. Macy knows funny. How could William H. Macy direct such an unholy mess?
It's on a par with the 3-D in most current films of the genre.
Lawrence pouts and screams and cries with great gusto. Her eyes dart about with mad fear at the lunatics who have invaded her house. It's a big performance, but not a GREAT big performance.

These are good people, and these are great actors portraying these good people, and if you not rooting for Louis and Addie to find comfort and love and peace with one another in their last years, then I just don't know what to tell you.
The Last Face spends so much time on the on-again, off-again romance between Bardem's Miguel and Theron's Wren, the African victims are all but nameless and faceless backdrops.
Get the 8-ounce Pinot Noir, settle in and have some mindless fun.

Cars 3 is a lovely, clever and entertaining generational tale with tons of heart, a simple and effective storyline, wonderful candy-colored visuals and winning voice work from the talented cast of returning regulars and welcome newcomers.
Almost none of it feels original or fresh or spirited.
The superb cast does a wonderful job of keeping us guessing as to everyone's motives.
What a fine performance by Jennifer Garner, playing a character we see almost totally through the filter of her husband's viewpoint.
Sometimes it takes a disaster of this magnitude to leave us hoping a studio will take a long hard look at the universe they're about to expand.
Kate Mara delivers one of the best performances of her career in the title role.
The problem is, the man we see onscreen only rarely comports himself like one of the greats. Far too often, he actually seems like the smallest man in the room.

It's a relatively straightforward biopic using conventional framing devices (including the liberal use of flashbacks) to tell the story of an extraordinary artist who overcame tremendous odds to become an American icon.
Dean left me eagerly anticipating Martin's next projects.
Three stars! Well played! But wait, there's one more scene. Look children - it's a falling star.

I wouldn't be surprised if some observers say Pitt made huge miscalculations in his acting choices with the result being the worst performance of his career - but I found it to be a brazenly effective piece of work, well-suited to the material.
When you make films from junk TV, more often than not you're going to wind up with a junk movie.
We have Oscar winners Geoffrey Rush and Javier Bardem hamming it up beneath all the makeup and CGI trickery, and that's a hoot. Bardem's Salazar is a genuinely frightening creation.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Paris Can Wait is Wealthy Empty Nester Porn ... The only missing ingredients are truly likable lead characters and something approaching an involving storyline.

Alien: Covenant takes place prior to the events of the original Alien (1979), but since it was filmed in the mid-2010s, it's an impressive technical achievement, with amazing CGI special effects plunging us deep into outer space and deep into the future.

Eva Longoria gives one of her most authentic performances as the strong and loving Gloria. Ross brings a wounded intensity to his character. Chavarria's narration is a tad low key, but his performance is natural and effective.
When Diana DOES spring into action, Wonder Woman rocks. It's as if we're learning exactly what she's capable of at the same time Diana is discovering the depths of her powers.
The visuals in Atomic Blonde pop right off the screen. Leitch periodically zooms in for tight close-ups of the stunning Theron, who conveys a world of emotions with a subtle movement of the eyes.

Of course Willis employs his trademark smirk and his familiar sarcastic line readings. Of course we've seen him play variations on this downtrodden, wisecracking cynic in better movies. But B-movie Willis is still kind of a hoot.
movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Venice (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The menu for "Beatriz at Dinner" is more appetizer than main course.

Pinkett Smith and Queen Latifah are as reliable as ever onscreen. And Regina Hall gives one of her best performances as Ryan, who keeps on telling everyone you can "have it all" even as her own marriage tells a different story.
[A] bizarre and bloated and clunky pop sci-fi epic.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Nolan has crafted a tight, gripping, deeply involving and unforgettable film that ranks about the best war movies of the decade.
Baldwin and Moore generate genuine heat and chemistry together, even in some ridiculous moments.
My favorite performance in the film comes from Bruce Dern, enthusiastically loopy as the booze-soaked town doctor. You can rarely accuse Bruce Dern of phoning it in.
Serkis is brilliant and memorable and sometimes absolutely heartbreaking as Caesar. The supporting players excel, with each getting a moment or two in the sun.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The premise and the framework of the story and the photography are much more memorable than the performances, and that feels mostly by design.

Of course the main selling point is Sam Elliott aka Lee Hayden. I don't even know who makes that barbecue sauce Lee is touting at the beginning of the film or whether it's really good or just mass-produced glop, but based on that voiceover, I'd buy it.
True, The Little Hours is essentially a one-joke comedy - but most of the jokes under the umbrellas of that one joke are pretty damn, I mean darn, funny.
All the best romantic comedies get even better upon repeat viewings. I'm fully confident The Big Sick will pass that test the next time I see it, which will be very soon.
There's more character development (and more believable plot turns) in a typical "Saturday Night Live" sketch.
Okja is an uneven but never complacent mix of fantastic fairy tale; social satire; heavy-handed commentary on corporate greed and our consumer-crazed culture, and bizarro action film.
Of course, something's gotta give, and when it does, The Beguiled reminds us we haven't been watching a fairy tale all this time -- we've been watching a very fractured fairy tale.
Edgar Wright's Baby Driver is one of the most entertaining thrill rides of this year, this decade.

Hawkins disappears into the performance, capturing Maud's physical limitations but also the light in her eyes, the sly humor in her observations about life -- and her gift for seeing the greatest beauty in the simplest things.
The Bad Batch has all the ingredients necessary for a minor cult classic, but it's tough to get that recipe just right.
"Spider-Man: Homecoming" is breezy fun.
This is a fitting and thorough tribute to a director whose work has left an enormous footprint on the popular culture.

This is a paint-by-numbers procedural that expects the audience to know the history of Watergate, hits the ground running-but then feels more like a steady jog through the past than a fast-paced thriller.
movie_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (2017)

movie_review_blurb: At one point you almost start rooting for the elements to win out, just so these two [characters] would just shut up.
Director McGuigan and screenwriter Matt Greenhalgh paint Film Stars Don't Die ... in unapologetically sentimental tones.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The attention to detail, the use of certain colors, the lush and vibrant photography of the dresses Reynolds makes and the clothes he wears - they're honestly breathtaking.
Many ridiculous things happen on the train.

The Insidious timeline is becoming so murky, even a scary ghost lurking behind a locked door in the basement might give up and say, "Time out! Am I even supposed to be in this particular story? Who am I haunting again, and what's my motivation?"
Wells is a talent as a storyteller and as a director with a nice visual touch, and as a screen presence. Emily is wonderful. We like spending time with them. (Noel and Emily, I mean.)
The standout is Bob Odenkirk as Ben Bagdikian, the kind of old-school reporter who wears out the soles of his shoes tracking down a scoop.
Bale is as good as he's ever been, especially in the film's final 30 minutes or so.
12 Strong winds up being an almost-good film about some great American soldiers.
For a time this movie will probably be best known for the behind-the-scenes drama. But the work itself deserves to endure as one of the better films of 2017.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Bright is basically a tired buddy-cop movie dressed up in bizarre trappings.
In its own cheesy and entertaining way, Hangman kept me guessing throughout.
Damon is in prime everyman mode as Paul, a good guy with a good heart who wouldn't mind catching a break, a big break, just once.
As a whole, Pitch Perfect 3 feels like an encore nobody asked for.
I, Tonya is kitschy and smart and funny and insightful, and sometimes sobering.
With all that corn and cheese and old-timey sentiment, "The Greatest Showman" ends up scoring some very timely social arguments. P.T. Barnum himself would have approved the dramatic sleight of hand.

Call Me by Your Name is a perfect, lazy, worry-free day, practically devoid of any real-world concerns and absolutely dripping with intellectual and artistic stimulation, and all manner of sexual enticement.
Few actors on the planet can shift gears as effortlessly as Chastain, who perfectly captures Molly's chameleon-like ability to adapt to situations and to rationalize her worst behavior.
Still, this is no mere placeholder of a story. Huge, important things happen to characters secondary and primary. Surprises big and small abound.
What makes Mom and Dad even creepier and chilling than a standard zombie movie is the parents don't turn into frothing-at-the-mouth, dead-eyed, robotic creatures.
Forte captures Kenney's deadpan comedic insanity and his wry humor, but also conveys the sense of melancholy and emotional restlessness plaguing Doug.
Director Nash Edgerton and screenwriters Anthony Tambakis and Matthew Stone do a fine job of juggling the multiple story lines, moving things along at an entertaining clip.
When, for the love of God, are these Horror Movie Families going to LEARN?
For all its scenes of characters flying and soaring and zooming here and there, it never really takes off.
Again and again, Death Wish feels anything but real.
The Game Night co-directors deliver a stylish and good-looking movie.
Along the way, Graham, Kinsey and Beatriz trade some hilariously X-rated dialogue.
Rogers Park is poetic and lovely and muscular and unforgiving at the same time, much like the area itself and the city as a whole.
What might have been a slick, smash-mouth, fast-paced piece of entertainment clocking in at 90 or 100 minutes somehow turns into a bloated, half-baked pie that drags on for 2 hours and 20 minutes.
"Annihilation" becomes ever more trippy and challenging - and thus ever more interesting.
Writer-director-producer Michael Glover Smith's Mercury in Retrograde is a smart, funny, quietly effective and authentic slice of older millennial life.
Black Panther is one of the best superhero movies of the century.
With little else to keep me interested as the story stumbled along, I did enjoy keeping track of all the trendy names of various minor supporting characters.
It's impossible to say whether The 15:17 to Paris would have been a better movie with professional actors in the lead roles. All we can do is go with what we've got.
Somewhere along the development trail, someone in charge should have said: Arm! Get me a rewrite, arm!
Based on what we see in "42 Grams," perhaps the place collapsed under the weight of the chef's massive ego.
This is a great time capsule about a team that dominated the sport for one season, and then fell apart all too quickly due to a variety of factors.
movie_title: '85: The Greatest Team In Football History (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Nicolas Cage's starring presence explains why it's such a compelling and offbeat little thriller.
Mostly, though, "Bullet Head" is about the characters and the crackling dialogue, and the first-rate actors giving just the right spin to their lines.
As played by [Gary] Oldman, Churchill has perhaps never seemed greater. Or more human
Mostly, though, this is a solid tribute to one of the most commanding forces an old-school newsroom has ever seen.
movie_title: The Newspaperman: The Life and Times of Ben Bradlee (2017)

movie_review_blurb: My dear. It could have been done in a dozen or more so much simpler ways.
The only thing I enjoyed more than the comedy in Thor: Ragnarok was a climactic battle sequence synced perfectly to Led Zeppelin's "Immigrant Song."
It's a well-calibrated performance, with Harrelson convincingly conveying how Lyndon Johnson felt the weight of the world on his shoulders and took on that challenge in mostly admirable ways.
You know a comedy is in trouble when it resorts to the Funny Montage multiple times.
The Killing of a Sacred Deer never hedges its bets, never takes its foot off the gas.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This is a powerful and valuable addition to the coming-home war movie canon.
Wonderstruck is a smart and interesting and well-acted film. We're just never really struck with ... wonder.
The end result is a brilliant and brave and beautifully honest film.
Make sure you hit "Pause" if you have to walk away from the Netflix stream for a moment, because you don't want to miss a trick here.

Thirty minutes in, we're pretty sure we know how the movie is going to turn out - even if we're unfamiliar with Robin's remarkable journey and his lasting impact. That doesn't mean Breathe isn't worth seeing.
Like a tap that was turned on, the sadness and anger never stopped pouring out.
Through the ups and downs of training, a few moments of comedic relief and partying, detours into family drama, Only the Brave marches slowly and with increasing intensity.
We enjoy the Meyerowitz clan, even as we praise the heavens we're not like them and we don't live next door to any of 'em.
Marshall reminds us that before the legend, there was the badass young warrior.
Vince Vaughn is so intimidating in "Brawl in Cell Block 99," even the back of his head seems to be glaring at us and asking, "Do we have a problem here?"
It's film that'll make you wince at times, and you'll most likely not want to see twice, but seeing it once is an experience you'll not soon forget.
Schwarzenegger has a great time hamming it up, and we have almost as much fun watching him have fun.

Joe Lynch's fantastically creative, subversive and Tarantino-esque Mayhem stands alone as an entertainingly bloody and dark and twisted social satire - but it's even more satisfying for those of us who loved Steven Yeun's Glenn on The Walking Dead.
Kudos to director Kelly Richmond Pope for applying just the right mix of "What the Heck?" whimsy and respectful, serious reporting to this incredible tale.
It's a stand-alone film. Maybe a sequel in terms of some themes, and the general plot device of a transformative train trip. This is one of the best movies of 2017.
Guillermo del Toro's "The Shape of Water" is like a beautiful painting you keep visiting at your favorite museum, because it continues to reveal its brilliant magic in new and different ways.
All hokum. All window dressing for a limp, underwhelming, irritating soap opera.
So no, it's not a sly, dark, romantic deadpan comedy after all. It's dark all right - but it looks more like a train than a light at the end of the tunnel.
Uneven but often strangely compelling.
In Neil Berkeley's fascinating, very funny and sometimes quite melancholy "Gilbert," we get to see the hunched-over, eccentric, surprisingly thoughtful man behind the comedic myth...
"The Disaster Artist" is a breezy, entertaining and even affectionate movie about the making of "The Room."
It's filled with so many theatrical flourishes and fantastical touches, one can envision this material as a work for the stage, or even an animated film.
Roman J. Israel, Esq. has pockets of intrigue, and writer-director Gilroy and Washington have teamed up to create a promising dramatic character. We just never get full delivery on that promise.
"Coco" is full of life, especially when we're hanging out the with the dead.
Unrecognizable under the prosthetics and the makeup, Jacob Tremblay is indeed wondrous as Auggie.
I Love You, Daddy is a technically impressive film ... And all rendered meaningless by the unmistakable stench of creepiness, narcissism and hypocrisy permeating the story.
Redemption and hope eventually shine through here and there, and when that happens, it's a beautiful thing.
This is the best movie I've seen this year.
It's a putting-the-band-together origins movie, executed with great fun and energy.
In the meantime, I don't want to oversell a near-great B-movie that is nonetheless a B-movie. Suffice to say Tragedy Girls has great fun with myriad horror movie tropes.
All right. This time I'm POSITIVE we're not going to see a holiday comedy this sour and cynical and profoundly unfunny for a very long time. At least that's my Christmas wish.
It's unique and original and fresh and wonderful, and can you tell I loved it?
Liev Schreiber is outstanding as the hulking, rough-edged, amiable and charismatic Wepner.
Sometimes very funny and occasionally legitimately tense.
Like the killer in Phone Booth and the entity in Lights Out and so many villains of all forms through the decades, the longer we go without seeing the tormenter, the more terrifying he becomes.
They should have just stayed home. There was plenty of comedy to be found right there.

"The Hollars" is an uneven, ineffective and self-conscious dysfunctional family comedy/drama with a Sundance-y vibe, and scene after scene in which the greatly talented and usually quite likable cast members keep stepping in big piles of wrong choices.
This is one of the worst movies of 2016.
I'm just not sure anyone could have turned this soap opera material into anything other than a sweeping, credibility-stretching, overwrought... soap opera.

Hands of Stone is a rousing, well-filmed and solid (if at times overly generous to Duran) biopic with a bounty of charismatic performances, two of the sexier scenes of the year, some welcome laughs and a few above average fight sequences.
In what is shaping up to a banner year for scary movies, this is another solid and memorable entry.

Of course this is a stylized -- and yes, on occasion, idealized -- version of the launching point of a lifelong romance between two young Chicago residents who would go on to make history. That's pretty much the point.
Imperium is a well-spun, tight thriller, thanks in no small part to Radcliffe's excellent, sharply focused performance.
The biggest reason to see the Italian dramedy "Mia Madre" can be summed up in two words: John Turturro.
Ben-Hur struggles to find an identity and never really gets there. The well-intentioned efforts to achieve moving, faith-based awakenings are undercut by the casually violent, PG-13 action sequences.
Despite all the cursing and envelope-pushing and bat-bleep crazy sexual stuff, Sausage Party isn't mean-spirited. It's just... stupid. But also pretty smart. And funny as hell.
You could freeze nearly any frame of Hell or High Water and you'd be looking at a work of art. It's stark and breathtaking and gorgeous to behold.
We've yet to get a masterpiece-level film adaptation of the classic novella The Little Prince, but if and until that day comes, this will do just nicely, thank you very much.
What a waste of a perfectly twisted Suicide Squad.
We appreciate the unique personalities of these two kids, and we're glad they found each other.
Tallulah is such a funny, insightful, engrossing and slightly twisted dysfunctional family drama.

Jason Bourne is the best action thriller of the year so far, with a half-dozen terrific chase sequences and fight scenes. At one point the action swings to Vegas, and while some of what transpires is almost cartoonishly over-the-top, it's great fun.
This is a solid example of the Sobering Comedy, where we laugh consistently at the madness onscreen, all the while lamenting how it's rooted in real-world reality.
Something tells me a lot of good moms will find some real truths contained within the bawdy antics of Bad Moms.
"One of the best movies of 2016."
Credit Joseph Gordon-Levitt -- first, for even playing Snowden, and also for attempting to mimic Snowden's unique cadence as well as his physical appearance.
Hacksaw Ridge is faithful to the story of Desmond Doss in every sense of the word.

Park Chan-wook is a master of classy trash... There's artistry in his filmmaking, but also a lot of blood, plenty of sick humor and moments of sheer lunacy. The Handmaiden ranks among his best films yet.
"Moonlight" is gorgeous and yet bleak, uplifting and yet sobering, exhilarating but also grounded in some unshakable realities.
The first one was a dud. This one's worse.
Subtlety sits this one out.
If you think Kevin Hart is funny -- as I do -- you'll laugh frequently, as I did. If you don't, you're not going to this movie in the first place, are you?
Madness abounds in The Accountant, an intense, intricate, darkly amusing and action-infused thriller that doesn't always add up but who cares, it's BIG FUN.
Smart, lovely, funny, occasionally edgy, slightly cynical and ultimately heart-tugging.
Despite the drawbacks, the power of the story shines through.
Parker reaches with both hands for greatness and falls short - but this is nevertheless a solid and strong and valuable piece of work.

It's shiny trash that begins with promise but quickly gets tripped up by its own screenplay and grows increasingly ludicrous and melodramatic, to the point where I was barely able to suppress a chuckle at some of the final scenes.
This is a messy, confusing, uninvolving mishmash of old-school practical effects and CGI battles that feels... off nearly every misstep of the way.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: In the hands of director Berg, who specializes in quick-cut, adrenaline-pumping action, it's a well-made, sometimes horrifyingly realistic re-creation of events -- but it often feels like a formulaic disaster film.
Over all, this is a rousing, albeit sometimes cheesy, action-packed Western.
It's a team effort, and even though we know this playbook by heart, cheers all around.
From start to finish, this film seems strangely out of touch, never more so than when it tries to come across as enlightened.
This film is the real deal. It will bring you into a world that exists parallel to yours, right outside your car window as you run errands on Main Street.
The result is a remarkable film that deserves an Academy Award nomination for best documentary.
Emma Roberts and Dave Franco are just fine, but there's no huge onscreen spark between them. Most of the supporting roles are thinly drawn and forgettable.
What a load of fun.

It's just a shame the end of the movie wasn't lurking around the corner far sooner than when it finally turned up, by which time a considerable amount of my emotional investment in the film had been exhausted.
Front and center, carrying the film, is Samberg in what is easily the most winning film performance of his career.

Me Before You is a beautifully filmed and well-intentioned weeper marred by an unfortunate performance from one of the leads, and a plot development that leaves us more angry and frustrated than moved in the final act.
You can't look away, but it's almost painful to watch.
I love movies like this. Movies where we eavesdrop on smart, self-involved, deeply flawed and consistently interesting people.
Even the hardcore geeks who like to get their Comic-Con on might be feeling a little superhero fatigue right about now. Still. You owe it to yourself to see Quicksilver do his thing.
The attempts at sentiment are heavy-handed. The Mad Hatter has Daddy Issues. Alice has Mommy Issues. The Red Queen has Sister Issues. Ugh.
"Careful What You Wish For" might have been a better film had the two leading ladies, McClure and Lucas, switched roles. But not that much better.
Farrell absolutely kills it as David. Weisz gives one of her best performances since her Oscar-winning turn in The Constant Gardener.

Love & Friendship has the air of one of those movies where you sense the actors had the time of their lives on the set, what with getting to wear the garb of the time and reciting such sublime dialogue and performing such exquisitely choreographed scenes.
A rich if occasionally slight bio of one of the most well-known artists of the last half-century.
Crowe and Gosling save the day. They both look like hell for most of the film, with neither actor demonstrating a wisp of vanity as they throw themselves into this cheerfully nasty mess.
I couldn't wait for this movie to end.
Despite its provocative title, How to Plan an Orgy in a Small Town isn't particularly sexy. More troubling, it's not very funny either.
movie_title: How to Plan an Orgy in a Small Town (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Wood and Cage have a terrific dynamic together.
Better remembered as the vehicle to healing for the family than a movie that made an impact.

Director Jay Roach turns Robert Schenkkan's acclaimed Broadway play into an engrossing, powerful if slightly overcrowded movie that works as a biopic of LBJ and as a time capsule of a crucial period in the civil rights movement.
You admire the look and the performances, and some interesting ideas are presented, but everything feels muted and predictable and lacking in spark.
While the kids and the supporting players do just fine, it's the veterans Russo and Walters who shine in searingly honest and raw performances.
It's a solid, entertaining, well-paced sequel featuring terrific voice work, a clever script and some ingenious action sequences.
Even the most cynical, jaded, seen-it-all-before critic cannot deny certain visceral reactions to a film. Lights Out gave me the chills.

Despite a brave and edgy performance by Viggo Mortensen and some shining moments of sharp comedy and true emotion, writer-director Matt Ross' hippie fantasy Captain Fantastic suffers from terminal self-satisfaction.
Mazur's story (and his book) is so compelling it was almost inevitable we'd see a movie one day -- and the movie we got is one of the best of the year.
Ghostbusters is a horror from start to finish, and that's not me saying it's legitimately scary.

Not a polished work of filmmaking. Some of the nighttime scenes are so poorly lit it's difficult to tell what's happening. The editing is ragged and adds to the confusion. More than a few of the supporting performances are embarrassingly amateurish.

There's too much dark, even mean-spirited cynicism. And the ending isn't nearly as heartwarming as it could have been because the writers and co-directors opted not to go with a certain (and seemingly pretty obvious) dramatic choice.
If you stick with it, there's a chance it'll grow on you as it grew on me - and you'll be rewarded with maybe the best ending of any movie so far this year.

More than once, characters in "Now You See Me 2" make references to pulling back the curtain... And what's behind that curtain is just as much of an incomprehensible jab at the audience as everything else in this film.
It's pulp, but it has real actors doing real acting in a gritty story -- which is a lot more than can be said for some of the much more high-profile buddy cop movies of the last couple of years.
Exiting the theater after the technically impressive but listless and tedious The BFG, I wondered: Of the more than 50 films Steven Spielberg has directed, was this my least favorite?
Well that was unnecessary.
Neon Demon is something to look at. It's gotta lot of bark and a little bit of a bite. It just never sinks in.
The Shallows is a great-looking film, peppered with overhead long shots of the amazingly clear water, and some terrific underwater photography as well.
This is no history lesson, but it's mainstream Hollywood entertainment that respects the history and seems to invite discussion and debate.

"Central Intelligence" is one of those slick, gunplay-riddled, stupidly plotted, aggressively loud buddy movies - so formulaic and dumb, even if you see it you'll probably forget you've seen it by the end of the year.
Perhaps the best advertisement for Genius -- not only did it make me want to revisit Berg's book, it had me lining up the Wolfe, Fitzgerald and Hemingway on the e-book runway.
While the talented cast and a solid director make for a serviceable and intermittently entertaining adventure, there's very little about this film that screams, YOU GOTTA SEE THIS.
Arrival is not a linear adventure of the mind, and it is a film probably best seen twice.
